text: The passage implies that Miller's Death of a Salesman was innovative for the era when it was first performed because:
explanations:
To help dramatize Willy's psychological deterioration, Miller makes liberal use of a technique known as interior monologue….  Thus, through Willy's mutterings, we are privy to his mental state as he becomes increasingly entangled in remembrances of things past.  Eventually, the ill-fated salesman is unable to distinguish between then and now, illusion and reality.  Perhaps more impactful is Miller's corresponding tactic of time shifts: as Loman vacillates between reality and reverie, the audience is effectively shuttled between present and past. (Paragraph 2)
Miller's stratagem of mobile concurrency…is a function of the main character's desperate condition.  Willy is acutely aware of himself as an aging man for whom career opportunities have foreclosed and for whom the time to realize goals has run out.  His hypersensitive state leaves him susceptible to episodes of spontaneous recollection: a seemingly trivial occurrence summons up a similar event from the past, or a casually uttered word or phrase (for example, mention of the Lomans' old car) triggers a barrage of memories.  The recalled event, along with its contiguous incidents and attendant emotions, is pulled from the matrix of the past into the flow of the present and reexperienced. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 2 describes Miller's distinctive staging techniques.  According to the author, "To help dramatize Willy's psychological deterioration, Miller makes liberal use of a technique known as interior monologue."  Thus, through Willy's monologues or "mutterings," Miller makes the audience "privy to [his protagonist's] mental state as he becomes increasingly entangled in remembrances of things past" to the point where he cannot distinguish these from reality.
Miller's "mobile concurrences" likewise blur time boundaries: "as Loman vacillates (alternates) between reality and reverie (dream state), the audience is effectively shuttled between present and past."  Although "highly subjective," these time shifts represent "intrusions of the past into the present."
In Paragraph 3, the author explains how these mobile concurrences operate through "episodes of spontaneous recollection" to bring past and present together into the play's structure: "a seemingly trivial occurrence summons up a similar event from the past, or a casually uttered word or phrase…triggers a barrage of memories.  The recalled event…is pulled from the matrix of the past into the flow of the present and reexperienced."
Consequently, Miller used the technique of interior monologue together with his own device of mobile concurrences to integrate past events into the stream of current events being depicted in the play.  Therefore, the passage implies that Miller's Death of a Salesman was innovative for the era when it was first performed because it portrayed past and present events as intertwined.
 (Choice A)  it revived the traditional presentation of tragedy.  Paragraph 1 refers to Miller's drama as "uniquely psychological" in that it gives the audience access to the inside of the protagonist's mind.  The play is also described as a "tragedy depicting the downfall of distraught salesman Willy Loman." These descriptions indicate that although Miller's play was tragic in its scope, it was highly innovative or unique in its presentation.  Consequently, the play was not aimed at reviving the traditional presentation of tragedy (the features of which are never described in the passage).
(Choice C)  it featured a protagonist who ultimately fails.  Paragraph 3 discusses Willy Loman's status as "an aging man for whom career opportunities have foreclosed and for whom the time to realize goals has run out."  This information suggests that the play's main character is an ordinary person who had not met with success.  However, the passage never suggests that Miller's play was innovative for its era because it featured a protagonist who ultimately fails.
(Choice D)  it featured extensive flashback sequences.  According to Paragraph 2, Miller used a "tactic of time shifts: as Loman vacillates between reality and reverie, the audience is effectively shuttled between present and past."  However, these time shifts, or "mobile concurrences," are "unlike the popular cinematic device of flashbacks, which aim to recreate prior events objectively"; they instead present "highly subjective reconstructions imparting Willy's version of those events."  Accordingly, Miller's play did not feature extensive flashback sequences; rather, it used a similar but distinct device of mobile concurrences.

text: The passage assertion that Death of a Salesman is "a requiem for the American dream of material success" (Paragraph 1) suggests that the play:
explanations:
Often regarded as a requiem for the American dream of material success, Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman is one of the best-known plays of the modern American stage.  Not so well known, however, is the 1949 drama's original title, "The Inside of His Head."  Yet that erstwhile label may more accurately capture the spirit of this uniquely psychological tragedy depicting the downfall of distraught salesman Willy Loman. (Paragraph 1)
Willy is acutely aware of himself as an aging man for whom career opportunities have foreclosed and for whom the time to realize goals has run out. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 1 describes Death of a Salesman "as a requiem (solemn remembrance) for the American dream of material success."  According to the passage author, Miller's play presents "the downfall of distraught salesman Willy Loman."  Paragraph 3 goes on to describe Willy as "an aging man for whom career opportunities have foreclosed and for whom the time to realize goals has run out."  Thus, the play highlights the failure of Willy's career aspirations, emphasizing that, despite his efforts, he has been unable to achieve the success the American dream would seem to have promised.
Consequently, the passage assertion that Death of a Salesman is "a requiem for the American dream of material success" (Paragraph 1) suggests that the play revealed the elusiveness of the success promised by the American dream.
 By contrast, the passage assertion that Death of a Salesman is "a requiem for the American dream of material success" would not suggest that the play:
was originally intended to convey a political message (Choice A).  Paragraph 1 states that Miller originally titled his play "The Inside of His Head," suggesting that the initial focus was on the "uniquely psychological" aspects of the work.  Accordingly, although the final version of the play is viewed as "a requiem for the American dream of material success," the passage never indicates whether an explicitly political message was part of Miller's original intention.
endorsed the conception of material success represented by the American dream (Choice C).  Through the character of Willy, Miller suggests that the success promised by the American dream is elusive and perhaps even empty.  Despite his long-term pursuit of this dream, Willy has ended up in a "desperate condition": he has become "acutely aware of himself as an aging man for whom career opportunities have foreclosed and for whom the time to realize goals has run out" (Paragraph 3).  This negative portrait of the unfulfilled and unsuccessful protagonist conveys implicit criticism of the American dream.  Accordingly, the play challenged rather than endorsed the dream's conception of material success.
had less impact on society than the idea of the American dream (Choice D).  Although Miller's drama is described as "one of the best-known plays of the modern American stage" (Paragraph 1), the passage does not discuss the play's impact on society, nor does it compare this impact with that of the American dream.

text: In Paragraph 2, the author states that, as a playwright, Arthur Miller:
explanations:
To help dramatize Willy's psychological deterioration, Miller makes liberal use of a technique known as interior monologue….  [I]nterior monologue exposes the audience to the inner workings of the protagonist's mind….  Thus, through Willy's mutterings, we are privy to his mental state as he becomes increasingly entangled in remembrances of things past.  Eventually, the ill-fated salesman is unable to distinguish between then and now, illusion and reality.  Perhaps more impactful is Miller's corresponding tactic of time shifts: as Loman vacillates between reality and reverie, the audience is effectively shuttled between present and past.  However, unlike the popular cinematic device of flashbacks, which aim to recreate prior events objectively, these intrusions of the past into the present—dubbed "mobile concurrences" by Miller—are highly subjective reconstructions imparting Willy's version of those events. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, "To help dramatize Willy's psychological deterioration, Miller makes liberal use of a technique known as interior monologue."  Through this nontraditional technique, the playwright "exposes the audience to the inner workings of the protagonist's mind."  Furthermore, Miller uses his own innovation on "the popular cinematic device of flashbacks," which he calls "mobile concurrences."  These mobile concurrences enable Miller to move the audience between the present and past even as Willy himself "vacillates (alternates) between reality and reverie (dream state)."  However, "unlike…flashbacks, which aim to recreate prior events objectively," mobile concurrences are described as "highly subjective reconstructions imparting Willy's version of those events."
Accordingly, Miller used nontraditional techniques to enable his audience to adopt Willy's personal point of view.  Therefore, in Paragraph 2, the author states that, as a playwright, Arthur Miller constructed Willy's subjective view by employing techniques that were not traditional.
 (Choice A)  downgraded the cinematic device of flashback.  In Paragraph 2, the author distinguishes Miller's mobile concurrences from "the popular cinematic device of flashbacks."  Whereas flashbacks "aim to recreate prior events objectively," the playwright's mobile concurrences "are highly subjective reconstructions imparting Willy's version of those events."  Consequently, Miller transformed the flashback into a subjective device by shaping the presentation of past events from his character's point of view.  However, the passage author neither evaluates Miller's modification as negative nor characterizes it as downgrading.
(Choice B)  dramatized events from the past in ways that tend to obscure Willy's perspective. According to Paragraph 2, "To help dramatize Willy's psychological deterioration, Miller makes liberal use of a technique known as interior monologue."  This technique "exposes the audience to the inner workings of the protagonist's mind," giving them direct access to his "mental state" or subjective view.  Thus, the author indicates that Miller dramatized past events in ways that tend to bring Willy's perspective into focus for the audience rather than obscuring it.
(Choice C)  dramatized his protagonist's decline through speech that is confusing to the audience.  Paragraph 2 indicates that Miller dramatized his protagonist's decline through the technique of interior monologue or speech that "exposes…the inner workings" of a character's mind.  Accordingly, "through Willy's mutterings (ie, monologues or speech), we are privy to his mental state as he becomes increasingly entangled in remembrances of things past."  However, even though Miller's protagonist expresses his state of mental confusion through his dramatized speech, Paragraph 2 does not indicate that the audience is confused by it.

text: The passage author suggests that the presentation of Willy's inner thoughts:
explanations:
To help dramatize Willy's psychological deterioration, Miller makes liberal use of a technique known as interior monologue.  Like stream of consciousness, which delivers a character's unfiltered and uncontrolled thoughts in all their incoherence, interior monologue exposes the audience to the inner workings of the protagonist's mind, only using slightly more verbal organization.  Thus, through Willy's mutterings, we are privy to his mental state as he becomes increasingly entangled in remembrances of things past. (Paragraph 2)
In the play, Miller presents Willy's inner thoughts through a technique he called interior monologue.  As Paragraph 2 explains, "Like stream of consciousness, which delivers a character's unfiltered and uncontrolled thoughts in all their incoherence, interior monologue exposes the audience to the inner workings of the protagonist's mind, only using slightly more verbal organization."  Accordingly, interior monologue allows all the contents of a character's mind to emerge freely without being censored in any way.  Therefore, the passage author suggests that the presentation of Willy's inner thoughts transmits his impressions indiscriminately.
 (Choices A and C)  conveys solely what Willy chooses to reveal; and it is mediated and restricted.  Paragraph 2 describes interior monologue, the technique Miller uses to present Willy's inner thoughts: "Like stream of consciousness, which delivers a character's unfiltered and uncontrolled thoughts in all their incoherence, interior monologue exposes the audience to the inner workings of the protagonist's mind, only using slightly more verbal organization."  Consequently, the playwright aimed to present all the thoughts of his character, not just those thoughts Willy might choose to reveal.  In addition, as Willy's inner thoughts are provided in their "unfiltered and uncontrolled" state, their presentation is not mediated and restricted.
(Choice D)  it constitutes a linear progression of ideas.  Paragraph 2 describes the thoughts conveyed by stream of consciousness and by the similar technique of interior monologue as "unfiltered and uncontrolled," adding that they are presented "in all their incoherence."  Accordingly, the presentation of Willy's inner thoughts would include involuntary, random, and even irrational thoughts; hence, it would most likely not constitute a linear progression of ideas.

text: The success ascribed to Miller in Paragraph 5 is based on his ability to portray:
explanations:
Through the techniques of interior monologue and mobile concurrences, Miller manipulates the temporal structure of his drama depicting the American dream's demise.  By making time's boundaries permeable for the broken and nostalgic Willy, Miller allows past and present to coexist for the audience as well.  Thus, the playwright succeeds at giving us his protagonist's subjective view—the view, that is, from the inside of his head (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 5, "Through the techniques of interior monologue and mobile concurrences, Miller manipulates the temporal structure of his drama."  The dramatist thereby enables his audience to share Willy's perception of the past and the present as existing simultaneously.  Hence, as the passage author concludes, "the playwright succeeds at giving us his protagonist's subjective view—the view, that is, from the inside of his head." Consequently, the success ascribed to Miller in Paragraph 5 is based on his ability to portray Willy's distinct perspective.
 By contrast, the success Paragraph 5 ascribes to Miller is not based on his ability to portray:
Willy's devastation by the American dream (Choice A).  Paragraph 3 describes Willy Loman as "acutely aware of himself as an aging man for whom career opportunities have foreclosed and for whom the time to realize goals has run out."  Hence, this character's "desperate condition" derives from the sense that he has failed to achieve the American dream.  In Paragraph 5, the author reinforces Willy's devastation by referring to him as "broken."  However, the author does not attribute the success Miller had in presenting his protagonist's subjective view as depending upon the playwright's ability to portray Willy in a specific state, namely, as devastated by the American dream.
nostalgia for America's past (Choice B).  As Paragraph 4 notes, Willy often lapses into "a romanticized past," losing himself in nostalgic daydreams of times gone by."  Accordingly, as presented by Miller, Willy's subjective view is often tinged with nostalgia, or feelings of longing for the past.  However, the actual dramatic techniques Miller uses to enable him to present Willy's (nostalgic) view (ie, interior monologue and mobile concurrences) do not depend on expressing nostalgia either for a personal past or for America's past.
an unbiased frame of reference (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 5, "Miller manipulates the drama's temporal structure" and "[b]y making time's boundaries permeable…allows past and present to coexist" not only for Willy, but for the audience.  Paragraph 5 then implies that Miller's success results from presenting to the audience "his protagonist's subjective view—the view, that is, from the inside of his head."  This subjective point of view constitutes a biased rather than an unbiased frame of reference.

text:
Passage information suggests that Colin Prior's mistaken assumption about the keys worn by Turkana females was based on his:
somewhat insufficient understanding of Blumer's principle.
somewhat insufficient training as a cultural researcher.
somewhat excessive attempt to avoid ethnocentrism.
explanations:
Research into other cultures has long been informed by the recognition that one must attempt to assimilate the viewpoint of the group under study, rather than proceed from ethnocentric conceptions. (Paragraph 1)
However, a peculiar sort of danger can arise from adherence to this clearly reasonable principle, as illustrated in the recent experience of anthropological photographer Colin Prior.  While studying the Turkana tribe of northwest Kenya, Prior…approached a group of girls: "In my naïveté, I asked the purpose of the keys worn around the girls' necks.  Their bemused reply was as much a surprise to me as the question had been a surprise to them.  'For our front doors.'" (Paragraph 2)
…with the Turkana he appears to have assumed that the obvious answer must not be right.  Paradoxically, Prior's openness to discovering the differences of another society led him away from, rather than toward, a correct understanding. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 1, to effectively research other cultures one "must attempt to assimilate the viewpoint of the group under study, rather than proceed from ethnocentric conceptions."  Nevertheless, Paragraph 2 conveys that this principle can be taken too far, "as illustrated in the recent experience of anthropological photographer Colin Prior."  Curious about the keys worn by Turkana females, Prior asked what their purpose was, only to receive the "'bemused reply'" that the keys were "'[f]or our front doors.'"
Paragraph 3 suggests that if Prior had been in a more familiar context, he "would have thought the function of the keys was obvious."  However, because he was so focused on how Turkana culture might differ from his own, he instead "appears to have assumed that the obvious answer must not be right," and thus that the girls' keys must have some other purpose than the straightforward one of opening their doors.  Ironically, then, his commitment to assimilating the viewpoint of another culture "led him away from, rather than toward, a correct understanding."
Accordingly, passage information suggests that Prior's mistaken assumption about the keys worn by Turkana females was based on his somewhat excessive attempt to avoid ethnocentrism (Number III).
 (Number I)  somewhat insufficient understanding of Blumer's principle.  Paragraph 1 cites Herbert Blumer's observation that "'people act toward things on the basis of the meaning that these things have for them, not on the basis of the meaning that these things have for the outside scholar.'"  However, Paragraph 2 then warns that "a peculiar sort of danger can arise from adherence to this clearly reasonable principle, as illustrated in the recent experience of anthropological photographer Colin Prior."  Therefore, the passage indicates that Prior was following Blumer's principle by not assuming that keys had the same meaning for the Turkana as they did for himself.  Thus, the passage does not suggest that Prior had an insufficient understanding of Blumer's principle.
(Number II)  somewhat insufficient training as a cultural researcher.  According to Paragraph 1, cultural researchers should be careful "not to import…the presuppositions of their own backgrounds into their understanding of another culture or tradition."  The author refers to this idea as a "clearly reasonable principle" (Paragraph 2), despite noting in Paragraph 3 that in Prior's case, it "[p]aradoxically…led him away from, rather than toward, a correct understanding."  Therefore, although Prior did make a mistaken assumption, he was still following a generally applicable principle of cultural research; the passage never suggests that Prior's mistake was the result of insufficient training as a cultural researcher.

text: Which of the following passage assertions is NOT supported by evidence in the passage?
explanations:
A mirror image of Prior's experience can be found among girls of another Kenyan tribe, the Samburu.  Noting the rarity of formal education among Samburu women, Carolyn Lesorogol describes the uneducated females' "incomprehension of what the [educated] girls did in school.  One woman commented that, as a child, she was at a loss to understand why the one school girl sat in her house looking at a paper (i.e. reading).  When the other girls asked her to join them outside to play or go to a dance, she refused, saying she wanted to stay in and look at the paper." (Paragraph 4)
For those who are literate, the sheer automaticity of the act of reading makes it difficult to imagine the confusion the woman felt as a child.  But to someone for whom even the concept of reading is unfamiliar, the school girl's actions would surely have seemed bizarre; presumably just sitting and staring at a piece of paper would indeed be quite boring. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 4 describes the experience of a Samburu woman who grew up without any formal education.  Because such education was a "rarity…among Samburu women," she and her peers were baffled by the behavior of a girl who did attend school.  In particular, the woman had no concept of literacy, remarking that "'as a child, she was at a loss to understand why the one school girl sat in her house looking at a paper (i.e. reading).'"
The author then remarks in Paragraph 5 that "[f]or those who are literate, the sheer automaticity of the act of reading makes it difficult to imagine the confusion the woman felt as a child."  However, the author never elaborates on why the automaticity of reading would make the woman's confusion difficult to imagine.  For instance, they do not cite any studies about literate people's perceptions of illiteracy, nor contrast the Samburu woman's experience with that of a child raised in a literate culture.
Accordingly, the passage assertion about the difficulty of imagining the Samburu woman's confusion is not supported by evidence in the passage.
 (Choice A)  "Presumably in the latter case Prior would have thought the function of the keys was obvious, but with the Turkana he appears to have assumed that the obvious answer must not be right."  In recounting his conversation with the Turkana girls, Prior claimed: "'In my naïveté, I asked the purpose of the keys worn around the girls' necks.  Their bemused reply was…"For our front doors"'" (Paragraph 2).  By describing himself as naïve for asking about the keys, Prior implies that he should have guessed the answer without needing to ask.  Unlocking doors is a common and obvious function of keys, and Prior's self-criticism in the face of the girls' "bemused reply" highlights this fact.  Therefore, the assertion that Prior simply assumed that the obvious answer must not be right is supported by passage evidence.
(Choice B)  "Research into other cultures has long been informed by the recognition that one must attempt to assimilate the viewpoint of the group under study, rather than proceeding from ethnocentric conceptions."  In Paragraph 1 the author cites "1969's influential Symbolic Interactionism," in which Herbert Blumer wrote that "'people act toward things on the basis of the meaning that these things have for them, not on the basis of the meaning that these things have for the outside scholar.'"  Accordingly, the information that this idea was expressed in an influential work published decades ago supports the passage assertion that "[r]esearch into other cultures has long been informed" by such a recognition.
(Choice C)  Samburu women displayed "'incomprehension of what the [educated] girls did in school.'"  Paragraph 4 discusses "the rarity of formal education among Samburu women," including the women's "'incomprehension of what the [educated] girls did in school.'"  This incomprehension is then evidenced by the specific example of a woman who "'commented that, as a child, she was at a loss to understand why the one school girl sat in her house looking at a paper (i.e. reading).'"

text: Based on the passage, the childhood perspective of the Samburu woman toward the school girl in her village is most similar to the perspective of:
explanations:
Noting the rarity of formal education among Samburu women, Carolyn Lesorogol describes the uneducated females' "incomprehension of what the [educated] girls did in school.  One woman commented that, as a child, she was at a loss to understand why the one school girl sat in her house looking at a paper (i.e. reading).  When the other girls asked her to join them outside to play or go to a dance, she refused, saying she wanted to stay in and look at the paper." (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, most Samburu women do not receive a formal education.  Thus, one woman described the confusion she felt as a child, when "'she was at a loss to understand why the one school girl sat in her house looking at a paper (i.e. reading).'"  In other words, she could observe the school girl's actions but could not understand the meaning behind those actions, perceiving them as "looking at a paper" instead of interpreting them as "reading."
Likewise, if a foreign traveler viewed a religious ceremony she had never seen before, she would observe various actions being performed as part of that ceremony.  However, she would not understand the meaning behind those actions.  For example, although she might see a person making specific movements, she would lack comprehension of the spiritual or symbolic significance of this behavior.  Therefore, the childhood perspective of the Samburu woman toward the school girl in her village is most similar to the perspective of a foreign traveler encountering an unfamiliar religious ceremony.
 (Choice A)  a sheltered student meeting diverse groups of people in college.  Paragraph 4 describes "the one school girl [who] sat in her house looking at a paper (i.e. reading)."  Accordingly, the Samburu woman encountered only a single person representing a diverse viewpoint, rather than diverse groups of people.  Moreover, the fact that there was only one school girl suggests that the Samburu woman had not been sheltered but was merely like the overwhelming majority of people in her community.
(Choices B and C)  a community leader shunning a social transgressor; and an outsider seeking acceptance from an in-group.  According to Paragraph 4, "the other girls asked [the school girl] to join them outside to play or go to a dance."  Therefore, the passage does not indicate that the group of girls shunned the school girl, but rather states that they attempted to include her in their activities.  Similarly, the passage does not portray the Samburu woman as an outsider seeking acceptance, but instead depicts her as being like most of the other girls.

text: Which of the following beliefs best exemplifies the "assumption of a deeper-level similarity underlying the surface-level differences" between cultures referred to in the passage?
explanations:
Nevertheless, diversity among peoples with regard to dress, family structure, gender, religious practices, and so on reflects a variety of answers to what are universal questions about human needs.  Thus, the foundation of understanding a culture other than one's own must still include the assumption of a deeper-level similarity underlying the surface-level differences. (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 6, "diversity among peoples with regard to dress, family structure, gender, religious practices, and so on reflects a variety of answers to what are universal questions about human needs."  Thus, the author asserts that people share common needs for human life and well-being, underneath the differences that exist between societies in terms of particular customs and traditions.  Therefore, the author concludes that "the foundation of understanding a culture other than one's own must still include the assumption of a deeper-level similarity underlying the surface-level differences."
Similarly, the belief that sentences from one language can in principle be translated into any other implies that the different languages refer to ideas that are common to all humans.  Such a belief would depend on the assumption that although diverse languages contain "surface-level" differences of words, those words are different ways of referring to the same "deeper-level" concepts.  Consequently, this belief about translation best exemplifies the "assumption of a deeper-level similarity underlying the surface-level differences" between cultures (Paragraph 6).
 By contrast, the "assumption of a deeper-level similarity underlying the surface-level differences" between cultures is not best exemplified by:
the belief that leaders from one nation should be respected by those of other nations (Choice A).  The idea that leaders from one nation should be respected by the leaders of other nations does not necessarily suggest anything about cultural similarity.  For example, one could believe that other leaders should be respected as a matter of practical policy, without assuming that there is a "deeper-level similarity" (Paragraph 6) between another culture and one's own.
the belief that children from one society can easily adapt to life in a new one (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 6, differences between societies constitute "a variety of answers to what are universal questions about human needs."  However, even if these questions are universal, that does not necessarily mean that it is easy for children (or anyone) to adapt to another society's "answers."  Moreover, customs and behaviors related to "dress, family structure, gender, religious practices, and so on" are likely to be strongly ingrained as part of one's way of life, suggesting that changing them would tend to be difficult.
the belief that food from one region is typically similar to that of its geographic neighbors (Choice C).  Food similarities among people in geographically neighboring regions would be based on factors such as local wildlife, climate, and agricultural conditions.  Thus, beliefs about such similarities would not depend on any assumptions about societies' cultural practices.

text: The passage author's central point in discussing the examples of the Turkana and Samburu tribes is that those who research other cultures should:
explanations:
Those who research other peoples are thus generally well served by the admonition not to import (whether overtly or subconsciously) the presuppositions of their own backgrounds into their understanding of another culture or tradition. (Paragraph 1)
However, a peculiar sort of danger can arise from adherence to this clearly reasonable principle, as illustrated in the recent experience of anthropological photographer Colin Prior. (Paragraph 2)
Paradoxically, Prior's openness to discovering the differences of another society led him away from, rather than toward, a correct understanding. (Paragraph 3)
One woman commented that, as a child, she was at a loss to understand why the one school girl sat in her house looking at a paper (i.e. reading).  When the other girls asked her to join them outside to play or go to a dance, she refused, saying she wanted to stay in and look at the paper." (Paragraph 4)
For those who are literate, the sheer automaticity of the act of reading makes it difficult to imagine the confusion the woman felt as a child.  But to someone for whom even the concept of reading is unfamiliar, the school girl's actions would surely have seemed bizarre; presumably just sitting and staring at a piece of paper would indeed be quite boring. (Paragraph 5)
The passage discusses two problematic extremes of cultural research: the overestimation of differences between groups, and the inability to adopt another perspective.  First, while the author warns scholars "not to import…the presuppositions of their own backgrounds into their understanding of another culture or tradition" (Paragraph 1), they also note that "a peculiar sort of danger can arise from adherence to this clearly reasonable principle" (Paragraph 2).  For instance, Colin Prior was so open to the possibility that Turkana culture differed from his own that his outlook "[p]aradoxically…led him away from, rather than toward, a correct understanding" (Paragraph 3).
Second, the author discusses the other end of the spectrum, where one is unable to see past one's own ideas and perceptions.  For example, Paragraph 4 describes a Samburu woman who had no concept of reading, only of "looking at a paper."  In Paragraph 5, the author points out that "[f]or those who are literate, the sheer automaticity of the act of reading makes it difficult to imagine the confusion the woman felt as a child."  However, they stress the importance of interpreting the behavior from the Samburu woman's standpoint, explaining that "to someone for whom even the concept of reading is unfamiliar, the school girl's actions would surely have seemed bizarre."
Accordingly, the passage author argues that cultural research can go astray both from being excessively open-minded and from being excessively narrow-minded.  Consequently, their central point in discussing the examples of the Turkana and Samburu tribes is that those who research other cultures should strike a balance between intellectual openness and rigid thinking.
 By contrast, the passage author's central point in discussing the examples of the Turkana and Samburu tribes is not that those who research other cultures should:
keep in mind the cultural effects caused by a society's level of literacy (Choice A).  In Paragraph 5, the author contrasts the perspectives of "those who are literate" and "someone for whom even the concept of reading is unfamiliar."  However, while this contrast relates to the author's discussion of the Samburu, they never discuss literacy in relation to the Turkana.  Moreover, the author draws on these examples to make a more comprehensive point about two pitfalls of cultural research.
be receptive to the idea that obvious interpretations may not be correct (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 conveys that Prior made a mistake about the Turkana girls' keys because "he appears to have assumed that the obvious answer must not be right."  In this way, his extreme "openness to discovering the differences of another society led him away from, rather than toward, a correct understanding."  Accordingly, the author makes the point that in some cases, obvious interpretations really are correct.
avoid closed-mindedness in interpreting cultural practices (Choice D).  Although the author indicates that cultural researchers must avoid "proceed[ing] from ethnocentric conceptions" (Paragraph 1), rigid thinking is only one of two extremes that they identify as problematic.

text: The passage suggests that the most interesting feature of the Lascaux caves is:
explanations:
In September 1940, near the tiny village of Montignac in the southwest region of France, a band of four youths and a dog accidentally stumbled upon the opening to a series of underground caverns whose walls were covered with prehistoric paintings.  Their monumental discovery unleashed a mystery that has continued to puzzle scholars: What function did these magnificent caves perform for the society that painted them?  One plausible theory, yet unproven, is that they constituted a kind of sacred space, perhaps a site for religious ceremonies. (Paragraph 1)
According to Paragraph 1, the "monumental discovery" of the caves "unleashed a mystery that has continued to puzzle scholars," namely, "What function did these magnificent caves perform for the society that painted them?"  Much of the passage then focuses on the possibility that the caves "constituted a kind of sacred space, perhaps a site for religious ceremonies" and on the initiation rites that may have taken place there.  This emphasis on the mysterious function of the caves indicates that their possible purpose is their most interesting feature.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 1 says: "One plausible theory, yet unproven, is that [the caves] constituted a kind of sacred space, perhaps a site for religious ceremonies."  Paragraph 4 adds that "countless footprints shown to have belonged to adolescent male suggest that the caves hosted initiation rituals."  Consequently, whether the caves actually served as sites for initiation rites is a matter of ongoing speculation in the passage rather than an actual feature of the caves.
(Choices C and D)  Paragraph 3 states that "[a]pproximately 900" of the Lascaux paintings depict animals associated with the hunt, such as "horses, bison, stags, large felines, and hares," and that "[v]arious pigments, mainly red, yellow, and brown were used" by the Lascaux artists to paint the images on the cave walls.  Although both the depiction of the hunt and the use of colorful pigments are definite features of the caves, they are secondary to the feature that is primary or most interesting in the passage, namely, the possible purpose the caves served for the society that painted them.

text:
According to the passage, the initiation rites of the hunter-gatherer society are based on the assumption that:
hunting occupies a prominent place within the community.
adolescent males are of particular concern to the older males.
adolescent males are naïve and inexperienced.
explanations:
More than 2,000 paintings and symbols [were found]….  Approximately 900 of these depict horses, bison, stags, large felines, and hares, clearly reflecting a society of hunter-gatherers. (Paragraph 3)
Moreover, countless footprints…suggest that the caves may have hosted initiation rituals marking a boy's passage from childhood to maturity.  At this critical juncture, the youths would have traditionally been separated from their families by the adult males and put through frightening ordeals….  The purpose of such traumas was to prepare the adolescent for the physical and psychological rigors of the hunt, the brutalities of warfare, and the inevitable trials of adulthood. (Paragraph 4)
When illuminated against the blackness, the realistic murals would have become a moving spectacle that simulated the hunt, the wonder and gravity of which was forever imprinted upon the boys' psyches. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 3 states that "[a]pproximately 900" of the Lascaux paintings "depict horses, bison, stags, large felines, and hares, clearly reflecting a society of hunter-gatherers."  Paragraph 5 adds that the initiation rites had the effect of turning "the realistic murals" into "a moving spectacle that simulated the hunt, the wonder and gravity of which was forever imprinted upon the boys' psyches."  Based on this passage information, it can be assumed that the hunt was extremely important to the people of Lascaux and so occupies a prominent position within that community (Number I).
Paragraph 4 describes how "the youths would have traditionally been separated from their families by the adult males and put through frightening ordeals."  This indicates that within the society the older males had an important role to play opposite the young boys: They were responsible for putting them through the ordeals of their initiation process that prepared them for adult life and the hunt.  Therefore, it can be assumed that adolescent males are of particular concern to the older males of the society (Number II).
Paragraph 4 describes the initiation rites as "marking a boy's rite of passage from childhood to maturity" when "the youths would have traditionally been separated from their families by the adult males and put through frightening ordeals."  The purpose of these ordeals was "to prepare the adolescent for the physical and psychological rigors of the hunt, the brutalities of warfare, and the inevitable trials of adulthood."  From this description it can be assumed that the boys being initiated need to learn about their role in society as well as the hunt and so are naïve and inexperienced (Number III).

text: The author of the passage is primarily attempting to explain the:
explanations:
Their monumental discovery unleashed a mystery that has continued to puzzle scholars: What function did these magnificent caves perform for the society that painted them?  One plausible theory, yet unproven, is that they constituted a kind of sacred space, perhaps a site for religious ceremonies. (Paragraph 1)
The paintings date from between 17,000 and 12,000 BCE, which places them within the Upper Paleolithic era. (Paragraph 2)
Nevertheless, the cave art of Lascaux suggests a purpose that goes beyond artistic expression. (Paragraph 3)
It is likely these chambers served as a sanctuary within which the paintings would have corresponded to the iconography of a temple.  Moreover, countless footprints shown to have belonged to adolescent males suggests that the caves may have hosted initiation rituals marking a boy's passage from childhood to maturity. (Paragraph 4)
In asking, "What function did these magnificent caves perform for the society that painted them?" (Paragraph 1), the author establishes an anthropological viewpoint, one that looks at a human culture and its practices.  The author then speculates about the "mystery" of these caves as it relates to the practices of this society, which would have flourished somewhere "between 17,000 to 12,000 BCE" (Paragraph 2).  For instance, Paragraph 3 says "the cave art of Lascaux suggests a purpose that goes beyond artistic expression."  Paragraph 4 adds that "[i]t is likely these chambers served as a sanctuary…[and] countless footprints shown to have belonged to adolescent males suggest that the caves may have hosted initiation rituals."
Accordingly, the passage author is primarily attempting to explain the practices of a prehistoric culture (ie, society) from an anthropological viewpoint.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 4 presents the initiation rites as "triggering 'a regressive disorganization of the personality' followed by 'a constructive reorganization' of the individual's faculties…meant to force the youth to call upon inner resources…thereby inducing a kind of psychological death and rebirth."  However, the passage author does not focus primarily on attempting to explain the transition from adolescence to maturity from a psychological viewpoint (one that considers mental and emotional states), but rather on explaining the possible purpose of the Lascaux caves.
(Choice B)  Paragraph 5 states that "descending into the darkness of the caves must have seemed like immersing oneself in what religious historian Mircea Eliade has termed 'sacred time,' a kind of dissociative (detached) state conducive (favorable) to the deeply transformative experience of the initiate."  However, although the passage author suggests that the initiates may have experienced "sacred time," he or she never attempts to explain the essential meaning of the initiation rites from a religious viewpoint (one involving the sacred or divine).
(Choice C)  The Lascaux caves displayed paintings of "horses, bison, stags, large felines, and hares" (Paragraph 3), which became "a moving spectacle that simulated the hunt, the wonder and gravity of which was forever imprinted upon the boys' psyches" (Paragraph 5).  Although this evidence indicates a relationship between humans and animals in the society, and mythologist Joseph Campbell's visit to Lascaux is mentioned, the author never attempts to explain this relationship from a mythological viewpoint (one based on traditional stories or myths).

text: If the author were to claim that the initiation rites described in Paragraph 4 served as an effective means for the adolescent boys to mature, the evidence provided for such an inference would be:
explanations:
At this critical juncture, youths would have traditionally been separated from their families by the adult males and put through frightening ordeals.  The boys might have been tattooed, confined, or presented with physical challenges.  The purpose of such traumas was to prepare the adolescent for the physical and psychological rigors of the hunt, the brutalities of warfare, and the inevitable trials of adulthood.  Theologian Karen Armstrong describes such experiences as triggering "a regressive disorganization of the personality" followed by a "constructive reorganization" of the individual's faculties.  In other words, the rites were meant to force the youth to call upon inner resources of which he was not yet aware, thereby inducing a kind of psychological death and rebirth. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, "[t]he purpose" of the "traumas" caused by the initiation rites "was to prepare the adolescent for the physical and psychological rigors of the hunt, the brutalities of warfare, and the inevitable trials of adulthood."  Such experiences are further described as "triggering 'a regressive disorganization of the personality' followed by 'a reconstructive reorganization' of the individual's faculties."  The rites would "force the youth to call upon inner resources of which he was not yet aware, thereby inducing a kind of psychological death and rebirth."
Although this evidence would imply that the initiation rites were designed to stimulate the maturation of these adolescent boys, the passage provides no examples that initiation did, in fact, lead to maturity.  As a result, the evidence that the rites were an effective means for helping the boys mature is weak.
(Choice B)  According to Paragraph 4, "the youths would have traditionally been separated from their families by the adult males and put through frightening ordeals" in which they "might have been tattooed, confined, or presented with physical challenges."  Paragraph 5 further states that in the darkness of the caves "all normal orientation" was "suspended."  This evidence would seem to imply that being frightened and disoriented was an essential part of the adolescent initiation rites.  However, the passage does not reveal whether the boys remained frightened and disoriented after the rites or whether they recovered and matured as a result.
(Choice C)  Paragraph 4 says, "At this critical juncture, the youths would have traditionally been separated from their families by the adult males and put through frightening ordeals."  This statement indicates that the elders in the society supervised, or at least played a strong role in, the initiation of the boys.  However, the passage never indicates that this supervision by the male elders ensured the boys' maturation.
(Choice D)  Paragraph 5 says that "[i]n primitive societies, descending into the darkness of the caves must have seemed like immersing oneself in what religious historian Mircea Eliade has termed 'sacred time,' a kind of dissociative (detached) state conducive (favorable) to the deeply transformative experience of the initiate."  However, this statement represents a comparison made by the author; the passage never establishes that the adolescent boys being initiated at Lascaux experienced sacred time during the rites and matured as a result.

text: Suppose that animal images painted on the flat surfaces of the cave seemed to move quickly when the initiates viewed them.  This information would most strongly oppose the passage claim that using the "edges and curvatures" of the cave wall:
explanations:
More than 2,000 paintings and symbols cover the insides of the caverns.  Approximately 900 of these depict horses, bison, stags, large felines, and hares, clearly reflecting a society of hunter-gatherers.  Various pigments, mainly red, yellow, and brown, were used.  By employing a novel method that took advantage of the edges and curvatures of the cave walls, the artists were able to give lifelike dimensions to these images as well as endow them with a sense of motion. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, "[b]y employing a novel method that took advantage of the edges and curvatures of the cave walls, the [Lascaux] artists were able to give lifelike dimensions to these [animal] images as well as endow (provide) them with a sense of motion."  This implies that it was essential for the artists to use the "edges and curvatures" of the cave walls to create dimension and "a sense of motion" (ie, movement) in the images.
However, if animal images painted on the flat surfaces of the cave appeared to move quickly when the initiates viewed them, this would imply that it was not essential to use the "edges and curvatures" of the cave walls to give these images the appearance of being in motion.  In fact, the illusion of movement could be created by some other technique.  Therefore, the appearance of motion in figures painted on the flat surfaces would strongly oppose the passage claim that using the "edges and curvatures" of the cave walls was essential for the artists to be "able to" create the illusion of movement.
(Choices A and C)  Paragraph 3 states that using "the edges and curvatures of the cave walls" produced images with "lifelike dimensions."  Accordingly, the passage is claiming that the images painted on the "edges and curvatures" of the cave walls are more realistic (ie, "lifelike") and have well-defined shape and appearance of mass (ie, "dimensions").  However, if initiates perceived images painted on the flat surfaces of the cave walls to be moving, this appearance of movement would be irrelevant to any claims about the realistic appearance or the dimensions of images painted on the cave walls' edges and curvatures.
(Choice B)  Paragraph 3 states that "[b]y employing a novel method that took advantage of the edges and curvatures of the cave walls, the artists were able to give lifelike dimensions to these images as well as endow them with a sense of motion."  However, even if the illusion of motion could also be achieved on a flat surface, this would constitute a different technique, separate from the innovative method used on non-flat surfaces.  Therefore, if images painted on the flat surfaces appeared to move, this would not oppose the claim that the Lascaux artists employed an innovative technique in taking advantage of the cave walls' edges and curvatures.

text: Based on the author's description of adolescent initiation, which of the following assertions could most reasonably be inferred about the hunter-gatherer society described in the passage?
explanations:
Moreover, countless footprints shown to have belonged to adolescent males suggest that the caves may have hosted the initiation rituals marking a boy's passage from childhood to maturity.  At this critical juncture, the youths would have traditionally been separated from their families by the adult males and put through frightening ordeals.  The boys might have been tattooed, confined, or presented with physical challenges.  The purpose of such traumas was to prepare the adolescent for the physical and psychological rigors of the hunt, the brutalities of warfare, and the inevitable trials of adulthood. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 states that the adolescent boys "would have traditionally been separated from their families by the adult males and put through frightening ordeals."  This indicates that the initiation rites consisted of established practices that were presumably handed down from one generation to the next and were meant "to prepare the adolescent for the physical and psychological rigors of the hunt."  Therefore, it can most reasonably be inferred that the rituals would have been based on long-established values such as beliefs about the importance of the hunt.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 4 states that "the youths would have traditionally been separated from their families by the adult males and put through frightening ordeals."  Therefore, adolescent initiation is not shown to be a voluntary process in the passage but rather an involuntary one, since it is imposed by the society for its own benefit and not chosen by the individual.
(Choice B)  According to Paragraph 4, "[t]he purpose of such traumas was to prepare the adolescent for the physical and psychological rigors of the hunt, the brutalities of warfare, and the inevitable trials of adulthood."  This demonstrates that the initiation rites were about preparing adolescents for their new adult role and integrating them into adult society.  Consequently, such ceremonies are meant to support rather than challenge societal expectations.
(Choice D)  Paragraph 4 indicates that "traumas" helped "to prepare the adolescent for the physical and psychological rigors of the hunt, the brutalities of warfare, and the inevitable trials of adulthood."  In addition, Paragraph 4 cites Karen Armstrong's description of such experiences "as triggering 'a regressive disorganization of the personality' followed by 'a constructive reorganization' of the individual's faculties."  As the passage explains, the trauma involved in the rites helped "to force the youth to call upon inner resources of which he was not yet aware, thereby inducing a kind of psychological death and rebirth."  Accordingly, trauma would not inhibit but facilitate the maturation process of the adolescents.

text: A triple-decker pulpit in an eighteenth-century church would most likely have been viewed in which of the following ways?
explanations:
[H]istorical websites laud [Christ Church] as "an extraordinary example of eighteenth-century architecture, featuring meticulous brickwork, vaulted ceilings, and gorgeous compass-headed windows."  Notably, the church also contains a triple-decker pulpit—a rare but distinctive feature of its era. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 conveys how historical websites have held up Christ Church as "'an extraordinary example of eighteenth-century architecture,'" emphasizing that this church "also contains a triple-decker pulpit—a rare but distinctive feature of its era."  By describing this kind of pulpit as rare and noteworthy, the passage suggests that it would have been an uncommon and attention-drawing feature even in a church of that time period.  Accordingly, a triple-decker pulpit in an eighteenth-century church would most likely have been viewed as an object of curiosity.
 (Choice A)  as an impractical innovation.  Paragraph 1 stresses that the triple-decker pulpit was "a rare but distinctive feature of its era" (ie, the eighteenth century).  However, the passage never discusses the practicality of triple-decker pulpits or of eighteenth-century church architecture in general.
(Choice B)  as a result of the Carter family's influence.  The original Christ Church building was "commissioned in 1665 by John Carter," whose grandsons oversaw its transformation into "'the most finely crafted Anglican parish church in all of colonial Virginia'" (Paragraph 1).  However, while the Carters were specifically responsible for building Christ Church, the passage does not indicate that the family took measures to have any other churches built or that any of them used their influence to have triple-decker pulpits installed in churches.  Accordingly, the passage never suggests that a triple-decker pulpit in an eighteenth-century church would have been viewed as a sign of the Carter family's influence.
(Choice C)  as an unremarkable phenomenon.  As Paragraph 1 reports, Christ Church "[n]otably…contains a triple-decker pulpit—a rare but distinctive feature of its era."  Accordingly, since triple-decker pulpits were rare even in an eighteenth-century church, the presence of such a pulpit would most likely have been viewed as nothing other than a remarkable phenomenon.

text: The passage comparison of Christ Church with the ancient temple of Apollo at Bassae is most likely intended to establish:
explanations:
…Christ Church constitutes an architectural feat of mathematical precision in harmony with nature's laws.  Indeed, horologist H. Stephen Stewart has characterized it as "a building of numbers"—specifically, calendric, solar, and lunar numbers….  [T]wo weeks after the vernal equinox…a sunbeam…rests upon the altar; this phenomenon repeats itself two weeks prior to the autumnal equinox.  Moreover, a shadow cast from a cornice of the building…tracks the progression from spring to fall.  For eight hours daily, the structure also acts as a sundial…. (Paragraph 2)
The locale and physical orientation of this sacred structure were critical: not just any terrestrial site could offer complete celestial alignment.  As a result, Christ Church has basked in splendid isolation amidst an untamed countryside in a spot described…as "a rather lonely one, with woods all around, few or no houses near, and no good roads."  Its exchange of geographical remoteness for astronomical positioning recalls another singular sanctuary, the fifth-century BCE Temple to Apollo, the god of the sun and rationality, at Bassae in Greece.  Thrust deep into the rural expanse, this imposing temple—whose design has been attributed to the same architect as the Athenian Parthenon—sits atop Kotylion Mountain.  There, this previously forgotten structure holds dominion over a desolate landscape through which, prior to the last century, no truly passable road led.  Oriented north to south rather than (the more typical) east to west, the building seems calibrated to track the sun's annual phases.  Like the church, the temple has moved from dilapidation to restoration, becoming the focus of scrutiny as scientists decipher the calculus of its blueprint. (Paragraph 3)
As Paragraph 2 explains, Christ Church is "an architectural feat of mathematical precision in harmony with nature's laws" and uniquely designed to track the yearly movements of the sun.  For example, "a shadow cast from a cornice…tracks the progression from spring to fall," while "[f]or eight hours daily, the structure also acts as a sundial."
Paragraph 3 then emphasizes how "[t]he locale and physical orientation" of the church's building were crucial for achieving "complete celestial alignment," enabling the structure to track the phases of the sun.  Notably, achieving such precise alignment resulted in the church's "geographical remoteness," reminiscent of the isolated fifth-century BCE Temple to Apollo at Bassae.  This temple is also comparable to the church as "[o]riented north to south rather than (the more typical) east to west, the building seems calibrated to track the sun's annual phases."
Consequently, the passage comparison of Christ Church with an ancient temple of Apollo is most likely intended to establish that each structure incorporated architectural calibrations based on solar movements.
 (Choice A)  that each structure was designed with the purpose of geographical isolation.  While both the church and the temple are known for their "geographical remoteness," the passage stresses how their sites were carefully selected to offer "complete celestial alignment" (Paragraph 3).  The precise location and "astronomical positioning" of Christ Church enable it to track the sun's yearly and daily cycles.  Likewise, due to its location and how it is "[o]riented north to south rather than (the more typical) east to west," the temple at Bassae can track the sun's annual phases.  Therefore, each structure was precisely aligned and deliberately designed to track the sun; the consequence of this alignment was geographical isolation.
(Choice C)  that ancient temples were more attuned to celestial phenomena than modern houses of worship.  According to Paragraph 2, Christ Church represents "an architectural feat of mathematical precision in harmony with nature's laws," allowing it to track solar cycles.  Likewise, as Paragraph 3 indicates, the ancient Temple of Apollo at Bassae is "[o]riented north to south rather than (the more typical) east to west," enabling it to track the sun's yearly phases.  Thus, the passage depicts each structure as attuned to celestial phenomena; however, it never describes the temple as being more attuned than either Christ Church or modern houses of worship.
(Choice D)  that the church was a typical example of Enlightenment-era architecture whereas the temple's physical orientation was uncommon.  Paragraph 1 describes Christ Church as "'an extraordinary example of eighteenth-century architecture.'"  By contrast, Paragraph 3 describes the temple at Bassae as uncommon among such ancient Greek temples in being "[o]riented north to south rather than (the more typical) east to west."  However, the author also emphasizes how both houses of worship were purposely positioned to track the solar cycle.  Accordingly, the passage comparison of Christ Church with the ancient temple is most likely intended to establish that each structure was precisely located to achieve "complete celestial alignment" (Paragraph 3).

text: Based on Paragraph 1, which of the following statements best describes an assumption made by the author?
explanations:
Situated near Weems, Virginia, Christ Church has long belied its appearance as a typical, if elite, Anglican house of worship from the colonial era.  Some have conjectured that the 1735 building is based on a prototype by the renowned English architect Christopher Wren, and, in truth, its resemblance to Farley Church in Wiltshire, England, which he designed, is almost uncanny. (Paragraph 1)
In Paragraph 1, the author makes the following comment regarding Christ Church: "Some have conjectured that the 1735 building is based on a prototype by the renowned English architect Christopher Wren, and, in truth, its resemblance to Farley Church in Wiltshire, England, which he designed, is almost uncanny."  With this statement the author does not indicate that they themselves believe that Christ Church was designed by Wren, or even based on one of his blueprints.  However, the author seems to assume that the almost disturbing resemblance of the church building to a genuine Wren church means it was likely inspired by a Wren creation.  Therefore, based on Paragraph 1, an assumption made the author is that the architecture of Christ Church was likely inspired by the work of Christopher Wren.
 By contrast, none of the following statements describes an assumption made by the author:
The most finely crafted Anglican churches of the eighteenth century were in Virginia (Choice A).  In Paragraph 1, the author refers to Christ Church as "'the most finely crafted Anglican parish church in all of colonial Virginia.'"  However, the author never mentions any other eighteenth-century Anglican churches in Virginia, nor compares such Virginian churches with those outside the state.
Christopher Wren was the most prolific architect of colonial America (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 1, "Some have conjectured that the 1735 building is based on a prototype by the renowned English architect Christopher Wren"; as the author points out, "its resemblance to Farley Church in Wiltshire, England, which he designed, is almost uncanny."  However, the author provides no information to suggest that Wren ever designed any other buildings in the US and certainly never suggests that Wren was the most prolific architect in colonial America.
The Carters were the most religious family in colonial Virginia (Choice D).  In Paragraph 1, the author reports how the wealthy Carter family had been responsible for the construction of Christ Church, which would eventually be considered "'the most finely crafted Anglican parish church in all of colonial Virginia.'"  However, while such an achievement shows that the Carters were dedicated to constructing an impressive church, without more information this fact is insufficient to establish whether they were more or less religious than other families in the area.  Therefore, the author does not necessarily assume that the Carters were the most religious family in colonial Virginia.

text: According to the passage, the timekeeping functions of the church's architecture suggest:
explanations:
The intricacies of this remarkable building point to its duality in being not only a religious sanctuary, but a shrine to rationality, a veritable temple of the Enlightenment.  Beneath its surface, Christ Church constitutes an architectural feat of mathematical precision in harmony with nature's laws.  Indeed, horologist H. Stephen Stewart has characterized it as "a building of numbers"—specifically, calendric, solar, and lunar numbers. (Paragraph 2)
Clearly, such anomalies were not the result of happenstance.  As spaces of worship, these shrines are at once pragmatic and sacred: their purposes overtly divine even as their designs honor nature and extol reason. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 2 presents the architecture of Christ Church as based on rational principles, emphasizing how its structure represents "an architectural feat of mathematical precision in harmony with nature's laws."  The author also conveys horologist (ie, specialist in time measurement) H. Stephen Stewart's characterization of this church as "'a building of numbers'—specifically, calendric, solar, and lunar numbers"—exemplified through its remarkable timekeeping capabilities.  Later, Paragraph 4 describes how "[a]s spaces of worship," both Christ Church and the Temple of Apollo at Bassae are "at once pragmatic (practical) and sacred."  Likewise, the purpose of both buildings is "overtly (openly) divine even as their designs honor nature and extol (praise) reason."
Thus, Christ Church is primarily a religious sanctuary, but one that was also purposely constructed to incorporate rational principles based on the laws of nature in the form of celestial calibrations.  Accordingly, the timekeeping functions of the church's architecture suggest an attempt to harmonize supernatural beliefs with the principles of reasoning.
 (Choices A and B)  the widespread correlation of architectural designs with the phases of the solar cycle; and a fundamental need for religious sites to align with astronomical coordinates.  Paragraph 2 refers to Christ Church as a "remarkable building," precisely positioned and constructed to use the solar cycles to tell time.  Similarly, Paragraph 3 emphasizes how by being "[o]riented north to south rather than (the more typical) east to west," the Temple of Apollo at Bassae tracks the sun's annual phases.  Accordingly, the architectural designs of both buildings were intended to correspond with the solar cycle; however, the passage also indicates that their locations were precisely calculated and stresses the extraordinary nature of each building.  In Paragraph 4, the author conveys that the solar-tracking features of these two astronomically aligned sanctuaries are "anomalies" (outside the norm) and "not the result of happenstance."  Thus, the solar-tracking functions of the church's architecture suggest neither a widespread correlation of architectural designs with the phases of the solar cycle nor a fundamental need for religious sites to align with astronomical coordinates.
(Choice C)  a reaction to a disconnection between nature and religion in modern times.  According to Paragraph 4, the church's space was built to be "at once pragmatic and sacred" with a purpose that is "overtly divine," even as the building's design with its remarkable timekeeping functions "honor[s] nature and extol[s] reason."  However, the passage never suggests that such harmonizing of natural laws with the divine was a reaction to a disconnection between nature and religion in modern times.

text: By referring to Christ Church as "a time machine" in Paragraph 2, Stewart implies that the church has the capacity to:
explanations:
Beneath its surface, Christ Church constitutes an architectural feat of mathematical precision in harmony with nature's laws.  Indeed, horologist H. Stephen Stewart has characterized it as "a building of numbers"—specifically, calendric, solar, and lunar numbers.  As Stewart explains, two weeks after the vernal equinox, on the mean date for Easter, a sunbeam shines through the oval window above the main entrance that faces due west and rests upon the altar; this phenomenon repeats itself two weeks prior to the autumnal equinox.  Moreover, a shadow cast from a cornice of the building…tracks the progression from spring to fall.  For eight hours daily, the structure also acts as a sundial, casting its shadow on the north lawn.  A seemingly multifunctional edifice, Christ Church, as Stewart astutely concluded, is a virtual "time machine." (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 conveys horologist (ie, specialist in time measurement) H. Stephen Stewart's characterization of Christ Church as "'a building of numbers'—specifically, calendric, solar, and lunar numbers."  The passage then reports how the church is designed to track the sun's cycles.  For instance, "a shadow cast from a cornice…tracks the progression from spring to fall," and "[f]or eight hours daily, the structure also acts as a sundial."
Paragraph 2 then provides Stewart's conclusion: the church with its perfect celestial alignment and many solar tracking functions is basically an oversized timekeeping device, or as he says, a "'time machine.'"  Thus, in referring to Christ Church as a "'time machine,'" Stewart implies that it has the capacity to measure the elapse between key celestial phenomena.
 (Choices A)  elevate the temporal aspects of phenomena over the divine.  In Paragraph 2, the author provides Stewart's assessment of Christ Church as "'a building of numbers'—specifically, calendric, solar, and lunar numbers."  The church's hidden functions as calendar and clock—or its ability to track the phases of the sun and act as a sundial—are then detailed, before relaying Stewart's conclusion that the building constitutes a kind of "'time machine.'"  Although Stewart does highlight the church's capacity to mark and measure time, he never goes on to suggest that it has the capacity to elevate the temporal aspects of phenomena over the divine aspects.
(Choices B)  partially replace worshippers' reliance on the clock and the calendar.  Paragraph 2 details Christ Church's timekeeping capabilities, for instance, how "a shadow cast from a cornice…tracks the progression from spring to fall," and "[f]or eight hours daily, the structure also acts as a sundial."  However, the passage never indicates that churchgoers are aware of or could make any practical use of those timekeeping functions.  Consequently, by calling the church "'a time machine,'" Stewart is not implying that it has the capacity to partially replace worshippers' reliance on standard timekeeping tools.
(Choice D)  make churchgoers feel as though they are in the eighteenth century.  Paragraph 1 cites how Christ Church is "'an extraordinary example of eighteenth-century architecture.'"  However, when Stewart characterizes this building as a "'time machine'" in Paragraph 2, his concern is not with historical time but with timekeeping.  As a horologist he notes how the church is "'a building of numbers'—specifically, calendric, solar, and lunar numbers"—with the ability to track the solar movements; for instance, "a shadow cast from a cornice to the building…tracks the progression from spring to fall."  Accordingly, although Christ Church bears the marks of being constructed in the 1700s, by calling it a time machine Stewart does not imply that it has the capacity to make churchgoers feel as though they are in the eighteenth century.

text: Given the information in the passage, the author would most likely say that the best art:
explanations:
To modern ears, this Greek conception of propriety must sound absurd or even humorous.  Nevertheless, it exemplifies the effect of cultural contact in challenging a society's values, whether through direct observation of a practice or mediated through the art that displays it.  Of course, that function of art also operates within a society, and this self-reflection and critique of cultural ethos is one of art's most important functions.  This is not necessarily to say that art must offer such a challenge to be great; indeed, there are many works that have extraordinary aesthetic worth simply for what they represent.  Still, the importance of art in posing difficult, even painful, questions cannot be overstated. (Paragraph 2)
In Paragraph 2, the author discusses criteria that give a work of art importance or worth.  First, the author highlights the use of art in "challenging a society's values," adding that the "self-reflection and critique of cultural ethos (ie, a culture's commonly held moral assumptions) is one of art's most important functions."  Hence, the author conveys that a crucial purpose of art is to question beliefs that a society takes for granted.
However, the author then asserts that some works may be highly valuable even if they do not question a society's values: "This is not necessarily to say that art must offer such a challenge to be great; indeed, there are many works that have extraordinary aesthetic worth simply for what they represent."  Thus, the author indicates that the aesthetic excellence of an artwork (ie, its beauty or skillfulness) may also be a strong source of artistic value.
Therefore, the author's view is that the best works of art pose an important challenge to society's values, or skillfully portray beauty.  In other words, he or she would most likely say that the best art serves to exemplify beauty or question assumptions.
  (Choice A)  must ignore societal norms about what is considered decent.  Paragraph 4 asserts that "much of what modern viewers take for granted would seem indecent to viewers of the past."  However, this is simply a descriptive claim about perceptions of decency changing over time; the author never argues that the best art must ignore norms of decency.  Rather, he or she implies that art should either exemplify or challenge those norms by portraying "life as it is" or "life as it ought to be."
(Choice B)  must be found in media other than television.  Paragraph 3 mentions the "truly bizarre" aspect of early television in which most fictional programs depicted "pairs of twin beds where the husbands and wives slept separately."  In Paragraph 4, the author suggests that, because this broadcasting standard "represented neither life as it is nor life as it ought to be," such shows may "simply fail to constitute art."  However, the author makes this suggestion specifically about "most shows of the 1950s and 1960s" (Paragraph 3).  He or she never makes a broader claim that all television fails to be art or that the best art can only be found in other forms of media.
(Choice D)  must succeed in expressing a society's values.  In Paragraph 2, the author asserts that "challenging a society's values…is one of art's most important functions."  Similarly, Paragraph 3 implies that art should either "reflect [or] challenge the values of its time."  Therefore, the author would not say that the best art must express a society's values.  In his or her view, at least some of the best works of art serve to question those values.

text: Implicit in the author's discussion of television standards (Paragraph 4) is the idea that:
explanations:
This television standard is hard to understand, in part because the implicit moral claims involved do not exemplify the kinds of cultural differences described above….  Nor can the standard be easily attributed to attitudes evolving over time; although much of what modern viewers take for granted would seem indecent to viewers of the past, surely the idea of a married couple occupying the same bed does not fall into that category.  Thus, the prohibition against depicting that practice could only have "protected" audiences from something wholly uncontroversial.  As such, this aspect of early television programming represented neither life as it is nor life as it ought to be—nor even how anyone thought life ought to be.  In this respect, then, does it simply fail to constitute art? (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 discusses an aspect of 1950s and 1960s television that is "hard to understand," in which married couples were typically depicted as sleeping in separate beds.  According to the author, this standard for television programming "represented neither life as it is nor life as it ought to be—nor even how anyone thought life ought to be."  As a result, he or she asks: "In this respect, then, does [early television] simply fail to constitute art?"
By posing this question, the author implies that an essential quality of art is to bear some connection to a society's accepted values.  In this context, depicting "life as it is" would affirm how married couples actually behave, while depicting "life as it ought to be" would portray a view about how married couples should behave.  More generally, then, the author conveys that for a work to qualify as art, it must either affirm or question what a society takes for granted.  Therefore, implicit in the author's discussion of television standards (Paragraph 4) is the idea that a work must either reflect societal values or challenge them in order to count as art.
  By contrast, none of the following ideas are implicit in the author's discussion of television standards:
standards are important for shielding viewers from offensive content (Choice A).  The author criticizes early television's prohibition against showing "a married couple occupying the same bed," asserting that it "could only have 'protected' audiences from something wholly uncontroversial" (Paragraph 4).  In other words, he or she argues that this particular standard did not relate to anything offensive in the first place.  The author never makes a general claim about whether such standards are important.
the effects of watching television are similar to those of encountering art from another culture (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 4, "The American audiences of American television were not another society at risk of being shocked and frightened by unfamiliar customs, as the Greeks experienced with the Etruscans."  Therefore, the author describes a scenario in which watching television is different than encountering art from another culture; he or she never suggests that those activities are similar.
censoring how common behaviors are depicted should be considered wrong rather than moral (Choice D).  The author is critical of the particular television standard under discussion, stating that it is "hard to understand" the prohibition against depicting "a married couple occupying the same bed" (Paragraph 4).
