At the least, it was heavily influential in the development of this film style due to its dark cinematography, enigmatic plot of an investigative nature, voiceover, multiple flashbacks, inventive camera angles, and themes of corruption. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 says that Welles' Citizen Kane "is considered noir by some critics" and that "it was heavily influential in the development of this film style due to its dark cinematography."  Therefore, the fact that some critics consider Citizen Kane noir—largely because it anticipated the noir style of cinematography—would most directly contradict the claim that the film had little influence on cinematography.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 5 states that Citizen Kane "is considered noir by some critics" and that "[at] the least, it was heavily influential in the development of this film style due to its dark cinematography, enigmatic plot of an investigative nature, voiceover, multiple flashbacks, inventive camera angles, and themes of corruption."  Such similarities between Citizen Kane and noir film suggest that considering this movie to be noir constitutes a sound inference.  Consequently, the fact that some critics consider Citizen Kane noir would not contradict but might even support the claim that those critics are real experts in noir.
(Choice C)  Paragraph 3 notes that noir's "stylistic tropes, along with morally questionable character types, brought noir into conflict with mid-20th-century American values."  This suggests that film noir may have been viewed as troubling or controversial.  Therefore, that some critics consider Citizen Kane noir would not contradict but would instead be consistent with the claim that the films of the renowned director Welles were occasionally controversial.
(Choice D)  Paragraph 5 says that Citizen Kane "has long been deemed a cinematic masterpiece and is considered noir by some critics."  However, the passage does not discuss film directors' judgments about either Citizen Kane or noir film in general.  Accordingly, the fact that some critics consider Citizen Kane noir is irrelevant to whether directors admired it as Welles' masterpiece.

text: Based on the passage, which of the following characters is LEAST likely to be portrayed in a conventional noir film?
explanations:
Standard noir roles include an isolated, "hardboiled" detective and a dangerous female character who proves as duplicitous as she is sharp-tongued and glamorous.  Often, a kind of anti-hero is also featured—a man disillusioned and marginalized, down on his luck, desperate to escape his past, and morally ambivalent—who makes an easy target for the double-crossing woman. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, noir films typically include "a dangerous female character who proves as duplicitous as she is sharp-tongued and glamorous," meaning a woman who is deceitful yet alluring (attractive).  Paragraph 3 also describes this typical female character as "double-crossing (betraying)," reinforcing the notion that she is untrustworthy.  Such a woman would be unlikely to sacrifice for the sake of love.  Consequently, given the information in the passage, an alluring woman who sacrifices everything for love is the least likely character to be portrayed in a conventional noir film.
(Choices A, B, and C)  Paragraph 3 describes a particular type of character who often appears in noir films: "a kind of anti-hero…a man disillusioned and marginalized, down on his luck, desperate to escape his past, and morally ambivalent."  At least some of these descriptors could easily apply to any of the following: an aging boxer who loses all his fights in an illegal boxing ring, a business tycoon who is conned out of his fortune, and an ordinary citizen who is suddenly dragged into a life of crime.  Therefore, all these characters represent a type that is likely to be portrayed in a conventional noir film.

text: Which of the following scenes is most likely to be included in a noir film primarily influenced by the German expressionist movement of the 1920s?
explanations:
At the same time, noir imitated the unsettling cinematography of the German expressionist movement of the 1920s and borrowed from French poetic realist cinema a fundamentally jaundiced and tragic worldview. (Paragraph 1)
Camera angles are distorting and disorienting, creating a sense of menace. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 1 says that film noir "imitated the unsettling cinematography of the German expressionist movement of the 1920s," indicating that some imagery in film noir is visually disturbing.  In a similar vein, Paragraph 2 indicates that in film noir, "camera angles are distorting and disorienting."  Accordingly, a scene in which a character's reflection is shown in a cracked mirror could constitute an example of cinematography that is "unsettling" as well as "distorting and disorienting."  It would therefore be the scene most likely to be included in a noir film primarily influenced by the German expressionist movement of the 1920s.
By contrast, the following scenes would not likely be included in such a film as these would not be "unsettling," "distorting," or "disorienting":
A man approaches a street lined with nondescript buildings (Choice A).  From the description of this scene, it can be assumed that buildings that are nondescript (unremarkable to look at) would not appear to be "unsettling."
A solitary woman overlooks a quiet lake (Choice B).  From the description, it is unclear whether this scene is peaceful or sinister (ie, "unsettling"), but it does not suggest that there is "distorting and disorienting" (Paragraph 2) imagery.
The entrance to a nightclub is illuminated in vibrant colors (Choice C).  A scene that is shot in vibrant colors would constitute a radical departure from the standard "black-and-white" (Paragraph 2) cinematography of film noir.

text: Which of the following statements, if true, would most challenge the author's claims about the Knights Templar?
explanations:
The seal of the Knights Templar depicts two knights astride a single horse, a visual testament of the order's poverty at its inception in 1119.  Nevertheless, these Knights of the Temple—who swore oaths not only of poverty but of chastity, loyalty, and bravery—would eventually become one of the wealthiest and most powerful organizations in the medieval world. (Paragraph 1)
Having secured a small benefice from Jerusalem's King Baldwin II, the knights inaugurated their mission at the site of the great Temple of Solomon.  They quickly attracted widespread admiration as well as many recruits from crusaders and other knights.  Within a year of its founding, the order received a financial endowment from the deeply impressed Count of Anjou, whose example was soon followed by other nobles and monarchs.  As early as 1128, the Templars even gained official papal recognition, and their wealth, holdings, and numbers swelled both in the Holy Land and throughout Europe, especially in France and England. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 1, the Templars were originally quite poor: "The seal of the Knights Templar depicts two knights astride a single horse, a visual testament of the order's poverty at its inception in 1119."  Paragraph 2 then further elaborates on the creation and funding of the Templar Order: "Having secured a small benefice (compensation for official service) from Jerusalem's King Baldwin II, the knights inaugurated their mission."  Therefore, the passage indicates that although the Templars did receive some initial resources from Baldwin II, at that time they were by no means wealthy.
Nevertheless, Paragraph 2 goes on to relate that the Templars did eventually gain wealth, but from other sources: "Within a year of its founding, the order received a financial endowment from the deeply impressed Count of Anjou, whose example was soon followed by other nobles and monarchs."  Hence, the passage indicates that it was because of these additional sources of support, rather than Baldwin II's original patronage, that the Templars' "wealth, holdings, and numbers swelled both in the Holy Land and throughout Europe."
Consequently, the author's claims about the Knights Templar would be challenged if it were true that the Templars acquired most of their extensive wealth from King Baldwin II.
  By contrast, none of the following statements would challenge the author's claims about the Knights Templar:
The Templars had at times given assistance to Philip the Fair before he plotted against them (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 4, the Templar Order came to an end shortly after "Philip the Fair of France joined forces with Pope Clement V to engineer the Templars' downfall beginning in 1307."  However, the passage never discusses any dealings that Philip and the Templars may have had prior to that point.  Therefore, although it might seem especially treacherous if Philip betrayed the Templars after they had aided him, the passage contains no information that would rule out this possibility.
The Templars who originally founded their order had previously considered just living as monks in the Holy Land (Choice C).  Paragraph 2 states that "[t]he first Templars were nine knights who took an oath to defend the Holy Land and any pilgrims who journeyed there after the First Crusade."  However, the passage never discusses whether these knights might have originally considered a different life before they founded the Templar Order.
The Templars required their recruits to swear that they would never retreat in battle (Choice D).  The passage conveys that the Knights Templar "swore oaths not only of poverty but of chastity, loyalty, and bravery" (Paragraph 1).  As swearing to never retreat in battle could be part of an oath of bravery, this statement would be consistent with passage information.

text: In 1187, Jerusalem fell to an opposing army and the Templar capital was moved to Paris, where it would remain until the order was dissolved.  Based on the passage, this information would most reasonably suggest that:
explanations:
Nevertheless, these Knights of the Temple—who swore oaths not only of poverty but of chastity, loyalty, and bravery—would eventually become one of the wealthiest and most powerful organizations in the medieval world.  So far-reaching was their strength and acclaim that their destruction must have seemed as sudden and surprising as it was utter and irrevocable.  The signs of danger could not have been wholly invisible, however, as the Templars' growing influence became perceived as a threat to European rulers. (Paragraph 1)
As early as 1128, the Templars even gained official papal recognition, and their wealth, holdings, and numbers swelled both in the Holy Land and throughout Europe, especially in France and England. (Paragraph 2)
However, this growing power contained the seeds of the order's downfall.  Although the Templars were generally held in high esteem, the passage of time saw censure and suspicion directed toward them….  Moreover, their increasingly elevated status brought them into conflict with established authorities. (Paragraph 3)
According to the passage, the Knights Templar grew so strong as an organization that they could rival the power of monarchs.  As Paragraph 1 states: "So far-reaching was their strength and acclaim that...the Templars' growing influence became perceived as a threat to European rulers."  Paragraph 2 further describes the Templars' ascendance, specifying that "their wealth, holdings, and numbers swelled…especially in France and England."  Likewise, Paragraph 3 conveys that the Templars' "growing power" caused tension as "their increasingly elevated status brought them into conflict with established authorities."
Therefore, the passage indicates both that the Templars' strength could challenge that of European rulers and also that their forces were most concentrated in France and England.  Accordingly, the fact that the Templar capital was located in Paris suggests that French rulers would have been the group most threatened by Templar power.  Consequently, this information would most reasonably suggest that the Templars would have seemed particularly dangerous to Philip the Fair.
  (Choices A and C)  the number of recruits to the Templar Order began to decline; and fewer knights were willing to embark on crusades.  Since the Templars "took an oath to defend the Holy Land and any pilgrims who journeyed there after the First Crusade" (Paragraph 2), the fall of Jerusalem would have constituted a significant loss.  However, that loss would not necessarily mean that the Templars suffered a decline in recruitment or that fewer knights were willing to embark on crusades.  For instance, it is possible that the desire to reclaim Jerusalem would have inspired even greater support for the Templar cause.
Moreover, Paragraph 1 indicates that the Templars were still a powerful organization when their order fell: "So far-reaching was their strength and acclaim that their destruction must have seemed as sudden and surprising as it was utter and irrevocable."  Accordingly, the Templars must have maintained or increased their strength over time, suggesting that there was no lack of recruits or enthusiasm for their mission.
(Choice B)  European nations abandoned their goal of controlling the Holy Land.  Paragraph 4 states that "in 1307…Clement invited the Templar Master, Jacques de Molay, to meet with him on the pretext of organizing a new crusade to retake the Holy Land."  De Molay's acceptance of the invitation suggests that the prospect of such a crusade was a believable story.  In addition, the fact that the Templar capital remained in Paris does not mean that no attempts were made to retake Jerusalem, only that any such attempts did not succeed.  Therefore, it cannot be concluded that the fall of Jerusalem led European nations to abandon their goal of controlling the Holy Land.

text: Which of the following items of passage information most clearly indicates that the author believes the Templars were innocent of the accusations against them?
explanations:
Shortly thereafter, Philip's forces arrested de Molay and his knights on charges the preponderance of which were almost certainly fabricated.  Ranging from the mundane to the unspeakably perverse, the accusations even included an incredible entry citing "every crime and abomination that can be committed."  Suffering tortures nearly as horrific as the acts of which they were accused, many Templars confessed. (Paragraph 4)
The author describes the eventual downfall of the Templars, but conveys that the accusations against them were probably false.  According to Paragraph 4, "Philip's forces arrested de Molay and his knights on charges the preponderance of which were almost certainly fabricated."  Furthermore, in discussing these charges, the author notes: "Ranging from the mundane to the unspeakably perverse, the accusations even included an incredible entry citing 'every crime and abomination that can be committed'."
By describing the entry as "incredible," the author highlights the implausibility of the accusation; the idea that the Templars had committed "'every crime and abomination'" would be an unreasonable thing to believe.  Hence, the author portrays the fact that the charges "even included" such an assertion as evidence that those charges "were almost certainly fabricated."  In this way, then, the author indicates that they believe the Templars were innocent.
  By contrast, none of the following items of passage information includes an expression of the author's own view of the charges against the Templars:
The Templars swore oaths of poverty, chastity, loyalty, and bravery (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 1, "these Knights of the Temple…swore oaths not only of poverty but of chastity, loyalty, and bravery."  However, even if it is assumed that the Templars of 1307 continued to uphold the values expressed by those oaths, the author never mentions the oaths in connection with the charges against the Templars.
Jacques de Molay declared that the Templars' confessions were lies (Choice C).  De Molay's declaration "that the Templars' confessions were lies obtained under torture" (Paragraph 5) would be a historical fact regardless of whether the author believed he was telling the truth.  Hence, the author's own view is not conveyed by the mention of de Molay's assertion in the passage.
The rulers of many countries did not believe the accusations (Choice D).  Paragraph 5 states that "Edward II of England remained convinced that the accusations were false, a view seemingly shared by other rulers."  However, this historical information would be true regardless of whether the author agreed or disagreed with those rulers.

text: Which of the following passage claims most strongly supports the assertion that the Templars' influence seemed threatening to European rulers?
explanations:
So far-reaching was their strength and acclaim that their destruction must have seemed as sudden and surprising as it was utter and irrevocable.  The signs of danger could not have been wholly invisible, however, as the Templars' growing influence became perceived as a threat to European rulers. (Paragraph 1)
Moreover, their increasingly elevated status brought them into conflict with established authorities.  One revealing example occurred in 1252 when, because of the Templars' "many liberties" as well as their "pride and haughtiness," England's King Henry III proposed to curb the order's strength by reclaiming some of its possessions.  The Templars' response was unambiguous: "So long as thou dost exercise justice thou wilt reign; but if thou infringe it, thou wilt cease to be King!" (Paragraph 3)
The passage conveys that the Templar Order became so powerful over time that many leaders began to view it with concern.  For instance, Paragraph 1 states that "the Templars' growing influence became perceived as a threat to European rulers," and Paragraph 3 notes that the Templars' "increasingly elevated status brought them into conflict with established authorities."
The author then provides an example of such a conflict in which the Templars demonstrated their superiority.  According to Paragraph 3, "[B]ecause of the Templars' 'many liberties' as well as their 'pride and haughtiness,' England's King Henry III proposed to curb the order's strength by reclaiming some of its possessions.  The Templars' response was unambiguous: 'So long as thou dost exercise justice thou wilt reign; but if thou infringe it, thou wilt cease to be King!'"
This example shows the Knights Templar not only successfully resisting the will of a monarch but threatening to remove that monarch from power if he continued to challenge them.  Thus, based on this occurrence, Henry III and other leaders would have been right to fear the Templars' power.  Consequently, the passage claim that the Templars defied the attempted reforms of Henry III best supports the assertion that the Templars' influence seemed threatening to European rulers.
  By contrast, none of the following passage claims shows the Templars threatening a ruler:
Nobles throughout Europe provided money to the Order (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 2, the Templar Order "quickly attracted widespread admiration….  Within a year of its founding, the order received a financial endowment from the deeply impressed Count of Anjou, whose example was soon followed by other nobles and monarchs."  Therefore, although nobles throughout Europe did provide money to the Templar Order, this financial support was because of their admiration for the Templars, not because they felt threatened by the Templars' influence.
The Templars were absorbing crusaders and other knights into their ranks (Choice C).  Paragraph 2 states that the Templars "quickly attracted widespread admiration as well as many recruits from crusaders and other knights."  Moreover, they "even gained official papal recognition, and their wealth, holdings, and numbers swelled."  However, although this information indicates that the Templar Order grew in manpower, it does not reveal any conflict between the Templars and European rulers.
Clement V conspired to condemn the Templars on false charges (Choice D).  Although the passage describes how Clement V helped to orchestrate the Templars' destruction, it does not portray him as acting from fear.  Rather, Paragraph 4 states: "Conspiring to seize the order's wealth, Clement invited the Templar Master, Jacques de Molay, to meet with him on the pretext of organizing a new crusade to retake the Holy Land."  Therefore, while it is possible that Clement felt threatened by the Templars, the passage indicates only that he was motivated by greed for the Templars' wealth.

text: The author's main point is that the Knights Templar:
explanations:
Nevertheless, these Knights of the Temple—who swore oaths not only of poverty but of chastity, loyalty, and bravery—would eventually become one of the wealthiest and most powerful organizations in the medieval world.  So far-reaching was their strength and acclaim that their destruction must have seemed as sudden and surprising as it was utter and irrevocable.  The signs of danger could not have been wholly invisible, however, as the Templars' growing influence became perceived as a threat to European rulers. (Paragraph 1)
However, this growing power contained the seeds of the order's downfall....  Moreover, their increasingly elevated status brought them into conflict with established authorities. (Paragraph 3)
Ultimately, the impoverished Philip the Fair of France joined forces with Pope Clement V to engineer the Templars' downfall beginning in 1307.  Conspiring to seize the order's wealth, Clement invited the Templar Master, Jacques de Molay, to meet with him on the pretext of organizing a new crusade to retake the Holy Land.  Shortly thereafter, Philip's forces arrested de Molay and his knights on charges the preponderance of which were almost certainly fabricated. (Paragraph 4)
By 1313, the Templar Order had been dissolved by papal decree, and many of its members were dead.  The following year, Jacques de Molay was burned at the stake after declaring that the Templars' confessions were lies obtained under torture. (Paragraph 5)
A consistent theme throughout the passage is that the Templars' own great strength would eventually be their undoing.  Although they became "one of the wealthiest and most powerful organizations in the medieval world," the Templars would later experience "utter and irrevocable" destruction after their "growing influence became perceived as a threat to European rulers" (Paragraph 1).  The rest of the passage elaborates on this point.  For instance, Paragraph 3 notes that the Templars' "growing power contained the seeds of the order's downfall" as "their increasingly elevated status brought them into conflict with established authorities."
Such conflict would ultimately prove fatal, as "the impoverished Philip the Fair of France joined forces with Pope Clement V to engineer the Templars' downfall in 1307.  Conspiring to seize the order's wealth…Philip's forces arrested de Molay and his knights" (Paragraph 4).  The Templars would never recover from this attack: "By 1313, the Templar Order had been dissolved by papal decree, and many of its members were dead" (Paragraph 5).
Therefore, the passage describes both how the Knights Templar gained great power and wealth, and how those assets eventually motivated rulers in Europe to betray and destroy them.  Consequently, the author's main point is that the Knights Templar possessed great power as an organization, which ironically brought them to ruin.
  (Choice A)  grew to possess power far beyond what might be expected from their humble beginnings.  Paragraph 1 mentions "the order's poverty at its inception in 1119" and notes that, despite these humble beginnings, the Templars "would eventually become one of the wealthiest and most powerful organizations in the medieval world."  However, the author goes beyond this point to discuss the further effects of that accumulating power and wealth.  Specifically, the passage stresses that the Templars would ultimately meet their end because their "growing influence became perceived as a threat to European rulers."
(Choice B)  were actually a more powerful force in Europe than they were in the Holy Land.  According to the passage, the Templars' "wealth, holdings, and numbers swelled both in the Holy Land and throughout Europe, especially in France and England" (Paragraph 2).  However, the author's main point also includes the idea that the Templars' assets in Europe led to their downfall, as "the impoverished Philip the Fair of France joined forces with Pope Clement V to…seize the order's wealth" (Paragraph 4).
(Choice D)  possessed sufficient power to challenge the rule of monarchs.  According to the passage, the Knights Templar became so strong that their power rivaled that of established authorities.  For instance, Paragraph 3 describes the Templars resisting the will of England's King Henry III, who had "proposed to curb the order's strength by reclaiming some of its possessions."  However, although the Templars' defiance of Henry shows that they possessed enough power to challenge monarchs, this is one example in the author's larger point that such conflict with rulers would eventually lead to the Templars' destruction.

text:
Passage information indicates that bells are prone to cracking unless foundries achieve:
the proper ratio between metals used to cast the bell.
the correct proportions between the bell's soundbow and its other parts.
a consistent chemical composition in the bell's alloy.
explanations:
The study further explains that "[t]he optimum composition for bell metal was considered to be about 77% copper and 23% tin.  Alloys containing higher amounts of tin are brittle and thus unsuitable for large bells."  Therefore, it would have seemed plausible at the time that either party could potentially have been responsible for the bell's damage. (Paragraph 2)
In 1960, drillings taken from the Liberty Bell were found to contain about 73% copper and 24% tin, with small amounts of lead and other elements composing the rest of the alloy.  A 1975 analysis using fluorescent X-rays further revealed that the bell's chemical composition varies at different points along its surface, shedding additional light on the reasons for the bell's structural failure. (Paragraph 6)
Paragraph 2 cites a study explaining that bells can suffer structural failure based on the proportions of metals used in their construction.  Specifically, "'[t]he optimum composition for bell metal was considered to be about 77% copper and 23% tin.  Alloys containing higher amounts of tin are brittle and thus unsuitable for large bells.'"  Therefore, the passage indicates that unless foundries achieve the proper ratio between metals used to cast the bell, the bell may be too brittle and thus run the risk of cracking (Number I).
According to Paragraph 6, in 1975 an "analysis using fluorescent X-rays" was conducted on the Liberty Bell.  This analysis "revealed that the bell's chemical composition varies at different points along its surface," indicating that the distribution of metals was inconsistent throughout the bell's alloy.  The author states that this fact "shed[s] additional light on the reasons for the bell's structural failure."  Therefore, passage information indicates that a consistent chemical composition in the bell's alloy is important to prevent a bell from cracking (Number III).
 (Number II)  the correct proportions between the bell's soundbow and its other parts.  According to the passage, successful bell-making involves both structural integrity and sound quality.  For instance, Paragraph 3 states: "In addition to these durability requirements, medieval bell-makers had also identified the correct ratios between the components of a bell to produce the desired tone, based on the thickness of its soundbow."  Therefore, the passage indicates that these ratios help to create the right kind of sound when the bell is rung, and that this is a separate matter from a bell's "durability requirements."  Accordingly, the passage never suggests that a bell would be prone to cracking if those proportions were not achieved, only that it would have an inferior tone.

text: Which of the following conclusions can most reasonably be drawn from the information presented in the passage?
explanations:
In fact, the Whitechapel Foundry of London created the original bell in 1751, at the request of the State House of colonial Philadelphia.  When the bell finally arrived several months later, the assembled onlookers' anticipation turned to horror as it was rung and immediately cracked. (Paragraph 1)
According to Hanson et al. in a metallurgical study, "Despite the massive appearance of large bells, they are quite fragile, and cracking may result from inferior casting techniques and vibrational stresses produced by improper ringing."  The study further explains that "[t]he optimum composition for bell metal was considered to be about 77% copper and 23% tin.  Alloys containing higher amounts of tin are brittle and thus unsuitable for large bells." (Paragraph 2)
Philadelphia brass workers Pass and Stow were commissioned to recast the cracked contribution from Whitechapel in 1753.  Melting the original bell down, the men added several pounds of copper to strengthen the alloy and prevent another crack. (Paragraph 5)
In 1960, drillings taken from the Liberty Bell were found to contain about 73% copper and 24% tin, with small amounts of lead and other elements composing the rest of the alloy. (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 1, Whitechapel Foundry created a bell for colonial Philadelphia that "immediately cracked" when it was rung for the first time.  Paragraph 2 then cites a metallurgical study conveying that "'cracking may result from inferior casting techniques.'"  The study further explains that for a bell to be structurally strong, it should be composed of "'about 77% copper and 23% tin.  Alloys containing higher amounts of tin are brittle and thus unsuitable for large bells.'"  Therefore, the passage indicates that if Whitechapel Foundry did not use the correct ratio of copper to tin, the original bell would have been brittle and likely to crack (as in fact it did).
Paragraph 5 later describes how the brass workers "Pass and Stow…recast the cracked contribution from Whitechapel," stating that they "added several pounds of copper to strengthen the alloy and prevent another crack."  According to Paragraph 6, this infusion of copper resulted in a bell composed of "73% copper and 24% tin, with small amounts of lead and other elements composing the rest of the alloy."
Therefore, the passage indicates that the final bell still contained too low a ratio of copper to tin, even after more copper had been added by Pass and Stow.  Consequently, it is clear that the original Whitechapel bell must have had an even lower ratio of copper to tin, rendering that bell brittle.  Based on that information, it is most reasonable to conclude that the original bell's cracking was probably the fault of Whitechapel Foundry.
 (Choice A)  The original bell's cracking should have been predictable in advance.  Paragraph 2 states that when the original bell cracked, "it would have seemed plausible at the time that either party [Whitechapel Foundry or the Philadelphians] could potentially have been responsible for the bell's damage."  However, this assertion refers to explaining the bell's cracking after it had already occurred.  The passage never suggests that there were prior reasons to expect or predict that the bell would crack.
(Choices B and D)  Pass and Stow were misguided in adding copper to prevent the new bell from cracking; and The original bell's cracking was probably not the fault of Whitechapel Foundry.  According to Paragraph 2, "'[t]he optimum composition for bell metal was considered to be about 77% copper and 23% tin.  Alloys containing higher amounts of tin are brittle and thus unsuitable for large bells.'"  However, this ratio between copper and tin was never achieved in either the original bell or the new one.  For instance, even after "Pass and Stow…added several pounds of copper" (Paragraph 5) to the original bell metal, the resulting alloy "contain[ed] about 73% copper and 24% tin" (Paragraph 6).  Therefore, it is clear that Whitechapel Foundry used too little copper in proportion to tin.  Consequently, the foundry was likely to blame for the bell's original crack, and Pass and Stow were correct to add more copper.

text: Which of the following statements would most challenge the information given in the passage?
explanations:
In the case of the Liberty Bell, Philadelphia brass workers Pass and Stow were commissioned to recast the cracked contribution from Whitechapel in 1753.  Melting the original bell down, the men added several pounds of copper to strengthen the alloy and prevent another crack.  This process was successful but the bell's tone was subpar, so they recast the bell again before it was entered into service.  Its most famous ringing was on July 8, 1776, when its peals announced the signing of the Declaration of Independence.  It was also rung on other significant occasions, including the funeral of Chief Justice John Marshall in 1835, when it cracked once again. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 5, a new version of the bell was created when "Philadelphia brass workers Pass and Stow…recast the cracked contribution from Whitechapel in 1753.  Melting the original bell down, the men added several pounds of copper to strengthen the alloy and prevent another crack."  The passage goes on to indicate that although this recasting process seemed to have gone well, "the bell's tone was subpar, so they recast the bell again before it was entered into service."  For several decades afterward, the new bell was "rung on…significant occasions, including the funeral of Chief Justice John Marshall in 1835, when it cracked once again."
Therefore, the passage conveys that although there were issues with the bell's tone after its initial recasting by Pass and Stow, the bell did not crack again until 1835.  Consequently, the information in the passage would be most challenged if the later Pass and Stow version of the Liberty Bell cracked during tests performed just after its first recasting.
 By contrast, none of the following statements would challenge passage information:
The later Pass and Stow version of the Liberty Bell included an inscription on its shoulder about proclaiming liberty (Choice B).  Paragraph 1 conveys that "[w]hat would later be known as the Liberty Bell initially had no specific connection to American freedom.  In fact, the Whitechapel Foundry of London created the original bell in 1751."  However, Paragraph 5 explains that this original bell was later melted down to create a new one, as "Philadelphia brass workers Pass and Stow were commissioned to recast the cracked contribution from Whitechapel in 1753."  Accordingly, if this later version of the Liberty Bell included an inscription about proclaiming freedom, that would not challenge passage information about the original version of the bell.
The original Whitechapel version of the Liberty Bell had a similar copper-to-tin ratio as other defective bells (Choice C).  Paragraph 2 indicates that a bell's structural integrity depends on its ratio of copper to tin: "'[t]he optimum composition for bell metal was considered to be about 77% copper and 23% tin.  Alloys containing higher amounts of tin are brittle and thus unsuitable for large bells.'"  Accordingly, if the original Whitechapel version of the Liberty Bell had a similar ratio to other defective bells, this fact would be consistent with passage information.
The original Whitechapel version of the Liberty Bell remained undamaged throughout its journey from London to Philadelphia (Choice D).  After the original bell cracked, "[t]he Philadelphians accused the Whitechapel Foundry of poor workmanship, while Foundry workers countered that the Philadelphians caused the crack by ringing the bell incorrectly" (Paragraph 1).  However, the passage never suggests an additional possibility that the bell was damaged during its trip from London to Philadelphia.

text: The description of medieval bell-making in Paragraph 3 most supports the passage claim that:
explanations:
According to Hanson et al. in a metallurgical study….  "[t]he optimum composition for bell metal was considered to be about 77% copper and 23% tin. (Paragraph 2)
The above ratio of metals comports fairly closely with knowledge from hundreds of years prior, as a twelfth-century set of instructions specifies that bells should be composed of four parts copper and one part tin to possess sufficient structural integrity.  In addition to these durability requirements, medieval bell-makers had also identified the correct ratios between the components of a bell to produce the desired tone, based on the thickness of its soundbow, the area struck by the bell's clapper.  The diameter of the bell's mouth should be fifteen times the thickness of the soundbow, and its upper portion or shoulder seven and a half times that thickness. (Paragraph 3)
Thus, aside from minor refinements, the process of casting large bells has remained relatively unchanged for centuries. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 2 explains that when the Liberty Bell was made, "'[t]he optimum composition for bell metal was considered to be about 77% copper and 23% tin.'"  According to Paragraph 3, that ratio of copper to tin "comports fairly closely with knowledge from hundreds of years prior, as a twelfth-century set of instructions specifies that bells should be composed of four parts copper and one part tin to possess sufficient structural integrity."  Therefore, the proper composition of bell metal had been basically understood for centuries.
Paragraph 3 then describes another aspect of bell-making that had long been known: "medieval bell-makers had also identified the correct ratios between the components of a bell to produce the desired tone, based on the thickness of its soundbow."  Thus, both of these crucial aspects of bell-making had been largely understood since the middle ages.  Accordingly, the author asserts that "the process of casting large bells has remained relatively unchanged for centuries" (Paragraph 4).
Therefore, the description of medieval bell-making in Paragraph 3 most supports the passage claim that the process of casting large bells had long been a well-established craft.
 (Choice B)  The bell from Whitechapel Foundry may have been cast using inferior techniques.  Paragraph 1 states that "[t]he Philadelphians accused the Whitechapel Foundry of poor workmanship" after the bell cracked.  Paragraph 2 then explains that "large bells…are quite fragile, and cracking may result from inferior casting techniques."  Based on this information alone, one might speculate that Whitechapel Foundry used inferior casting techniques when producing the bell for Philadelphia.  However, such a conclusion is neither supported nor challenged by the description of medieval bell-making in Paragraph 3, which provides no information about the quality of work performed by Whitechapel Foundry.
(Choice C)  The bell-making process results in bells that are massive but surprisingly fragile.  Paragraph 2 explains that "'[d]espite the massive appearance of large bells, they are quite fragile.'"  However, although the description of medieval bell-making in Paragraph 3 discusses some aspects of the craft, it does not mention the fragility of large bells.
(Choice D)  77% copper and 23% tin constitutes the ideal ratio for bell metal.  According to Paragraph 3, this proportion "comports fairly closely" with medieval instructions that "bells should be composed of four parts copper and one part tin."  Therefore, these instructions recommend approximately, but not exactly, the 77% to 23% ratio described in Paragraph 2.  Moreover, Paragraph 3 goes on to discuss how "medieval bell-makers had also identified the correct ratios between the components of a bell to produce the desired tone," illustrating another facet of bell-making that had been understood for centuries.  Accordingly, although Paragraph 3 provides some support for a specific 77% to 23% ratio being ideal, it more strongly supports the general claim that the process of casting large bells had long been a well-established craft.

text: Which of the following questions about making the Liberty Bell is NOT addressed by the passage author?
explanations:
What would later be known as the Liberty Bell initially had no specific connection to American freedom.  In fact, the Whitechapel Foundry of London created the original bell in 1751, at the request of the State House of colonial Philadelphia.  When the bell finally arrived several months later, the assembled onlookers' anticipation turned to horror as it was rung and immediately cracked.  The Philadelphians accused the Whitechapel Foundry of poor workmanship, while Foundry workers countered that the Philadelphians caused the crack by ringing the bell incorrectly. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 discusses "[w]hat would later be known as the Liberty Bell" and notes that "the Whitechapel Foundry of London created the original bell in 1751, at the request of the State House of colonial Philadelphia."  However, the author never explains why the Philadelphians asked Whitechapel Foundry to produce the bell, nor why they did not select an American foundry.
 By contrast, the passage author provides additional information addressing all of the following questions:
Why did the final bell crack, despite the steps Pass and Stow took to strengthen its alloy? (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 6, an analysis conducted in 1975 "revealed that the bell's chemical composition varies at different points along its surface, shedding additional light on the reasons for the bell's structural failure."  Therefore, the author indicates that the uneven distribution of metals in the final bell's alloy contributed to causing the bell to crack.
Why did the bell come to represent American freedom, when it had originally been made in England? (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 5, the bell became connected to American freedom "on July 8, 1776, when its peals announced the signing of the Declaration of Independence."  In addition, Paragraph 6 explains that "[i]n the years before the Civil War, abolitionists (opponents of slavery) adopted the 'Liberty Bell' as a symbol representing liberation (i.e., freedom) from slavery."
Why would the bell's core and cope have been made as separate pieces, instead of as a single mould? (Choice C).  Paragraph 4 describes "the process of casting large bells," stating that "[a]n inner mould or core is constructed of brick, then covered with clay, animal hair, and manure.  The core is wound with rope, which, when later removed, creates the space for the metal.  The cope or outer mould is shaped around the core."  Therefore, the passage indicates that the core and cope are made separately to allow the rope to be removed (creating space to pour the metal) once the correct shapes for the moulds have been produced.

text:
According to the author, Shang oracle bone inscriptions were used for which of the following purposes?
I. Invoking spiritual powers
II. Guiding behavior
III. Determining the next king
explanations:
These inscriptions reveal several aspects of Shang spiritual practice, which was dominated by attempts to divine the future and to secure the aid of various natural and supernatural powers. (Paragraph 1)
The term "oracle bone inscriptions" derives from the method the Shang used to seek guidance from the spiritual world.  An animal bone, most commonly a tortoise shell or cow scapula, would be inscribed with a statement, such as "on the tenth day, there will be rain" or "we should go to battle."  The shell or bone was then exposed to a heated piece of metal, and the king would interpret the resulting cracks as either affirming or denying the inscription. (Paragraph 2)
Because of this seeming ambivalence, the Shang instead sought to incur Di's favor through the intercession of their deceased kings.  While these kings were not as powerful as Di, they could bestow some measure of blessing (or bane) upon the living ruler and his subjects. (Paragraph 5)
A third group of powers comprised natural spirits, such as the Yellow River Power or the Great Winds.  These forces lacked the direct control over events that Di possessed; however, they did have some influence over natural phenomena.  Hence, both for such powers and for the ancestor kings, some oracle bone inscriptions described a wish and an attempt to gain an entity's favor; for example, "to the Mountain we pray for rain and offer a burnt sacrifice." (Paragraph 6)
In Paragraph 1, the author describes "Shang spiritual practice, which was dominated by attempts to…secure the aid of various natural and supernatural powers."  The passage later provides more details about those spiritual powers, such as the Shang's "deceased kings," who "could bestow some measure of blessing (or bane) upon the living ruler and his subjects" (Paragraph 5).  Likewise, Paragraph 6 identifies "natural spirits" that possessed "influence over natural phenomena."  The author then notes that with both groups, "some oracle bone inscriptions described a wish and an attempt to gain an entity's favor."  Therefore, those inscriptions were used for invoking spiritual powers (Number I).
Paragraph 2 discusses how the Shang used oracle bone inscriptions "to seek guidance from the spiritual world."  As the author explains, "An animal bone, most commonly a tortoise shell or cow scapula, would be inscribed with a statement, such as…'we should go to battle.'"  Then, after exposing the bones to heat, "the king would interpret the resulting cracks as either affirming or denying the inscription."  Therefore, the Shang used oracle bone inscriptions to help determine whether a particular action should be taken, thus guiding behavior (Number II).
 (Number III)  Determining the next king.  According to Paragraph 3, one function of the oracle bone inscriptions was to "legitimize the king's authority."  When a king was believed to have correctly interpreted the bones and predicted future events, his "role as an intermediary between the divine and physical realms was therefore reinforced."  However, this process relates to how the current king was perceived, not to how the next king was selected.  Moreover, the passage does not discuss how the Shang selected new kings.  Accordingly, the author never suggests that oracle bone inscriptions were used for determining the next king.

text: Which of the following conclusions about the Shang dynasty can be drawn from the information in the passage?
explanations:
The earliest documentation of Chinese religious belief comes from the oracle bone inscriptions of the Shang dynasty, which, intriguingly, the newest archaeological evidence has now dated to approximately 1554–1040 B.C.E.  These inscriptions reveal several aspects of Shang spiritual practice, which was dominated by attempts to divine the future and to secure the aid of various natural and supernatural powers. (Paragraph 1)
When the author first mentions the Shang dynasty in Paragraph 1, he or she states that "intriguingly, the newest archaeological evidence has now dated [it] to approximately 1554–1040 B.C.E."  By specifying that this time period is based on "the newest archaeological evidence" and how that evidence "has now dated" the dynasty, the author implies that prior evidence had suggested a different time span.  Accordingly, it can be concluded from passage information that the Shang dynasty was originally believed to have spanned a different time period in China's history.
 (Choice A)  It was extremely reverential toward certain animals.  Paragraph 2 describes how the Shang practiced divination using oracle bone inscriptions, "most commonly [using] a tortoise shell or cow scapula."  However, the passage never explains why the bones of tortoises and cows were most commonly used, nor suggests that those animals (or any others) were revered by the Shang.  For instance, those bones could have simply been the most widely available and convenient.  Therefore, it cannot be concluded from passage information that the Shang were reverential toward any animals.
(Choice C)  It was an era of greater spiritual concern than any other period in Chinese history.  According to Paragraph 7, "The frequency and prominence of oracle bone inscriptions, as well as their emphasis on the role of divine forces, evince (make evident) a high degree of spiritual concern in the time of the Shang dynasty."  Thus, the passage indicates that the Shang dynasty was an era of great spiritual concern.  However, the author never discusses the level of spiritual concern in other periods of Chinese history, nor draws a comparison between such periods and the Shang.  Accordingly, it cannot be concluded from the passage that spiritual concern was greater during the Shang dynasty than at any other time in China's history.
(Choice D)  It was the first time in Chinese history in which any religious practices occurred.  According to Paragraph 1, "The earliest documentation of Chinese religious belief comes from the oracle bone inscriptions of the Shang dynasty."  However, the fact that the earliest documentation of Chinese religion comes from the Shang dynasty means only that there are no earlier historical records of Chinese religious practices.  Such practices could still have occurred in earlier times even if no records of them exist.

text: In some scholars' studies of oracle bones, the inscriptions are viewed as statements to be confirmed, but in other scholars' studies of oracle bones, the inscriptions are viewed as questions to be answered.  This information:
explanations:
The earliest documentation of Chinese religious belief comes from the oracle bone inscriptions of the Shang dynasty, which, intriguingly, the newest archaeological evidence has now dated to approximately 1554–1040 B.C.E.  These inscriptions reveal several aspects of Shang spiritual practice, which was dominated by attempts to divine the future and to secure the aid of various natural and supernatural powers. (Paragraph 1)
The term "oracle bone inscriptions" derives from the method the Shang used to seek guidance from the spiritual world.  An animal bone, most commonly a tortoise shell or cow scapula, would be inscribed with a statement, such as "on the tenth day, there will be rain" or "we should go to battle." (Paragraph 2)
Four days later, the pronouncement was viewed as confirmed when a messenger reported attacks on two settlements.  The king's important role as an intermediary between the divine and physical realms was therefore reinforced. (Paragraph 3)
A third group of powers comprised natural spirits, such as the Yellow River Power or the Great Winds.  These forces lacked the direct control over events that Di possessed; however, they did have some influence over natural phenomena.  Hence, both for such powers and for the ancestor kings, some oracle bone inscriptions described a wish and an attempt to gain an entity's favor; for example, "to the Mountain we pray for rain and offer a burnt sacrifice." (Paragraph 6)
The passage author's main point concerns the connection between oracle bone inscriptions and the spiritual life of the Shang dynasty.  According to Paragraph 1, the inscriptions "reveal several aspects of Shang spiritual practice, which was dominated by attempts to divine the future and to secure the aid of various natural and supernatural powers."  This claim serves as a thesis for the passage, which describes these different aspects of Shang religion.
For instance, the Shang used the inscriptions "to seek guidance from the spiritual world" (Paragraph 2), and to reinforce "[t]he king's important role as an intermediary between the divine and physical realms" (Paragraph 3).  In addition, the Shang sought the aid of powers such as "natural spirits" and "ancestor kings," which were believed capable of influencing events in beneficial or detrimental ways (Paragraph 6).
However, none of these descriptions would be affected by whether the oracle bone inscriptions are statements or questions.  For example, there is no real difference between affirming or denying the statement "'on the tenth day, there will be rain'" (Paragraph 2) versus receiving an answer to the question "on the tenth day, will there be rain?"  In either case, the inscription is being used to seek guidance in order to predict the future and determine the best course of action.  Similarly, in either case the spiritual powers would bear the same relationship to China's welfare.
Therefore, the fact that scholars disagree on whether the inscriptions represent statements or questions does not significantly affect the passage author's main point.
 (Choices A and D)  undermines the passage author's main point; and strengthens the passage author's main point.  Whether the inscriptions represent questions to be answered or statements to be affirmed or denied, the function of the oracle bone inscriptions and the role ascribed to the spiritual powers would still be the same.  Therefore, this possibility would neither undermine nor strengthen the passage author's main point.
(Choice B)  shows the passage author made an oversight in presenting his or her main point.  Even if some scholars believe the inscriptions were questions, the failure to acknowledge that fact is not necessarily an oversight.  For instance, if the passage author believes the evidence favors viewing the inscriptions as statements, he or she may have intentionally ignored the alternative view.

text: The author does NOT provide any information to help explain:
explanations:
The term "oracle bone inscriptions" derives from the method the Shang used to seek guidance from the spiritual world.  An animal bone, most commonly a tortoise shell or cow scapula, would be inscribed with a statement, such as "on the tenth day, there will be rain" or "we should go to battle."  The shell or bone was then exposed to a heated piece of metal, and the king would interpret the resulting cracks as either affirming or denying the inscription.  Usually, the king's pronouncement would then be recorded. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 discusses how the Shang used oracle bone inscriptions to seek spiritual guidance.  According to the author, "An animal bone…would be inscribed with a statement, such as 'on the tenth day, there will be rain' or 'we should go to battle.'  The shell or bone was then exposed to a heated piece of metal, and the king would interpret the resulting cracks as either affirming or denying the inscription."
However, although the passage states that the king would interpret the cracks in the bones, the author never explains any details or methods behind this interpretation.  For instance, he or she does not discuss how a particular crack would be seen as affirming or denying the inscribed statement.  Accordingly, the author does not provide any information to help explain the criteria the Shang used to interpret oracle bones.
 (Choice B)  the role played by natural spirits in Shang religious belief.  Paragraph 6 describes the Shang's conception of "natural spirits, such as the Yellow River Power or the Great Winds.  These forces… [had] some influence over natural phenomena."  Accordingly, the author indicates that in Shang religious belief, such spirits played a role in influencing the course of natural events.
(Choice C)  the methods the Shang employed to gain favor from spiritual powers.  In Paragraph 6, the author conveys that the Shang would seek blessings from natural spirits and deceased former kings.  As a result, "some oracle bone inscriptions described a wish and an attempt to gain an entity's favor; for example, 'to the Mountain we pray for rain and offer a burnt sacrifice.'"  Therefore, the author indicates that the Shang would make sacrifices as a method of gaining favor from spiritual powers.
(Choice D)  the reasons why the Shang viewed Di as ambivalent.  According to Paragraph 5, although Di was "the high god of the Shang," he did not reliably act to benefit the Shang people and sometimes acted against them.  For instance, both positive and negative occurrences were attributed to Di, who might "send or withhold rain and wind, bring fortune or misfortune upon the land, grant military assistance, or even induce other peoples to attack China."  As such, "Di was viewed as distant from the people and willing to harm as well as aid them throughout various times."  Hence, this conception of Di as sometimes aiding the Shang but sometimes increasing their hardships explains his "seeming ambivalence."

text: Which of the following discoveries would most weaken the author's central point?
explanations:
These inscriptions reveal several aspects of Shang spiritual practice, which was dominated by attempts to divine the future and to secure the aid of various natural and supernatural powers. (Paragraph 1)
The term "oracle bone inscriptions" derives from the method the Shang used to seek guidance from the spiritual world.  An animal bone…would be inscribed with a statement, such as "on the tenth day, there will be rain" or "we should go to battle."  The shell or bone was then exposed to a heated piece of metal, and the king would interpret the resulting cracks as either affirming or denying the inscription.  Usually, the king's pronouncement would then be recorded. (Paragraph 2)
However, legitimation of royal authority could not have been the only function of the divination process, as there are a limited number of records in which a king failed to predict the future accurately. (Paragraph 4)
Throughout the passage, the author emphasizes the importance the Shang placed on predicting future events.  According to Paragraph 1, the oracle bone inscriptions "reveal several aspects of Shang spiritual practice, which was dominated by attempts to divine the future."  Similarly, the author conveys that the Shang used these inscriptions to "seek guidance from the spiritual world" (Paragraph 2) in an effort to "predict the future accurately" (Paragraph 4).
However, if it were discovered that the oracle bone inscriptions were records of past decisions rather than prospective actions of Shang kings, the inscriptions would not be part of divining the future or seeking spiritual guidance as the author claims.  Instead, they would merely be descriptions of past events, contradicting much of the information in the passage.  In that case, the author's central point would be severely weakened.
 (Choice A)  The Shang kings sometimes disagreed with their scribes about whether a prediction's results should be recorded.  According to Paragraph 3, "the outcome of the king's forecast was also inscribed—however, these cases were almost always when the king had been correct in his divination."  Paragraph 4 later states that correct predictions served as "legitimation of royal authority" but adds that "there are a limited number of records in which a king failed to predict the future accurately."  Hence, based on the passage, one can easily imagine that the king might not have wanted scribes to record incorrect predictions, as these would have weakened rather than reinforced his "important role as an intermediary between the divine and physical realms" (Paragraph 3).
(Choice C)  The oracle bone inscriptions were more prominent in other Chinese dynasties.  Paragraph 7 mentions "[t]he frequency and prominence of oracle bone inscriptions…in the time of the Shang dynasty."  However, the author never discusses whether oracle bone inscriptions might have been more prominent in other dynasties.  Moreover, the author states that the Shang's "practices and beliefs would guide the course of Chinese thought through successive centuries."  Accordingly, if it were discovered that oracle bones played an even greater role in other dynasties, that could stem from the Shang's influence as described by the author.
(Choice D)  The term "Di" referred not to a Shang high god but to any spiritual powers mentioned in the oracle bone inscriptions.  Although such a discovery would undermine the author's claims about a "high god of the Shang" (Paragraph 5), it would not significantly weaken his or her central point about how the Shang would "seek guidance from the spiritual world" (Paragraph 2).  For instance, even if "Di" refers to spiritual powers in general rather than a high god, the oracle bone inscriptions would still be part of a "divination process…to predict the future" (Paragraph 4).  Similarly, the Shang would still have made appeals to "their deceased kings" (Paragraph 5) and to "natural spirits, such as the Yellow River Power or the Great Winds" (Paragraph 6).  Hence, while this discovery would challenge one part of the passage, the author's central point would still be preserved.

text: The author most likely recounts the dream described on the stele to show that:
explanations:
Notably, the forepaws of the Sphinx enclose an open temple containing a stele or stone slab.  Dating from circa 1400 BC, the inscription on the stele relates how the god Re appeared in a dream to the young Egyptian prince Thutmose IV, promising that if he dug the Sphinx out of the sand, he would be crowned Pharaoh of Upper and Lower Egypt.  Archaeological evidence confirms that Thutmose not only freed the Sphinx but, having discovered that some of the stones of its body had fallen off, restored them to their proper place and filled in damaged areas.  Lastly, Thutmose had a wall built around the area of the Sphinx, its mudbricks inscribed with his name. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, "the inscription on the stele relates how the god Re appeared in a dream to the young Egyptian prince Thutmose IV, promising that if he dug the Sphinx out of the sand, he would be crowned Pharaoh of Upper and Lower Egypt."  Paragraph 4 further states that "[a]rchaeological evidence confirms that Thutmose not only freed the Sphinx but, having discovered that some of the stones of its body had fallen off, restored them to their proper place and filled in damaged areas."
This account of Thutmose's restoration efforts shows that the stele's inscription interweaves the historical facts with a dream narrative that includes elements of the supernatural.  Therefore, the author most likely recounts the dream described on the stele to show that a legend (a traditional story loosely based on history) was formed to explain how the Sphinx was restored.
 (Choice A)  ancient inscriptions were fanciful in nature.  Although the stele's inscription of the dream narrative in which "the god Re appeared in a dream to the young Egyptian prince" could be considered fanciful or imaginative in nature, the passage does not discuss any other ancient inscriptions.  Therefore, in recounting the dream described on the stele, the author does not show that ancient inscriptions were necessarily fanciful in nature.
(Choice B)  archaeological efforts were generally intended to influence politics.  Paragraph 4 states that "the inscription on the stele relates how the god Re appeared in a dream to the young Egyptian prince Thutmose IV, promising that if he dug the Sphinx out of the sand, he would be crowned Pharaoh of Upper and Lower Egypt."  This passage information suggests that Thutmose may have been politically motivated in his excavation efforts, but in recounting the dream described on the stele, the author does not show that archaeological efforts were generally intended to influence politics.
(Choice D)  a supernatural intervention was necessary to save the Sphinx.  Although "the inscription on the stele relates how the god Re appeared in a dream to the young Egyptian prince Thutmose IV" (Paragraph 4), the author does not present the supernatural elements of the dream as factual.  Instead, the inscription is part of the "[a]rchaeological evidence" confirming that Thutmose freed the Sphinx.  Therefore, in recounting the dream described on the stele, the author does not show that supernatural intervention was necessary to save the Sphinx.

text: According to the passage, the body of the Sphinx was dug out of the sand on at least 6 different occasions throughout its history.  The passage author would most likely agree that those numerous excavations:
explanations:
In 1817, Italian Egyptologist Giovanni Battista Caviglia led the first modern archaeological dig to rescue the monument from the desert sands….  Artifacts from various time periods show that the statue had been dug out no fewer than 6 previous times, the last at the order of the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius in AD 160.  However, the Sphinx's body would not be completely freed until French Egyptologist Emile Baraize conducted extensive excavations of the monument and surrounding area in 1926. (Paragraph 1)
Reconstructive efforts on the statue were accelerated and continue to this day, guided by advances in science and technology.  Despite the increased attention, the Sphinx has not yet revealed all its secrets but remains an archaeological riddle. (Paragraph 6)
Paragraph 1 relates that "[a]rtifacts from various time periods show that the statue had been dug out no fewer than 6 previous times, the last at the order of the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius in AD 160."  In Paragraph 6, the author conveys that even today, "[d]espite the increased attention, the Sphinx has not yet revealed all its secrets but remains an archaeological riddle."
As this passage evidence indicates, the excavations of the Sphinx at various time periods have left behind artifacts from diverse historical contexts, as well as secrets yet to be revealed.  Consequently, the passage author would most likely conclude that those numerous excavations are a factor that makes research on the Sphinx an interesting undertaking.
 (Choice A)  have had their historical significance diminished by advances in archaeological methods.  Paragraph 6 mentions that "[r]econstructive efforts on the statue…continue to this day, guided by advances in science and technology."  However, the passage never implies that these advances in archaeological methods have diminished the historical significance of the earlier excavations of the Sphinx.
(Choice B)  have impeded some of the archaeological research on the Sphinx.  Paragraph 1 mentions that "[a]rtifacts from various time periods show that the statue had been dug out no fewer than 6 previous times, the last at the order of the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius in AD 160."  Moreover, Paragraph 4 indicates that the "stele or stone slab" was an important archaeological artifact for dating the first restoration of the Sphinx by Thutmose to about 1400 BC.  Accordingly, given the success of prior archaeological endeavors in establishing dates and historical facts about the monument, the author would likely conclude that the numerous excavations have not impeded (hindered) but rather facilitated some of the archaeological research on the Sphinx.
(Choice C)  suggest a commonality between the ancient and modern archaeologist.  Paragraph 1 conveys how in 1817, "Caviglia led the first modern archaeological dig to rescue the monument from the desert sands.…  Artifacts from various time periods show that the statue had been dug out no fewer than 6 previous times, the last at the order of the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius in AD 160."  Paragraph 1 further cites the "extensive excavations of the monument and surrounding area" by Emile Baraize in 1926, and Paragraph 4 relates how Thutmose IV restored the Sphinx in 1400 BC.  However, although the passage discusses both modern and ancient archaeological endeavors, it never compares ancient and modern archaeologists.  Therefore, the author would not necessarily conclude that those numerous excavations suggest a commonality between the ancient and modern archaeologist.

text: For which of the following claims about Egyptology does the author provide the LEAST support in the passage?
explanations:
Interestingly, these prodigious stone structures were built not by slaves, as commonly assumed, but by Egyptian civil servants who held a privileged position in society. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 states that "these prodigious stone structures were built not by slaves, as commonly assumed, but by Egyptian civil servants who held a privileged position in society."  However, the passage provides no additional evidence or support for the claim that the major monuments of the Giza Plateau were built by civil servants.
 By comparison, the author provides more support for the following claims about Egyptology:
New archaeological theories bred controversy among established researchers (Choice A).  Paragraph 5 describes a controversy about the statue's age, noting that "[a]n alternative theory dates the original construction of the Sphinx back to 7000 BC or earlier."  The author then clarifies that "[s]ome experts claim that wind and sand would not have caused the pattern of erosion seen on the Sphinx's lower body; more likely it was the effect of heavy and repeated rainfalls on the limestone.  While many scholars dispute this theory, geological studies have revealed that the Giza Plateau…was once a rich and fertile plain subject to frequent precipitation."
The restoration of the Sphinx had increased in urgency and sophistication by the 1990s (Choice B).  Paragraph 6 provides the supporting information that "in 1988, a piece of the Sphinx's shoulder collapsed onto the ground.  Reconstructive efforts on the statue were accelerated and continue to this day, guided by advances in science and technology."
Excavations of the Sphinx were planned and carried out prior to the 1800s (Choice D).  Paragraph 1 states that "[a]rtifacts from various time periods show that the statue had been dug out no fewer than 6 previous times, the last at the order of the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius in AD 160."  Paragraph 4 also cites the stele's inscription "[d]ating from circa 1400 BC," which describes how "Thutmose…freed (ie, excavated) the Sphinx."

text: Which of the following statements most accurately characterizes how the passage depicts Thutmose IV's efforts to preserve the Sphinx?
explanations:
Dating from circa 1400 BC, the inscription on the stele relates how the god Re appeared in a dream to the young Egyptian prince Thutmose IV, promising that if he dug the Sphinx out of the sand, he would be crowned Pharaoh of Upper and Lower Egypt.  Archaeological evidence confirms that Thutmose not only freed the Sphinx but, having discovered that some of the stones of its body had fallen off, restored them to their proper place and filled in damaged areas.  Lastly, Thutmose had a wall built around the area of the Sphinx, its mudbricks inscribed with his name. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, "the inscription on the stele relates how the god Re appeared in a dream to…Thutmose IV, promising that if he dug the Sphinx out of the sand, he would be crowned Pharaoh of Upper and Lower Egypt.  Archaeological evidence confirms that Thutmose not only freed the Sphinx but, having discovered that some of the stones of its body had fallen off, restored them to their proper place and filled in damaged areas."
Based on this evidence, the statement that most accurately characterizes how the passage depicts Thutmose IV's efforts to preserve the Sphinx is that after the dream, he committed to freeing the Sphinx but also desired to restore it.
 By contrast, none of the following statements accurately characterize how the passage depicts Thutmose's efforts:
On hearing the sun god speak through the Sphinx, he planned to obey the dream (Choice B).  Paragraph 4 states that "[a]rchaeological evidence confirms that Thutmose…freed the Sphinx."  However, the passage does not mention whether, on hearing the sun god speak through the Sphinx, Thutmose planned (ie, originally intended) to obey the dream or only later decided to free the monument from the sand.
Once he had ruled Egypt for a while, he decided to restore the body of the Sphinx (Choice C).  Paragraph 4 states that "[a]rchaeological evidence confirms that Thutmose not only freed the Sphinx but, having discovered that some of the stones of its body had fallen off, restored them to their proper place and filled in damaged areas."  However, the passage does not make it clear exactly when Thutmose's restoration took place.  Furthermore, the passage depicts Thutmose as not only restoring the Sphinx but having to dig it out of the sand first.
As a result of his devotion to the sun god, Upper and Lower Egypt became unified (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 4, "the inscription on the stele relates how the god Re appeared in a dream to the young Egyptian prince Thutmose IV, promising that if he dug the Sphinx out of the sand, he would be crowned Pharaoh of Upper and Lower Egypt."  However, the passage never indicates whether Upper and Lower Egypt actually did become unified as a result of Thutmose's efforts to preserve the Sphinx.

text: According to the passage, what evidence has led some experts to argue that the erosion on the Sphinx was caused by rainfall?
explanations:
An alternative theory dates the original construction of the Sphinx back to 7000 BC or earlier.  Some experts claim that wind and sand would not have caused the pattern of erosion seen on the Sphinx's lower body; more likely, it was the effect of heavy and repeated rainfalls on the limestone.  While many scholars dispute this theory, geological studies have revealed that the Giza Plateau, which sits on the edge of the Sahara Desert, had a few millennia before been a rich and fertile plain subject to frequent precipitation. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 5, "[s]ome experts claim that wind and sand would not have caused the pattern of erosion seen on the Sphinx's lower body; more likely, it was the effect of heavy and repeated rainfalls on the limestone."  This passage statement shows that the type of erosion seen on the Sphinx's surface was more consistent with that caused by rainfall than by wind and sand.  Therefore, that the Sphinx's appearance is less consistent with erosion from wind and sand constitutes evidence that has led some experts to argue that the erosion on the Sphinx was caused by rainfall.
 By contrast, none of the following represents evidence that has led some experts to argue that the erosion on the Sphinx was caused by rainfall:
Rainfall caused damage to the surrounding monuments (Choice A).  Paragraph 3 identifies "the Great Pyramid, the Causeway, the Sphinx Temple, and the Valley Temple" as the monuments surrounding the Sphinx on the Giza plateau.  However, the passage does not discuss damage to these surrounding monuments.
The Sphinx is significantly older than the surrounding monuments (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 5, "[a]n alternative theory dates the original construction of the Sphinx back to 7000 BC," which would make it far older than the surrounding monuments.  This theory claims "wind and sand would not have caused the pattern of erosion seen on the Sphinx's lower body; more likely, it was the effect of heavy and repeated rainfalls on the limestone."  In addition, "geological studies have revealed that the Giza Plateau…had a few millennia before been a rich and fertile plain subject to frequent precipitation."  Therefore, the statement that the Sphinx is older than the surrounding monuments is a hypothesis formulated from information about the erosion on the Sphinx's surface and the geological history of the region; it is not the reason why some believe that the erosion was caused by rainfall.
The region around the Sphinx at one time had abundant rainfall (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 5, "geological studies have revealed that the Giza Plateau…had a few millennia before been a rich and fertile plain subject to frequent precipitation" (ie, abundant rainfall).  However, this information merely provides support for the primary evidence of the Sphinx's appearance being more consistent with the effects of rainfall and less consistent with erosion from wind and sand.

text: According to the passage, Heidegger believed that both the revered triumvirate and Descartes:
explanations:
In this tortured and intimidating tome, Heidegger…dared to target the lofty towers of traditional Western metaphysical thought.  Above all, he believed that the revered triumvirate of Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle had diverted the course of philosophy by turning away from ontology, or the study of Being, toward a metaphysics that merely pondered the nature of individual entities.  Furthermore, Heidegger thought that Descartes, as the first modern philosopher, had exacerbated this misguided focus. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, Heidegger "believed that the revered triumvirate…had diverted the course of philosophy by turning away from ontology, or the study of Being, toward a metaphysics that merely pondered the nature of individual entities."  Furthermore, Heidegger believed that "Descartes…had exacerbated (made worse) this misguided focus."
This information shows that, in Heidegger's view, the revered triumvirate (Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle) and, later, Descartes were concerned with certain metaphysical issues but neglected issues of Being or ontology—the very issues Heidegger considered most fundamental.  Therefore, according to the passage, Heidegger believed that both the revered triumvirate and Descartes disregarded the relevance of ontological issues to metaphysical studies.
 (Choices A and D) diverged from the approaches to metaphysics that prevailed; and developed theories that were long suppressed.  According to Paragraph 2, "Heidegger…dared to target the lofty towers of traditional Western metaphysical thought."  In particular, he "believed that the revered triumvirate…had diverted the course of philosophy by turning away from ontology…toward a metaphysics that merely pondered the nature of individual entities."  Moreover, in Heidegger's view, "Descartes, as the first modern philosopher had exacerbated this misguided focus."  Accordingly, the evidence shows that the revered triumvirate and Descartes exemplified—and in fact, instituted—the metaphysical approaches that became traditional or prevailed in the West.  Likewise, this information indicates that the theories of these thinkers were not suppressed but became mainstream.
(Choice B) adapted their philosophical principles to embrace everyday issues.  Paragraph 2 states that "Heidegger believed that the revered triumvirate…had diverted…from ontology…toward a metaphysics that merely pondered the nature of individual entities."  Furthermore, Descartes "had exacerbated this misguided focus."  By contrast, Heidegger diverged from the approach of his predecessors and deliberately focused on "ordinary, everyday experience" (Paragraph 2).  Accordingly, the passage never indicates that either the revered triumvirate or Descartes adapted philosophical principles to embrace everyday issues.

text:
Based on the passage, Heidegger's main purpose in Being and Time is to:
show the everyday world and metaphysical concerns as essentially irreconcilable.
use extraordinary as opposed to ordinary language to express his ideas more accurately.
try to derive knowledge of Being through its fundamentally human dimension.
