explanations:
Heidegger tackled such questions in Being and Time….  He also began his quest for the meaning of Being with ordinary, everyday experience, with what it means to dwell within the world as a human being—the only being sufficiently aware of its own existence to question it. (Paragraph 2)
Accordingly, Heidegger sought to gain an understanding of Being by analyzing the inherent structures of our basic ontological condition, the reality of our distinctively human existence or mode of Being, which he referred to as Dasein—a term roughly translated as "being there." (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 2, Heidegger "began his quest for the meaning of Being with ordinary, everyday experience, with what it means to dwell within the world as a human being."  Paragraph 3 then describes Heidegger's approach to this quest: he "sought to gain an understanding of Being by analyzing the inherent structures of our basic ontological condition, the reality of our distinctively human existence or mode of Being, which he referred to as Dasein…'being there.'"  Therefore, based on the passage, Heidegger's main purpose in Being and Time is to try to derive knowledge of Being through its fundamentally human dimension, or what he referred to as Dasein (Number III).
 (Number I) show the everyday world and metaphysical concerns as essentially irreconcilable.  As Paragraph 2 indicates, "Heidegger began his quest for the meaning of Being with ordinary, everyday experience" in order to direct Western metaphysical thought back to issues of Being.  Paragraph 5 later reveals that "in trying to 'call us back to the remembrance of Being'…Heidegger pitched ordinary experience into the ontological register, grounding metaphysics in everyday reality."  Accordingly, this information indicates that Heidegger viewed the everyday world and metaphysical concerns as reconcilable (compatible) rather than irreconcilable.
(Number II) use extraordinary as opposed to ordinary language to express his ideas more accurately.  According to Paragraph 2, "In this tortured and intimidating tome, Heidegger strung words into hyphenated chains to build terms better befitting his dense ideas and dared to target the lofty towers of traditional Western metaphysical thought."  Consequently, Heidegger used extraordinary as opposed to ordinary language to try to articulate his ideas in Being and Time more precisely.  However, rather than being Heidegger's main purpose, this use of language is merely a means of expressing the ideas involved in his primary task of deriving knowledge of Being.

text: The passage does NOT imply which of the following claims about Heidegger's concept of Dasein?
explanations:
Heidegger saw Dasein's primary structure as "thrownness": we are summarily tossed into the world and into a particular configuration of circumstances that impose limitations but also provide possibilities.  Overall, we belong to a world that is exquisitely attuned to us and toward which we, in turn, are uniquely disposed.  This existential condition of "being-in-the-world" implies complete engagement with our environment: we are inextricably entangled and deeply invested in its intricate web of people and things. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, "Heidegger saw Dasein's primary structure as 'thrownness': we are summarily tossed into the world and into a particular configuration of circumstances that impose limitations but also provide possibilities."  As Paragraph 3 explains, "[W]e belong to a world that is exquisitely attuned to us and toward which we…are uniquely disposed."  Furthermore, "[t]his existential condition of 'being-in-the-world' implies…[that] we are inextricably entangled and deeply invested in its intricate web of people and things."
This evidence indicates that, for Heidegger, our condition of "thrownness" offers us some choice and is fundamentally in tune with our needs.  Nevertheless, "thrownness" is ultimately an unchangeable and inescapable, condition.  Therefore, the passage does not imply that Dasein represents a process of overcoming "thrownness."
 By contrast, the passage does imply each of the following claims about the concept of Dasein:
Dasein is shaped through overlapping subcontexts of meaning (Choice B).  Paragraph 3 states that "[i]n the day-to-day business of living, we play shifting roles within countless contexts and subcontexts that form an interactive, seamlessly integrated totality of which we are the co-creators."  For instance, a boat "functions primarily as a piece of equipment within a nexus (connected group) of related such items"; furthermore, it "operates within many possible domains…and might be utilized…by diverse individuals" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, through daily encounters, Dasein interacts with different entities and participates in different activities within various, ever-larger contexts of meaning.
Dasein is uniquely characterized by existential introspection (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 2, Heidegger considered the human being "the only being sufficiently aware of its own existence to question it."  Accordingly, this information indicates that humans (who, enmeshed with the world, constitute Dasein) alone among all beings have a natural capacity to think or introspect about their own existence.
Dasein is informed by a nondualistic perspective of reality (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 2, "While this Cartesian paradigm (model) effectively severed self from world and subject from object, Heidegger adopted a nondualistic, phenomenological approach wherein perceiver and perceived are interdependent."  Furthermore, "Heidegger sought to gain an understanding of Being by analyzing…the reality of our distinctively human existence or mode of Being, which he referred to as Dasein…'being there'" (Paragraph 3).  Consequently, in exploring the concept of Dasein, Heidegger would have adopted a nondualistic approach.

text: Given the information in the passage, it can be concluded that Heidegger views objects like hammers and boats as:
explanations:
Consequently, we are interconnected not only socially but "equipmentally."  The world is filled with objects we can manipulate for a variety of purposes.  For example, a hammer is typically not an object we stop and analyze but a tool we pick up and use, experiencing it more as an extension of our hand than an ontologically distinct entity.  Therefore, the hammer's common mode of Being is usefulness—in Heideggerian terminology, it is "ready-to-hand" rather than merely "present-at-hand."  Likewise, a boat on the water is only secondarily an object for observation and interpretation.  It functions primarily as a piece of equipment within a nexus of related such items that might include oars, fishing tackle, and life preservers.  Furthermore, the vessel operates within many possible domains—boatbuilding, fish markets, travel—and might be utilized in sundry activities by diverse individuals. (Paragraph 4)
In Heidegger's view, "[t]he world is filled with objects we can manipulate for a variety of purposes" (Paragraph 4).  He notes that "a hammer is typically not an object we stop and analyze but a tool we pick up and use."  Furthermore, like the hammer, "a boat…is only secondarily an object for observation and interpretation...[and] functions primarily as a piece of equipment within a nexus (connected group) of related such items."  The boat also "operates within many possible domains…and might be utilized…by diverse individuals."
This evidence reveals that, for Heidegger, an item's specific function depends on the context in which it is encountered, the purpose for which it is used, and those who use it.  Accordingly, the object's function is modified based on the role it plays in the various shifting and interconnected contexts of Dasein's totality.  Consequently, it can be concluded that Heidegger views objects like hammers and boats as assuming different functions within a fluid system.
 (Choice A) having a mode of Being that is not immediately apparent.  Paragraph 4 conveys Heidegger's perspective: "a hammer is typically not an object we stop and analyze but a tool we pick up and use....  Therefore, the hammer's common mode of Being is usefulness…it is 'ready-to-hand' rather than merely 'present-at-hand.'"  Similarly, a boat is "only secondarily an object for observation and interpretation" and "primarily…a piece of equipment within a nexus of related such items…within many possible domains…utilized…by diverse individuals."  Accordingly, objects like hammers and boats are items of equipment with "a common mode of Being" that is immediately apparent as useful or "ready-to-hand."
(Choice C) items laden with meaning apart from their contexts.  For Heidegger, Dasein means "we are interconnected not only socially but 'equipmentally.'"  Hence, "[t]he world is filled with objects we can manipulate for a variety of purposes."  As Heidegger sees it, "a hammer is…a tool we pick up and use, experiencing it more as an extension of our hand than an ontologically distinct entity."  Like the hammer, "a boat…functions primarily as a piece of equipment within a nexus of related such items" and "operates within many possible domains" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, items like hammers and boats are always embedded within various contexts that largely determine their meaning.
(Choice D) symbolizing the basic ingenuity of human beings.  Paragraph 4 describes both the hammer and the boat as primarily "ready-to-hand' or having a "common mode of Being that is usefulness."  However, Heidegger never discusses these objects as symbolizing human ingenuity (creative resourcefulness); instead, he sees them as serving different functions within the ever-shifting networks of Dasein's totality.

text: Which of the following best represents the main theme of the passage?
explanations:
When twentieth-century German thinker Martin Heidegger contemplated the history of philosophy in the West, he noticed something astonishing: it seemed to have forgotten about the most fundamental of all philosophical questions, the question of Being. (Paragraph 1)
In this tortured and intimidating tome, Heidegger…dared to target the lofty towers of traditional Western metaphysical thought….  Above all, he believed that the revered triumvirate of Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle had diverted the course of philosophy by turning away from ontology, or the study of Being, toward a metaphysics that merely pondered the nature of individual entities.  Furthermore, Heidegger thought that Descartes, as the first modern philosopher, had exacerbated this misguided focus….  [Heidegger] also began his quest for the meaning of Being with ordinary, everyday experience, with what it means to dwell within the world as a human being. (Paragraph 2)
Accordingly, Heidegger sought to gain an understanding of Being by analyzing the inherent structures of our basic ontological condition, the reality of our distinctively human existence or mode of Being, which he referred to as Dasein—a term roughly translated as "being there." (Paragraph 3)
Thus, in trying to "call us back to the remembrance of Being," so long consigned to oblivion, and to overturn Western philosophy, Heidegger pitched ordinary experience into the ontological register, grounding metaphysics in everyday reality. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 1, Heidegger remarked that "the history of philosophy in the West…seemed to have forgotten…the question of Being."  As Paragraph 2 explains, Heidegger "believed that the revered triumvirate…had diverted the course of philosophy…toward a metaphysics that merely pondered the nature of individual entities."  Furthermore, "Descartes…had exacerbated (made worse) this misguided focus."  Consequently, Heidegger "began his quest for the meaning of Being with ordinary, everyday experience."
Paragraph 3 then outlines Heidegger's quest "to gain an understanding of Being by analyzing…the reality of our distinctively human existence or mode of Being."  Finally, Paragraph 5 conveys that "in trying to 'call us back to the remembrance of Being'…and to overturn Western metaphysics, Heidegger pitched ordinary experience into the ontological register, grounding metaphysics in the everyday world."
This evidence shows that the passage focuses on Heidegger's quest to restore the more basic question of Being to Western metaphysics.  Therefore, the statement that Heidegger strove to address the issue of Being through reincorporating more fundamental aspects of metaphysical study represents the main theme of the passage.
 By contrast, each of the following statements represents only a supporting passage idea:
In Heidegger's view, a dualistic approach to ontology cannot grasp the inherent structures of Being (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 2, "the Cartesian paradigm (model) effectively severed self from world and subject from object."  To counter this orientation, "Heidegger adopted a nondualistic, phenomenological approach wherein perceiver and perceived are interdependent."  Heidegger would then have used this approach to conduct his study of Being through an analysis of Dasein's inherent structures.  Accordingly, Heidegger's stated view of Descartes' approach serves only to highlight his own nondualistic approach in trying to analyze Dasein and reincorporate ontology into metaphysics.
Heidegger thought his predecessors had neglected the most essential philosophical question (Choice B).  Heidegger believed that his predecessors (the revered triumvirate and Descartes) "seemed to have forgotten…the question of Being" (Paragraph 1) and "had diverted the course of philosophy by turning away from ontology" (Paragraph 2).  However, this perceived neglect merely provides the context for Heidegger's quest to reincorporate Being.
According to Heidegger, we play a role along with other entities in co-creating the totality of Dasein (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 describes Heidegger's view: "this existential condition of 'being-in-the-world' implies…we are…deeply invested in its intricate web of people and things."  As Paragraph 3 specifies, "[i]n the day-to-day business of living, we play shifting roles within countless contexts and subcontexts that form an interactive, seamlessly integrated totality of which we are the co-creators."  Consequently, this statement pertains only to the concept of Dasein, which Heidegger analyzes in his quest to reincorporate Being.

text: Which of the following actions by a candidate in an election best exemplifies an "unwavering purity of principle" as it is described in Paragraph 5?
explanations:
A virtuous speaker thus faces a choice: (1) to present his case logically and without appeal to emotions or chicanery, trusting that the truth will prevail; or (2) to use every means at his disposal, noble or base, to achieve victory.  If Aristotle had observed enough instances of legal injustice, he may well have concluded that unwavering purity of principle simply risks too much. (Paragraph 5)
On this line of thought, Aristotle came to believe that ensuring the right outcomes justified whatever techniques were needed to secure them. (Paragraph 6)
Paragraph 5 describes a choice that must be made by any "virtuous speaker" while arguing in court.  Such a speaker must choose whether: "(1) to present his case logically and without appeal to emotions or chicanery (trickery or underhandedness)…or (2) to use every means at his disposal, noble or base, to achieve victory."  Accordingly, a speaker who cares about justice has to decide whether to depend solely on legitimate reasoning or to engage in dirty tricks and deception to increase the chance of winning.
The author argues that "[i]f Aristotle had observed enough instances of legal injustice, he may well have concluded that unwavering purity of principle simply risks too much" (Paragraph 5).  In other words, Aristotle may have decided that while choice 1 might be more noble, that wasn't as important as whether the courts actually reached a just verdict.  Thus, the author suggests that "Aristotle came to believe that ensuring the right outcomes justified whatever techniques were needed to secure them" (Paragraph 6).  Accordingly, "unwavering purity of principle" (Paragraph 5) would mean refusing to resort to underhanded tactics.
Similarly, a political candidate must choose whether to run her campaign based only on honest reasoning and relevant issues, or to use tricks and deception to increase her chances of winning.  Consequently, an "unwavering purity of principle" would be best displayed by a candidate who discovers embarrassing personal information about her opponent's spouse but does not release it to the public.  Releasing such information might cause a negative perception of the opponent, but it would do so by attacking his or her loved one rather than addressing the opponent's experience, positions, or record.
  By contrast, none of the following decisions represents a refusal to use underhanded tactics:
The candidate refuses to deviate from her planned campaign strategy, even when her approval rating fluctuates (Choice A).  Although such a candidate would display unwavering commitment to a strategy, the scenario does not specify whether that strategy is based on honest reasoning or involves trickery.
The candidate continues to stress the platform on which she initially decided to run, even when polling shows that voters are more concerned with other issues (Choice C).  While this candidate would show commitment to her original platform, there is nothing to indicate that she refuses underhandedness by sticking to it.
The candidate compares records only for times in which she and her opponent both served in government, not stressing her own additional years of service (Choice D).  Although such a decision could be seen as a way of leveling the playing field, stressing the candidate's additional years of service would represent honest discussion about relevant facts, not deception or trickery.

text:
The author dismisses the idea that Aristotle was merely acknowledging emotional appeals as a common practice in the Rhetoric, because:
Aristotle seems to advocate other tactics of a similar nature
Aristotle would have been more thorough in addressing his topics
Aristotle's other works never enumerate practices without evaluating them
explanations:
At the beginning of Book 1, the philosopher admonishes his students toward conscientious public speaking, denouncing the sophistical practices of arguing for false or unjust positions and making emotional appeals to the judges in court.  Rather, he instructs, one must argue only for what is true and good, and do so by appealing to proper reasoning and facts.  In light of Aristotle's other works, none of this is surprising.  What is puzzling, however, is that as soon as the second chapter he seems to suggest the opposite. (Paragraph 1)
For example, one of the modes of persuasion discussed there entails putting the audience into "a certain frame of mind" which "stirs their emotions."  One might suppose that Aristotle is not advocating this technique but merely acknowledging it as a common practice.  However, that explanation is undercut by the subsequent recommendation about written and unwritten law: "If the written law tells against our case, clearly we must appeal to the universal law, and insist on its greater equity and justice….  If however the written law supports our case, we must urge that…not to use the laws is as bad as to have no laws at all." (Paragraph 2)
In Paragraph 1, the author describes how Aristotle's Rhetoric appears to give conflicting instructions about how persuasive speaking should be conducted.  First, "the philosopher admonishes his students toward conscientious public speaking, denouncing the sophistical practices of arguing for false or unjust positions and making emotional appeals to the judges in court."  The author then remarks: "What is puzzling, however, is that as soon as the second chapter he seems to suggest the opposite."  Therefore, although Aristotle begins by denouncing the practices of making emotional appeals and arguing for false or unjust positions, he then appears to advocate both strategies.
Paragraph 2 considers the possibility that Aristotle does not actually endorse the technique of "putting the audience into 'a certain frame of mind' which 'stirs their emotions,'" but instead is "merely acknowledging it as a common practice."  However, the author rejects this idea because "that explanation is undercut by the subsequent recommendation about written and unwritten law."  Specifically, Aristotle writes that "'If the written law tells against our case, clearly we must appeal to the universal law, and insist on its greater equity and justice….  If however the written law supports our case, we must urge that…not to use the laws is as bad as to have no laws at all.'"
This instruction implies that one would not care about which position on the law is more just, only about which helps one win.  Accordingly, Aristotle implicitly recommends "arguing for false or unjust positions" (Paragraph 1), which he had previously opposed.  Therefore, the author's reason for dismissing the idea that Aristotle was merely acknowledging emotional appeals as a common practice in the Rhetoric is that Aristotle seems to advocate other tactics of a similar nature (Number I).
  (Number II)  Aristotle would have been more thorough in addressing his topics.  Paragraph 1 conveys that Aristotle "admonishes his students toward conscientious public speaking."  Paragraph 2 then considers the suggestion that Aristotle was "not advocating this technique [of making emotional appeals] but merely acknowledging it as a common practice."  However, the author never suggests that Aristotle would have displayed a lack of thoroughness by acknowledging a common practice in this way.
(Number III)  Aristotle's other works never enumerate practices without evaluating them.  Paragraph 3 discusses "the Aristotelian corpus," noting that "the Metaphysics bases all reasoning on the law of non-contradiction, and the Nicomachean Ethics associates injustice with taking more than one's deserved share.  Both are a far cry from the Rhetoric's call to affirm or dispute the legality of contracts depending on 'whichever way suits us.'"  However, the author never mentions whether Aristotle's works ever enumerate practices without evaluating them.

text: Which of the following best describes the central concern of the passage?
explanations:
On first reading, there appears to be significant tension between what Aristotle initially claims in the Rhetoric and what he later proceeds to argue.  At the beginning of Book 1, the philosopher admonishes his students toward conscientious public speaking, denouncing the sophistical practices….  What is puzzling, however, is that as soon as the second chapter he seems to suggest the opposite. (Paragraph 1)
For example, one of the modes of persuasion discussed there entails putting the audience into "a certain frame of mind" which "stirs their emotions."  One might suppose that Aristotle is not advocating this technique but merely acknowledging it as a common practice.  However, that explanation is undercut by the subsequent recommendation about written and unwritten law. (Paragraph 2)
Another suggestion might be that Aristotle's view evolved, and that extant copies of the Rhetoric's first chapter are from an earlier version of the work.  However, this position would conflict with most of the Aristotelian corpus. (Paragraph 3)
A more fruitful resolution to this conundrum lies in drawing an important distinction.  While the Rhetoric does contain two conflicting implications about public speaking, the change in Aristotle's position may affect the method rather than the goal of rhetoric. (Paragraph 4)
This interpretation alleviates the tension within the Rhetoric by making the aim of achieving justice a precondition of those modes of argumentation. (Paragraph 6)
The passage is structured in a way that first presents a puzzle about one of Aristotle's works, then explores possible solutions to resolve it.  Paragraph 1 states that "there appears to be significant tension between what Aristotle initially claims in the Rhetoric and what he later proceeds to argue."  The author points out that "[a]t the beginning of Book 1, the philosopher admonishes his students toward conscientious public speaking, denouncing…sophistical practices."  Accordingly, it is "puzzling" that "as soon as the second chapter he seems to suggest the opposite."
The rest of the passage considers possible explanations for this tension.  For example, Paragraph 2 suggests that perhaps "Aristotle is not advocating this [sophistical] technique but merely acknowledging it as a common practice."  However, the author dismisses that idea because it "is undercut by the subsequent recommendation about written and unwritten law."  Similarly, Paragraph 3 mentions "[a]nother suggestion…that Aristotle's view evolved," but notes that "this position would conflict with most of the Aristotelian corpus."
Paragraph 4 introduces the "more fruitful resolution" that "[w]hile the Rhetoric does contain two conflicting implications about public speaking, the change in Aristotle's position may affect the method rather than the goal of rhetoric."  Paragraph 6 endorses this view, concluding that "[t]his interpretation alleviates the tension within the Rhetoric."  Therefore, the central concern of the passage is best described as resolutions to a discrepancy between certain sections in Aristotle's Rhetoric.
  (Choice A)  problems inherent to the role of judges as described in Aristotle's Rhetoric.  The author argues that "[w]hile the Rhetoric does contain two conflicting implications about public speaking, the change in Aristotle's position may affect the method rather than the goal of rhetoric" (Paragraph 4).  He or she then states: "One point in favor of this interpretation is Aristotle's view of judges as a necessary but regrettable feature of the courts."  Therefore, this view of judges is supporting evidence for the author's overall position.
(Choice B)  the relative importance of written versus unwritten law as advocated in Aristotle's Rhetoric.  The author considers the possibility that "Aristotle is not advocating this [sophistical] technique but merely acknowledging it as a common practice."  However, "that explanation is undercut by the subsequent recommendation about written and unwritten law" (Paragraph 2).  Accordingly, the author cites this possibility as a supporting idea in the broader passage discussion.
(Choice D)  effects of Athenian injustice on the instruction offered in Aristotle's Rhetoric.  Paragraph 5 suggests: "If Aristotle had observed enough instances of legal injustice, he may well have concluded that unwavering purity of principle simply risks too much."  Although this is an important point in the author's argument, the passage as a whole also concerns other potential resolutions to the discrepancy in the Rhetoric.  Therefore, the effects of Athenian injustice on the instruction offered in Aristotle's Rhetoric forms only one part of the passage's central concern.

text: According to the author, the Rhetoric makes divergent claims about oratory because Aristotle came to believe achieving justice outweighed his principles about methods.  Based on passage information, which of the following statements represents a competing hypothesis that might account for the differing claims instead?
explanations:
Another suggestion might be that Aristotle's view evolved, and that extant copies of the Rhetoric's first chapter are from an earlier version of the work.  However, this position would conflict with most of the Aristotelian corpus.  Notably, the Metaphysics bases all reasoning on the law of non-contradiction, and the Nicomachean Ethics associates injustice with taking more than one's deserved share.  Both are a far cry from the Rhetoric's call to affirm or dispute the legality of contracts depending on "whichever way suits us."  This apparent shift toward sophism thus seems strangely anomalous. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 considers the possibility that "Aristotle's view evolved, and that extant copies of the Rhetoric's first chapter are from an earlier version of the work."  The author dismisses that idea because "this position would conflict with most of the Aristotelian corpus."  Hence, he or she notes that Book 1 of the Rhetoric reflects Aristotle's typical view while the later "apparent shift toward sophism thus seems strangely anomalous (ie, a deviation from general tendencies)."  Accordingly, the passage implies it is unlikely that Aristotle's position had shifted toward sophism.
However, a shift in the opposite direction would be consistent with what the passage says about Aristotle's works.  If the position expressed in "most of the Aristotelian corpus" is considered his mature view, then Book 1 of the Rhetoric would reflect any evolution that had taken place in Aristotle's thinking.  Therefore, based on passage information, a competing hypothesis that might account for the differing claims in the Rhetoric instead would be that extant copies of the Rhetoric's first chapter are the beginning of a revision reflecting Aristotle's mature view.
  (Choice A)  Aristotle was not especially concerned with consistency in his writings.  Paragraph 1 describes what Book 1 of the Rhetoric states about public speaking, and notes that "[i]n light of Aristotle's other works, none of this is surprising."  Paragraph 3 likewise implies that these views are consistent with "most of the Aristotelian corpus."  Accordingly, the passage suggests that Aristotle generally did exhibit consistency in his writings.
(Choice B)  Aristotle saw it as more important to follow the universal law than the written law.  According to Paragraph 2, the Rhetoric states: "'If the written law tells against our case, clearly we must appeal to the universal law….  If however the written law supports our case, we must urge that…not to use the laws is as bad as to have no laws at all.'"  Hence, Aristotle advocates arguing for either type of law depending on circumstance.  Therefore, passage information implies that Aristotle did not see it as more important to follow the universal law than the written law.
(Choice D)  Aristotle had concluded that it was necessary to use dishonest orators' own tactics against them.  Paragraph 4 discusses Aristotle's concern about "dishonest orators, who may use emotional appeals and deceptive reasoning to confuse the judges into inadvertently rendering an unjust decision."  The author suggests that Aristotle decided "disreputable oratorical methods would then be permissible in service of a righteous cause, especially if one must counter similar tactics from an opponent."  Hence, the author's argument includes the idea that Aristotle thought it was necessary to use dishonest orators' own tactics against them; thus, that would not represent a competing hypothesis.

text: Based on Paragraphs 5 and 6, a modern lawyer would be most like Aristotle's "virtuous speaker" if she:
explanations:
A virtuous speaker thus faces a choice: (1) to present his case logically and without appeal to emotions or chicanery, trusting that the truth will prevail; or (2) to use every means at his disposal, noble or base, to achieve victory.  If Aristotle had observed enough instances of legal injustice, he may well have concluded that unwavering purity of principle simply risks too much.  Perhaps he even had Socrates in mind, who famously upheld (1) at his own trial yet was convicted and executed through corruption in the Athenian courts. (Paragraph 5)
His instruction would therefore presuppose that a virtuous speaker always argues for the correct side.  Otherwise disreputable oratorical methods would then be permissible in service of a righteous cause, especially if one must counter similar tactics from an opponent.  This interpretation alleviates the tension within the Rhetoric by making the aim of achieving justice a precondition of those modes of argumentation. (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 5, "[a] virtuous speaker thus faces a choice: (1) to present his case logically and without appeal to emotions or chicanery, trusting that the truth will prevail; or (2) to use every means at his disposal, noble or base, to achieve victory."  The author suggests that Aristotle eventually advocated option 2, because he decided that achieving justice was more important than refusing to engage in trickery: "[i]f Aristotle had observed enough instances of legal injustice, he may well have concluded that unwavering purity of principle simply risks too much."  On this view, using deceptive reasoning would be justified if it helped to ensure a just outcome.
Paragraph 6 elaborates on this point, stating that Aristotle's instruction "would therefore presuppose that a virtuous speaker always argues for the correct side."  Given that assumption, "[o]therwise disreputable oratorical methods would then be permissible in service of a righteous cause...making the aim of achieving justice a precondition of those modes of argumentation."  Based on this description, Aristotle's idea of a virtuous speaker is someone who is entirely committed to ensuring that justice is done.
Consequently, a modern lawyer would be most like Aristotle's virtuous speaker if she accepts only clients whose cases she believes to be just.  By limiting her clients to those she believes are in the right, the lawyer would commit herself to the aim of achieving justice and always arguing for the correct side.
  (Choice B)  refuses to use emotional appeals in her arguments.  Paragraph 5 states that "[a] virtuous speaker thus faces a choice" of whether to argue "logically and without appeal to emotions" or to "use every means at his disposal, noble or base, to achieve victory."  Paragraph 6 then suggests that "Aristotle came to believe that ensuring the right outcomes justified whatever techniques were needed to secure them," indicating that even a virtuous speaker would engage in emotional appeals if necessary.  Therefore, refusing to use emotional appeals would not most exemplify Aristotle's idea of a virtuous speaker as described in Paragraphs 5 and 6.
(Choices C and D)  promises not to charge clients if they lose the case; and uses whatever tactics are necessary to win.  According to Paragraph 6, "Aristotle came to believe that ensuring the right outcomes justified whatever techniques were needed to secure them.  His instruction would therefore presuppose that a virtuous speaker always argues for the correct side."  In each of these scenarios, the modern lawyer is described as committed to winning on behalf of her clients.  However, there is nothing which specifies that this lawyer only represents clients "in service of a righteous cause" or that she shares the virtuous speaker's "aim of achieving justice" in all her cases.

text: Assume research reveals that human beings have a tendency to make specific types of logical errors.  How would this information affect the author's argument about the conflicting instructions in Aristotle's Rhetoric?
explanations:
One point in favor of this interpretation is Aristotle's view of judges as a necessary but regrettable feature of the courts.  Because laws cannot cover every conceivable situation or contingency, judges are needed to decide whether a man has acted lawfully in a particular circumstance.  Unfortunately, this makes the justice system subject to potential bias or corruption, or simply the errors of fallible judgment.  The latter concern is considerably heightened due to dishonest orators, who may use emotional appeals and deceptive reasoning to confuse the judges into inadvertently rendering an unjust decision. (Paragraph 4)
On this line of thought, Aristotle came to believe that ensuring the right outcomes justified whatever techniques were needed to secure them.  His instruction would therefore presuppose that a virtuous speaker always argues for the correct side.  Otherwise disreputable oratorical methods would then be permissible in service of a righteous cause, especially if one must counter similar tactics from an opponent. (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 4, Aristotle viewed judges as "a necessary but regrettable feature of the courts" because they could potentially be tricked into promoting injustice.  Thus, although judges' roles were crucial, the dependence on them "makes the justice system subject to potential bias or corruption, or simply the errors of fallible judgment."  This concern about fallible (imperfect) judgment is "heightened due to dishonest orators, who may use emotional appeals and deceptive reasoning to confuse the judges into inadvertently rendering an unjust decision."
Paragraph 6 argues that as a result of this possibility, "Aristotle came to believe that ensuring the right outcomes justified whatever techniques were needed to secure them."  In particular, "[o]therwise disreputable oratorical methods would then be permissible in service of a righteous cause, especially if one must counter similar tactics from an opponent."  Therefore, the author attributes some of Aristotle's claims in the Rhetoric to the idea that judges were susceptible to making mistakes in their reasoning.
If research revealed that human beings have a tendency to make specific types of logical errors, this finding would apply to the Athenian judges as well, supporting the idea that they could be tricked into making unjust decisions.  Consequently, the research would support the idea that Athenian judges were vulnerable to being deceived.
  (Choice B)  the research would challenge the idea that Aristotle's view changed in regard to method rather than goal.  The author states that "the change in Aristotle's position may affect the method rather than the goal of rhetoric.  One point in favor of this interpretation is Aristotle's view of judges as…subject to potential bias or corruption, or simply the errors of fallible judgment" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, research revealing that human beings have a tendency to make logical errors would not challenge the author's argument; it would be consistent with his or her suggestion about Aristotle's motivations.
(Choices C and D)  the research would support the idea that orators mistakenly argued for false or unjust positions; and the research would challenge the idea that dishonest orators were responsible for causing injustice.  Paragraph 4 refers to "dishonest orators, who may use emotional appeals and deceptive reasoning to confuse the judges into inadvertently rendering an unjust decision."  Accordingly, the author does not suggest that orators mistakenly argued for false or unjust positions, but that they did so intentionally in order to deceive the judges.  Furthermore, a natural tendency for humans to make specific types of logical errors would facilitate the orators' ability to confuse and deceive the judges.  Therefore, research that revealed such a tendency would not challenge the idea that dishonest orators were responsible for causing injustice.

text: According to the passage, Poe believed that a machine could never play chess due to:
explanations:
At one time, the prospect of machines playing chess was widely deemed absurd.  Writer Edgar Allan Poe declared in 1836 that its impossibility could be established a priori because, unlike the steps of a mathematical demonstration, "[n]o one move in chess necessarily follows upon any one other."  In the early 19th century, a human-shaped, turban-wearing machine called "The Turk" toured the United States as a supposed chess-playing automaton.  Although its owner claimed and seemed to prove that it was purely mechanical, Poe correctly concluded that the device was actually operated by a real person hidden inside its cabinet.  Despite this subterfuge, however, machine chess was not fundamentally impossible as Poe believed. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, Poe believed that the "impossibility" of a machine playing chess "could be established a priori (purely through reason) because, unlike the steps of a mathematical demonstration, '[n]o one move in chess necessarily follows upon any one other.'"  This indicates Poe's belief that machines are capable of performing only tasks that proceed in a determinate, step-by-step fashion, like those in a mathematical demonstration.
Because playing chess is not an example of such a task, Poe believed that it was "fundamentally impossible" for a machine to play chess (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, according to the passage, Poe believed that a machine could never play chess because of a personal belief that machines are limited to certain types of functions.
  (Choice A)  the example of "The Turk" that had proved to be a fraud.  According to Paragraph 4, "Poe correctly concluded that [The Turk] was actually operated by a real person hidden inside its cabinet."  However, Poe's belief that The Turk could not play chess was based on his more general belief that it was "fundamentally impossible" for any machine to play chess.  In other words, his belief that machines cannot play chess was not based on discovering that the Turk was a fraud.  Rather, the reverse is true; he concluded that the Turk must be a fraud because of his belief that it was impossible for a machine to play chess.
(Choice B)  a mathematical proof that seemed to show machine chess to be impossible.  Poe argued that a game of chess was "unlike the steps of a mathematical demonstration" because "[n]o one move in chess necessarily follows upon any one other" (Paragraph 4).  However, the passage never states that Poe was influenced by a mathematical proof that seemed to show machine chess to be impossible.
(Choice D)  a prevailing opinion that the idea of machine chess was absurd.  Paragraph 4 states that "[a]t one time, the prospect of machines playing chess was widely deemed absurd."  Although the passage mentions Poe as an example of someone who shared that opinion, it describes him as arriving at that belief through a process of reasoning, not because it was widely held.  Specifically, Poe argued that no machine could play chess because they were limited to processes with fixed steps, whereas "[n]o one move in chess necessarily follows upon any one other."

text: For which of the following items of passage information does the author provide the LEAST explanation or evidence?
explanations:
The early chess computers of the 1960s possessed only limited abilities, but by 1997 IBM's "Deep Blue" had defeated world champion Garry Kasparov.  Today, the strongest chess computers are unbeatable in fair contests by even the most skilled human grandmasters. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 mentions Deep Blue, the IBM chess computer that "defeated world champion Garry Kasparov" in 1997.  However, the passage never discusses the reason for the computer's name.  Therefore, the author provides no explanation or evidence for the reason behind the name "Deep Blue."
  (Choice A)  What it means to win "by flag."  Paragraph 2 states that in addition to checkmate or the opponent's resignation, "[o]ne may also win 'by flag' if the opponent runs out of time."  Therefore, although the specific reference to a flag is not explained, the author makes clear that winning "by flag" means that the opponent has run out of time.
(Choice B)  What it means for a game to end "by stalemate."  According to Paragraph 2, "not all games of chess result in a win for either side.  A draw may ensue by agreement of the players, by stalemate, or under certain other conditions."  Therefore, the author indicates that "by stalemate" refers to one of the ways in which a game of chess may end in a draw (tie).
(Choice D)  The reason behind the name "The Turk."  Paragraph 4 states that "[i]n the early 19th century, a human-shaped, turban-wearing machine called 'The Turk' toured the United States as a supposed chess-playing automaton."  By describing the supposed automaton's appearance as "human-shaped" and mentioning a part of its clothing, the author conveys that it was meant to look like a mechanical human being.  Hence, the passage suggests that the machine was depicted as a person from Turkey (ie, a Turk) as part of its human-like persona.

text:
Based on passage information, one should expect:
experienced chess players to be unsurprised by a loss.
novice chess players to rarely achieve checkmate.
human chess players to lose to a strong computer.
explanations:
Similarly, a common scenario in fiction is for a player to defeat an opponent by sudden surprise…In real chess such abrupt triumph occurs rarely or never, as the inevitability of checkmate will have been readily apparent to both sides. (Paragraph 1)
Indeed, at higher levels of play checkmate is uncommon, because the losing side typically resigns rather than prolong an unavoidable defeat by playing until checkmate has occurred. (Paragraph 2)
The early chess computers of the 1960s possessed only limited abilities, but by 1997 IBM's "Deep Blue" had defeated world champion Garry Kasparov.  Today, the strongest chess computers are unbeatable in fair contests by even the most skilled human grandmasters. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 1 indicates that in chess games between experienced players, an "abrupt triumph occurs rarely or never, as the inevitability of checkmate will have been readily apparent to both sides."  Therefore, based on passage information, one should expect experienced chess players to be unsurprised by a loss (Number I) as the impending loss would already be obvious.
Paragraph 4 discusses the strength of chess computers compared to humans, and notes that "the strongest chess computers are unbeatable in fair contests by even the most skilled human grandmasters."  Therefore, based on passage information, one should expect human chess players to lose to a strong computer (Number III).
  (Number II)  novice chess players to rarely achieve checkmate.  Paragraph 2 states that "at higher levels of play checkmate is uncommon."  However, the passage never suggests that checkmate is uncommon among novice players (ie, at lower levels of play).  Accordingly, the passage does not suggest that one should expect novice chess players to rarely achieve checkmate.

text: Based on the passage, which of the following most accurately represents the author's view regarding the Frank Marshall chess game of 1912?
explanations:
Public discourse about chess can occasionally veer into the ridiculous.  In 1912, it was reported that a move made by chess champion Frank Marshall elicited such admiration from onlookers that they showered gold pieces onto the board.  While the move may indeed be considered a brilliancy (thought by some to be the most beautiful chess move ever played), the story must otherwise be spurious.  Even supposing that the viewers were so impressed as to engage in such specific and effusive praise, precisely how much gold were they supposed to have had? (Paragraph 3)
The author states that Marshall's move in 1912 "may indeed be considered a brilliancy" and elaborates that it is "thought by some to be the most beautiful chess move ever played" (Paragraph 3).  He or she further states that it was such an amazing move that, supposedly, onlookers "showered gold pieces onto the board" in response.
The author then asks rhetorically: "Even supposing that the viewers were so impressed as to engage in such specific and effusive praise, precisely how much gold were they supposed to have had?" (Paragraph 3).  This remark expresses the author's skepticism that those spectators would have "showered gold pieces onto the board," regardless of how brilliant or beautiful Marshall's move may have been.  Therefore, the author's view regarding the Frank Marshall chess game of 1912 is that the reports about the game were exaggerated.
  (Choices A and C)  Marshall's move was not as impressive as the story suggests; and The supposed game may not have really occurred.  Paragraph 3 states that Marshall's move "may indeed be considered a brilliancy (thought by some to be the most beautiful chess move ever played)," but asserts that "the story must otherwise be spurious" (ie, aside from Marshall's brilliancy, other claims regarding the story were likely false).  Therefore, although the author doubts some of the details of the story, he or she views Marshall's move as impressive and believes that the game in which it occurred did take place.
(Choice B)  "Beauty" in chess is highly subjective.  By calling Marshall's move "a brilliancy," the author supports the view that Marshall's move should be considered beautiful.  However, the author never suggests that beauty in chess is highly subjective.

text: The passage discussion about machines and chess implies that:
explanations:
For instance, a non-player might wonder about the maximum number of moves that can be planned in advance, but an experienced player would find that question naïve.  The unsatisfying but accurate answer is that it depends on the position, because the opponent's potential moves will at some points require calculating numerous possibilities but at other points will be an entirely forced sequence. (Paragraph 1)
Today, the strongest chess computers are unbeatable in fair contests by even the most skilled human grandmasters. (Paragraph 4)
Nevertheless, however unassailable in the realm of calculation, computers will always lack the most valuable trait of any chess player. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 1, planning moves in advance can be difficult "because the opponent's potential moves will at some points require calculating numerous possibilities."  This indicates that human chess players are limited in their ability to calculate all the possible moves that could arise from a particular point in a game.
On the other hand, "the strongest chess computers are unbeatable in fair contests by even the most skilled human grandmasters" (Paragraph 4), as computers are "unassailable in the realm of calculation" (Paragraph 5), meaning that they are able to calculate a multitude of future moves.  Therefore, the passage discussion of machines and chess implies that a computer's advantage over humans lies in its greater ability to calculate possible moves.
  (Choice B)  The Turk was a forerunner of modern chess computers.  Although The Turk was claimed to be a mechanical "chess-playing automaton," it was actually a fraud "operated by a real person hidden inside its cabinet" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, The Turk was not a forerunner of modern chess computers, which are genuine chess-playing machines.
(Choice C)  Poe's reasoning about machine chess was flawed due to the technology of his time.  According to Paragraph 4, Poe declared in 1836 that the impossibility of machine chess "could be established a priori (purely through reason) because, unlike the steps of a mathematical demonstration, '[n]o one move in chess necessarily follows upon any one other.'"  The author later mentions "[t]he early chess computers of the 1960s," indicating that the first chess-playing machines were not invented until more than a century after Poe's claim.  Therefore, although Poe was wrong that machine chess is impossible, his reasoning was based on facts about mathematics and the nature of chess; the passage never suggests that Poe's reasoning was based on the technology of his time.
(Choice D)  when humans play chess against computers, the humans always lose.  Paragraph 4 states that "the strongest chess computers are unbeatable in fair contests by even the most skilled human grandmasters."  This statement implies that there are weaker chess computers that a human player may be able to defeat.  Hence, the passage does not necessarily suggest that when humans play chess against (any) computers, the humans always lose.

text: Which of the following is an assumption in the passage?
explanations:
Although most people have some idea of what chess entails, there are many misconceptions about its practice.  For instance, a non-player might wonder about the maximum number of moves that can be planned in advance, but an experienced player would find that question naïve.  The unsatisfying but accurate answer is that it depends on the position, because the opponent's potential moves will at some points require calculating numerous possibilities but at other points will be an entirely forced sequence.  Similarly, a common scenario in fiction is for a player to defeat an opponent by sudden surprise—the rival's look of confidence morphing into complete disbelief as the winner unexpectedly proclaims "Checkmate."  In real chess such abrupt triumph occurs rarely or never, as the inevitability of checkmate will have been readily apparent to both sides. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 discusses some of the "many misconceptions" that non-players imagine about chess, such as the "unsatisfying but accurate answer" regarding the "number of moves that can be planned in advance," which "depends on the position" rather than solely on a player's mental skills.  Similarly, although a dramatic surprise checkmate granting sudden victory over a rival may be "a common scenario in fiction," in actual chess it "occurs rarely or never."  Accordingly, the passage makes the assumption that some aspects of chess are less dramatic than people imagine.
  (Choice A)  The strongest computers make human chess obsolete.  Paragraph 4 states that "the strongest chess computers are unbeatable in fair contests by even the most skilled human grandmasters."  However, the passage goes on to state that "computers will always lack the most valuable trait of any chess player" because, unlike humans, "they can never experience their victory" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, the passage suggests that human chess still has value that is absent in computer chess, and does not assume that the strongest computers make human chess obsolete.
(Choice C)  Even people who do not play chess usually know a lot about it.  Paragraph 1 states that "[a]lthough most people have some idea of what chess entails, there are many misconceptions about its practice."  The passage then goes on to describe some of the mistaken impressions that "a non-player" may have, such as the "naïve" idea that experts can plot a certain number of moves in advance regardless of the position.  Therefore, the passage assumes that people who do not play or are unfamiliar with chess often know only a little about it.
(Choice D)  It is relatively rare for a game of chess to end in a draw.  Paragraph 2 states that "not all games of chess result in a win for either side.  A draw may ensue by agreement of the players, by stalemate, or under certain other conditions."  However, the passage never discusses how frequently or infrequently draws occur.  Therefore, the passage does not include the assumption that it is relatively rare for a game of chess to end in a draw.

text: Suppose that a chess expert intentionally continues playing until his opponent has achieved checkmate, instead of just resigning.  Based on passage information, the most reasonable explanation for this fact would be that:
explanations:
Similarly, a common scenario in fiction is for a player to defeat an opponent by sudden surprise—the rival's look of confidence morphing into complete disbelief as the winner unexpectedly proclaims "Checkmate."  In real chess such abrupt triumph occurs rarely or never, as the inevitability of checkmate will have been readily apparent to both sides. (Paragraph 1)
Indeed, at higher levels of play checkmate is uncommon, because the losing side typically resigns rather than prolong an unavoidable defeat by playing until checkmate has occurred. (Paragraph 2)
…a move made by chess champion Frank Marshall…may indeed be considered a brilliancy (thought by some to be the most beautiful chess move ever played)… (Paragraph 3)
The artistry of a move like Marshall's will forever be lost on them, while a human being can view and partake in its beauty, making the enjoyment of chess a distinctly human pleasure. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 1 states that "a common scenario in fiction is for a player to defeat an opponent by sudden surprise."  However, "[i]n real chess such abrupt triumph occurs rarely or never, as the inevitability of checkmate will have been readily apparent to both sides."  Thus, the passage indicates that a chess expert who continued playing until his opponent achieved checkmate would know that his opponent was about to win the game.
Similarly, Paragraph 2 asserts that "at higher levels of play checkmate is uncommon, because the losing side typically resigns rather than prolong an unavoidable defeat by playing until checkmate has occurred."  Accordingly, the passage conveys that if a chess expert were going to be checkmated, he would be aware of that fact in advance, and would typically resign prior to checkmate actually happening.  Thus, if an expert did not resign in that situation, there must be a reason why he was motivated to keep playing until his opponent achieved checkmate.
One potential reason is suggested later in the passage, as certain moves in chess are described as beautiful and artistic.  For example, Paragraph 3 calls a particular move "a brilliancy," and notes that it is "thought by some to be the most beautiful chess move ever played."  Likewise, Paragraph 5 describes the "artistry" of such a move, stating that "a human being can view and partake in its beauty, making the enjoyment of chess a distinctly human pleasure."
Therefore, a chess expert might intentionally continue to play until his opponent had achieved checkmate (rather than just resigning) if the sequence of moves leading to checkmate was so beautiful that the expert let it play out.
  (Choice B)  The opponent's choice of moves demonstrated that he was an even stronger player than the expert.  Although being a stronger player would make it more likely for the opponent to win, that would not mean that the expert would fail to recognize "the inevitability of checkmate" (Paragraph 1), or have a reason not to resign.
(Choice C)  Throughout the game, the moves made by the opponent were extremely unusual.  This scenario suggests that because the opponent's moves were unusual, the chess expert was caught off guard and did not realize that he was about to be checkmated.  However, the passage explicitly rules out this idea as one of "many misconceptions" about chess, stating that although it represents "a common scenario in fiction," it "occurs rarely or never" in real chess (Paragraph 1).
(Choice D)  The expert believed that the opponent's attack was bound to eventually succeed.  Paragraph 2 states that "at higher levels of play checkmate is uncommon, because the losing side typically resigns rather than prolong an unavoidable defeat by playing until checkmate has occurred."  Accordingly, believing the opponent's attack would succeed is a reason for the expert to resign; it is not a reason for him to keep playing.

text: The passage discussion of stage acting is unusual in that the author gives attention to:
explanations:
Most scholarly attention, however, has traditionally been directed toward one-way theatrical practices by which performers engage, transform, and heighten the bodily state of the audience through a framework of communal 'felt-experience,' and not vice versa.  (Paragraph 1)
The actors on stage are ostensibly the central object of attention, yet their communication with those in attendance is not solely a one-way discourse.  (Paragraph 2)
The audience serves an integral function in the performance: it activates, intensifies, and amplifies the circulation of emotional affect in a communal social space.  Individually and collectively, each spectator is able to participate in the intrinsically variable theatrical plot….  In this way, the performer dutifully influences the audience, and the audience, in essence, "re-affects" the stage.  (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 1, "most scholarly attention…has traditionally been directed toward one-way theatrical practices by which performers engage, transform, and heighten the bodily state of the audience...and not vice versa."  In other words, theater historians have generally focused their "scholarly attention" on how the performer affects the audience.
However, the author diverges from this trend by highlighting the idea that an audience can also affect performers.  For example, Paragraph 2 states that the actors' "communication with those in attendance is not solely a one-way discourse."  Similarly, Paragraph 6 describes a two-way emotional exchange or "mutual 'transmission of affect'" between performers and audience: "the performer dutifully influences the audience, and the audience, in essence, 're-affects' the stage."  Therefore, the passage discussion of stage acting is unusual in that the author gives attention to the impact of the audience on performers.
 (Choices A and C)  the effect of performers on audiences; and the transformative nature of theater for audiences.  According to Paragraph 1, "Most scholarly attention…has traditionally been directed toward one-way theatrical practices by which performers engage, transform, and heighten the bodily state of the audience."  Therefore, the passage implies that it is typical to discuss a transformative effect that theater performers have on audiences.
(Choice D)  the ability of some performers to capture an audience.  Paragraph 5 presents a general view of theater that "[b]ecause the audience is the proclaimed foundation of a theatrical event, a staged play aims to affect the audience, usually by 'capturing' the viewers in some poignant manner."  However, the passage never suggests that it is unusual for discussions of stage acting to give attention to this idea.

text: Based on the passage, audience members must do which of the following to have an emotional connection with performers and impact them on stage?
explanations:
Nevertheless, performers are ultimately the vessels responsible for detecting and absorbing the moods, attitudes, and emotions of individuals, and these aspects are vital to the apparent success or failure of the performative process.  (Paragraph 3)
According to this paradigm, there can be no performance without an audience.  Despite this, the presence of spectators does not guarantee that a meaningful emotional, or affective, exchange will transpire.  Such collective encounters in a shared space and time present only the possibility—for connection or disconnection; and, accordingly, an audience member must be physically present and willing to be affectively influenced.  (Paragraph 5)
The audience serves an integral function in the performance: it activates, intensifies, and amplifies the circulation of emotional affect in a communal social space…In this way, the performer dutifully influences the audience, and the audience, in essence, "re-affects" the stage.  (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 3, "performers are…responsible for detecting and absorbing the moods, attitudes, and emotions of individuals, and these aspects are vital to the apparent success or failure of the performative process."  However, the author argues that this process of emotional exchange requires the active participation of the audience.  For instance, Paragraph 5 conveys that the mere "presence of spectators does not guarantee that a meaningful emotional, or affective, exchange will transpire….  [A]n audience member must be physically present and willing to be affectively influenced."
Paragraph 6 further stresses the audience's role, which "serves an integral function in the performance: it activates, intensifies, and amplifies the circulation of emotional affect in a communal social space."  In other words, by engaging with the performance and reacting to it emotionally, the audience takes part in a mutual exchange: "the performer dutifully influences the audience, and the audience, in essence, 're-affects' the stage."  Implicitly, then, for audience members to have an emotional connection with performers and impact them on stage, they must be attentive and expressive during the performance.
 (Choice A)  Be willing to engage in theatrical experiments.  Paragraph 1 conveys that "[c]ontextual Futurists, nonsensical Dadaists, and the surreal avant-garde theatrical experiments upended the conventional notion of passive spectatorship."  Therefore, the author indicates that theatrical experiments represented one method by which audiences played a more active role in influencing performers on stage, but not that it was the only such method.  Moreover, the passage does not suggest that theatrical experiments were required for the process of performers "detecting and absorbing the moods, attitudes, and emotions" of the audience (Paragraph 3).
(Choice B)  Feel excited about the prospect of viewing the performance.  According to Paragraph 5, "the presence of spectators does not guarantee that a meaningful emotional, or affective, exchange will transpire."  Rather, in order for such an exchange to occur, "an audience member must be physically present and willing to be affectively influenced."  Therefore, the passage indicates that to have an emotional connection with performers and impact them on stage, an audience member must be willing to take part in such a connection during the performance.  However, the passage never indicates that such a connection requires audience members to feel excited in advance of viewing the performance (ie, excited about the prospect of viewing it).
(Choice D)  Actively participate in parts of the live performance.  In Paragraph 4, the author quotes an actor's description that "for the audience to be 'with' the performer, it must embrace a state of tension and immerse itself in the profundity of the performance."  Accordingly, the passage indicates that to have an emotional connection with performers and impact them on stage, an audience member must be willing to take part in a shared emotional experience.  However, the passage never suggests that this emotional connection requires audience members to actively participate in parts of the live performance itself.

text: Which of the following scenarios would be the best example of a "transmission of affect" as it is described in the passage?
explanations:
The audience serves an integral function in the performance: it activates, intensifies, and amplifies the circulation of emotional affect in a communal social space.  Individually and collectively, each spectator is able to participate in the intrinsically variable theatrical plot.  Affect is thereby experienced simultaneously through action, thought, and perception by both the artist and the audience.  This mutual "transmission of affect" induces a corporeal sentiment that ultimately resonates as a palpably emotional atmosphere...In this way, the performer dutifully influences the audience, and the audience, in essence, "re-affects" the stage.  (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 6, the "transmission of affect" is an experience in which performers and audiences impact each other in a mutual exchange of emotion: "the performer…influences the audience, and the audience, in essence, 're-affects' the stage."  In other words, the audience receives and reflects the emotion of the performers, which in turn emotionally influences the performers themselves.  The author describes this phenomenon more generally as a "circulation of emotional affect in a communal social space."  Therefore, the transmission of affect is like an emotional loop in which two parties influence, and are influenced by, each other.
Consequently, such an exchange would be best exemplified by cheering fans at a basketball game who encourage their team to score the winning points.  The fans collectively raise their voices to encourage their team; the team, influenced by the fans' cheering, is further motivated to score (which in turn encourages further cheering).  In this way, the fans and the team mutually amplify the emotional atmosphere, producing a transmission of affect.
 By contrast, each of the following scenarios describes an emotional influence on a single party, not a mutual exchange of emotion:
A child is given a hearing aid and feels joy upon hearing sound for the first time (Choice A).  Although the child has been impacted emotionally by the experience of hearing, no mention is made of the child's joy impacting another person.
The memory of a childhood coach motivates an Olympic diver before her toughest dive (Choice C).  In this situation, the diver is emotionally influenced by the memory of her coach.  However, the motivation she feels as a result of this memory does not in turn influence her coach or another party.
A surgeon promises a patient's spouse that a surgical procedure will be successful (Choice D).  The surgeon's promise might provide emotional relief to the spouse by reassuring him or her of a positive outcome to the surgery.  However, no suggestion is made that the spouse also emotionally influences the surgeon.

text: The author's attitude toward the comments of the "well-known stage actor" (Paragraph 3) can be best described as:
explanations:
Their predilection for tactile idiomatic expressions when describing the performer-audience connection is perfectly captured in these remarks from a well-known stage actor…  (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 states that when performers describe the experience of connecting with the audience, they have a "predilection" (preference or liking) to use "tactile idiomatic expressions" (ie, language relating to the perception of physical touch).  The author then asserts that this feature of the performer-audience connection is "perfectly captured" by the remarks of a well-known stage actor, implying that they constitute an extremely representative example of such tactile idiomatic expressions.  Therefore, the author has an assenting attitude toward those remarks.
 (Choice A)  affectionate.  The author indicates that he or she agrees with the actor's remarks by stating that they have "perfectly captured" performers' "predilection for tactile idiomatic expressions" (Paragraph 3).  However, agreement is not the same as displaying an attitude of affection (ie, fondness or tenderness).
(Choices B and D)  impartial; and adverse.  By stating that performers' "predilection for tactile idiomatic expressions…is perfectly captured in these remarks from a well-known stage actor" (Paragraph 3), the author implies that he or she agrees with those remarks.  Accordingly, the author's attitude toward those remarks would not be impartial or adverse.

text: Suppose that the plays "Shogun" and "The King and I" are being performed at a Broadway theater in New York City.  Based on the passage, which of the following is least likely to be true?
explanations:
Nevertheless, performers are ultimately the vessels responsible for detecting and absorbing the moods, attitudes, and emotions of individuals, and these aspects are vital to the apparent success or failure of the performative process.  One day, actors might find the audience energetic, welcoming, and appreciative; the next day, they may find a stiff, critical, and disconnected crowd, even when performing in the same production with unchanged levels of enthusiasm.  In some instances, a single audience may be unmoved, regardless of how well a show is performed.  (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, there may be significant variation in how different audiences react to a performance: "One day, actors might find the audience energetic, welcoming, and appreciative; the next day, they may find a stiff, critical, and disconnected crowd, even when performing in the same production with unchanged enthusiasm."  Therefore, the passage implies that performers cannot predict how a given audience will respond to a show, even in light of their experience with previous audiences.  Consequently, it would be least likely that performers can predict the audience response to the upcoming production of "Shogun."
 By contrast, the passage suggests that all of the following scenarios would be more likely:
Performers are able to clearly gauge the audience's reaction during "Shogun" (Choice A).  Paragraph 3 states that "performers are ultimately the vessels responsible for detecting and absorbing the moods, attitudes, and emotions of individuals….  One day, actors might find the audience energetic, welcoming, and appreciative; the next day, they may find a stiff, critical, and disconnected crowd."  Accordingly, the passage conveys that performers can and do gauge how an audience reacts to a performance.
Performers are capable of describing the audience's reaction to "The King and I" (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 2, "it is common to hear professional performers commentate on audience reaction."  For instance, "sometimes the spectators were 'attuned'; at other times they seemed 'aloof.'  Occasionally, performers feel as if they 'captured' the audience; at other times, they perceive that they 'lost touch' with the viewers entirely."  Therefore, the passage provides examples of how performers describe an audience's reaction to a show.
(Choice D)  The audience members hold the actors responsible for the success of "The King and I."  In Paragraph 3, the author states that "performers are ultimately…responsible for detecting and absorbing the moods, attitudes, and emotions" of the audience.  Furthermore, the performance skills of the actors are "vital to the apparent success or failure of the performative process."  Therefore, passage information suggests it is likely that audience members would hold the actors responsible for the success of a performance of "The King and I" (or any show).

text: Suppose that a new actor is scheduled to appear in the musical "Oklahoma."  Based on the passage, the author would most likely argue it is important for the actor to:
explanations:
Nevertheless, performers are ultimately the vessels responsible for detecting and absorbing the moods, attitudes, and emotions of individuals, and these aspects are vital to the apparent success or failure of the performative process.  (Paragraph 3)
The audience serves an integral function in the performance: it activates, intensifies, and amplifies the circulation of emotional affect in a communal social space….  Entertainers can only know if the audience is 'present' to the degree that they also embrace the mutual tension of the experience.  In this way, the performer dutifully influences the audience, and the audience, in essence, "re-affects" the stage.  (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 3, "performers are…responsible for detecting and absorbing the moods, attitudes, and emotions of individuals," factors that the author asserts are "vital to the apparent success or failure of the performative process."  Paragraph 6 further emphasizes the effect of an audience's emotional response, asserting that "[t]he audience serves an integral function in the performance: it activates, intensifies, and amplifies the circulation of emotional affect in a communal social space."
Thus, the passage conveys that the emotional interaction between audience and performer is a crucial aspect of theatrical success: "the performer dutifully influences the audience, and the audience, in essence, 're-affects' the stage" (Paragraph 6).  Consequently, the author would most likely argue that it is important for an actor to perceive the heightened feelings of the audience during a powerful scene.
 By contrast, the author would not most likely argue it is important for the actor to:
discuss audience engagement with fellow actors after the first performance (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 2, "After the curtain falls at the end of a performance, it is common to hear professional performers commentate on audience reaction."  However, the author would most likely view discussing audience engagement after a show as less important than perceiving audience engagement during a show, which is "vital to the apparent success or failure of the performative process" (Paragraph 3).
comprehend theater and the role of the audience from a historical perspective (Choice B).  The passage focuses largely on how performers and audiences influence each other through "the circulation of emotional affect in a communal social space" (Paragraph 6).  However, the author never suggests that an actor must comprehend theater and the role of the audience from a historical perspective in order to engage in that process.
become accustomed to a derisive audience after making a blunder on stage (Choice D).  Paragraph 2 states that "[i]n some instances, a single audience may be unmoved, regardless of how well a show is performed."  However, the author never discusses actors making blunders (mistakes) on stage or how an audience might react to such blunders.

text: Based on information contained in the passage, which of the following would one LEAST expect to have observed in the theater throughout the twentieth century?
explanations:
Throughout the twentieth century, the performer-spectator dynamic has been challenged both in artistic practice and from a theoretical perspective.  Contextual Futurists, nonsensical Dadaists, and the surreal avant-garde theatrical experiments upended the conventional notion of passive spectatorship, paving the way for performers to disrupt the invisible wall between artist and audience altogether.  (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 begins by describing innovations to the theater in which "[t]hroughout the twentieth century, the performer-spectator dynamic has been challenged."  In particular, performances included "theatrical experiments" that "upended the conventional notion of passive spectatorship, paving the way for performers to disrupt the invisible wall between the artist and audience altogether."  Accordingly, the passage indicates that performers and audiences had traditionally been viewed as completely separate, divided by an "invisible wall" that could not be crossed.
However, because this "conventional notion" was challenged in the twentieth century, one could no longer assume that the distance between performers and audiences was absolute or uncrossable.  Consequently, one would least expect to find impenetrable boundaries between the performers on stage and the spectators throughout the twentieth century.  Instead, the separation between the two groups would be blurred, suggesting that such boundaries might be ignored or eliminated during a performance.
 By contrast, any of the following would be more expected in twentieth century theater, as they represent a challenge to the separation of audience and performers:
Unique methods of incorporating audience members into the first act of a play (Choice A).  Incorporating audience members into the play would exemplify how "the performer-spectator dynamic has been challenged…in artistic practice" (Paragraph 1).
Audience members joining cast members on stage during the curtain call (Choice B).  By placing audience members literally on stage with the actors, this situation would "disrupt the invisible wall between the artist and audience altogether" (Paragraph 1).
Live theatrical experiments involving spectators and performers (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 1, "surreal avant-garde theatrical experiments upended the conventional notion of passive spectatorship."

text: Which of the following supposed features of ancient Jericho best explains why Braidwood stated that the radiocarbon dates must be wrong?
explanations:
