Initial radiocarbon dating indicated that Jericho's original walls were built in around 6900 to 6800 B.C.  As Emmanuel Anati noted in a 1962 publication, that would not just make Jericho "the only place in the world where a walled town has been found to date back to nine thousand years ago," but also make it "four thousand years older than any similar settlement known at present."  Moreover, the city would have been politically unique for its time and region, as constructing the fortifications—including a defensive ditch and tower in addition to the walls—must have required extensive coordination of labor by a strong, centralized leadership.  Other contemporaneous groups were generally much smaller and more loosely organized, often semi-nomadic confederations largely dependent on hunting. (Paragraph 2)
These and other considerations have divided the archaeological community, with scholars such as Robert Braidwood stating that the supposed radiocarbon dates are too early and must be wrong.  Others, like British School of Archaeology director Kathleen Kenyon, accept the accuracy of the dates but seek to explain why Jericho appears to represent such an anomaly. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 2, if the initial radiocarbon dates of "around 6900 to 6800 B.C." are correct, then many features of ancient Jericho would have been extremely unusual for its time.  For example, Jericho would be not just "'the only place in the world where a walled town has been found to date back to nine thousand years ago,' but also…'four thousand years older than any similar settlement known at present.'"  In addition, Jericho "would have been politically unique" in possessing "a strong, centralized leadership" at a time when "[o]ther contemporaneous groups were generally much smaller and more loosely organized."
Paragraph 3 then asserts: "These and other considerations have divided the archaeological community, with scholars such as Robert Braidwood stating that the supposed radiocarbon dates are too early and must be wrong."  Therefore, Jericho's radical difference from other settlements (if the radiocarbon dates are correct) best explains why Braidwood stated that those dates must be wrong.
  (Choice A)  Jericho's mysterious abandonment.  Paragraph 3 states that "[a]nother puzzle" surrounding Jericho's sustenance is "why Jericho, if it was particularly conducive to cultivating crops, seems to have been abandoned at certain points in its history while nearby settlements flourished."  However, the passage does not connect the fact that Jericho "seems to have been abandoned at certain points" to Braidwood's objection to the initial radiocarbon dates.  Moreover, such a puzzle would require explanation regardless of when Jericho was built.
(Choice C)  Jericho's agricultural similarity to other settlements.  According to Paragraph 3, scholars such as Kathleen Kenyon "accept the accuracy of the dates but seek to explain why Jericho appears to represent such an anomaly (departure from the norm)."  Part of Kenyon's proposed explanation for Jericho's uniqueness was that Jericho was sustained by "successful agriculture."  However, Braidwood "disputes this conclusion, arguing that Jericho's land was no more suitable for agriculture than were neighboring areas."  Therefore, the passage connects the initial radiocarbon dates to the idea that Jericho was agriculturally distinct from other settlements, not agriculturally similar.  In other words, agricultural similarity is part of Braidwood's view, not one of the "supposed features" of ancient Jericho that he argues against.
(Choice D)  Jericho's dependence on the Dead Sea.  Paragraph 4 describes Emmanuel Anati's view that "the Dead Sea indeed played a critical role in Jericho's sustenance…by providing valuable economic resources."  However, the passage does not suggest that Braidwood objects to the idea that Jericho depended on the Dead Sea.  Rather, he disputes the initial radiocarbon dates because of how historically unusual Jericho would be if those dates were accurate.  For instance, Jericho would be "'four thousand years older than any similar settlement known at present'" (Paragraph 2).

text: According to the passage, given the city's fortifications, which of the following features did Jericho probably possess that made it atypical among settlements of its time?
explanations:
Moreover, the city would have been politically unique for its time and region, as constructing the fortifications—including a defensive ditch and tower in addition to the walls—must have required extensive coordination of labor by a strong, centralized leadership.  Other contemporaneous groups were generally much smaller and more loosely organized, often semi-nomadic confederations largely dependent on hunting. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 states that Jericho "would have been politically unique for its time and region, as constructing the fortifications…must have required extensive coordination of labor by a strong, centralized leadership."  The author then adds that "[o]ther contemporaneous groups were generally much smaller and more loosely organized, often semi-nomadic confederations."  Consequently, the passage indicates that, given Jericho's fortifications, it was most likely atypical among settlements of its time in possessing an unusually centralized government.
  (Choice A) An unusually trade-based economy.  According to Paragraph 4, Emmanuel Anati concluded that "'Only trade comes seriously into consideration as a major means of accumulating the surplus necessary to maintain such a wealthy town in the seventh millennium B.C.'"  Therefore, a trade-based economy is suggested as an explanation for Jericho's wealth; however, it is not specifically mentioned as a requirement for constructing the city's fortifications.  In addition, the passage never discusses the extent to which other settlements engaged in trade.  By contrast, the presumed "strong, centralized leadership" of Jericho is treated as highly atypical compared to "[o]ther contemporaneous groups," which "were generally much smaller and more loosely organized" (Paragraph 2).
(Choices B and C) An unusually plentiful food supply for its population; and An unusually fertile farmland.  Kathleen Kenyon has attributed Jericho's sustenance in part to "'the spring by which the settlement is situated, assuring the productivity of the fields.'"  However, this idea is meant to explain how food could be provided for such "a large, permanent city" (Paragraph 3), a question that would arise even if the city were not surrounded by fortifications.  The fortifications themselves are instead presented as evidence of "extensive coordination of labor by a strong, centralized leadership" (Paragraph 2).

text: According to the author, scholars agree that hunting would have been insufficient to provide for Jericho's sustenance.  However, flint arrowheads have been discovered in the excavations of Jericho.  Does this information challenge the scholars' view as it is described in the passage?
explanations:
One issue relates to Jericho's food supply, which must have been substantial to maintain a large, permanent city.  In 1954, Kenyon concluded that "the basis of the settlement must be successful agriculture," further noting "the spring by which the settlement is situated, assuring the productivity of the fields."  But Braidwood disputes this conclusion, arguing that Jericho's land was no more suitable for agriculture than were neighboring areas.  Another puzzle is why Jericho, if it was particularly conducive to cultivating crops, seems to have been abandoned at certain points in its history while nearby settlements flourished.  All sides in the debate agree that hunting would have been insufficient to sustain a population of Jericho's size.  Fishing has been suggested as an alternative possibility, but this too is widely deemed unlikely to have provided adequate support for Jericho's growth. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, archaeologists have debated factors related to "Jericho's food supply, which must have been substantial to maintain a large, permanent city."  Some, like Kathleen Kenyon, proposed that Jericho was sustained primarily through "'successful agriculture,'" while others such as Robert Braidwood argued that "Jericho's land was no more suitable for agriculture than were neighboring areas."  Despite disagreeing about agriculture, however, "[a]ll sides in the debate agree that hunting would have been insufficient to sustain a population of Jericho's size."  Similarly, "[f]ishing…is widely deemed unlikely to have provided adequate support for Jericho's growth."
However, arguing that a particular method of food acquisition would have been inadequate is not the same as arguing that it was absent altogether.  For example, even if "hunting would have been insufficient to sustain a population of Jericho's size" (Paragraph 3), that does not mean that the people of Jericho did not obtain some portion of their food through hunting.  Therefore, the discovery of flint arrowheads at Jericho does not challenge the scholars' view, because the scholars suggest only that hunting would have been inadequate to sustain Jericho's population on its own.
  (Choices A and B)  Yes, because it is more consistent with the information that contemporaneous groups were largely dependent on hunting; and Yes, because it constitutes material evidence that the inhabitants of Jericho fashioned implements for hunting.  According to Paragraph 2, "Other contemporaneous groups were generally much smaller and more loosely organized, often semi-nomadic confederations largely dependent on hunting."  Therefore, the passage suggests that Jericho was atypical in comparison to contemporaneous groups that were largely hunting-based.  However, even if other settlements were more dependent on hunting than Jericho was, the population of Jericho may still have obtained some of its food through hunting.  Consequently, the discovery of flint arrowheads would not challenge scholars' view that "hunting would have been insufficient to sustain a population of Jericho's size" (Paragraph 3).
(Choice D)  No, because the arrowheads could have been acquired from other settlements through Jericho's trade economy.  Paragraph 4 describes the view that Jericho relied on a trade-based economy, and that "the profit obtained from exporting…goods could plausibly account for how and why Jericho occupied its unique position in the ancient Near East."  However, whether the arrowheads were produced in Jericho or acquired through trade, their discovery would not challenge the claim that "hunting would have been insufficient to sustain a population of Jericho's size" (Paragraph 3).  Rather, the arrowheads are evidence that hunting did take place in Jericho, even if that activity was not the primary method by which the city's food was procured.

text: Which of the following discoveries would most challenge Anati's argument about Jericho's sustenance?
explanations:
Anati argues that the Dead Sea indeed played a critical role in Jericho's sustenance, but in a different way, namely, by providing valuable economic resources….  As he points out, tools and ornamental items originating from Anatolia, Sinai, and the Mediterranean coast have been found at ancient Jericho.  More importantly, in surrounding regions "the Dead Sea has always been the principal source of salt," which was "becoming an indispensable substance [for preparing and preserving food] at exactly the time when Jericho was becoming a walled town."  The sea would also have yielded large amounts of bitumen, important for fashioning tools and waterproofing containers, as well as sulphur, which even today is "still used by Bedouin to prepare medicines and to light fires."  Hence, the profit obtained from exporting these and other goods could plausibly account for how and why Jericho occupied its unique position in the ancient Near East. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 presents Emmanuel Anati's argument that "the Dead Sea indeed played a critical role in Jericho's sustenance…by providing valuable economic resources" that facilitated a trade-based economy.  Some evidence of this trade comes from foreign artifacts, such as "tools and ornamental items originating from Anatolia, Sinai, and the Mediterranean coast...found at ancient Jericho."  However, Anati treats Jericho's valuable natural resources, especially salt, as even stronger evidence: "More importantly, in surrounding regions 'the Dead Sea has always been the principal source of salt,' which was 'becoming an indispensable substance [for preparing and preserving food] at exactly the time when Jericho was becoming a walled town.'"
Accordingly, Anati argues that the trade of salt and, to a lesser extent, other resources such as bitumen and sulphur, enabled Jericho to sustain itself as a large, permanent city.  As the author explains, "[T]he profit obtained from exporting these and other goods could plausibly account for how and why Jericho occupied its unique position in the ancient Near East."
However, if other settlements had enjoyed easy access to salt, they would have had little need to import it from Jericho, undermining the most important evidence in Anati's argument that Jericho was sustained through a trade-based economy.  Consequently, that argument would be most challenged if salt was a widely available resource throughout many settlements of the ancient Near East.
 By contrast, none of the following discoveries would most challenge Anati's argument:
The importance of sulphur to Bedouin society has increased in modern times compared to what it was in the seventh millennium B.C. (Choice A).  Paragraph 4 notes the value of "sulphur, which even today is 'still used by Bedouin to prepare medicines and to light fires.'"  However, even if sulphur is more important to Bedouin society today, it could still have also been an important resource in ancient times.
The use of salt was only one method of preparing and preserving food in ancient times (Choice B).  A key point in Anati's argument is the value of salt, "which was 'becoming an indispensable substance [for preparing and preserving food] at exactly the time when Jericho was becoming a walled town'" (Paragraph 4).  However, even if there were other methods for preparing and preserving food in ancient times, that fact would not necessarily diminish the importance of salt.  For instance, salt could have represented the simplest or most effective method, which would explain why it was so highly valued.
Items and tools from Sinai and Anatolia are difficult to distinguish from those made in Jericho (Choice D).  This scenario suggests that excavated artifacts believed to be imported "ornamental items originating from Anatolia, Sinai, and the Mediterranean coast" (Paragraph 4) could be misidentified objects that were actually produced in Jericho.  However, Anati's argument is primarily based not on the import of such items, but rather on Jericho's access to valuable resources for export, especially salt.  Hence, this discovery would be less challenging to Anati's argument than if salt were widely available throughout the ancient Near East.

text: Why does the author most likely mention Jericho's defensive ditch and tower?
explanations:
Moreover, the city would have been politically unique for its time and region, as constructing the fortifications—including a defensive ditch and tower in addition to the walls—must have required extensive coordination of labor by a strong, centralized leadership.  Other contemporaneous groups were generally much smaller and more loosely organized, often semi-nomadic confederations largely dependent on hunting. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, Jericho "would have been politically unique for its time and region, as constructing the fortifications—including a defensive ditch and tower in addition to the walls—must have required extensive coordination of labor by a strong, centralized leadership."  The author also draws the contrast that "[o]ther contemporaneous groups were generally much smaller and more loosely organized."
Hence, the passage asserts that Jericho must have had an unusually powerful and centralized political authority because building its fortifications would have been a complex and labor-intensive endeavor.  Therefore, the author most likely mentions Jericho's defensive ditch and tower to emphasize the point that the fortifications represented a significant undertaking.
  By contrast, the author does not most likely mention Jericho's defensive ditch and tower in order:
to emphasize the point that other groups were often semi-nomadic (Choice A).  The author's statement that Jericho's fortifications "includ[ed] a defensive ditch and tower in addition to the walls" (Paragraph 2) does not provide any information about other groups.  Moreover, the later information that "[o]ther contemporaneous groups were…often semi-nomadic confederations largely dependent on hunting" would be true whether or not Jericho possessed a defensive ditch and tower.  Even if a contrast between Jericho and such nomadic groups is implied, that contrast is based on Jericho's status as a "large, permanent city" (Paragraph 3), not specifically on whether fortifications were present.
to emphasize why Jericho's historical record has caused controversy (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 2, if the radiocarbon dates for Jericho are accurate, then Jericho would be "'the only place in the world where a walled town has been found to date back to nine thousand years ago.'"  Similarly, it would be "'four thousand years older than any similar settlement known at present.'"  Therefore, the controversy that has "divided the archaeological community" (Paragraph 3) is based on the supposed date of Jericho's walls and the difference from other settlements of its time, factors that do not depend on whether Jericho had a defensive ditch and tower.
to emphasize why Jericho's walls have become famous (Choice D).  Although Paragraph 1 states that "[t]he ancient city of Jericho has long been famous for its walls," the passage never suggests that this fame was related to a defensive ditch and tower.  Moreover, the specific mention that such a ditch and tower were included "in addition to the walls" (Paragraph 2) suggests that these features of the fortifications are not as widely known as the walls themselves.

text: Suppose that more advanced methods of radiocarbon dating indicate that Jericho's original walls were constructed around 7400 B.C.  What effect would this discovery have on Robert Braidwood's view as it is described in the passage?
explanations:
Initial radiocarbon dating indicated that Jericho's original walls were built in around 6900 to 6800 B.C.  As Emmanuel Anati noted in a 1962 publication, that would not just make Jericho "the only place in the world where a walled town has been found to date back to nine thousand years ago," but also make it "four thousand years older than any similar settlement known at present." (Paragraph 2)
These and other considerations have divided the archaeological community, with scholars such as Robert Braidwood stating that the supposed radiocarbon dates are too early and must be wrong. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 2, "[i]nitial radiocarbon dating indicated that Jericho's original walls were built in around 6900 to 6800 B.C."  Those dates are historically significant because if they are accurate, then "that would not just make Jericho 'the only place in the world where a walled town has been found to date back to nine thousand years ago,' but also make it 'four thousand years older than any similar settlement known at present.'"  Paragraph 3 then points out that "[t]hese and other considerations have divided the archaeological community, with scholars such as Robert Braidwood stating that the supposed radiocarbon dates are too early and must be wrong."
Therefore, Braidwood's argument that the radiocarbon dates must be wrong is based on the belief that those dates are too early.  In other words, he objects to the conclusion that a walled town had existed millennia before any other known similar settlements.  However, if more advanced methods of radiocarbon dating indicated that Jericho's original walls were constructed around 7400 B.C., then those walls would have existed even earlier than the initial dating indicated.  In that case, Braidwood's view would be challenged; Jericho's walls would be even older than originally supposed.
  (Choice B)  Braidwood's view would be challenged; Jericho's walls would be even stronger evidence of a trade economy.  Although Braidwood argued that "the supposed radiocarbon dates…must be wrong" (Paragraph 3), this claim is meant to dispute the idea that Jericho was "'four thousand years older than any similar settlement known at present'" (Paragraph 2).  Paragraph 4 presents Emmanuel Anati's view that "'Only trade comes seriously into consideration'" as an explanation for Jericho's sustenance, but the passage never suggests that Braidwood's view is concerned with whether Jericho possessed a trade economy.
(Choices C and D)  Braidwood's view would be unaffected; he makes no reference to different methods of radiocarbon dating; and Braidwood's view would be supported; he correctly stated that the original radiocarbon dates must be wrong.  According to Paragraph 3, Braidwood claimed that "the supposed radiocarbon dates are too early and must be wrong."  Hence, he argued that Jericho could not be as old as those radiocarbon dates suggested.  Therefore, the discovery that Jericho was even older than originally conjectured would challenge (not support) Braidwood's view.  Furthermore, this conclusion does not depend on whether Braidwood referred to different methods of radiocarbon dating; it is based only on Braidwood's claim that Jericho could not be as old as that dating would suggest.

text: Which of the following could be considered an inconsistency in Descartes' approach?
explanations:
Into this collapsing Weltanschauung was born René Descartes—a thinker seemingly destined to become the symbol of a new totalizing skepticism as well as the progenitor of a rationalism so absolute it promised to unite the sciences and philosophy into a single system of thought.  Less overtly, however, Descartes would embody the irreconcilable differences of an age in which faith and reason, superstition and science, and alchemy and chemistry vied with one another. (Paragraph 1)
The rational thinker was convinced that these overpowering dreams had descended "from above."  As reported by his earliest biographer, Adrien Baillet, Descartes "thought he could perceive through their shadows the signs of a path which God had marked out for him" because of his commitment to the truth.  Thus, this rising "Father of Modern Philosophy" whose instinct was to doubt everything drew the inspiration for his theories from the elusive realm of dreams. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 1, "Descartes [was] a thinker seemingly destined to become the symbol of a new totalizing skepticism as well as the progenitor (parent) of a rationalism so absolute it promised to unite the sciences and philosophy into a single system of thought."  Similarly, Paragraph 5 states that Descartes was inclined to "doubt everything."  However, as Paragraph 5 also conveys, "[t]he rational thinker was convinced that these overpowering dreams had descended 'from above.'"
Furthermore, according to his first biographer, Descartes believed he could discern in these dreams "the signs of a path which God had marked out for him'" because he was seeking the truth.  Accordingly, this "rising 'Father of Modern Philosophy' whose instinct was to doubt everything drew the inspiration for his [rational] theories from the elusive realm of dreams."
Thus, Descartes' position exhibits a marked tension: having assumed a skeptical attitude of doubt and promoted rationality, he nevertheless trusted what he believed to be the message of his dreams, which seems irrational or unscientific.  Consequently, trusting in transient (ie, quickly vanishing) visions while adopting a relentlessly skeptical mindset could be considered an inconsistency in Descartes' approach.
 By contrast, none of the following could be considered an inconsistency in Descartes' approach:
designing a broad philosophical system while witnessing Scholasticism's collapse (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 1, "Scholasticism—that longstanding but unwieldy edifice (structure) of Catholic dogma buttressed (supported) by Aristotelian reasoning—was now tottering."  In contrast, Descartes was "destined to become…the progenitor of a rationalism so absolute it promised to unite the sciences and philosophy into a single system of thought."  He thus sought to design a broad philosophical system that would be based on an absolute and unifying certainty.  Therefore, Descartes did not object to the broadness of philosophical systems like Scholasticism but to their lack of certainty.
committing to rationalism while fiercely opposing Aristotelian philosophy (Choice B).  Paragraph 1 describes Scholasticism as "Catholic dogma buttressed (supported) by Aristotelian reasoning."  By contrast, the passage describes Descartes' goal as "a rationalism so absolute it promised to unite the sciences and philosophy into a single system" and states that he scorned the Scholasticism or "'rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations'" he had been taught (Paragraph 2).  Thus, Descartes objected to the interpretations of Aristotelian reasoning (rationality).  However, the passage never suggests that he rejected all rational thinking or opposed Aristotelian philosophy in general.
wavering over philosophy's purpose while harshly judging the work of other philosophers (Choice D).  Paragraph 2 indicates that Descartes "felt only scorn for the steady diet he had been fed of 'rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations.'"  Furthermore, "[b]elieving that mathematics alone afforded certainty, he nimbly circumvented (avoided)…'the morass of metaphysics,'" or the existing theories about the nature of reality.  Therefore, although Descartes had a negative view of other philosophers' work, he was clear that philosophy's overarching purpose was to achieve certainty.

text: Based on the passage, which of the following inferences can most reasonably be drawn about Scholasticism?
explanations:
By the seventeenth century, the noxious fumes of epistemological doubt were rapidly seeping into the sensibility of the European intelligentsia.  Society had been left reeling from the world-altering discoveries and inventions of the past two centuries.  Additionally, the seismic shifts of the Renaissance and Reformation had set churchmen at odds with other thinkers and ignited devastating religious wars.  Scholasticism—that longstanding but unwieldy edifice of Catholic dogma buttressed by Aristotelian reasoning—was now tottering. (Paragraph 1
According to Paragraph 1, by Descartes' time, traditional ideas were beginning to be challenged: "[T]he noxious (harmful) fumes of epistemological doubt (ie, doubt about what can truly be known) were rapidly seeping into the sensibility of the European intelligentsia."  Furthermore, the massive changes brought about by the Renaissance and Reformation "had set churchmen at odds with other thinkers."  As a result, "Scholasticism—that longstanding but unwieldy edifice (structure) of Catholic dogma (authoritative principles or teachings) buttressed (supported) by Aristotelian reasoning—was now tottering."
Accordingly, the passage indicates that although churchmen may have continued to embrace Scholasticism during these unstable times, other thinkers had already begun to reject its doctrines (teachings).  Therefore, based on the passage, the most reasonable inference that can be drawn about Scholasticism is that it was less likely to appeal to purely philosophical thinkers than to churchmen.
 By contrast, none of the following inferences about Scholasticism can reasonably be drawn:
It was a system of thought meant to liberate the church from secular influences (Choice A).  Paragraph 1 describes Scholasticism as "Catholic dogma buttressed by Aristotelian reasoning."  Thus, this system of thought combined church teachings with the secular or nonreligious thinking of the ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle.  Consequently, Scholasticism was meant to harmonize nonreligious thinking with church doctrine rather than to free the church from secular influences.
It was revised due to the intense personal visions of thinkers such as Descartes (Choice B).  Paragraph 1 indicates that as a result of the "world-altering discoveries" and "the seismic shifts" of the preceding centuries, Scholasticism was already "tottering" when Descartes expressed his disdain for this "'rehashed Aristotle'" (Paragraph 2) and then experienced his visions.  However, the passage never suggests that the intellectual system of Scholasticism was revised due to Descartes' dreams—or the intense personal visions of any thinkers like him.
It was particularly reassuring to a society being rocked by constant upheavals (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 1, the "longstanding" intellectual system of Scholasticism was "unwieldy" and, by Descartes' time, was "tottering" due to the constant social upheavals of the preceding centuries.  Therefore, the passage suggests that Scholasticism was itself crumbling beneath the strain of those upheavals; it never suggests that Scholasticism was seen as a source of reassurance to a society experiencing such shifts.

text: Given the information presented in Paragraph 2, which of the following assertions most accurately describes Descartes' attitude toward philosophy?
explanations:
By the time Descartes had completed his preliminary education and entered law school, he was thoroughly disillusioned.  As Paul Strathern notes, the would-be philosopher felt only scorn for the steady diet he had been fed of "rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations."  Believing that mathematics alone afforded certainty, he nimbly circumvented what Strathern calls "the morass of metaphysics"….  [I]n the Netherlands, he encountered Dutch mathematician and thinker Isaac Beeckman, who renewed his appetite for original thought.  Descartes began to imagine that by applying the laws of mathematics to philosophy he could achieve the certainty he craved. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, Descartes had become "thoroughly disillusioned" with the philosophy that he had learned in school.  In fact, he "felt only scorn for the steady diet he had been fed of 'rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations.'"  Moreover, "[b]elieving that mathematics alone afforded certainty," Descartes turned away from "'the morass of metaphysics,'" or what seemed to be a confused collection of theories about the nature of reality.  Subsequent interactions with the mathematician Isaac Beeckman led Descartes to think that "by applying the laws of mathematics to philosophy he could achieve the certainty he craved."
Accordingly, Descartes viewed the philosophy of his day as lacking originality and certainty; he believed that accepted philosophical ideas needed to be reexamined, particularly in the light of mathematical laws.  Therefore, the assertion that philosophy ought to scrutinize even established ideas most accurately describes Descartes' attitude toward philosophy.


(Choice A)  Philosophy ought to focus on metaphysical ideas.  As Paragraph 2 states, "Believing that mathematics alone afforded certainty, [Descartes] nimbly circumvented (avoided)…'the morass (bog) of metaphysics, or the confused collection of theories of reality.'"  Accordingly, Descartes believed that philosophy should not focus on metaphysical ideas but turn away from them; it should look instead to the certainty that mathematics can provide.
(Choices C and D)  Philosophy ought to elaborate on previous thinkers' theories; and Philosophy ought to treat established ideas as indispensable.  Paragraph 2 notes that Descartes scorned the "'rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations'" that still prevailed.  Furthermore, he believed "that mathematics alone afforded certainty" and so made sure to avoid "'the morass of metaphysics,'" which included the currently accepted but confused ideas about the nature of reality.  Thus, Descartes saw previous thinkers' theories as no longer vital and established metaphysical ideas as needing to be dispensed with.  Philosophy, he thought, should be overhauled to achieve the certainty found in mathematics.  Therefore, Descartes did not believe that philosophy ought to reinterpret or elaborate on the theories of the thinkers who came before him, nor that it ought to treat established ideas as indispensable.

text: Based on the passage, Descartes most likely left school and joined the army in order to:
explanations:
By the time Descartes had completed his preliminary education and entered law school, he was thoroughly disillusioned.  As Paul Strathern notes, the would-be philosopher felt only scorn for the steady diet he had been fed of "rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations."  Believing that mathematics alone afforded certainty, he nimbly circumvented what Strathern calls "the morass of metaphysics."  Abandoning his studies and seeing the Thirty Years' War raging through Europe, the now aimless youth enlisted as a volunteer in the army.  While garrisoned in the Netherlands, he encountered Dutch mathematician and thinker Isaac Beeckman, who renewed his appetite for original thought.  Descartes began to imagine that by applying the laws of mathematics to philosophy he could achieve the certainty he craved. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, "By the time Descartes had completed his preliminary education and entered law school, he was thoroughly disillusioned" and hated "the steady diet he had been fed of 'rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations.'"  Furthermore, he sought to avoid "'the morass of metaphysics'"—or what could be seen as a confused collection of theories about the nature of reality—as he believed it lacked the certainty of mathematics.  Consequently, "[a]bandoning his studies and seeing the Thirty Years' War raging through Europe, the now aimless youth enlisted as a volunteer in the army."
This information indicates that when Descartes decided to join the army, he was completely frustrated with both school and the state of philosophy, specifically the unoriginal thinking exemplified by Scholasticism and the established metaphysical ideas he felt lacked certainty.  Therefore, Descartes most likely joined the army in order to escape the current intellectual climate in which he found himself immersed.
 By contrast, Descartes most likely did not leave school and join the army in order to:
pursue his designated mission in life (Choice A).  Paragraph 2 suggests only that Descartes was "disillusioned" with the unoriginal thinking exemplified by the "'rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations'" he had been taught.  A "now aimless youth," he volunteered for the army.  Later, through his interactions with Beeckman and subsequent visions, Descartes discovered his personal mission in life, namely, to achieve philosophical certainty.  Accordingly, the passage shows that when he left school and joined the army Descartes was "aimless"—that is, without a designated mission in life.
use his adventures to reenvision philosophy (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 2, "By the time Descartes…entered law school, he was thoroughly disillusioned," particularly with the "'rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations'" he had been taught.  He also believed "that mathematics alone afforded certainty" and that metaphysical ideas should be avoided.  Being a "now aimless youth," he decided to join the army.  While serving, he encountered Beeckman and "began to imagine that by applying the laws of mathematics to philosophy he could achieve the certainty he craved."  Therefore, although Descartes would later be intent on reenvisioning philosophy, the passage never suggests that this was his motivation when he left school and joined the army.
support the war effort through its conclusion (Choice C).  Paragraph 2 states that "the now aimless youth enlisted as a volunteer in the army."  However, the passage never indicates that the "aimless" Descartes planned to serve in the army for the duration of the war or for any specified amount of time.

text: In the description of Descartes' dreams (Paragraph 4), the author's reference to the title of the Ausonius poem "Which path in life will I choose?" can best be viewed as:
explanations:
In the first dream, Descartes found himself pursued by apparitions while fierce whirlwinds prevented him from retreating inside a church.  He awoke, only to be terrorized by a second vision in which a lightning bolt flooded his room with countless sparks.  Finally, in a third dream, a dictionary and a poetry anthology materialized on a table next to him.  He opened the anthology to a verse by the late Latin poet Ausonius entitled, "Which path in life will I choose?"  The shadowy figure of a man appeared and recommended another poem beginning with the Pythagorean phrase "Yes and No." (Paragraph 4)
While still slumbering, Descartes began to decipher this last dream: the dictionary represented the sciences, whereas the poetry anthology symbolized the union between wisdom and philosophy," and "Yes and No" alluded to the accuracy or error of human understanding.  Upon waking, he interpreted the winds from the first dream as forces directing him away from Scholasticism and the lightning bolt of the second as "the signal of the Spirit of Truth.  The rational thinker was convinced that these overpowering dreams had descended "from above."  As reported by his earliest biographer, Adrien Baillet, Descartes "thought he could perceive through their shadows the signs of a path which God had marked out for him" because of his commitment to the truth. (Paragraph 5)
As Paragraph 4 details, Descartes experienced a series of three dreams or visions.  In the first, he was prevented from entering a church; in the second, his room was filled with lightning sparks; in the third, "a dictionary and a poetry anthology materialized on a table next to him.  He opened the anthology to a verse by the late Latin poet Ausonius entitled, 'Which path in life will I choose?'"
Paragraph 5 conveys Descartes' interpretation of some of the content of these dreams.  In the third dream, according to Descartes, "the dictionary represented the sciences, whereas the poetry anthology symbolized the union between wisdom and philosophy."  Furthermore, he "interpreted the winds from the first dream as forces directing him away from Scholasticism and the lightning bolt of the second as 'the signal of the Spirit of Truth."'
These interpretations are consistent with Descartes' disillusionment, as related in Paragraph 2, with the "rehashed Aristotle" he had been taught, his avoidance of current metaphysical ideas as confused, and his desire for the certainty only mathematics seemed to provide.  Thus, as an "aimless youth," Descartes left school, abandoning philosophical pursuits to join the army.  When it came to these dreams, the budding philosopher "'thought he could perceive through their shadows the signs of a path which God had marked out for him'" (Paragraph 5) because he was dedicated to the truth.
Consequently, the contents of the dreams, including the title of the poem, reflect aspects of Descartes' situation at the time and his desire to achieve certainty and truth in philosophy.  Therefore, in the description of Descartes' dreams (Paragraph 4), the author's reference to the title of the Ausonius poem "Which path in life will I choose?" can best be viewed as symbolically meaningful.
 (Choice A)  rhetorically unnecessary.  In Paragraph 4, the author supplies the details of Descartes' dream, including the title of the Ausonius poem "Which path in life will I choose?"  Those details are symbolic of Descartes' philosophical situation and the role of his dreams in motivating his mission.  Therefore, the author's reference to the title of the poem is relevant to connecting Descartes' dreams with his mission.  Consequently, the title's inclusion is best viewed as a significant detail rather than an unnecessary bit of rhetoric.
(Choices B and C)  purposely misleading; and likely embellished.  Paragraph 2 portrays Descartes as an "aimless youth" who, "disillusioned" with his education and the state of philosophy, was uncertain about his life's direction.  Later, Descartes experienced dreams that he purportedly believed conveyed '''the signs of a path which God had marked out for him' because of his commitment to the truth" (Paragraph 5).  Accordingly, the poem's title, "Which path in life will I choose?" reflects Descartes' lack of direction at the time.  Therefore, the reference to the title is best viewed as meaningful and relevant; the passage does not suggest that it is deliberately misleading, nor that it is embellished or exaggerated for emphasis.

text: Based on the final paragraph, which of the following best describes how the passage author portrays Descartes' philosophical position?  Descartes' position is:
explanations:
Into this collapsing Weltanschauung was born René Descartes—a thinker seemingly destined to become the symbol of a new totalizing skepticism as well as the progenitor of a rationalism so absolute it promised to unite the sciences and philosophy into a single system of thought.  Less overtly, however, Descartes would embody the irreconcilable differences of an age in which faith and reason, superstition and science, and alchemy and chemistry vied with one another. (Paragraph 1)
The rational thinker was convinced that these overpowering dreams had descended "from above."  As reported by his earliest biographer, Adrien Baillet, Descartes "thought he could perceive through their shadows the signs of a path which God had marked out for him" because of his commitment to the truth.  Thus, this rising "Father of Modern Philosophy" whose instinct was to doubt everything drew the inspiration for his theories from the elusive realm of dreams. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 1, Descartes would come to symbolize "a new totalizing skepticism" and was "the progenitor (parent) of a rationalism so absolute it promised to unite the sciences and philosophy into a single system of thought."  However, Descartes also "would embody the irreconcilable differences of an age in which faith and reason, superstition and science, and alchemy and chemistry vied with one another."
Paragraph 5 reveals how Descartes exemplified this tension between opposites.  Descartes "was convinced" that the dreams he experienced "'had descended 'from above.'"  Indeed, he thought that these visions had been sent to indicate his personal philosophical mission in life, that they were "'the signs of a path which God had marked out for him'" because he was seeking the truth.  However, the last sentence highlights an apparent inconsistency, namely, that "this rising 'Father of Modern Philosophy' whose instinct was to doubt everything drew the inspiration for his theories from the elusive realm of dreams."
Accordingly, Descartes' apparent conviction that the content of his dreams was meaningful is not consistent with the firmly rational and radically skeptical position the author ascribes to him.  Therefore, the author portrays Descartes' philosophical position as ironic, or the opposite of what one would expect.
 By contrast, the author does not portray Descartes' position as being:
predictable (Choice B).  Paragraph 5 describes Descartes as someone "whose instinct was to doubt everything."  However, Descartes also "drew the inspiration for his theories from the elusive realm of dreams."  Given the descriptions of Descartes as a thinker inclined toward skepticism and doubt, one would not expect or predict that he would trust information readily—particularly information communicated through dream phenomena.
unvarying (Choice C).  The author emphasizes that Descartes "[l]ess overtly…embod[ied] the irreconcilable differences" of his times (Paragraph 1) and that "this rising 'Father of Modern Philosophy' whose instinct was to doubt everything drew the inspiration for his theories from the elusive realm of dreams" (Paragraph 5).  Accordingly, the author portrays the philosophical position of this purportedly rational and skeptical thinker as being inconsistent or varying rather than unvarying.
frivolous (Choice D).  The author conveys that Descartes' position is inconsistent because although he embraced rationality and his "instinct was to doubt everything," he nevertheless "drew the inspiration for his theories from the elusive world of dreams" (Paragraph 5).  However, while the author describes Descartes' position as inconsistent, he or she never suggests that this inconsistency makes his philosophical position frivolous (ie, trivial or silly).

text: Why does the author most likely mention Isaac Beeckman (Paragraph 2)?
explanations:
By the time Descartes had completed his preliminary education and entered law school, he was thoroughly disillusioned.  As Paul Strathern notes, the would-be philosopher felt only scorn for the steady diet he had been fed of "rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations."  Believing that mathematics alone afforded certainty, he nimbly circumvented what Strathern calls "the morass of metaphysics."  Abandoning his studies and seeing the Thirty Years' War raging through Europe, the now aimless youth enlisted as a volunteer in the army.  While garrisoned in the Netherlands, he encountered Dutch mathematician and thinker Isaac Beeckman, who renewed his appetite for original thought.  Descartes began to imagine that by applying the laws of mathematics to philosophy he could achieve the certainty he craved. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 describes Descartes as "thoroughly disillusioned" by the '"rehashed Aristotle encrusted with centuries of interpretations'" that he had been taught in school.  In Descartes' view, "mathematics alone afforded certainty."  Having left school and joined the army, he met Isaac Beeckman, a Dutch mathematician and thinker.  Through interactions with Beeckman, Descartes' "appetite for original thought" was revived; specifically, he "began to imagine that by applying the laws of mathematics to philosophy he could achieve the certainty he craved."
Accordingly, the author mentions Isaac Beeckman as part of the narrative of Descartes' life and of the context of that time.  The passage then continues its discussion of Descartes and his philosophical breakthrough without further reference to Beeckman.  Therefore, the most likely reason that the author mentions Isaac Beeckman (Paragraph 2) is to supply historical facts.
 By contrast, the author does not most likely mention Isaac Beeckman:
to challenge Descartes' originality (Choice A).  The author mentions Isaac Beeckman as someone instrumental in renewing Descartes' "appetite for original thought" (Paragraph 2).  Accordingly, the author suggests that Beeckman inspired Descartes to pursue his own original thoughts and ideas; however, he or she never suggests that Beeckman's influence made Descartes' thinking any less original.
to highlight another important thinker (Choice B).  In Paragraph 2, the author mentions "Dutch mathematician and thinker Isaac Beeckman" as someone who was able to renew Descartes' "appetite for original thought."  However, the passage continues to focus on Descartes without further reference to Beeckman.  Accordingly, the author's purpose is most likely not to highlight Beeckman's importance as a thinker, but simply to cite his influence on Descartes.
to suggest the superiority of mathematics (Choice D).  In Paragraph 2, the author mentions "Dutch mathematician and thinker Isaac Beeckman" as someone who inspired Descartes' "appetite for original thought."  As the author explains, interacting with Beeckman led Descartes "to imagine that by applying the laws of mathematics to philosophy he could achieve the certainty he craved."  However, although the mention of Beeckman relates to Descartes' view that mathematics was superior to other disciplines, the author never expresses that view as his or her own.

text: Based on the author's description, the behavior of the prosecutor in Paragraph 1 is most like that of:
explanations:
Suppose a prosecutor is considering whether to bring a case to trial.  He is not sure that the suspect is guilty—in fact, based on the evidence, it's more likely that the suspect is not guilty.  Nevertheless, he feels confident he can secure a guilty verdict.  His powers of persuasion are considerable, and there's a good chance he could trick a jury into believing the evidence is strong instead of weak.  In addition, the case is high profile and could be very lucrative; winning would likely lead to a substantial raise or promotion.  He decides to charge the suspect, and ultimately succeeds in persuading the jury to convict. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 describes a hypothetical situation in which a prosecutor brings a case to trial purely for personal gain.  Even though "it's more likely that the suspect is not guilty," the prosecutor "feels confident he can secure a guilty verdict."  Accordingly, since winning the case "would likely lead to a substantial raise or promotion," he tricks a jury into convicting a suspect who is probably innocent.
Based on that description, the prosecutor treats the suspect unjustly in order to personally profit.  Therefore, this prosecutor's behavior is most like that of a casting director who sabotages a more talented actor's audition so she can take the part herself.  If that actor is more talented, then they deserve to have the part.  Consequently, by sabotaging the actor's audition to give the part to herself, the casting director treats the actor unjustly for the sake of her own profit.
 (Choice A)  a college admissions officer who ignores a student's personal essay so she can focus on judging academic performance.  In this situation, there is no indication that the admissions officer is motivated by personal gain.  Furthermore, it is also not evident that the student suffers due to the officer's decision; for instance, that decision would actually benefit a student who performed well academically but wrote a subpar essay.  Therefore, the admissions officer's behavior is unlike that of the prosecutor, who charges a probably innocent suspect because "winning [the case] would likely lead to a substantial raise or promotion" (Paragraph 1).
(Choice B)  a hiring manager who sabotages a more qualified candidate's application so she can give the job to her friend.  The hiring manager does treat the more qualified candidate unjustly in order to achieve a personal goal.  However, this goal is to help her friend rather than to gain financially; by contrast, the prosecutor is motivated by the prospect of his own "substantial raise or promotion" (Paragraph 1).  Therefore, although the hiring manager is similar to the prosecutor in some respects, there is also a relevant difference between their actions.
(Choice D)  a restaurant manager who fires her head chef so she can hire a more experienced one to improve her menu.  Although the restaurant manager causes the head chef to suffer, it is not clear that she has treated the chef unjustly.  For example, if the chef's lack of experience led to poor performance on the job, then the manager would be justified in replacing the chef.  By contrast, in the question scenario, the prosecutor is not justified in charging the suspect because "it's more likely that the suspect is not guilty" (Paragraph 1).  Therefore, the behavior of the restaurant manager may be very different from that of the prosecutor.

text: The author argues that it is unethical for defense attorneys to take certain defendants as clients.  However, the Sixth Amendment guarantees every defendant the right to legal representation.  Can the author's argument accommodate this fact?
explanations:
Paid handsomely to represent even the vilest of clients, they apply their oratorical prowess to manipulating jury perception, keeping the guilty free and unpunished in exchange for money and status.  To the extent that this behavior takes place, are some defense attorneys as unethical as our hypothetical prosecutor? (Paragraph 2)
With the exception of court-appointed attorneys or public defenders, who are assigned to provide representation to those who would otherwise lack it, an attorney is never required to represent a defendant.  Therefore, meeting one's obligations as a defense attorney does not necessarily make one ethical, because the choice to accept a specific case (and thus to incur those obligations in the first place) may itself be an unethical act. (Paragraph 4)
Moreover, the role of court-appointed attorneys is to help protect the rights of citizens who cannot secure their own representation, usually for financial reasons. (Paragraph 5)
For those who strive to ensure citizens' rights, or who truly believe their clients are innocent, providing a defense is a noble undertaking.  But for those whose overriding motivation is greed, that legally "zealous defense" is ethically indefensible. (Paragraph 6)
The author argues that it is unethical for defense attorneys to choose to represent guilty defendants.  For instance, Paragraph 2 denounces defense attorneys who "represent even the vilest of clients…keeping the guilty free and unpunished in exchange for money and status."  Likewise, Paragraph 4 states that "the choice to accept a specific case…may itself be an unethical act."  Finally, Paragraph 6 calls it "ethically indefensible" for a lawyer to defend the guilty out of greed.
However, the author also points out that while some attorneys can choose their clients, others do not have this choice: "With the exception of court-appointed attorneys or public defenders, who are assigned to provide representation to those who would otherwise lack it, an attorney is never required to represent a defendant" (Paragraph 4).  In other words, only private attorneys can decide whether or not to accept any particular client.  By contrast, public attorneys must represent anyone to whom they are assigned, "to help protect the rights of citizens who cannot secure their own representation" (Paragraph 5).
Therefore, even if every private defense attorney accepted the author's argument, the existence of public attorneys would still ensure the right of all citizens to legal representation.  Accordingly, the author's argument can accommodate the Sixth Amendment's guarantee because the author's ethical claim applies specifically to private attorneys.
 (Choice A)  Yes, because the needed reforms to the legal system could include the Sixth Amendment.  Although the author proposes reforms to the legal system, they assert that these "needed reforms must come from individual attorneys committing to work for the right reasons."  In addition, the author never suggests that the right to representation should be altered.  Rather, they affirm this right's importance by stating that "[f]or those who strive to ensure citizens' rights…providing a defense is a noble undertaking" (Paragraph 6).
(Choice C)  No, because if all attorneys accepted the author's argument, then some defendants could not get representation.  If all attorneys accepted the author's argument, then certain defendants could not get representation from private defense attorneys.  However, this change would not affect public defense attorneys, such as "court-appointed attorneys or public defenders, who are assigned to provide representation to those who would otherwise lack it" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, even if all attorneys accepted the author's argument, the defendants in question would still receive representation.
(Choice D)  No, because a collective refusal to represent certain defendants could lead to innocent people being convicted.  The author argues that defense attorneys should not sell their services to people who actually are guilty.  For example, Paragraph 2 refers to lawyers who "represent even the vilest of clients…keeping the guilty free and unpunished in exchange for money and status."  However, the author also states that when attorneys "truly believe their clients are innocent, providing a defense is a noble undertaking" (Paragraph 6).  Therefore, the collective refusal the author advocates applies only to defendants who are probably guilty.  Accordingly, this refusal would be unlikely to cause more innocent people to be convicted.

text: A 1993 opinion of the D.C. Bar stated that in certain situations, a defense attorney who discovers their client intends to lie on the stand cannot choose to withdraw from the case.  How is this opinion most relevant to the information in the passage?
explanations:
It is worth distinguishing two senses of the word "ethical" here.  For there are standards of professional ethics to which any attorney must conform, including standards particular to the defense.  Most relevant to our purposes, a lawyer is obligated to provide their client with a "zealous defense."  In other words, once an attorney takes on a client, they are ethically bound to promote that client's rights, interests, or innocence—in fact, not to do so would be unethical.  Thus, one might try to suggest that this obligation undermines the claim that some defense attorneys act unethically. (Paragraph 3)
However, meeting that professional standard is not the same as being ethical in the general sense of the word….  Therefore, meeting one's obligations as a defense attorney does not necessarily make one ethical, because the choice to accept a specific case (and thus to incur those obligations in the first place) may itself be an unethical act. (Paragraph 4)
Part of the author's argument involves distinguishing between two types of ethics: one that is specific to a profession, and one that relates to a general sense of right and wrong.  Paragraph 3 discusses the first type, noting that there are "standards of professional ethics to which any attorney must conform."  For example, a defense attorney who represents a client is "ethically bound to promote that client's rights, interests, or innocence."
Paragraph 4 contrasts this obligation with the more general type of ethics.  A defense attorney who knows their client is guilty would still have a professional duty to defend that client.  However, it would be wrong overall if that defense was successful because the guilty client would escape justice.  Accordingly, the author asserts that "meeting that professional standard is not the same as being ethical in the general sense of the word."
Similarly, the question scenario illustrates this distinction between professional ethics and ethics in general.  In terms of right or wrong, attorneys may want to withdraw from a case when they know their client intends to lie.  However, the D.C. Bar opinion states that in certain situations, those lawyers may not do so—instead, they are obligated as lawyers to continue defending the lying client.  Therefore, this opinion exemplifies a tension between attorneys' professional obligations and ethics in general.
 (Choice A)  It shows that an attorney's motivations may be ethically indefensible.  Paragraph 6 states that it is "ethically indefensible" if a lawyer whose "overriding motivation is greed" defends a guilty client.  However, in the scenario described, the lawyer wants to withdraw from the case because they know their client plans to lie.  Therefore, the lawyer's motivations are to uphold the truth and not defend a guilty client, which is the opposite of the "indefensible" conduct the passage describes.
(Choice C)  It explains why reforms to the system must come from individual attorneys.  In Paragraph 6, the author writes that "the needed reforms to the system must come from individual attorneys committing to work for the right reasons."  However, in the D.C. Bar's opinion, a lawyer may not be allowed to withdraw from a case even if they discover their client is lying.  In that situation, an attorney would be attempting to act from the "right reasons" the author refers to, but would be prevented from doing so by the system itself.  Therefore, this opinion would not explain why reforms to the system must come from individual attorneys.
(Choice D)  It illustrates the effect of wealth and class disparities on defense attorney ethics.  According to Paragraph 5, "wealth and class contribute to injustice" because only the wealthy can afford to hire "top-level private lawyers."  However, the scenario described makes no reference to the wealth or class of the lawyer's client, only the fact that the client intends to lie.  Therefore, while the D.C. Bar's opinion does relate to defense attorney ethics, there is no indication that it relates to wealth and class disparities.

text: The claim that most people would easily view the hypothetical prosecutor as unethical is used to support the assertion that:
explanations:
Looking at this situation, most of us would easily judge the prosecutor as extremely unethical.  His conduct is outrageous and wrong—he clearly acted with corrupt intent, perpetrating injustice in order to profit financially.  Why is it not shocking, then, that we tolerate the mirror image of this behavior from defense attorneys?  For they engage in the same outrageous conduct, only on the other side.  Paid handsomely to represent even the vilest of clients, they apply their oratorical prowess to manipulating jury perception, keeping the guilty free and unpunished in exchange for money and status.  To the extent that this behavior takes place, are some defense attorneys as unethical as our hypothetical prosecutor? (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, most people would quickly agree that the hypothetical prosecutor is "extremely unethical" and that "[h]is conduct is outrageous and wrong."  The author then poses the rhetorical question: "Why is it not shocking, then, that we tolerate the mirror image of this behavior from defense attorneys?  For they engage in the same outrageous conduct, only on the other side."
By referencing "the same outrageous conduct," the author implies that people should judge some defense attorneys just as harshly as they would judge the hypothetical prosecutor.  Thus, the author conveys that it is "shocking" that people typically do not judge them that way but instead "tolerate the mirror image of this behavior" (Paragraph 2).
Consequently, the claim that most people would easily view the hypothetical prosecutor as unethical is used to support the assertion that it is strange that we accept the behavior of defense attorneys.
 (Choices A and C)  defense attorneys represent even the vilest of clients; and defense attorneys are mirror images of the hypothetical prosecutor.  Both of these answer choices get the author's argument backwards.  The author does not suggest that because the hypothetical prosecutor is unethical, some defense attorneys defend vile clients and act like the prosecutor's mirror image.  Rather, the author suggests that because some defense attorneys defend vile clients and act like the prosecutor's mirror image, those defense attorneys are as unethical as the prosecutor.
(Choice B)  prosecutors can be just as unethical as defense attorneys.  The passage describes a hypothetical scenario in which a prosecutor engages in "extremely unethical" conduct (Paragraph 2).  However, the author never suggests that any actual prosecutors engage in such conduct; rather, the scenario is designed to show that some real-life defense attorneys behave unethically.

text:
If statistics suggest that the effectiveness of a legal defense correlates positively with the expense of securing it, which of the following conclusions would be reasonable?
The most talented defense attorneys tend to be hired by private firms rather than government agencies.
Increasing the funding available to public defenders would give disadvantaged citizens more effective representation.
Highly paid lawyers face more professional obligations in taking on clients than lesser paid lawyers.
explanations:
Moreover, the role of court-appointed attorneys is to help protect the rights of citizens who cannot secure their own representation, usually for financial reasons.  Although preserving those rights is necessary to uphold justice, this situation highlights how wealth and class contribute to injustice.  While some defendants possess the means to hire top-level private lawyers, others must depend on public servants—frequently less experienced lawyers from overloaded, understaffed agencies.  As a result, the rich are more likely to escape conviction even when they are guilty, and the poor are more likely to be convicted even when they are innocent. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 5, wealthy people can afford "top-level private lawyers" while persons of lower income must turn to "public servants—frequently less experienced lawyers from overloaded, understaffed agencies."  Therefore, statistics suggesting that the effectiveness of a legal defense correlates positively with the expense of securing it would support the idea that most "top-level" lawyers work at private firms.  Consequently, it would be reasonable to conclude that the most talented defense attorneys tend to be hired by private firms rather than government agencies (Number I).
Paragraph 5 conveys that those who are financially disadvantaged "must depend on public servants" for legal representation.  However, these public servants are "frequently less experienced lawyers from overloaded, understaffed agencies."  Accordingly, the quality of that representation suffers: "the rich are more likely to escape conviction even when they are guilty, and the poor are more likely to be convicted even when they are innocent."
Therefore, if statistics suggest that the effectiveness of a legal defense correlates positively with the expense of securing it, that would mean that providing more resources to public servants would help them provide higher quality defenses.  Thus, it would be reasonable to conclude that increasing the funding available to public defenders would give disadvantaged citizens more effective representation (Number II).
 (Number III)  In Paragraph 4, the author notes that private attorneys can choose their clients, but public attorneys cannot: "With the exception of court-appointed attorneys or public defenders, who are assigned to provide representation to those who would otherwise lack it, an attorney is never required to represent a defendant."  Paragraph 5 then indicates that private attorneys are more highly paid, as they are hired by the wealthy while those of lesser means "must depend on public servants."
Accordingly, it would not be reasonable to conclude that highly paid lawyers face more professional obligations in taking on clients than lesser paid lawyers.  Rather, the opposite would be true: highly paid lawyers face fewer obligations in taking on clients because, unlike public servants, they are "never required to represent a defendant."

text: What does the passage suggest about higher education for women in the nineteenth century?
explanations:
There can be little doubt that Margaret Fuller embodied a new paradigm for women.  At a time when women were barred from higher education, she was arguably the best-read individual in New England and would become the first female public intellectual in the US. (Paragraph 1)
However, for Margaret—a child prodigy who was reading before the age of 4 and studying Latin under her father's stern but liberal-minded tutelage by 6—realizing her considerable potential would always come at a price….  From her earliest school days, Fuller's precocity provoked both awe and ridicule.  Later, when she demonstrated her irrepressible love of learning, she was accused of "flaunting her erudition in gratuitous digressions."  (Paragraph 2)
She taught at progressive New England schools before managing to support herself by leading discussion groups for women in Boston.  These seminars, or Socratic-style "Conversations," were meant to supplement the paltry educational opportunities for women by allowing them to explore their intellectual interests and stimulating them to think in new ways. (Paragraph 3)
The passage states that "women were barred from higher education" (Paragraph 1) during the nineteenth century and emphasizes how even for Fuller, advanced learning or "realizing her considerable potential would come at a price" as from early on it "provoked both awe and ridicule" from others (Paragraph 2).  However, Paragraph 3 then details the "seminars, or Socratic-style 'Conversations,'" led by Fuller and intended "to supplement the paltry (limited) educational opportunities for women by allowing them to explore their intellectual interests and stimulating them to think in new ways."
This information strongly suggests that nineteenth-century women who were interested in higher learning could sometimes find alternatives to the formal education from which they were excluded.  Consequently, the passage implies that, in the nineteenth century, some women had alternative opportunities for higher education.
 (Choice A) Few women considered higher education advantageous.  Paragraph 3 conveys how Fuller "manag[ed] to support herself by leading discussion groups for women in Boston."  These groups were "seminars, or Socratic-style 'Conversations'…meant to supplement the paltry educational opportunities for women" by encouraging them "to explore their intellectual interests and…think in new ways."  Because Fuller was able to support herself through these seminars, it is likely they were popular.  Accordingly, the passage suggests that more than a few women in the nineteenth century considered having some sort of higher education advantageous.
(Choice C) Higher education garnered women greater respect.  According to Paragraph 2, "[f]rom her earliest school days," Fuller's mature intellect "provoked both awe and ridicule."  Later, because of her impressive knowledge, she "was accused of 'flaunting her erudition in gratuitous digressions.'"  Accordingly, Fuller's learning sometimes elicited harsh reactions.  Therefore, the example of the extremely learned Margaret Fuller suggests that having higher education would not necessarily garner a nineteenth-century woman greater respect; in fact, it might have caused her to be perceived negatively.
(Choice D) Higher education constituted a realistic option only for upper-class women.  Paragraph 1 states that "women were barred from higher education" in Fuller's time.  Paragraph 3 describes Fuller's own seminars as "meant to supplement the paltry educational opportunities for women."  Furthermore, the passage never mentions upper-class women nor suggests that the educational restrictions imposed on women allowed for exceptions.  Therefore, the passage never indicates that formal higher education was a realistic option only for upper-class women.

text: If nineteenth-century society had embraced Fuller's ideas about gender, it would be reasonable to suppose that:
explanations:
In Woman, Fuller not only sounded the clarion call of social equality for women but also advocated for the rights of all human beings, regardless of gender or race.  A synthesis of classical mythology and German Romanticism led her to believe that the ideal person was a felicitous integration of male and female elements that perpetually flowed into one another.  Thus, although Fuller bemoaned male dominance, she felt it was incumbent upon women to embrace an Emersonian self-reliance and develop their "Minerva" or rational, warrior side rather than merely play the traditional part of supporting muse.  Likewise, she urged men to cultivate their "Apollo" or intuitive side.  Indeed, Fuller insisted that the well-being of society hinged on replacing the radically polarized model of the sexes with a more balanced one. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 5, "In Woman, Fuller…sounded the clarion call (ie, a clear summons to action) of social equality for women."  Fuller believed that "the ideal person was a felicitous (favorable) integration of male and female elements that perpetually flowed into one another."  She "bemoaned male dominance" but also thought women ought "to embrace an Emersonian self-reliance and develop their 'Minerva' or rational, warrior side."  In particular, she thought that women should avoid "merely play[ing] the traditional part of supporting muse."  Furthermore, Fuller "insisted that the well-being of society hinged on replacing the radically polarized model of the sexes with a more balanced one."
Consequently, Fuller believed that women should become more independent and that the polarization of the sexes should be moderated accordingly.  Therefore, if nineteenth-century society had embraced Fuller's ideas about gender, it would be reasonable to suppose that, as females became more independent, women would have sought more autonomy within marriage.
 (Choices A and D) independent women would have more often be considered misfits; and many more women would have moved from nonconformist to traditional roles.  According to Paragraph 2, "Although nonconformity, freedom, and self-development were the prevailing watchwords of Transcendentalism, Fuller was nevertheless stigmatized for exhibiting what some perceived to be 'the bravado (boldness) of a misfit' and many deemed 'an unwomanly arrogance.'"  However, in Fuller's view, "the ideal person was a felicitous integration of male and female elements that perpetually flowed into one another" (Paragraph 5).  Hence, Fuller encouraged women "to embrace an Emersonian self-reliance and develop their 'Minerva' or rational, warrior side rather than merely play the traditional part of supporting muse."
Accordingly, if nineteenth-century society had embraced Fuller's ideas about gender, independent women would not have been considered misfits.  Furthermore, it would be reasonable to suppose that instead of just filling traditional roles, many more women might have moved into roles that previously would have been considered nonconformist.
(Choice B) fewer men would have autonomy within marriage.  Paragraph 5 states that "In Woman, Fuller not only sounded the clarion call of social equality for women but also advocated for the rights of all human beings, regardless of gender or race."  Accordingly, although "Fuller bemoaned male dominance," she believed that it is up to women themselves to become autonomous "rather than merely play the traditional part of supporting muse."  In Fuller's view, "the well-being of society hinged on replacing the radically polarized model of the sexes with a more balanced one."  Consequently, embracing Fuller's ideas about gender would not mean that the number of men having autonomy within marriage would decrease, but rather that the number of women having autonomy within marriage would increase.

text: In the twentieth century, Swiss psychologist Carl Jung maintained that, to become well-balanced individuals, women must develop the masculine aspect in their psyche he called the animus, and men the feminine aspect or anima.  The parallels between Jung's ideas and Fuller's could be due to any of the following EXCEPT:
explanations:
Having earned the admiration of the eminent Ralph Waldo Emerson, Fuller penetrated the inner circle of the highly influential but short-lived sociophilosophical movement known as Transcendentalism, where her talents found an outlet.  An integral part of both nineteenth-century social reforms and the literary renaissance that bred Hawthorne and Dickinson, Fuller became deeply woven into the fabric of American history. (Paragraph 1)
Her emancipatory tract Woman in the Nineteenth Century was an instant bestseller in 1845. (Paragraph 4)
…[S]he perished in a shipwreck off the New York coast on returning from Italy in 1850. (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 1, Fuller was "[a]n integral part of both nineteenth-century social reforms and the literary renaissance" of the time and would become "deeply woven into the fabric of American history."  Paragraph 4 notes that Fuller's treatise Woman in the Nineteenth Century "was an instant bestseller in 1845," while Paragraph 6 conveys that Fuller "perished in a shipwreck…in 1850."
These dates situate Fuller firmly in the first half of the nineteenth century.  Because Carl Jung is described as maintaining his theories about gender in the twentieth century, his ideas could not have influenced Fuller's.  Therefore, the parallels between Jung's ideas and Fuller's could not have been due to Jung's impact on Fuller.
 (Choice A) Fuller's impact on Jung.  Paragraph 4 describes Fuller's Woman in the Nineteenth Century as "an instant bestseller in 1845."  Furthermore, as noted in Paragraph 1, Fuller was an active member of both "the inner circle of the highly influential…sociophilosophical movement known as Transcendentalism" and the "literary renaissance" in America, so her ideas could have been transmitted through transcendentalist texts.  Accordingly, Fuller's theories were well known prior to the twentieth century in which Jung was writing.  Therefore, the parallels between Jung's and Fuller's ideas about gender could have been due to Fuller's impact on Jung.
(Choices C and D) Fuller's impact on Transcendentalism; and Transcendentalism's impact on Jung.  According to Paragraph 1, Fuller won "the admiration of the eminent Ralph Waldo Emerson" and "penetrated the inner circle of the highly influential but short-lived sociophilosophical movement known as Transcendentalism, where her talents found an outlet."  Fuller is also described as "[a]n integral part of…the literary renaissance."  Later, as noted in Paragraph 3, "Emerson made Fuller the inaugural (first) editor of the transcendentalist magazine The Dial."  Thus, Fuller clearly contributed to the nineteenth-century phenomenon of Transcendentalism and its textual output.  Therefore, any similarity between Jung's and Fuller's ideas could have been due to Fuller's impact on Transcendentalism or to Transcendentalism's influence on Jung in the twentieth century.

text: If the passage demonstrates that new paradigms for women in the nineteenth century broke down traditional barriers, then one can reasonably conclude that:
explanations:
There can be little doubt that Margaret Fuller embodied a new paradigm for women.  At a time when women were barred from higher education, she was arguably the best-read individual in New England and would become the first female public intellectual in the US. (Paragraph 1)
She taught at progressive…schools before managing to support herself by leading discussion groups for women in Boston.  These seminars, or Socratic-style "Conversations," were meant to supplement the paltry educational opportunities for women by allowing them to explore their intellectual interests and stimulating them to think in new ways.  In 1844, Emerson made Fuller the inaugural editor of the transcendentalist magazine The Dial.
