For instance, "[w]hile ballet was made to appear effortless, Graham's main goal as a choreographer was to display the physical exertion of articulating (expressing) emotion through the body's movement."  Consequently, the passage description of the "Graham technique" of dance largely reveals that liberating (freeing) dance from ballet conventions featured overt (unconcealed) indications of physical effort.
By contrast, the description of the "Graham technique" of dance does not reveal that
lingering prejudices were a hindrance to the development of new dance techniques (Choice B).  Paragraph 1 states that initially dancers had to "break through the prejudice of tradition" in order to establish new dance techniques.  However, the description in Paragraph 3 does not indicate that such prejudices hindered the later development of the "Graham technique."  Moreover, Paragraph 3 claims that "contraction became a regular feature of modern dance."
emphasizing the connection between the professional dancer and the audience was essential (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 states that "the 'Graham technique' originated from her cardinal belief that movement expresses the emotions that people attempt to conceal and words are inadequate to express."  However, the passage never implies that performing the technique requires establishing any connection with the audience.
highlighting sociopolitical issues in modern dance had become increasingly common (Choice D).  Paragraph 2 explains that "by dramatizing events on stage to inspire a collective emotional response, dance became a vehicle designed to spur sociopolitical change" in the early 20th century.  However, the description of the "Graham technique" in Paragraph 3 never connects the technique with sociopolitical issues.

text: Graham's contention that movement expresses the emotions that people attempt to conceal and words are inadequate to express is:
explanations:
Martha Graham…develop[ed] a radical new system of movement.  The "Graham technique" originated from her cardinal belief that movement expresses the emotions that people attempt to conceal and words are inadequate to express.  The new technique was organic; based on the natural rhythm of breathing, it exaggerated the muscular contraction and release, as well as the consequent flexion of the spine, required to breathe.  The visual effects were startling, and the iconoclastic Graham went so far as to assert that the technique "represented the human being's inner conflicts." (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, Martha Graham "develop[ed] a radical new system of movement."  The resulting "'Graham technique' originated from her cardinal belief that movement expresses the emotions that people attempt to conceal and words are inadequate to express."
Paragraph 3 then describes the physical aspects of the "Graham technique" as "organic," "based on the natural rhythm of breathing," and as exaggerating "the muscular contraction and release, as well as the consequent flexion of the spine required to breathe."  Paragraph 3 also states that Graham "went so far as to assert that the technique 'represented the human being's inner conflicts.'"  However, the passage never explains Graham's contention that movement expresses the emotions that people attempt to conceal and words are inadequate to express.
By contrast, Graham's contention is not:
exemplified by scenes from Appalachian Spring discussed in the passage (Choice A).  Paragraph 5 mentions Graham's "modern 'ballet' Appalachian Spring"; however, the passage never discusses specific scenes from this work.
undermined by additional details provided in the passage (Choice B).  Paragraph 3 describes the "Graham technique" as "based on the natural rhythm of breathing" and exaggerating "the muscular contraction and release, as well as the consequent flexion of the spine, required to breathe."  However, the passage provides no additional details about the technique that would serve to undermine (ie, challenge) Graham's contention that movement expresses the emotions that people attempt to conceal and words are inadequate to express.
diminished by her desire to create holistic works (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 6, "Graham also strove to make the works she created and choreographed holistic."   Paragraph 6 then explains that Graham "collaborated with sculptor Isamu Noguchi on stage sets, consulted with the designer Halston on costumes, and partnered with composers, such as Louis Horst and Samuel Barber" in order to achieve her aim.  Accordingly, these collaborative efforts had to do with the presentation of the performance and not with whether the physical dance technique expressed concealed emotion.

text: Based on passage information, the prime objective of modern dance is most probably:
explanations:
In the 1890s…a group of pioneering dancers dared to challenge the rigid 350-year-old protocols of classical ballet.  The likes of Isadora Duncan, Loie Fuller, and Ruth St. Denis rebelled against ballet tradition while simultaneously rejecting the alternative world of vaudeville.  Duncan, in particular, was a proponent of what was deemed "uninhibited freedom of movement"…[S]he performed natural, flowing movements she claimed "emanated from her solar plexus."  For her part, Fuller combined billowing costumes, dramatic lighting, and improvised movements in attempting to imitate natural phenomena, as exemplified by her "serpentine" dance. (Paragraph 1)
The second generation of artists, which included Doris Humphrey and Lester Horton, continued to loosen dance from the restraints of classical ballet. (Paragraph 2)
Martha Graham, a student of St. Denis and Shawn, went on to develop a radical new system of movement…The new technique was organic; based on the natural rhythm of breathing, it exaggerated the muscular contraction and release, as well as the consequent flexion of the spine, required to breathe. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 1 states that "dancers…rebelled against ballet tradition while simultaneously rejecting the alternative world of vaudeville and that Duncan…was a proponent of…'uninhibited freedom of movement.'"  Paragraph 1 further specifies that Duncan "performed natural, flowing movements she claimed 'emanated from her solar plexus (the central area of the abdomen below the rib cage).'"  Meanwhile, Fuller used "improvised movements in attempting to imitate natural phenomena," and St. Denis and Ted Shawn "incorporated elements of Native American and East Asian ritualistic dance into their work."
Paragraph 2 then explains that "[t]he second generation of artists…continued to loosen dance from the restraints of classical ballet."  As Paragraph 3 details, "Martha Graham…went on to develop a radical new system of movement," one that was not only "organic" and "based on the natural rhythm of breathing," but that sought "to display the physical exertion of articulating emotion through the body's movement."
Therefore, the prime objective of modern dance is most probably to facilitate a broader range of physical expression.
By contrast, passage information does not suggest that the prime objective of modern dance is:
to depict current sociopolitical controversies before audiences (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 2, "the second generation of artists…were also determined to raise the audience's consciousness about contemporary social concerns."  More specifically, "[f]or a while…by dramatizing events on stage to inspire a collective emotional response, dance became a vehicle designed to spur sociopolitical change" (Paragraph 2).  Consequently, depicting current sociopolitical controversies before audiences was at one time an important objective of modern dance; however, it was not the prime objective nor even an enduring aim.
to allow dancers to perform nonlinear movements on stage (Choice C).  Paragraph 4 states that "[a]s modern dance evolved, it became the antithesis (opposite) of ballet" and that "the choreography featured nonlinear movements."  Therefore, allowing dancers to perform nonlinear movements on stage was an aim of modern dance, but the passage never suggests that it was the prime objective.
to enable dancers to convey their personalities through movement (Choice D).  According to the passage, modern dancers "managed to break through the prejudice of tradition" (Paragraph 1) to create new styles of movement that were often distinctive, such as Fuller's "serpentine" dance or the "Graham technique" (Paragraph 3).  However, the passage never indicates that the aim of such techniques or of modern dance was to enable dancers to convey their particular personalities.

text: Which of the following claims about the characters of Candide and Zadig is NOT implied by the passage argument?
explanations:
Given this understanding, those who see Voltaire through the lens of Candide would likely be shocked to read another of his works, Zadig.  The stories are similar in that both title characters experience a long series of undeserved evils.  However, whereas Candide moves from believing in Pangloss' worldview to eventually rejecting it, Zadig's lesson seems to be the exact opposite. (Paragraph 2)
That assessment is fitting not only in Zadig's case but also in that of Candide and his companions, who are repeatedly the victims of other people's greed, selfishness, and violence….  Both tales, then, are best understood as a commentary not on the callousness of providence, but on the heartlessness of humanity. (Paragraph 5)
According to the passage author, both Candide and Zadig suffer through no fault of their own.  For instance, Paragraph 2 states that their "stories are similar in that both title characters experience a long series of undeserved evils."  Paragraph 5 expands on this point, describing how "not only in Zadig's case but also in that of Candide and his companions," the characters "are repeatedly the victims of other people's greed, selfishness, and violence."
Thus, by describing the two characters as "victims" subjected to "undeserved evils," the passage indicates that neither Candide nor Zadig is responsible for causing the misfortunes he experiences.  Consequently, the passage does not imply that Candide and Zadig are to blame for their own suffering.
  (Choices A and B)  Both Candide and Zadig are given explanations for the existence of evil; and Both Candide and Zadig come to revise their views of the world.  One of the author's comparisons between Candide and Zadig concerns the justifications each character is given for the evils they encounter.  Paragraph 1 states that in Candide, Dr. Pangloss "offers many supposed proofs that all events 'must necessarily be for the best end.'"  These arguments explain how the characters' "horrible and comically absurd misfortunes" are part of a world that is "ordered to produce the greatest good."  Paragraph 2 describes a similar situation in Zadig: "Convinced of the unfair cruelty of life, Zadig is visited by the angel Jesrad, who justifies many of the apparent tragedies Zadig has witnessed."  According to Jesrad, "[E]verything that occurs 'ought to be, in its proper time and place.'"
In addition, Paragraph 2 relates how each character changes with regard to these ideas, stating: "[B]oth title characters experience a long series of undeserved evils.  However, whereas Candide moves from believing in Pangloss' worldview to eventually rejecting it, Zadig's lesson seems to be the exact opposite."  Therefore, the passage implies that Candide and Zadig both receive explanations for the existence of evil, and both come to revise their views about the world.
(Choice D)  Both Candide and Zadig face misfortunes inspired by Voltaire's own life.  According to Paragraph 3, "Candide was written long after Zadig, near the end of a career in which Voltaire faced frequent difficulties of his own….  Although the writer's hardships never approached the severity of those visited upon his characters, it is easy to imagine them influencing both his outlook and his stories."  Therefore, the passage implies that Voltaire most likely based some of Candide's and Zadig's misfortunes on events from his own life.

text:
Based on the passage, one can most reasonably conclude that Voltaire:
received popular acclaim but political backlash.
struggled to find an audience for his writing.
viewed human suffering as ultimately unexplainable.
explanations:
Candide was written long after Zadig, near the end of a career in which Voltaire faced frequent difficulties of his own.  The satirizing and free-thinking that made his novels so popular with readers were not always appreciated by other aristocrats or monarchs, and Voltaire found it necessary to move from city to city throughout Europe.  Although the writer's hardships never approached the severity of those visited upon his characters, it is easy to imagine them influencing both his outlook and his stories. (Paragraph 3)
The passage conveys that Voltaire experienced both success and hostility as a result of his writing.  According to Paragraph 3, "The satirizing and free-thinking that made his novels so popular with readers were not always appreciated by other aristocrats or monarchs, and Voltaire found it necessary to move from city to city throughout Europe."  Therefore, the passage indicates that although Voltaire's novels were well liked by many people, they also offended those in positions of power, causing him to experience "hardships."  In other words, Voltaire received popular acclaim but political backlash (Number I).
  (Number II)  struggled to find an audience for his writing.  Paragraph 3 describes the "satirizing and free-thinking that made [Voltaire's] novels so popular with readers."  Therefore, the passage does not indicate that Voltaire struggled to find an audience for his writing, but that Voltaire's works were read and enjoyed by many.
(Number III)  viewed human suffering as ultimately unexplainable.  Paragraph 5 describes how "other people's greed, selfishness, and violence" cause Candide and Zadig to suffer, noting that "[b]oth tales, then, are best understood as a commentary…on the heartlessness of humanity."  The passage concludes with the assertion that "in Voltaire's estimation, it is people's wickedness that truly fills the world with misery."  Consequently, the passage portrays Voltaire as attributing human suffering to people's immoral actions; it does not suggest that Voltaire viewed human suffering as ultimately unexplainable.

text: Which of the following best describes how the passage author treats the idea that the differences between the stories of Zadig and Candide might reflect changes in Voltaire's own outlook over time?
explanations:
Candide was written long after Zadig, near the end of a career in which Voltaire faced frequent difficulties of his own….  Although the writer's hardships never approached the severity of those visited upon his characters, it is easy to imagine them influencing both his outlook and his stories.  A fairly straightforward conclusion would be that Zadig reflects a younger and more optimistic Voltaire, while Candide expresses the more cynical sentiments of a man grown frustrated at the world's ignorance and persecution. (Paragraph 3)
However, there is another way to view the two works….  Jesrad explains: "The wicked…are always unhappy.  They serve to prove and try the small number of the just that are scattered throughout the earth."  Thus, the angel implies that human cruelty is to blame for most of the unhappiness in the world. (Paragraph 4)
That assessment is fitting not only in Zadig's case but also in that of Candide and his companions, who are repeatedly the victims of other people's greed, selfishness, and violence….  Both tales, then, are best understood as a commentary not on the callousness of providence, but on the heartlessness of humanity.  Life is replete with pointless suffering, even if some misfortune could potentially serve a greater purpose.  But in Voltaire's estimation, it is people's wickedness that truly fills the world with misery. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 3 mentions that "Voltaire faced frequent difficulties" throughout his career, and the author asserts that "it is easy to imagine [those difficulties] influencing both his outlook and his stories."  In particular, this influence could plausibly explain why Zadig and Candide seem to present very different messages about suffering.  According to the author, a "fairly straightforward conclusion" would be that Voltaire's view changed over time, such that "Zadig reflects a younger and more optimistic Voltaire, while Candide expresses the more cynical sentiments of a man grown frustrated at the world's ignorance and persecution."
However, although the author considers that view reasonable, he or she ultimately favors a different interpretation.  Paragraph 4 states that "there is another way to view the two works," based on a consistent theme that "human cruelty is to blame for most of the unhappiness in the world."  According to Paragraph 5, "That assessment is fitting not only in Zadig's case but also in that of Candide and his companions, who are repeatedly the victims of other people's greed, selfishness, and violence."  Thus, the passage author argues that, despite the apparent differences between the two stories, both of them "are best understood as a commentary…on the heartlessness of humanity."
Therefore, although the passage author considers the possibility that the differences between the novels might reflect changes in Voltaire's own outlook over time, he or she treats this idea as less convincing than an alternative analysis of the stories.
  (Choice A)  The passage author treats this idea as an implausible explanation of the stories' differences.  Paragraph 3 states that "[a]lthough [Voltaire's] hardships never approached the severity of those visited upon his characters, it is easy to imagine them influencing both his outlook and his stories."  The passage author then mentions the "fairly straightforward conclusion" that Zadig and Candide reflect changes in Voltaire's outlook over time.  Accordingly, he or she depicts this idea as a reasonable interpretation, despite going on to argue that "there is another way to view the two works" (Paragraph 4).
(Choice B)  The passage author treats this idea as uninformed by historical evidence.  According to Paragraph 3, Voltaire's "satirizing and free-thinking…were not always appreciated by other aristocrats or monarchs, and Voltaire found it necessary to move from city to city throughout Europe."  Therefore, the passage author portrays the idea of "the writer's hardships...influencing both his outlook and his stories" as partially based on historical evidence about Voltaire's life.
(Choice D)  The passage author treats this idea as overlooking the role of satire in the stories.  Paragraph 1 discusses "Candide, which satirizes…18th-century Europe" and in which "the novel's characters endure a constant succession of horrible and comically absurd misfortunes."  Paragraph 3 later mentions that "Candide was written long after Zadig."  Consequently, the possibility that "Zadig reflects a younger and more optimistic Voltaire, while Candide expresses the more cynical sentiments of a man grown frustrated at the world's ignorance and persecution" (Paragraph 3) is connected to Voltaire's use of satire in depicting his characters' suffering.

text: The passage author most likely mentions that Dr. Pangloss teaches "metaphysico-theologo-cosmolonigology" (Paragraph 1) in order to:
explanations:
Voltaire's most famous work is undoubtedly Candide, which satirizes both 18th-century Europe and the philosophy of Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz.  In particular, the character of Dr. Pangloss (who teaches "metaphysico-theologo-cosmolonigology") parodies Leibniz's view that this is the best of all possible worlds.  While Pangloss offers many supposed proofs that all events "must necessarily be for the best end," the novel's characters endure a constant succession of horrible and comically absurd misfortunes. (Paragraph 1)
According to Paragraph 1, Voltaire's work Candide "satirizes…the philosophy of Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz.  In particular, the character of Dr. Pangloss (who teaches 'metaphysico-theologo-cosmolonigology') parodies Leibniz's view that this is the best of all possible worlds."  By highlighting the over-the-top and silly-sounding portrayal of Pangloss' subject matter, the passage author illustrates a way in which Voltaire holds Leibniz's ideas up for ridicule.  Accordingly, the passage author most likely mentions that Dr. Pangloss teaches "metaphysico-theologo-cosmolonigology" in order to emphasize that the view Pangloss represents is depicted as absurd.
  (Choice A)  suggest a common theme between Candide and Voltaire's other satires.  Paragraph 1 discusses "Candide, which satirizes both 18th-century Europe and the philosophy of Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz."  One part of that satire involves a mocking description of "the character of Dr. Pangloss (who teaches 'metaphysico-theologo-cosmolonigology')."  However, the passage author never discusses whether the presence of such descriptions is a common theme of Voltaire's other satires.
(Choice B)  foreshadow a contrast between the views of Pangloss and Jesrad.  According to Paragraph 1, "Pangloss offers many supposed proofs that all events 'must necessarily be for the best end.'"  Paragraph 2 later describes how "Zadig is visited by the angel Jesrad, who justifies many of the apparent tragedies Zadig has witnessed."  For example, "[t]he man whose house burned down found a hidden treasure beneath it."  Therefore, the passage author does not draw a contrast between the views of Pangloss and Jesrad; rather, both characters maintain that every event is part of a plan for the greater good.
(Choice C)  illustrate the importance of Leibniz's philosophical position.  According to Paragraph 1, "Dr. Pangloss (who teaches 'metaphysico-theologo-cosmolonigology') parodies Leibniz's view that this is the best of all possible worlds."  The passage author notes that "[w]hile Pangloss offers many supposed proofs that all events 'must necessarily be for the best end,' the novel's characters endure a constant succession of horrible and comically absurd misfortunes."  Therefore, the passage author's mention of Pangloss' subject matter is not meant to depict the importance of Leibniz's philosophical position; rather, it serves to illustrate how Voltaire mocked that position in his novel.

text: Which of the following would be the best example of the passage author's claim that, in Voltaire's stories, humankind is portrayed as the cause of most of the suffering in the world?
explanations:
Given this understanding, those who see Voltaire through the lens of Candide would likely be shocked to read another of his works, Zadig.  The stories are similar in that both title characters experience a long series of undeserved evils. (Paragraph 2)
On several occasions, Zadig laments that he has been punished for doing what is right: "Knowledge, virtue, and courage, have hitherto served only to make me miserable."  While he never wavers from righteousness, he does question why evils befall those who do not deserve them.  Jesrad explains: "The wicked…are always unhappy.  They serve to prove and try the small number of the just that are scattered throughout the earth."  Thus, the angel implies that human cruelty is to blame for most of the unhappiness in the world. (Paragraph 4)
That assessment is fitting not only in Zadig's case but also in that of Candide and his companions, who are repeatedly the victims of other people's greed, selfishness, and violence….  Life is replete with pointless suffering, even if some misfortune could potentially serve a greater purpose.  But in Voltaire's estimation, it is people's wickedness that truly fills the world with misery. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 2, both Candide and Zadig suffer through no fault of their own, as "both title characters experience a long series of undeserved evils."  The passage author further suggests that most of this suffering is deliberately caused by other people.  For instance, Paragraph 4 cites Zadig's question of "why evils befall those who do not deserve them."  In response, the angel Jesrad explains: "'The wicked…serve to prove (test) and try the small number of the just that are scattered throughout the earth.'"  Thus, the story conveys the view that human beings cruelly cause each other to suffer.
Paragraph 5 describes this view as accurate "not only in Zadig's case but also in that of Candide and his companions, who are repeatedly the victims of other people's greed, selfishness, and violence."  The passage concludes that "in Voltaire's estimation, it is people's wickedness that truly fills the world with misery."  Therefore, according to the passage author, Voltaire portrayed most suffering as resulting from people's immoral intentions to harm each other.
Consequently, the best example of this claim would be a story in which a man loses his freedom when his country is destroyed by invaders.  In this case, the man's suffering is caused by the harmful actions of other human beings.
  By contrast, none of the following examples represent suffering that is caused by a person's choice to harm others:
A man loses his possessions when a storm sinks the ship carrying them (Choice B).  In this case, the man's suffering is caused by a natural disaster, not another person intentionally causing him harm.
A man loses most of his pack animals when he takes them on a dangerous journey (Choice C).  This description does not indicate that the man embarks on the journey due to someone else's harmful intentions.
A man loses faith in a woman's love when he learns misleading information about her (Choice D).  The suffering in this case results from a mistake or misunderstanding; there is no suggestion that someone has intentionally caused harm to the couple.

text: The claim that Candide is Voltaire's most famous work is:
explanations:
Voltaire's most famous work is undoubtedly Candide, which satirizes both 18th-century Europe and the philosophy of Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz.  In particular, the character of Dr. Pangloss (who teaches "metaphysico-theologo-cosmolonigology") parodies Leibniz's view that this is the best of all possible worlds.  While Pangloss offers many supposed proofs that all events "must necessarily be for the best end," the novel's characters endure a constant succession of horrible and comically absurd misfortunes. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 begins with the claim that "Voltaire's most famous work is undoubtedly Candide."  However, although the passage author discusses various details of the story, he or she provides no further information to justify the assertion that it is Voltaire's most famous work.  Therefore, that claim is presented without the inclusion of supporting evidence.
  (Choice A)  supported by readers' surprise at the content of Zadig.  Paragraph 2 asserts that "those who see Voltaire through the lens of Candide would likely be shocked to read another of his works, Zadig," because the two stories appear to have contradictory messages.  Specifically, "whereas Candide moves from believing in Pangloss' worldview to eventually rejecting it, Zadig's lesson seems to be the exact opposite."  Therefore, the claim that readers might be surprised by the content of Zadig is based on its seeming divergence from Candide.  However, this claim does not depend on how well known or obscure each of the works may be.  For instance, even if Zadig were Voltaire's most famous work, its content might surprise readers who had read Candide first.
(Choice C)  in tension with the claim that Voltaire's works convey similar messages.  The statement that "Voltaire's most famous work is undoubtedly Candide" (Paragraph 1) might be true (or false) regardless of whether Voltaire's works convey similar messages.  For example, the author's claim that Candide and Zadig "are similar in that both title characters experience a long series of undeserved evils" (Paragraph 2) depends on the contents of those stories, not on the number of people who have read them.  Therefore, these claims are not in tension with each other.
(Choice D)  justified by the relative obscurity of Voltaire's other writings.  Although Paragraph 1 states that "Voltaire's most famous work is undoubtedly Candide," the passage never discusses how well known Voltaire's other works may be.  Likewise, the passage never suggests that Voltaire's other works are obscure.

text: Which of the following quotes cited in the passage LEAST supports the passage author's argument?
explanations:
While Pangloss offers many supposed proofs that all events "must necessarily be for the best end," the novel's characters endure a constant succession of horrible and comically absurd misfortunes.  Voltaire's clear message is that life—far from being ordered to produce the greatest good—is full of unnecessary suffering. (Paragraph 1)
Convinced of the unfair cruelty of life, Zadig is visited by the angel Jesrad, who justifies many of the apparent tragedies Zadig has witnessed….  Thus, Jesrad explains, "Men…judge of all without knowing anything," but everything that occurs "ought to be, in its proper time and place, according to the immutable decrees of him who comprehends all." (Paragraph 2)
Jesrad explains: "The wicked…are always unhappy.  They serve to prove and try the small number of the just that are scattered throughout the earth."  Thus, the angel implies that human cruelty is to blame for most of the unhappiness in the world. (Paragraph 4)
That assessment is fitting not only in Zadig's case but also in that of Candide and his companions, who are repeatedly the victims of other people's greed, selfishness, and violence….  Both tales, then, are best understood as a commentary not on the callousness of providence, but on the heartlessness of humanity.  Life is replete with pointless suffering, even if some misfortune could potentially serve a greater purpose.  But in Voltaire's estimation, it is people's wickedness that truly fills the world with misery. (Paragraph 5)
According to the passage author, both Candide and Zadig portray the world as filled with pointless evil.  Paragraph 1 states that "Voltaire's clear message [in Candide] is that life—far from being ordered to produce the greatest good—is full of unnecessary suffering."  Paragraph 4 then suggests that a similar sentiment can be found in Zadig, which attributes such suffering to humanity's immoral choices: "Thus, the angel implies that human cruelty is to blame for most of the unhappiness in the world."
Paragraph 5 reinforces this assertion, calling it "fitting not only in Zadig's case but also in that of Candide and his companions, who are repeatedly the victims of other people's greed, selfishness, and violence."  Thus, the passage author argues that both works illustrate the theme that "[l]ife is replete (filled) with pointless suffering."  He or she concludes that "in Voltaire's estimation, it is people's wickedness that truly fills the world with misery."  Therefore, the passage author interprets both Zadig and Candide as implying that human immorality causes extensive evil that does not lead to any greater good.
However, the quote "Men…judge of all without knowing anything" appears in the context of the angel Jesrad "[justifying] many of the apparent tragedies Zadig has witnessed" (Paragraph 2).  In this way, Jesrad explains how what appeared to be evil ultimately led to greater good.  Thus, by stating that humans make judgments "without knowing anything," the angel casts doubt on the idea that seemingly evil events truly constitute pointless suffering.  Instead, the quote suggests that the suffering serves a greater purpose, aligning with Pangloss' view that "all events 'must necessarily be for the best end'" (Paragraph 1).  Consequently, the passage author's argument is least supported by this quote.
  By contrast, the passage author's argument is more supported by each of the following quotes:
"The wicked…are always unhappy" (Paragraph 4) (Choice B).  This quote suggests that wickedness leads to unhappiness.  Thus, it aligns with the author's interpretation of Zadig as illustrating that "human cruelty is to blame for most of the unhappiness in the world" (Paragraph 4).
"There are a "small number of the just that are scattered throughout the earth" (Paragraph 4) (Choice C).  By conveying that there are only a small number of just people on earth, this quote implies that the majority of human beings are immoral in their dealings with others.  Accordingly, this sentiment is consistent with the author's claims that Voltaire's works "are best understood as a commentary…on the heartlessness of humanity" and that "in Voltaire's estimation, it is people's wickedness that truly fills the world with misery" (Paragraph 5).
"Mankind…were not born wolves, and yet they have become wolves" (Paragraph 5) (Choice D).  The passage author argues that both Candide and Zadig "are best understood as a commentary not on the callousness of providence (divine will), but on the heartlessness of humanity" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, this quote from Candide accords with that view by suggesting that humans have chosen to corrupt themselves.

text:
Which of the following individuals took actions that contributed to President Garfield's eventual death from infection?
Dr. Willard Bliss
Alexander Graham Bell
Charles Guiteau
explanations:
Thus it was that on July 2, 1881, Charles Guiteau could simply walk up to President James A. Garfield and shoot him in broad daylight. (Paragraph 1)
Although Guiteau's bullet would ultimately dim this light for Garfield, the president actually survived the initial attack and for a time appeared headed for recovery.  Tragically, however, the hubris shown by his main physician, Dr. Willard Bliss, would lead instead to weeks of prolonged suffering.  None of the doctors who examined Garfield were able to locate the bullet, and its lingering presence—along with the unwashed hands of the doctors who probed for it—led to an infection. (Paragraph 3)
However, other historians suggest that Dr. Bliss, unwilling to consider challenges to his original assessment, prevented Bell from more thoroughly searching the president's body.  Certainly, Bliss ignored the advice and protestations of other physicians, even as Garfield continued to decline.  With death imminent, Garfield asked to be taken to his seaside cottage, where he died on the 19th of September. (Paragraph 4)
According to the passage, there is a good chance that Garfield would not have died if his primary doctor had acted differently.  Paragraph 3 states that "the president actually survived the initial attack and for a time appeared headed for recovery.  Tragically, however, the hubris (destructive pride) shown by his main physician, Dr. Willard Bliss, would lead instead to weeks of prolonged suffering."  Paragraph 4 adds that Dr. Bliss may have "prevented Bell from more thoroughly searching the president's body" for the bullet, and furthermore states that "Bliss ignored the advice and protestations of other physicians, even as Garfield continued to decline."  Therefore, the passage conveys that the actions of Dr. Willard Bliss contributed to President Garfield's eventual death from infection (Number I).
Paragraph 1 describes how "on July 2, 1881, Charles Guiteau could simply walk up to President James A. Garfield and shoot him in broad daylight."  Although Garfield did not die immediately, Guiteau's "bullet, and its lingering presence…led to an infection" (Paragraph 3).  As a result, the president ultimately "died on the 19th of September" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, the passage indicates that the actions of Charles Guiteau contributed to President Garfield's eventual death from infection (Number III).
 (Number II)  Alexander Graham Bell.  According to Paragraph 3, inventor Alexander Graham Bell tried to assist in Garfield's recovery.  By "attempt[ing] to adapt his patented telephone technology to locate foreign metal in the human body," Bell hoped to "isolate the site of the bullet" and thus enable Garfield's doctors to remove it.  Although Paragraph 4 states that "Bell's searches were unsuccessful," this fact shows only that Bell was unable to help save the president.  The passage never suggests that Bell's actions contributed to President Garfield's eventual death from infection.

text: The Republican convention of 1880 required 36 separate rounds of voting over the course of three days before the delegates were finally able to agree on a presidential candidate.  This information most strongly supports which of the following passage claims?
explanations:
While serving in the war he was nominated for the House of Representatives but accepted the seat only after President Lincoln declared that the country had more need of him as a congressman than a general.  The reluctant politician would later himself become president under similar circumstances, after multiple factions of a deadlocked Republican convention unexpectedly nominated him instead of their original candidates in 1880. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, Garfield would "become president…after multiple factions (competing sides) of a deadlocked Republican convention unexpectedly nominated him instead of their original candidates in 1880."  The additional information that this convention required dozens of rounds of voting over multiple days illustrates that the delegates were in conflict and could not come to a consensus.  Therefore, this information strongly supports the passage claim that Garfield's nomination was a compromise to resolve a deadlock.
 By contrast, the additional information about the 1880 Republican convention provides less support for the following claims, which go beyond the occurrence of the deadlock to speculating about its cause:
Some members of the Republican Party were engaged in corrupt politics (Choice A).  The author describes Garfield as "[a]n honest man who opposed corruption within the party."  However, the passage never suggests that party corruption was the root cause of the "deadlocked Republican convention" (Paragraph 2).
Some Republicans were disgruntled with the state of the party (Choice C).  Paragraph 1 cites Menke's description that Charles Guiteau "'had come to identify with a disgruntled (dissatisfied or aggrieved) wing of the Republican Party after his deranged fantasies of winning a post from the new administration had come to nothing.'"  Accordingly, the passage refers to "a disgruntled wing of the Republican Party" in the time after Garfield had been elected.  However, it does not discuss whether that wing of the party had been dissatisfied previously or had contributed to the deadlock at the nominating convention.
America still suffered from the lingering divisions of the Civil War (Choice D).  Paragraph 2 implies that the effects of the Civil War were still being felt, as "Garfield strove both to heal the fractures of the Civil War and to uphold the aims for which it was fought."  However, the passage never specifies whether those fractures were the reason why convention delegates were deadlocked and unexpectedly nominated Garfield.

text: The author's description of Charles Guiteau (Paragraph 1) seems to imply that:
explanations:
Thus it was that on July 2, 1881, Charles Guiteau could simply walk up to President James A. Garfield and shoot him in broad daylight.  As Richard Menke portrays events, "Guiteau was in fact a madman who had come to identify with a disgruntled wing of the Republican Party after his deranged fantasies of winning a post from the new administration had come to nothing."  Believing that God had told him to kill the president, Guiteau thought this act would garner fame for his religious ideas and thereby help to usher in the Apocalypse. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 indicates that Charles Guiteau had both political and religious motivations for assassinating President Garfield.  First, the author presents Menke's description that "'Guiteau was in fact a madman who had come to identify with a disgruntled (dissatisfied or aggrieved) wing of the Republican Party after his deranged fantasies of winning a post from the new administration had come to nothing.'"  The author then describes the religious dimension of Guiteau's actions: he believed "God had told him to kill the president" and thought that the assassination "would garner fame for his religious ideas and thereby help to usher in the Apocalypse (end of the world)."
Accordingly, Guiteau attributed his political assassination to God's will, and believed that killing President Garfield would simultaneously further both his political and religious goals.  Therefore, the author's description of Charles Guiteau seems to imply that Guiteauviewed achieving religious and political ends as essentially interconnected.
 (Choice A)  Guiteau viewed religion as a necessary tool for achieving his political ends.  According to Paragraph 1, "Guiteau thought [killing Garfield] would garner fame for his religious ideas and thereby help to usher in the Apocalypse."  Therefore, Guiteau did not see religion as a tool for achieving his political ends, but rather viewed political assassination within the larger framework of his religious ideas.
(Choices C and D)  Guiteau pretended to hold religious views as an excuse for achieving his political ends through violence; and Guiteau pretended to hold religious and political views as an excuse for avenging a personal grievance.  Based on the passage, Guiteau was genuinely motivated by both political and religious beliefs.  For example, Paragraph 1 conveys that Guiteau both "'had come to identify with a disgruntled wing of the Republican Party'" and also "thought [killing Garfield] would garner fame for his religious ideas and thereby help to usher in the Apocalypse."  Accordingly, the author's description portrays Guiteau as truly believing in the political and religious ends he pursued; it does not imply that he only pretended to hold religious and political views.

text: In his ascent to the presidency, Garfield was probably LEAST motivated by which of the following?
explanations:
Garfield would go on to join the Union Army, where he attained the rank of major general and argued that black soldiers should receive the same pay as their white compatriots.  While serving in the war he was nominated for the House of Representatives but accepted the seat only after President Lincoln declared that the country had more need of him as a congressman than as a general.  The reluctant politician would later himself become president under similar circumstances, after multiple factions of a deadlocked Republican convention unexpectedly nominated him instead of their original candidates in 1880. (Paragraph 2)
According to the passage, Garfield did not initially seek out either of the political offices to which he was elected.  For example, Paragraph 2 relates that he accepted the congressional seat to which he had been nominated "only after President Lincoln declared that the country had more need of him as a congressman than as a general."  The author then describes how "[t]he reluctant politician would later himself become president under similar circumstances, after multiple factions (competing sides) of a deadlocked Republican convention unexpectedly nominated him instead of their original candidates in 1880."
Therefore, the passage conveys that Garfield had not originally intended to become either a congressional representative or the president but accepted those nominations and offices only after others pushed for his candidacy.  Consequently, in Garfield's ascent to the presidency, he was probably least motivated by ambition.
 (Choices A and C)  Duty; and Service.  Paragraph 2 suggests that Garfield's entry into politics was based on his sense of duty and service to the country.  Specifically, "While serving in the war he was nominated for the House of Representatives," but he did not accept the seat until "President Lincoln declared that the country had more need of him as a congressman than as a general."  Similarly, the author describes Garfield as a "reluctant politician" who became president only "after multiple factions of a deadlocked Republican convention unexpectedly nominated him instead of their original candidates in 1880."  Therefore, this same sense of duty and service likely motivated Garfield's ascent to the presidency.
(Choice B)  Justice.  According to the passage, Garfield was motivated by a sense of integrity and fair-mindedness.  For example, Paragraph 2 describes him as "[a]n honest man who opposed corruption within the party."  Similarly, he sought to "uphold the aims for which [the Civil War] was fought, until 'the equal sunlight of liberty shall shine upon every man, black or white, in the Union.'"  Therefore, Garfield's commitment to ending corruption and advancing equality suggests that he viewed his ascent to the presidency as a means of promoting justice.

text: Which of the following would most likely have occurred if Dr. Bliss had displayed more humility as a physician?
explanations:
Although Guiteau's bullet would ultimately dim this light for Garfield, the president actually survived the initial attack and for a time appeared headed for recovery.  Tragically, however, the hubris shown by his main physician, Dr. Willard Bliss, would lead instead to weeks of prolonged suffering. (Paragraph 3)
However, other historians suggest that Dr. Bliss, unwilling to consider challenges to his original assessment, prevented Bell from more thoroughly searching the president's body.  Certainly, Bliss ignored the advice and protestations of other physicians, even as Garfield continued to decline.  With death imminent, Garfield asked to be taken to his seaside cottage, where he died on the 19th of September. (Paragraph 4)
Based on the passage, Garfield's own doctor probably bears some blame for the president's death.  For instance, Paragraph 3 states that Garfield "actually survived the initial attack and for a time appeared headed for recovery.  Tragically, however, the hubris (destructive pride) shown by his main physician, Dr. Willard Bliss, would lead instead to weeks of prolonged suffering."  Similarly, Paragraph 4 suggests that Bliss was "unwilling to consider challenges to his original assessment," and further adds that he "ignored the advice and protestations of other physicians, even as Garfield continued to decline."
Therefore, the passage conveys that Dr. Bliss pridefully insisted on continuing his original course of treatment for Garfield despite its ineffectiveness and the dissenting opinions of other doctors.  Consequently, if Dr. Bliss had displayed more humility as a physician, then he would have been open to considering those other doctors' suggestions.  Most likely, then, the medical treatment given to Garfield would have been modified.
 (Choice A)  Another doctor would have taken over as Garfield's main physician.  Paragraph 4 states that "Bliss ignored the advice and protestations of other physicians, even as Garfield continued to decline."  However, Dr. Bliss could have displayed more humility even without another doctor taking over.  For instance, he could have accepted the advice of other physicians and incorporated their suggestions into his plan of treatment.
(Choice C)  Alexander Graham Bell would have identified the location of the bullet.  According to Paragraph 4, historians disagree about whether Bell would have been successful if Dr. Bliss had not interfered.  For instance, "Menke asserts that Bell's efforts 'would probably have fallen short' regardless.  However, other historians suggest that Dr. Bliss, unwilling to consider challenges to his original assessment, prevented Bell from more thoroughly searching the president's body."  Therefore, although it is possible that Bell would have located the bullet if Bliss had displayed more humility, the passage also presents the possibility that Bell's efforts would still have "'fallen short.'"
(Choice D)  The wound caused by the bullet would not have become infected.  According to Paragraph 3, "None of the doctors who examined Garfield were able to locate the bullet, and its lingering presence—along with the unwashed hands of the doctors who probed for it—led to an infection."  Therefore, the passage attributes the infection to the bullet itself and the medical hygiene practices of the day, not to Dr. Bliss' lack of humility.

text: The author's description of Pascal's Wager as a "purely practical argument" for belief in God (Paragraph 1) is based on that argument's:
explanations:
In the 17th century, Blaise Pascal provided a purely practical argument for theism with his famous "wager."  The most basic form of the argument can be understood as follows.  Suppose one believes in God.  This choice includes the loss of certain earthly goods, for instance, time and resources devoted to spiritual matters instead of oneself.  If God does not exist, these goods are lost unnecessarily, but if God does exist, one gains eternal happiness in the afterlife.  On the other hand, by not choosing to believe in God, one gains those earthly goods.  If God does not exist, one loses nothing, but if God does exist, one loses eternal happiness.  Pascal's Wager, then, is essentially a risk/reward analysis.  Believing in God involves a finite loss but may result in an infinite gain, whereas not believing in God risks an infinite loss for the sake of a finite gain.  Therefore, Pascal argues, choosing to believe in God is the only rational decision to make in terms of one's own self-interest. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 describes Pascal's Wager as "a purely practical argument for theism (belief in God)."  As the author explains, the Wager is based on the possible outcomes of believing or not believing in God, depending on whether God does or does not exist.  Specifically, believing in God means that one loses certain "time and resources" in life, but could gain "eternal happiness in the afterlife" if God does exist.  On the other hand, if one does not believe in God then one regains those "time and resources," but loses the chance of eternal happiness.
Accordingly, Pascal's point is that one should choose to believe in God, because doing so "involves a finite loss but may result in an infinite gain, whereas not believing in God risks an infinite loss for the sake of a finite gain" (Paragraph 1).  However, these possible gains and losses are the entire basis of the argument; the Wager does not include any reasoning designed to show that God's existence is more likely than unlikely.  Therefore, the description of the argument as "purely practical" is based on its focus on the potential risks and rewards of belief.
  (Choice A)  attempt to establish the truth of God's existence.  According to Pascal's Wager, "choosing to believe in God is the only rational decision to make in terms of one's own self-interest" (Paragraph 1).  This argument is based on the idea that one is better off if one believes in God than if one doesn't, because doing so "may result in an infinite gain" if God exists.  However, that argument is merely an appeal to one's self-interest; it is not an argument that God in fact does exist.
(Choices B and C)  portrayal of the choice to believe as a continuous process; and attention to addressing possible objections.  According to Paragraph 3, "Pascal was well aware of [objections to his argument], and actually raised such worries himself."  For example, the author points out that "[Pascal] does not treat choosing to believe in God as a discrete event, but as a process that unfolds throughout one's life (ie, a continuous process)," which addresses the objection that one cannot simply choose to believe in God.  However, these observations are not related to the claim that Pascal's Wager is "a purely practical argument for theism."  Rather, that claim concerns Pascal's assertion about the potential reward of choosing theism over atheism.  In other words, the argument is "purely practical" because it is based on the idea that "choosing to believe in God is the only rational decision to make in terms of one's own self-interest" (Paragraph 1).

text:
According to the passage, "many critics" object that following Pascal's Wager would be:
inauthentic.
unfeasible.
irrational.
explanations:
This argument elicits several objections, the most immediate of which relate to the nature of belief.  First, there is clearly a difference between truly believing in God versus choosing to believe for the sake of a hoped-for reward.  Hence, many critics have viewed the Wager as essentially cynical—not to mention the fact that if God does exist, he would presumably not be fooled by "belief" deriving from such mercenary motivations.  Even setting such concerns aside, however, the more important problem is that, put simply, belief doesn't work that way.  One cannot just will oneself to believe a proposition apart from some kind of evidence….  Regardless of the reasons for her wish to believe, belief is not a matter of choice; she cannot make herself believe in God or anything else.  Hence, a prescription to believe would seem to be pointless, even if one accepts that believing would represent the most rational, self-interested decision. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 mentions "several objections" that are commonly raised about Pascal's Wager, most of which relate to the nature of belief.  For example, "there is clearly a difference between truly believing in God versus choosing to believe for the sake of a hoped-for reward.  Hence, many critics have viewed the Wager as essentially cynical (ie, as disparaging what should truly be valued)."  In other words, these critics argue that following Pascal's Wager would not truly constitute belief in God, because believing in order to gain a reward is not the same as genuinely thinking an idea is true.  Therefore, such critics object that a person who follows Pascal's Wager would be inauthentic (Number I).
Pascal's Wager is based on the idea that one should choose to believe in God because of "one's own self-interest" (Paragraph 1).  However, Paragraph 2 describes the objection that "belief doesn't work that way.  One cannot just will oneself to believe a proposition apart from some kind of evidence."  Furthermore, even if it were possible to just choose to believe in this manner, "many critics" also argue that the Wager wouldn't succeed because God "would presumably not be fooled by 'belief' deriving from such mercenary motivations."  Consequently, the passage suggests two reasons why the critics object that following Pascal's Wager would be unfeasible (Number II).
  (Number III)  irrational.  Paragraph 2 describes the objection that "[o]ne cannot just will oneself to believe a proposition apart from some kind of evidence….  Hence, a prescription to believe would seem to be pointless, even if one accepts that believing would represent the most rational, self-interested decision."  Accordingly, the "many critics" do not object to the idea that following Pascal's Wager would be a rational decision.  Rather, they argue that one cannot simply make oneself believe in God, even if it is true that doing so would represent a rational, self-interested decision.

text: Based on the passage, what does Pascal's Wager suggest about the existence of God?
explanations:
Suppose one believes in God.  This choice includes the loss of certain earthly goods, for instance, time and resources devoted to spiritual matters instead of oneself.  If God does not exist, these goods are lost unnecessarily, but if God does exist, one gains eternal happiness in the afterlife. (Paragraph 1)
Thus, Pascal offers advice for those who struggle with their inability to believe: "Learn of those who have been bound like you…who know the way which you would follow, and who are cured of an ill of which you would be cured.  Follow the way by which they began; by acting as if they believed, taking the holy water, having mass said, etc.  Even this will naturally make you believe..."  In this way, Pascal implies that by practicing religion and engaging in its rituals one may eventually grow to develop real faith, a phenomenon that he suggests is valuable in its own right because it gives one's life meaning and purpose. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 1 describes the potential outcomes of Pascal's Wager.  For instance: "Suppose one believes in God….  [I]f God does exist, one gains eternal happiness in the afterlife."  Accordingly, Pascal argues that belief in God is clearly beneficial if God does exist.
In addition, Paragraph 3 presents Pascal's "advice for those who struggle with their inability to believe."  Pascal argues that a person who does not believe should begin to behave like those who do, because "by practicing religion and engaging in its rituals one may eventually grow to develop real faith, a phenomenon that he suggests is valuable in its own right because it gives one's life meaning and purpose."  Thus, Pascal contends that even if God does not exist, believing in God could improve a person's life.  Therefore, Pascal's Wager suggests that belief in God could be beneficial regardless of whether God exists.
  (Choices B and D)  Belief in God is beneficial only if God does exist; and Whether God actually exists is unimportant.  According to Paragraph 3, Pascal implies that "practicing religion and engaging in its rituals…is valuable in its own right because it gives one's life meaning and purpose."  Hence, Pascal suggests that believing in God could be beneficial even if God does not exist.  Nevertheless, whether God actually exists is still extremely important to those who follow Pascal's Wager, because that fact determines whether belief in God would lead to the "infinite gain" of "eternal happiness in the afterlife" (Paragraph 1).
(Choice C)  Whether God exists can be determined in a practical sense.  Paragraph 1 states that "Pascal provided a purely practical argument for theism (belief in God) with his famous 'wager.'"  However, Pascal never suggests that his Wager helps determine whether God exists.  Rather, the Wager is "purely practical" because it is based solely on whether believing in God is "the most rational decision to make in terms of one's own self-interest."

text: Which of the following decisions in a woman's life would be most similar to the way Pascal's Wager is described in Paragraph 3?
explanations:
However, as compelling as those objections might appear, it is easy to overlook the fact that Pascal was well aware of them, and actually raised such worries himself.  Notably, he does not treat choosing to believe in God as a discrete event, but as a process that unfolds throughout one's life.  Thus, Pascal offers advice for those who struggle with their inability to believe….  In this way, Pascal implies that by practicing religion and engaging in its rituals one may eventually grow to develop real faith, a phenomenon that he suggests is valuable in its own right because it gives one's life meaning and purpose.  As such, Pascal's Wager need not be seen as either cynical or impossible, but as an attempt to open a genuine path to theism. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, Pascal "does not treat choosing to believe in God as a discrete event, but as a process that unfolds throughout one's life."  Specifically, Pascal suggests that although someone may not believe in God at a particular moment, he or she may come to do so over time: "[B]y practicing religion and engaging in its rituals one may eventually grow to develop real faith."  Thus, Pascal implies that a person can potentially change the way he or she thinks or feels about a subject by living life in a particular way.
Therefore, this description is most similar to the scenario in which the woman accepts a man's marriage proposal even though she is unsure of her feelings, hoping that over time she will fall in love with her fiancé.  The woman is unsure of her feelings, but hopes that by living a married life she will truly fall in love with her fiancé over time.  Similarly, Pascal suggests that one who is unsure whether she believes in God may hope to develop genuine belief by living a religious life.
  By contrast, each of the following scenarios describes a change to an external situation, not a change to the woman's own feelings:
The woman chooses a college major even though she is unsure her parents will approve, hoping that over time they will support her decision (Choice B).  In this situation, the woman is hoping that her parents' feelings toward her major will change over time, not her own feelings.
The woman auditions for parts in movies even though she is unsure she will be cast, hoping that over time she will land a breakout role (Choice C).  This description does not suggest that the woman's feelings toward acting will change, but rather that over time her auditions will be more successful.
The woman sticks with a new job even though she is unsure she enjoys it, hoping that over time it will turn into a stable career (Choice D).  This scenario does not describe the woman as hoping that her feelings toward the job will change, but rather as hoping that the job itself will change by turning into a stable career.

text: Suppose it were discovered that Pascal himself did not come to believe in God by following his Wager, but instead believed due to a prior, personal religious experience.  How would this information affect the author's claims in the passage?
explanations:
In this way, Pascal implies that by practicing religion and engaging in its rituals one may eventually grow to develop real faith, a phenomenon that he suggests is valuable in its own right because it gives one's life meaning and purpose.  As such, Pascal's Wager need not be seen as either cynical or impossible, but as an attempt to open a genuine path to theism. (Paragraph 3)
In Paragraph 3, the author describes Pascal's view that "by practicing religion and engaging in its rituals one may eventually grow to develop real faith, a phenomenon that he suggests is valuable in its own right because it gives one's life meaning and purpose."  Similarly, if Pascal had a personal religious experience that led him to believe in God, this would strongly suggest that he viewed this experience of coming to believe in God as providing meaning and purpose to his life.  Therefore, this information would support the claim that Pascal saw believing in God as valuable in its own right.
  (Choice A)  It would support the claim that Pascal was well aware of the objections to his argument.  Paragraph 2 mentions "several objections" to Pascal's Wager.  Paragraph 3 then states: "[A]s compelling as those objections might appear, it is easy to overlook the fact that Pascal was well aware of them, and actually raised such worries himself."  However, whether Pascal believed in God or had a personal religious experience is irrelevant to the claim that he was aware of objections to his argument; he could have been aware of those objections whether or not he had such an experience.
(Choice B)  It would challenge the claim that Pascal thought choosing to believe in God is the only rational decision.  According to Pascal's Wager, "choosing to believe in God is the only rational decision to make in terms of one's own self-interest" (Paragraph 1).  This conclusion is based on the idea that even if one doesn't know whether God exists, one is better off believing in God than not believing in God because that is the only option that could possibly lead to "eternal happiness in the afterlife."  Therefore, if Pascal had a personal religious experience that led him to believe God does exist, this point about self-interest would only be reinforced; in that case, he would have all the more reason to think that choosing to believe in God is the only rational decision to make.
(Choice D)  It would challenge the claim that Pascal's Wager is essentially a risk/reward analysis.  According to Paragraph 1, "Pascal's Wager, then, is essentially a risk/reward analysis.  Believing in God involves a finite loss but may result in an infinite gain, whereas not believing in God risks an infinite loss for the sake of a finite gain."  However, the nature of this analysis would not be changed or challenged if Pascal believed in God due to a personal religious experience.  Regardless of Pascal's beliefs, the point of the Wager is that any person could consider the potential gains and losses it describes.

text: Suppose that new government regulations require the elimination of financial compensation for egg donors.  How would this affect the author's claims about concerns facing the oocyte market?
explanations:
Because of these issues, bioethicists have called for the establishment of a global register of egg donors and longitudinal follow-ups that aim to identify potential negative side effects.  But even if this were implemented, other ethical concerns would loom heavy.  For instance, there is the question of why, or on what grounds, fertility clinics pay donors thousands of dollars for eggs in the first place.  Donors of other sorts are not compensated for the goods they donate, so why should egg donors be so fortunate?…Critics claim that this aspect of the industry is revealing: In compensating donors, they say, the egg procurement industry transforms women's bodies into an economic resource, mere organisms from which a supply of biological matter must be "harvested" for the ultimate gain of others. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, "bioethicists have called for the establishment of a global register of egg donors and longitudinal follow-ups that aim to identify potential negative side effects."  However, the author notes that "even if this were implemented, other ethical concerns would loom heavy.  For instance, there is the question of why, or on what grounds, fertility clinics pay donors thousands of dollars for eggs in the first place."  The author further describes the criticism that by compensating egg donors "the egg procurement industry transforms women's bodies into an economic resource…for the ultimate gain of others."
Consequently, the "other ethical concerns" mentioned by the author (Paragraph 4) all relate to the fact that egg donors receive financial compensation.  If new government regulations required the elimination of that compensation, then those ethical concerns would no longer arise.  Therefore, such regulations would weaken the claim that ethical issues would remain even if a global register of egg donors were established.
 (Choice A)  It would support the claim that there is little research on the long-term risks and effects of egg donation on women's health.  Paragraph 3 states that "there is very little research on the long-term risks and effects of egg donation on women's health."  However, the issue of whether it should be legal to "pay donors thousands of dollars for eggs" is part of "other ethical concerns [that] would loom heavy" even if there were more information about the health effects of egg donation (Paragraph 4).  Hence, government regulations eliminating financial compensation for egg donation would not necessarily support (or challenge) the claim that there is little research on the long-term risks and effects of egg donation on women's health.
(Choice B)  It would support the claim that government regulations would make women vulnerable to exploitation.  Paragraph 3 states that "without regulations governing the commercialization of the oocyte industry…women in need of short-term financial gain become especially vulnerable to exploitative or coercive business practices."  Accordingly, the author claims that government regulations would serve to prevent exploitation and coercion, not make women vulnerable to them.
(Choice D)  It would weaken the claim that the global demand for egg donors continues to increase.  According to Paragraph 1, "[a]s the clientele of fertility clinics—primarily women seeking to conceive through the aid of medical intervention and reproductive technology—continues to grow, so does the immense global demand for egg donors."  Whether egg donors are financially compensated is irrelevant to whether there is a demand for egg donation (ie, whether women seek medical intervention in order to conceive).  Therefore, new government regulations that eliminated financial compensation for egg donors would not weaken the claim that the global demand for egg donors continues to increase.

text: Based on passage information, which of the following claims about egg donation could most easily be challenged by contradictory evidence?
explanations:
For instance, there is the question of why, or on what grounds, fertility clinics pay donors thousands of dollars for eggs in the first place.  Donors of other sorts are not compensated for the goods they donate, so why should egg donors be so fortunate? (Paragraph 4)
In response to this criticism, advocates for the oocyte market claim that, unlike donations of other sorts, the egg donation process requires a medically invasive and time-consuming procedure.  Their position is that the thousands of dollars given to donors merely serves as compensation for the valuable time (not the eggs) lost during the donation process. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 5, "advocates for the oocyte market claim that, unlike donations of other sorts, the egg donation process requires a medically invasive and time-consuming procedure.  Their position is that the thousands of dollars given to donors merely serves as compensation for the valuable time (not the eggs) lost during the donation process."  This claim depends upon the idea that other types of donation are not medically invasive or time-consuming.
Consequently, the only evidence necessary to falsify such a claim would be an example of another type of donation that is medically invasive and time-consuming, but for which people are not paid.  For instance, organ donations involve invasive surgery and could potentially require extensive hospital stays; thus, such a donation would clearly challenge the distinction being drawn by advocates of the oocyte industry to justify their position.  Therefore, the statement other sorts of donations are not medically invasive or time-consuming could most easily be challenged by contradictory evidence.
 (Choice A)  "Informed consent" may not always be part of the egg donation process.  Paragraph 3 states that "it is unclear that 'informed consent' is part of the [egg] donation process."  To challenge this claim, it would be necessary to demonstrate that egg donors typically do act with informed consent.  However, "[i]n today's unregulated marketplace, fertility clinics are not required to warn would-be donors about the potential health risks or the inadequate body of knowledge we currently have about these risks."  Therefore, it would be difficult to establish that informed consent is always part of the egg donation process.
(Choice B)  The oocyte industry compensates donors for their time, not their eggs.  Paragraph 4 discusses "the question of why, or on what grounds, fertility clinics pay donors thousands of dollars for eggs."  This question assumes that egg donors are paid for the eggs they donate, not for their time.  However, the oocyte industry's position is that egg donors are paid "for their valuable time (not the eggs)" (Paragraph 5).  Resolving this difference in position would likely require a conceptual debate regarding the definition of selling, if not a legal judgment about sales practices.  Therefore, it would be difficult to contradict the claim that egg donors are paid for their time rather than for their eggs.
(Choice D)  The oocyte industry will continue to exist in the years to come.  Paragraph 6 states that "it seems…the oocyte industry is here to stay."  Since this is a claim about the future, it would be difficult to provide currently existing contradictory evidence to challenge it.

text: Why does the author stress the fact that "an egg is a nonrecyclable sex cell" (Paragraph 4)?
explanations:
...[T]here is the question of why, or on what grounds, fertility clinics pay donors thousands of dollars for eggs in the first place.  Donors of other sorts are not compensated for the goods they donate, so why should egg donors be so fortunate?  It is relevant to note that, by definition, an egg is a nonrecyclable sex cell; women are born with a fixed number of these and this number drastically decreases with age.  Critics claim that this aspect of the industry is revealing: In compensating donors, they say, the egg procurement industry transforms women's bodies into an economic resource, mere organisms from which a supply of biological matter must be "harvested" for the ultimate gain of others. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 states that the definition of an egg is "relevant" to the question of why egg donors are paid, because "an egg is a nonrecyclable sex cell; women are born with a fixed number of these and this number drastically decreases with age."  In other words, eggs have economic value because they are a limited commodity; each woman has only a certain number, which decreases over time and can never be replenished.
Accordingly, the author stresses the "revealing" fact that "an egg is a nonrecyclable sex cell" because it illustrates why critics think "the egg procurement industry transforms women's bodies into an economic resource" (ie, eggs for cash) (Paragraph 4).
 (Choice B)  To acquaint readers with anatomical terminology related to egg donation procedures.  The definition of an egg includes anatomical or biological terms; however, the author indicates that the definition is "relevant" to the ethical question of why egg donors are compensated (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, the definition is not used in order to acquaint readers with anatomical terminology.
(Choice C)  To highlight the consequences to the donor's body of repeated donations.  Although the definition of an egg implies that there will be certain consequences for women who repeatedly donate their eggs (ie, the depletion of their "fixed number" of eggs), the author states that the definition is "relevant" to the question of why "fertility clinics pay…for eggs in the first place" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, the definition does not serve to highlight consequences of repeated donations to a donor's body.
(Choice D)  To emphasize the sentimental value attached to a resource that is scarce.  By defining an egg, the author suggests that eggs have economic value as a scarce resource (ie, because they are "fixed" in number).  However, the author never suggests that eggs have sentimental value (ie, that people are emotionally attached to eggs).

text: Based on the passage, there is an implicit assumption that:
explanations:
...[A]dvocates for the oocyte market claim that…the thousands of dollars given to donors merely serves as compensation for the valuable time (not the eggs) lost during the donation process. (Paragraph 5)
If this claim helps to alleviate the concern that the oocyte industry commodifies women's bodies, there will be room for a collaborative effort toward long-term progress.  The proponents of this industry, as well as its opponents, can work together to ensure that government regulations provide safeguards against issues of consent and exploitation. (Paragraph 6)
According to Paragraph 5, oocyte market advocates claim that donors are compensated for their time, "not their eggs."  Paragraph 6 states that if this claim helps alleviate the ethical concern about commodifying women's bodies, "a collaborative effort" between advocates for the oocyte industry and its opponents (ie, bioethicists) would be possible.
This proposed effort is further explained as one in which advocates and opponents "work together to ensure that government regulations provide safeguards against issues of consent and exploitation" (Paragraph 6).  Therefore, the passage assumes that advocates of the oocyte market could agree with bioethicists about the need for government regulation.
 (Choice A)  most of the high-quality eggs available in today's market are provided by female college students.  According to Paragraph 1, "today's market [has] considerably fewer donors than needed to supply clinics with high-quality eggs."  Paragraph 2 then states that "a disproportionate number of female college students are donating their eggs."  However, the fact that female college students are over-represented among egg donors does not in itself mean that the majority of high-quality eggs come from college students.  Rather, it implies only that more eggs (of whatever quality) are donated by college students than would be expected from a random distribution of donors.
(Choice B)  there is no way to alleviate the concern that the oocyte industry commodifies women's bodies.  The author says that "there will be room for a collaborative effort" between opponents and proponents of the oocyte industry if "the concern that the oocyte industry commodifies women's bodies" can be alleviated or resolved (Paragraph 6).  Accordingly, the author implies that this concern could be alleviated.
(Choice D)  a collaborative effort toward ethical or moral progress would be undesirable.  Paragraph 6 claims that "a collaborative effort toward long-term [ethical or moral] progress…would certainly be desirable," not undesirable.

text: Based on information in the passage, bioethicists would NOT agree with which of the following statements?
explanations:
Some bioethicists are particularly worried about the current lack of government oversight in the oocyte market…Notice that, at present, there is very little research on the long-term risks and effects of egg donation on women's health.  In today's unregulated marketplace, fertility clinics are not required to warn would-be donors about the potential health risks or the inadequate body of knowledge we currently have about these risks.  In the absence of such information, it is unclear that "informed consent" is part of the donation process. (Paragraph 3)
Because of these issues, bioethicists have called for the establishment of a global register of egg donors and longitudinal follow-ups that aim to identify potential negative side effects. (Paragraph 4)
According to the passage, bioethicists worry about "the long-term risks and effects of egg donation on women's health," especially because "it is unclear that 'informed consent' is part of the [egg] donation process" (Paragraph 3).  To address these concerns, bioethicists "have called for the establishment of a global register of egg donors" as well as "follow-ups that aim to identify potential negative side effects" of egg donation.  Therefore, this information indicates that bioethicists favor increased access to information about egg donation procedures.  Consequently, they would not agree that the government should reduce access to data collected by fertility clinics.
 (Choice A)  The government should reduce subsidies to health care providers.  Although bioethicists would presumably have a general interest in health care, the passage contains no information about health care providers or government subsidies of them.
(Choice C)  Lawmakers should impose regulations on student loan programs.
