In light of that distinction, one can imagine the most typical criticism of any educational entertainment program.  Education and entertainment are, at their cores, not aimed at the same ends.  Whether it is the worse crime to be insufficiently didactic or to be excessively didactic may depend on whom one asks; either way, one might worry that a work attempting to impart both amusement and instruction would ultimately fail in at least one of those objectives. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 conveys that because educational entertainment programs attempt "to impart both amusement and instruction (ie, both entertainment and education)," they run the risk of "ultimately fail[ing] in at least one of those objectives."  In other words, these "edutainment" programs run the risk of being either "insufficiently didactic" (entertaining but not educational enough) or "excessively didactic" (too educational and not entertaining enough).  In this context being too educational means that the show lacks entertainment value; therefore, the phrase "excessively didactic" probably refers to an instructional method that is insufficiently entertaining.
  By contrast, "excessively didactic" would probably not refer to any of the following:
an inflexible attitude toward teaching (Choice A).  An inflexible attitude means only that the teacher is unlikely to change his or her teaching methods; it would not necessarily mean that his or her instruction is "excessively didactic" (too educational and not entertaining enough).  For instance, the teacher could be inflexibly committed to trying to amuse students while teaching a subject.
an ineffective presentation of a lesson plan (Choice B).  An ineffective presentation would suggest that the teacher delivered his or her lesson plan poorly.  However, this ineffective delivery would not necessarily mean that the lesson plan was too focused on education at the expense of entertainment.  For instance, the teacher's presentation might simply be confusing or difficult to follow.
an instructional method that is overly complex (Choice D).  An overly complex method might still be very entertaining to students and not necessarily "excessively didactic."  For example, if a teacher asked students to play an amusing but difficult game to learn mathematical concepts, the method could be overly complex but the learning fun.

text: What is the main point of the passage?
explanations:
The word "edutainment" refers to educational entertainment, media designed to educate while entertaining the audience.  One of the more successful of such enterprises was Square One, a television show that aired in the 1980s and 1990s. (Paragraph 1)
...either way, one might worry that a work attempting to impart both amusement and instruction would ultimately fail in at least one of those objectives.  Yet Square One was that rare instance in which both goals were met. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 1 notes that educational entertainment is "designed to educate while entertaining the audience," and that Square One was "[o]ne of the more successful of such enterprises."  The rest of the passage is spent describing Square One, at the end of which Paragraph 5 states that "Square One was that rare instance in which both goals (of education and entertainment) were met."  Accordingly, the main point of the passage is that Square One was an especially successful example of educational entertainment.
  (Choice A)  Square One was successful even among students who did not enjoy mathematics.  Paragraph 5 states that "[m]any children who disliked mathematics in school still enjoyed viewing a show with songs and skits about the subject."  However, this statement is just one of many claims supporting the passage's central point regarding Square One's overall success as an educational entertainment program.
(Choice B)  Square One was the most successful example of well-made "edutainment" programs.  Paragraph 1 describes some of the features of "well-made educational entertainment" and notes that Square One was "[o]ne of the more successful of such enterprises."  However, the passage does not state that Square One was the most successful example of educational entertainment programs.
(Choice C)  Square One's success illustrates why "edutainment" can be a valuable resource for teachers.  The passage states that "[t]eachers had good reason to be happy about [Square One's] existence" and that the program "can surely be credited with the improved academic performance of many students" (Paragraph 5).  However, the main point of the passage is the success of Square One as an "edutainment" program.  Its approval from teachers is simply one component of that success.

text: On the basis of the information contained in the passage, which of the following would one probably NOT expect to find as a segment in an episode of Square One?
explanations:
Focusing on mathematics, Square One aimed to instruct elementary school children in a way that captured their attention and made them eager to learn. (Paragraph 1)
Songs like "Angle Dance" and "Less Than Zero" described concepts such as acuteness or negative numbers…the exhausted singers of "That's Infinity" tried vainly to reach the largest number, while "Eight Percent of My Love" saw a boy serenade his girlfriend about the small fraction of love he could give her (having already given away 92 percent to friends, the USA, his bicycle, and other things). (Paragraph 2)
In addition to the music, skits, cartoons, and parodies constituting many of the program's segments, game shows were another way in which Square One imparted instruction. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 mentions "the music, skits, cartoons, and parodies constituting many of the program's segments."  Thus, all of these types of programs would appear as segments of Square One.
However, Paragraph 1 states that "Square One aimed to instruct elementary school children," and Paragraph 2 provides examples of concepts that the show taught, such as percentages, the meaning of acuteness, and the fact that there is no largest number.  Given the age of the target audience and the examples of concepts described, it is clear that the show focused on more basic mathematical ideas rather than high-level equations.  Therefore, one would probably not expect to find "Adventures of Gal-culus," a cartoon where a superheroine explains how to solve high-level mathematical equations, as a segment in an episode of Square One.
  By contrast, all of the following involve less advanced mathematical concepts and would be much more likely to appear in a program aimed at elementary school children:
"Workout the Answer," a skit where a fitness guru explains how to determine time or distance exercised (Choice A).  Determining time or distance exercised involves only simple arithmetic.
"Pump Up the Volume," a song where a band explains how to measure the volume of geometric shapes (Choice B).  Measuring the volume of geometric shapes involves only basic geometry.
"Al Gebra, P.I.," a parody where a private investigator explains how to use algebraic variables (Choice C).  Using algebraic variables involves only foundational concepts of algebra.

text: Based on passage information, which of the following is most analogous to the role of popular culture references in Square One?
explanations:
The creativity of these songs featured popular culture aspects that were often more noticeable to parents than to the child viewers themselves….  Other parts of the show included similar references.  Details such as these functioned as a bonus, however, as the target audience found the material compelling despite not grasping all the references that elicited smiles from their elders.  Cabot and Marshmallow's "What's in a Name?" was comedic even without knowledge of the famous Abbott and Costello "Who's on First?" skit from which it was derived. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, Square One's material "featured popular culture aspects that were often more noticeable to parents than to the child viewers themselves."  However, the author asserts that "the target audience found the material compelling despite not grasping all the references…."  For example, "Cabot and Marshmallow's 'What's in a Name?' was comedic even without knowledge of the famous Abbott and Costello 'Who's on First?' skit from which it was derived."  As such, these references "functioned as a bonus" to Square One's material but were not integral to the purpose of the program, which was to teach and entertain.
Similarly, diamonds decorating a watch are extra additions (ie, a bonus feature) that are not integral to the purpose of the watch, which is to tell time.  Accordingly, these diamonds are most analogous to the role of popular culture references in Square One.
  By contrast, none of the following are analogous to the role of popular culture references in Square One, because they are main features rather than a bonus:
the feathers of a peacock, a distinctive and obvious mark of the species (Choice A).  Because a peacock's feathers are distinctive and obvious, they are a primary component of any person's conception of the animal.  The same is not true of Square One's popular culture references, which were extra features "that were often more noticeable to parents than to the child viewers themselves" (Paragraph 3).
the external frame of a house, supporting the rest of the structure (Choice C).  The support provided by the frame of a house is essential for the rest of the structure to stand, rather than a bonus feature like the popular culture references in Square One.
a hidden code in a document, expressing the document's true meaning (Choice D).  Knowledge of such a code would be required to understand the main point of the document in question.  However, knowledge of Square One's popular culture references was not required to understand the main point of its material, which was "amusing and instructional, even to those too young" to understand those references (Paragraph 3).

text: Suppose that clothing with the Square One logo currently sells for large amounts of money online and is worn throughout the country.  If true, how would this information affect the author's claims about Square One's game shows?
explanations:
One of the more successful of such enterprises was Square One, a television show that aired in the 1980s and 1990s. (Paragraph 1)
…game shows were another way in which Square One imparted instruction.  The prizes were unexciting (everyday apparel bearing the Square One logo), but that was to be expected for a production that aired on public broadcasting.  Of course, the prizes were also not the point.  Part of the draw of a commercial game show may be a fabulous package of expensive prizes and money, but the game shows of Square One focused on education. (Paragraph 4)
The passage states that when Square One "aired in the 1980s and 1990s" (Paragraph 1), the "everyday apparel bearing the Square One logo" that served as prizes for its game shows was "unexciting" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, the author claims that when the game shows were actually taking place (around thirty years ago), the prizes were not considered exciting or valuable.
If the apparel in question currently sells for large amounts of money online and is worn throughout the country, that would indicate that the apparel is now considered to be valuable and exciting to own or wear.  However, that fact would not change the way that the prizes were perceived by those who originally watched or participated in Square One's game shows.
Therefore, even if apparel with the Square One logo currently sells for large amounts of money online, it would not affect what the author says about Square One's game shows when they originally aired.
  (Choices A and D)  It would challenge what the author says about Square One's game shows; and It would support what the author says about Square One's game shows.  Paragraph 4 states that Square One's "prizes were unexciting," unlike the "fabulous package of expensive prizes" that one may find on a commercial game show.  Even if the prizes for Square One's game shows currently sold for large amounts of money online and were worn throughout the country, that fact would not change how the prizes were perceived when Square One and its game shows originally aired.  Therefore, that fact would neither challenge nor support the author's claims about Square One's game shows.
(Choice B)  It would lessen the distinction between commercial game shows and Square One's game shows.  The author distinguishes commercial game shows from Square One's game shows by noting that the former typically offer "a fabulous package of expensive prizes and money," but the latter "focused on education," as "the prizes were…not the point."  Even if the prizes from Square One's game shows were now considered expensive and exciting, that would not change the fact that those prizes seemed unexciting when the game shows originally aired.  Therefore, the current perception of the prizes would not lessen the distinction between commercial game shows and the game shows on Square One.

text: The main purpose of the passage is:
explanations:
A common charge leveled at elected officeholders is that they are "playing politics."  The implication of the claim is that its target has skewed priorities: he or she ought to care about addressing the needs of the citizenry through legislation and governing but is wrongly focused on politics instead. (Paragraph 1)
In the classical sense, however….ethics concerns the good of the individual, while politics concerns the good of society. (Paragraph 2)
In other words, the object of political power is to bring to fruition a particular conception of the good….  But if the power itself is the goal—if one seeks authority for the sake of having authority—then the good of society becomes either forsaken entirely or, at best, an afterthought. (Paragraph 3)
In this cynical form of politics….  A party that achieves nothing, or even stands for nothing, can still maintain power if the alternative party seems sufficiently loathsome—even if, ironically, the supposed loathsomeness comes from a perception that its members are "playing politics." (Paragraph 4)
So how do we fix this problem, restoring the original sense of "politics" in the minds of both voters and politicians?  The answer is twofold.  First, politicians must commit themselves to acting in good faith and to upholding a kind of mutual aspiration….  Second, citizens must commit themselves to valuing nuanced positions and open-minded reflection from candidates, rather than the snappy soundbites and one-liners that typify so much of political debate and media coverage.  If each group strives to embody these aims, we can return to genuinely engaging in politics rather than playing politics. (Paragraph 5)
The passage begins with a discussion of "playing politics," the accusation that a politician "ought to care about addressing the needs of the citizenry…but is wrongly focused on politics instead" (Paragraph 1).  The author contrasts this idea with the classical Aristotelian conception that politics intrinsically "concerns the good of society" (Paragraph 2).
Paragraph 3 connects these ideas with politicians' failure to uphold the ideal that "the object of political power is to bring to fruition a particular conception of the good."  Such politicians are not focused on the public good because for them "power itself is the goal," so "the good of society becomes…at best, an afterthought."  Paragraph 4 further criticizes "this cynical form of politics" in which parties try to maintain power primarily by depicting their opposition as "sufficiently loathsome (vile or disgusting)" by comparison.
The preceding considerations all lead up to the question: "So how do we fix this problem, restoring the original sense of 'politics' in the minds of both voters and politicians?" (Paragraph 5).  The author offers solutions to address the problems discussed in the passage, promoting the conclusion that "we can return to genuinely engaging in politics rather than playing politics."
Accordingly, the passage is structured to first describe a puzzling feature of modern politics, then evaluate that feature as problematic, and finally present solutions for changing it.  Therefore, the main purpose of the passage is to encourage reform of ideas and practices surrounding modern politics.
 By contrast, although the author discusses the following ideas, the main purpose of the passage goes beyond them:
to contrast the modern conception of politics with the classical Aristotelian conception (Choice A).  Paragraph 1 notes the modern criticism that a politician "ought to care about addressing the needs of the citizenry…but is wrongly focused on politics instead."  However, the contrast between this idea and the classical Aristotelian conception, in which "there is no distinction between engaging in politics and addressing society's needs" (Paragraph 2), functions to highlight a problem in modern politics that the author wants to reform.
to explore implications of the fact that politics is essentially based on struggle (Choice B).  Paragraph 3 describes politics as "a struggle between competing ideas about the good of society and between competing aspirants to society's leadership."  However, exploring this idea leads to the ultimate goal of "restoring the original sense of 'politics' in the minds of both voters and politicians" (Paragraph 5).
to denounce those who aspire to political power without embodying actual leadership (Choice C).  Paragraph 4 criticizes the "cynical form of politics…in which the supposed qualification to lead is divorced from leadership."  However, the author's larger purpose is encouraging the rejection of such cynicism so "we can return to genuinely engaging in politics rather than playing politics" (Paragraph 5).

text: Suppose studies show that negative campaign advertisements are much more effective at swaying voters than positive advertisements.  How would this finding affect the author's claims in the passage?
explanations:
In its ideal form, the latter contest is subordinate to the former.  In other words, the object of political power is to bring to fruition a particular conception of the good, and it is for the sake of that good—a public good—that power is sought and exercised.  But if the power itself is the goal…then the good of society becomes either forsaken entirely or, at best, an afterthought. (Paragraph 3)
When extended to political parties, playing politics would entail striving to aggrandize one's own side or diminish the opposition without actually contributing to the resolution of an issue.  In this cynical form of politics, persuasion is attempted by comparison rather than substance, the vaunting of an empty façade in which the supposed qualification to lead is divorced from leadership.  A party that achieves nothing, or even stands for nothing, can still maintain power if the alternative party seems sufficiently loathsome—even if, ironically, the supposed loathsomeness comes from a perception that its members are "playing politics." (Paragraph 4)
Second, citizens must commit themselves to valuing nuanced positions and open-minded reflection from candidates, rather than the snappy soundbites and one-liners that typify so much of political debate and media coverage. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 3, "In its ideal form…the object of political power is to bring to fruition a particular conception of the good, and it is for the sake of that good…that power is sought and exercised."  However, if politicians do not live up to this ideal, then political power is treated as an end in itself instead of as a means to improve citizens' well-being: "if the power itself is the goal…then the good of society becomes either forsaken entirely or, at best, an afterthought."
Paragraph 4 criticizes this focus on power, especially the tactic of "striving to aggrandize (glorify) one's own side or diminish the opposition without actually contributing to the resolution of an issue" so that "persuasion is attempted by comparison rather than substance."  In other words, this approach is based primarily on making one's political opponents look bad: "A party that achieves nothing, or even stands for nothing, can still maintain power if the alternative party seems sufficiently loathsome (vile or disgusting)."
Finally, Paragraph 5 conveys that modern politics is largely based on "the snappy soundbites and one-liners that typify so much of political debate and media coverage."  Therefore, if studies show that negative campaign advertisements are much more effective at swaying voters than positive advertisements, those studies would accord with the author's critique of modern politics.  This finding would be consistent with the author's characterization that modern politics focuses on swaying voters by vilifying members of the opposing party.
 (Choice A)  It would challenge the author's claims about a means/ends distinction.  Paragraph 3 discusses "a means/ends distinction" in politics, suggesting that often "political power is viewed as an end in itself."  If negative campaign advertisements are shown to be more effective than positive ones, this finding would support the author's claim that politicians try to maintain their power by portraying rivals as "sufficiently loathsome" (Paragraph 4).
(Choice B)  It would change the relevance of the author's reference to Aristotle.  On the Aristotelian view, "there is no distinction between engaging in politics and addressing society's needs" (Paragraph 2).  The author refers to Aristotle as part of an argument for embracing that conception, so that "we can return to genuinely engaging in politics rather than playing politics" (Paragraph 5).  The author states that "playing politics would entail striving to…diminish the opposition" (Paragraph 4); thus, negative advertisements could be an example.  Accordingly, the effectiveness of such advertisements would not change the relevance of the reference to Aristotle.
(Choice D)  It would suggest that the author's concerns are understated.  The author criticizes the "cynical form of politics" in which "[a] party that achieves nothing, or even stands for nothing, can still maintain power if the alternative party seems sufficiently loathsome" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, the greater effectiveness of negative advertisements would suggest that the author has correctly assessed modern politics, not suggest that his or her concerns are understated.

text: Implicit in the author's argument is the idea that:
explanations:
In other words, the object of political power is to bring to fruition a particular conception of the good, and it is for the sake of that good—a public good—that power is sought and exercised.  But if the power itself is the goal—if one seeks authority for the sake of having authority—then the good of society becomes either forsaken entirely or, at best, an afterthought. (Paragraph 3)
Such an end we might call the "false microcosm," a corrupted analogue to ethics in the framework Aristotle describes.  In that situation, a politician achieves neither society's good nor her own, but simply the continuation of her time in office. (Paragraph 4)
In Paragraph 3, the author states that ideally "the object of political power is to bring to fruition a particular conception of the good, and it is for the sake of that good—a public good—that power is sought and exercised."  However, some politicians ignore that basis for politics: "if the power itself is the goal—if one seeks authority for the sake of having authority—then the good of society becomes either forsaken entirely or, at best, an afterthought."
The author then asserts: "In that situation, a politician achieves neither society's good nor her own, but simply the continuation of her time in office" (Paragraph 4).  Thus, the author states that continuing in office does not serve the politician's own good, which implies that such a politician would be better off leaving office instead.  Accordingly, the author implicitly assumes that some politicians would be better off if they did not seek to remain in office.
 (Choice A)  In the classical conception of politics, political power is an end in itself.  According to Paragraph 2, "In the classical sense…politics concerns the good of society."  Paragraph 3 further conveys that under this conception, "the object of political power is to bring to fruition a particular conception of the good, and it is for the sake of that good—a public good—that power is sought and exercised."  Therefore, the idea that "power itself is the goal" is presented in contrast to the classical conception of politics.
(Choice C)  The "false microcosm" can never be completely eliminated.  Paragraph 3 describes how "power itself is the goal" for some politicians, so "the good of society becomes either forsaken entirely or, at best, an afterthought."  Paragraph 4 calls such a motive "the 'false microcosm,' a corrupted analogue to ethics in the framework Aristotle describes."  However, the author never implies that this false microcosm cannot be eliminated.  Rather, he or she suggests that we can "fix this problem, restoring the original sense of 'politics' in the minds of both voters and politicians" (Paragraph 5).
(Choice D)  "Playing politics" is an inefficient method for winning elections.  According to Paragraph 4, "A party that achieves nothing, or even stands for nothing, can still maintain power if the alternative party seems sufficiently loathsome—even if, ironically, the supposed loathsomeness comes from a perception that its members are 'playing politics.'"  Therefore, although the author opposes the kind of tactics involved in "playing politics," he or she implies that those tactics can successfully help a political party maintain power.  Accordingly, the author never suggests that playing politics is an inefficient method for winning elections.

text: In order to uphold the author's ideals, which of the following traits would be most important for a politician to exhibit?
explanations:
Politics is inherently agonistic: a struggle between competing ideas about the good of society and between competing aspirants to society's leadership.  In its ideal form, the latter contest is subordinate to the former. (Paragraph 3)
In this cynical form of politics, persuasion is attempted by comparison rather than substance, the vaunting of an empty façade in which the supposed qualification to lead is divorced from leadership.  A party that achieves nothing, or even stands for nothing, can still maintain power if the alternative party seems sufficiently loathsome—even if, ironically, the supposed loathsomeness comes from a perception that its members are "playing politics." (Paragraph 4)
So how do we fix this problem, restoring the original sense of "politics" in the minds of both voters and politicians?  The answer is twofold.  First, politicians must commit themselves to acting in good faith and to upholding a kind of mutual aspiration.  For instance, when attendees at a 2008 John McCain rally suggested that Barack Obama was untrustworthy and not an American citizen, McCain famously defended his rival as "a decent family man, citizen, that I just happen to have disagreements with on fundamental issues." (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 4 describes a "cynical form of politics" in which "persuasion is attempted by comparison rather than substance."  Using this tactic, "[a] party that achieves nothing, or even stands for nothing, can still maintain power if the alternative party seems sufficiently loathsome (vile or disgusting)."  The author rejects this type of politics, recommending steps that can be taken to "fix this problem, restoring the original sense of 'politics' in the minds of both voters and politicians" (Paragraph 5).
The first of these recommendations is that "politicians must commit themselves to acting in good faith and to upholding a kind of mutual aspiration."  The author illustrates this idea with a real-life example: "when attendees at a 2008 John McCain rally suggested that Barack Obama was untrustworthy and not an American citizen, McCain famously defended his rival as 'a decent family man, citizen, that I just happen to have disagreements with on fundamental issues'" (Paragraph 5).
By making this remark, McCain refused to endorse an unjustly negative personal portrayal of his opponent.  Instead, he characterized the two of them as equally engaged in what the author calls "a struggle between competing ideas about the good of society and between competing aspirants to society's leadership" (Paragraph 3).  Thus, McCain encouraged voters to consider each candidate according to an honest assessment of his merits.  Therefore, since the author cites this event as an example of how politicians ought to act, it would be most important for a politician to exhibit integrity in order to uphold the author's ideals.
 (Choice B)  Compassion.  The author praises how John McCain "famously defended his rival as 'a decent family man, citizen, that I just happen to have disagreements with on fundamental issues'" (Paragraph 5).  However, this defense was not primarily a matter of compassion or treating someone with kindness.  Rather, by refusing to go along with an undeservedly negative portrayal of his opponent, McCain exemplified "acting in good faith," displaying a sense of integrity.  Therefore, it is integrity, rather than compassion, that most connects to upholding the author's ideals.
(Choice C)  Self-assuredness.  A sense of self-assuredness would suggest a confidence in one's current position.  However, such confidence would not necessarily lend itself to the "open-minded reflection from candidates" that the author views as important (Paragraph 5).  Accordingly, the passage does not suggest that self-assuredness in a politician would be important for upholding the author's ideals.
(Choice D)  Optimism.  The author argues that "politicians must commit themselves to acting in good faith and to upholding a kind of mutual aspiration" (Paragraph 5).  However, the author's example of this process is how John McCain "famously defended his rival" from an unjustly negative portrayal.  Therefore, the type of aspiration that the author advocates specifically involves exhibiting decency and respect, not necessarily a sense of optimism.

text: Which of the following scenarios would LEAST exemplify "playing politics" as the author describes it?
explanations:
A common charge leveled at elected officeholders is that they are "playing politics."  The implication of the claim is that its target has skewed priorities: he or she ought to care about addressing the needs of the citizenry through legislation and governing but is wrongly focused on politics instead. (Paragraph 1)
Politics is inherently agonistic: a struggle between competing ideas about the good of society and between competing aspirants to society's leadership.  In its ideal form, the latter contest is subordinate to the former. (Paragraph 3)
When extended to political parties, playing politics would entail striving to aggrandize one's own side or diminish the opposition without actually contributing to the resolution of an issue.  In this cynical form of politics, persuasion is attempted by comparison rather than substance, the vaunting of an empty façade in which the supposed qualification to lead is divorced from leadership. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 1, an accusation of "'playing politics'" suggests that a politician "ought to care about addressing the needs of the citizenry through legislation and governing but is wrongly focused on politics instead."  Paragraph 4 elaborates on this idea, stating that "playing politics would entail striving to aggrandize (glorify) one's own side or diminish the opposition without actually contributing to the resolution of an issue.  In this cynical form of politics, persuasion is attempted by comparison rather than substance."
However, if a mayoral candidate continually stresses how his proposed solutions to the city's problems differ from those proposed by his opponent, he would be offering a comparison that is based on how each of the candidates would address the city's issues.  This fact-based argument for choosing him over his opponent would exemplify the classical conception of politics as "a struggle between competing ideas about the good of society and between competing aspirants to society's leadership" (Paragraph 3).  Consequently, this scenario would least exemplify "'playing politics'" as the author describes it.
 By contrast, each of the following would more strongly exemplify "'playing politics'" as the author describes it:
One party blocks all legislation proposed by another and then tells voters the other party has achieved nothing in office (Choice A).  This scenario exemplifies "striving to…diminish the opposition without actually contributing to the resolution of an issue" (Paragraph 4).
In preparation for a re-election campaign, a congressional representative researches the most effective ways to attack her likely opponent (Choice B).  This description mentions how the representative would attack her opponent, but it does not convey anything about her positions or goals in office.  Therefore, it suggests an attempt "to aggrandize one's own side or diminish the opposition without actually contributing to the resolution of an issue" (Paragraph 4).
To defend himself against accusations of lying, a senator highlights how frequently many senators are dishonest (Choice C).  Such a senator would be doing nothing to actually address the accusations against him.  Instead, he would simply be portraying other senators as "sufficiently loathsome (vile or disgusting)" in an attempt to look less bad by comparison (Paragraph 4).

text: The author would probably recommend that political debates should:
explanations:
So how do we fix this problem, restoring the original sense of "politics" in the minds of both voters and politicians?  The answer is twofold….  Second, citizens must commit themselves to valuing nuanced positions and open-minded reflection from candidates, rather than the snappy soundbites and one-liners that typify so much of political debate and media coverage.  If each group strives to embody these aims, we can return to genuinely engaging in politics rather than playing politics. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 begins by asking: "So how do we fix this problem [in modern politics], restoring the original sense of 'politics' in the minds of both voters and politicians?"  Part of the author's answer mentions political debate specifically: "citizens must commit themselves to valuing nuanced positions and open-minded reflection from candidates, rather than the snappy soundbites and one-liners that typify so much of political debate."
Because the author stresses the value of nuance and reflection, he or she most likely believes that political debate would be improved if politicians gave more detailed descriptions of their positions rather than quick answers to questions (ie, "snappy soundbites and one-liners").  Accordingly, the author would most likely recommend that political debates should encourage candidates to give longer, more thorough responses to questions.
 (Choice B)  ensure questions come from moderators representing multiple political parties.  Paragraph 5 conveys the author's disapproval of "the snappy soundbites and one-liners that typify so much of political debate and media coverage" (Paragraph 5).  Accordingly, it is possible that he or she would find fault with the kinds of questions asked at debates.  However, the author never discusses moderators or the parties to which they belong.  Moreover, the author's vision for politics concerns "acting in good faith" regardless of a candidate's party; by contrast, this scenario would seem to presume partisanship from moderators.
(Choice C)  incorporate more questions from professional scholars rather than ordinary citizens.  The author argues that "citizens must commit themselves to valuing nuanced positions and open-minded reflection from candidates, rather than the snappy soundbites and one-liners that typify so much of political debate and media coverage" (Paragraph 5).  However, he or she never discusses the source of the questions posed to candidates, nor suggests that such questions should come from scholars rather than ordinary citizens.
(Choice D)  prioritize asking questions to candidates with the widest voter appeal.  The author advocates "valuing nuanced positions and open-minded reflection from candidates" (Paragraph 5), suggesting that he or she favors significant consideration of various ideas.  However, a system that prioritized asking questions to certain candidates would deny others the same opportunities to voice their ideas, limiting the attention and discussion those candidates' views would receive.  Hence, the author would be unlikely to recommend this approach.

text: Shortly after the rally described in the passage, John McCain went on to lose the 2008 presidential election to Barack Obama.  Does this information undermine the author's recommendations for politicians?
explanations:
So how do we fix this problem, restoring the original sense of "politics" in the minds of both voters and politicians?  The answer is twofold.  First, politicians must commit themselves to acting in good faith and to upholding a kind of mutual aspiration.  For instance, when attendees at a 2008 John McCain rally suggested that Barack Obama was untrustworthy and not an American citizen, McCain famously defended his rival as "a decent family man, citizen, that I just happen to have disagreements with on fundamental issues."  Second, citizens must commit themselves to valuing nuanced positions and open-minded reflection from candidates, rather than the snappy soundbites and one-liners that typify so much of political debate and media coverage.  If each group strives to embody these aims, we can return to genuinely engaging in politics rather than playing politics. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 5, the goal of the author's recommendations is "restoring the original sense of 'politics' in the minds of both voters and politicians."  In order to achieve this goal, "politicians must commit themselves to acting in good faith and to upholding a kind of mutual aspiration."  As an example of this ideal, the author cites how John McCain refused to characterize Barack Obama as "untrustworthy and not an American citizen" but instead "famously defended his rival as 'a decent family man, citizen, that I just happen to have disagreements with on fundamental issues.'"
The author argues that if politicians and voters uphold this aspirational approach to political contests, then "we can return to genuinely engaging in politics rather than playing politics" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, the point of the author's recommendations for politicians is to improve the political process.  However, he or she never suggests that every politician who does so will win his or her election.  (Moreover, only one candidate can win any election, so if both candidates were to follow the author's recommendations, one of them would still lose.)
Consequently, the fact that John McCain lost the 2008 presidential election does not challenge the author's recommendations for politicians; those recommendations are aimed at transforming politics as a whole rather than ensuring particular electoral outcomes.
 Accordingly, the following responses mistake the author's goal to be about winning elections rather than reforming the political process:
Yes, it suggests they are too optimistic (Choice B).  Whether the author's recommendations are too optimistic would depend on whether they promote the "return to genuinely engaging in politics rather than playing politics" (Paragraph 5), not on whether a particular candidate wins or loses.
Yes, it reveals they are ineffective (Choice C).  McCain's remark was effective in "acting in good faith and…upholding a kind of mutual aspiration" (Paragraph 5), regardless of any electoral impact it may have had.
Yes, it shows they are unreliable (Choice D).  The author's recommendations might reliably help in "restoring the original sense of 'politics' in the minds of both voters and politicians" (Paragraph 5), even if individual politicians follow the recommendations and lose their elections.

text: Given the information in the passage, the assertion that representational art is "if not objectively, then at least concretely" superior to abstract art (Paragraph 1) is most likely meant to imply that:
explanations:
To begin with, we should make an admission: there is a sense in which—if not objectively, then at least concretely—representational art is superior to abstract art. (Paragraph 1)
Although that claim may seem shocking, the reasons behind it need to be acknowledged.  One advantage of representational art that abstract art often lacks is definite conditions for success.  To a significant degree, with representational works it is clear when an artist has done well: if an object or person has been accurately portrayed, anyone can see that something skillful has been accomplished.  Moreover, human beings have a natural desire to depict the world around us.  With representational art, then, ordinary viewers will generally see some purpose to the work whether or not they discern any deeper meaning or symbolism that the artist may have intended. (Paragraph 2)
With many abstract works, however, there are no broadly accessible grounds for judging their success or failure.  Nor is it always apparent what the purpose of such a work is….  The problem is not necessarily a perception that abstract works lack meaning—the real issue is more subtle. (Paragraph 3)
By stating that representational art is "not objectively" superior to abstract art (Paragraph 1), the author implies that it may not be better in an absolute sense or regardless of one's perspective.  However, the idea that it is "concretely" superior suggests there is some clearly defined advantage of representational art that motivates people's preference for it.  Paragraph 2 discusses such an advantage by noting that there are "definite conditions for success" in representational art that are absent in abstract art.  Specifically, "if an object or person has been accurately portrayed, anyone can see that something skillful has been accomplished."
In addition, these success conditions relate to human beings' "natural desire to depict the world around us."  As such, "ordinary viewers will generally see some purpose to" a representational work, regardless of any opinions they may have about its quality (Paragraph 2).  By contrast, with abstract works "there are no broadly accessible grounds for judging their success or failure.  Nor is it always apparent what the purpose of such a work is" (Paragraph 3).  Thus, the author argues that the purpose of abstract art requires justification, but the purpose of representational art is essentially taken for granted.  Accordingly, representational art is superior in this specific respect.
Therefore, the "concrete" advantage of representational art is that, unlike abstract works, it is easy for people to see the purpose of representational works.  Consequently, the assertion that representational art is "if not objectively, then at least concretely" superior to abstract art (Paragraph 1) is most likely meant to imply that while the value of any art can be questioned, there is a naturally accepted purpose to representation.
  (Choice A)  scholars should recognize the futility of promoting abstract art to the public.  Paragraph 1 describes "the low opinion that the public at large has of abstract works and styles."  However, the passage never suggests that promoting abstract works to the public is futile.  Rather, the author implies that the public's attitude might be changed, and offers recommendations for how art scholars can "better convey the value of abstract works" (Paragraph 5).
(Choice B)  unlike abstract art, representational art expresses an artist's meaning concretely.  Paragraph 2 implies that viewers may fail to perceive the meaning of representational art: "ordinary viewers will generally see some purpose to the work whether or not they discern any deeper meaning."  In addition, Paragraph 4 states that "the difficulty with abstract art is not that ordinary viewers can find no meaning in it."  Therefore, the passage does not suggest that representational art is superior in terms of the way in which an artist's meaning is expressed.
(Choice D)  the two types of art differ in terms of value rather than goals.  The author does not draw such a distinction between value and goals in the passage.  Moreover, the passage suggests that the two types of art do differ in terms of goals, as only representational art is intended to "portray literal likenesses" (Paragraph 1).

text: Which of the following statements best describes the main point of the passage?
explanations:
For those of us whose careers are devoted to art, a common frustration is the low opinion that the public at large has of abstract works and styles....  Naturally, we in the art world would like to change this attitude, to better share what we recognize as valuable artistic experiences….  I think it behooves us to re-evaluate our perspective.  If we are committed to the idea that art is enriching to ordinary lives, we must take more seriously the question of why the popular preference exists. (Paragraph 1)
One advantage of representational art that abstract art often lacks is definite conditions for success.  To a significant degree, with representational works it is clear when an artist has done well….  Moreover, human beings have a natural desire to depict the world around us.  (Paragraph 2)
Thus, our frustrating cliché may reveal an important truth: the difficulty with abstract art is not that ordinary viewers can find no meaning in it.  Rather, there is no obvious reason why anyone other than the artist should care what that meaning is. (Paragraph 4)
This, then, is the issue that we as art scholars must address if we want to better convey the value of abstract works.  To explore this topic fully will require a more extensive treatment, but I would like to offer a starting point for reflection….  The task is to universalize: to make clear how an artist's vision is more than idiosyncratic, extending to the shared spaces of human experience. (Paragraph 5)
At both the beginning and the end of the passage, the author expresses the goal of encouraging ordinary people to appreciate abstract art.  For instance, Paragraph 1 mentions "the low opinion that the public at large has of abstract works and styles," with the author asserting that "we in the art world would like to change this attitude."  He or she suggests that in order to accomplish such a change, art scholars must "re-evaluate our perspective" on ordinary views and "take more seriously" the reasons behind them.
The middle sections of the passage then address those reasons.  According to the author, a crucial difference between the two types of art is that there are "definite conditions for success" with representational works, relating to humans' "natural desire to depict the world around us" (Paragraph 2).  By contrast, abstract works lack this feature, leading to a perception that they have value only for the artist and not anyone else: "there is no obvious reason why anyone other than the artist should care what [an abstract work's] meaning is" (Paragraph 4).
Paragraph 5 identifies this perception as "the issue that we as art scholars must address if we want to better convey the value of abstract works."  Thus, the author returns to the goal from Paragraph 1, offering recommendations for changing ordinary people's attitudes toward abstract art.  He or she ultimately concludes that "[t]he task is to universalize: to make clear how an artist's vision is more than idiosyncratic, extending to the shared spaces of human experience."  Therefore, the main point of the passage is that for ordinary viewers to value abstract works, scholars must forge connections between such works and people's own experiences.
  (Choices B and D)  Representational art is superior to abstract art in at least one important respect; and Abstract works of art lack clearly identifiable conditions for judging their success or failure.  According to Paragraph 1, "there is a sense in which…representational art is superior to abstract art."  Paragraph 2 then specifies: "One advantage of representational art that abstract art often lacks is definite conditions for success."  Thus, these points relate to why most ordinary viewers prefer representational art over abstract art.  However, the main point of the passage concerns what "we as art scholars" should do in response to that preference, in order "to better convey the value of abstract works" (Paragraph 5).
(Choice C)  Representational art is generally preferred by most people over abstract art.  According to Paragraph 1, "[t]he tendency for most people is to strongly prefer representational art, while mostly disdaining works that do not portray literal likenesses."  However, the main point of the passage concerns how those in the art world could work "to change this attitude, to better share what we recognize as valuable artistic experiences."

text: Based on the information in the passage, the author believes that his or her audience is largely:
explanations:
For those of us whose careers are devoted to art, a common frustration is the low opinion that the public at large has of abstract works and styles.….  Naturally, we in the art world would like to change this attitude, to better share what we recognize as valuable artistic experiences.  Perhaps we even look down upon the public a little bit—smugly superior in the face of one more clichéd remark that "a four-year-old could do that."  I think it behooves us to re-evaluate our perspective.  If we are committed to the idea that art is enriching to ordinary lives, we must take more seriously the question of why the popular preference exists.  To begin with, we should make an admission: there is a sense in which—if not objectively, then at least concretely—representational art is superior to abstract art. (Paragraph 1)
Although that claim may seem shocking, the reasons behind it need to be acknowledged.  One advantage of representational art that abstract art often lacks is definite conditions for success. (Paragraph 2)
This, then, is the issue that we as art scholars must address if we want to better convey the value of abstract works. (Paragraph 5)
The author writes from the perspective of "those of us whose careers are devoted to art" (Paragraph 1) and appears to be directing his or her remarks to a similarly dedicated audience.  For instance, Paragraph 1 describes an attitude that "we in the art world would like to change," and Paragraph 5 discusses "the issue that we as art scholars must address."  Thus, part of the author's argument concerns how his or her fellow art scholars are likely to react to passage claims.
In particular, the author refers to how such scholars view ordinary people's tendency to appreciate representational art but dislike abstract art.  In Paragraph 1, he or she suggests that "we even look down upon the public a little bit" for their preference, adding that "we must take more seriously the question of why the popular preference exists."  Furthermore, after suggesting there is a sense in which the ordinary view is justified, the author states: "Although that claim may seem shocking, the reasons behind it need to be acknowledged" (Paragraph 2).  Thus, the author implies that his or her audience is dismissive of ordinary people's views and needs to be convinced that those views deserve further consideration.
Therefore, based on the information in the passage, the author believes that his or her audience is largely biased against the passage idea that ordinary people's views may be reasonable.
  (Choice A)  skeptical of how the passage describes ordinary people's attitudes.  According to Paragraph 1, people in the art world share "a common frustration" regarding "the low opinion that the public at large has of abstract works and styles."  Similarly, the author suggests that "we even look down on the public" because of their "clichéd" reactions to such works.  Therefore, the author seems to assume the audience's agreement about how the passage describes ordinary people's attitudes.
(Choice C)  unsure of the passage claim that art is enriching to ordinary lives.  In Paragraph 1, the author discusses how "we in the art world would like…to better share what we recognize as valuable artistic experiences."  He or she later adds: "If we are committed to the idea that art is enriching to ordinary lives, we must take more seriously the question of why the popular preference exists."  Thus, the author implies that his or her audience does believe that art is enriching to ordinary lives.
(Choice D)  predisposed to favor the passage's recommendations for those in the art world.  In Paragraph 1, the author recommends that "we in the art world" should "re-evaluate our perspective" regarding ordinary views of art.  Similarly, after suggesting that the ordinary views might have some justification, he or she remarks that "that claim may seem shocking" (Paragraph 2).  Therefore, the author implies that his or her audience needs to be convinced to accept the passage's recommendations, not that the audience is predisposed to favor them.

text: Why does the author most likely "revisit the hypothetical four-year-old" (Paragraph 4)?
explanations:
Perhaps we even look down upon the public a little bit—smugly superior in the face of one more clichéd remark that "a four-year-old could do that."  I think it behooves us to re-evaluate our perspective.  If we are committed to the idea that art is enriching to ordinary lives, we must take more seriously the question of why the popular preference exists. (Paragraph 1)
To a curator, an untitled Joan Mitchell canvas may be a "bold departure from traditional forms" warranting serious contemplation.  But to museum visitors, it may be an indistinct hodgepodge warranting only a brief glance en route to paintings with recognizable subjects. (Paragraph 3)
To see why, let us revisit the hypothetical four-year-old.  When a child produces art, we likely judge the production as beneficial to her: she has expressed herself, exercised creativity, and so on.  But there is little reason to think that anyone else (save perhaps her parents or teacher) should find her work important.  Thus, our frustrating cliché may reveal an important truth: the difficulty with abstract art is not that ordinary viewers can find no meaning in it.  Rather, there is no obvious reason why anyone other than the artist should care what that meaning is. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 1 describes a "clichéd" response to abstract works of art in which people claim that "'a four-year-old could do that.'"  Although people in the art world look down on this attitude, the author suggests that they should "take more seriously the question of why" this reaction is so common.  Thus, he or she later revisits this idea in discussing the public's tendency to be unimpressed by abstract works.  After suggesting that most viewers would ignore an abstract painting in favor of "paintings with recognizable subjects" (Paragraph 3), the author writes: "To see why, let us revisit the hypothetical four-year-old" (Paragraph 4).
Specifically, abstract works may seem similar to the works of young children in terms of how their meaning is perceived by observers.  For instance, when a child produces an artwork, "she has expressed herself, exercised creativity, and so on.  But there is little reason to think that anyone else…should find her work important" (Paragraph 4).  Similarly, if an abstract work does not concern "recognizable subjects" (Paragraph 3), there may be nothing to connect it to a viewer's experience.  Hence, while it may express the artist's personal ideas, there would be "no obvious reason why anyone other than the artist should care what [the work's] meaning is" (Paragraph 4).
Therefore, the author most likely decides to "revisit the hypothetical four-year-old" to help clarify why abstract art is often underappreciated.
  (Choice A)  to demonstrate the clichéd nature of a common reaction to abstract styles.  According to Paragraph 4, "our frustrating cliché may reveal an important truth" about abstract art.  Therefore, the author's choice to "revisit the hypothetical four-year-old" is not meant to demonstrate the clichéd nature of the common reaction, but to explain why abstract works lead to such a reaction in the first place.
(Choice B)  to help explain why the general public dislikes works by Joan Mitchell.  Paragraph 3 refers to "an untitled Joan Mitchell canvas" as an example of art that professional scholars may find impressive but that the general public would likely ignore.  However, the author uses this example to make a claim about perceptions of abstract art as a whole: "The problem is not necessarily a perception that abstract works lack meaning—the real issue is more subtle."  Therefore, the suggestion to "revisit the hypothetical four-year-old" (Paragraph 4) is not meant to explain an attitude toward Joan Mitchell works specifically, but to make a broader observation about how people perceive abstract art.
(Choice D)  to describe why abstract works have less value than representational ones.  The author's aim in the passage is to help promote the value of abstract works of art.  For instance, Paragraph 1 refers to such works as "valuable artistic experiences," and Paragraph 5 expresses the goal of "better convey[ing] the value of abstract works."  Therefore, although revisiting the hypothetical four-year-old helps explain why most ordinary viewers prefer representational works, the author does not argue that abstract works have less value than representational ones.

text: Which of the following works would be an example of "representational art" as the author uses the term?
explanations:
For those of us whose careers are devoted to art, a common frustration is the low opinion that the public at large has of abstract works and styles.  The tendency for most people is to strongly prefer representational art, while mostly disdaining works that do not portray literal likenesses. (Paragraph 1)
To a significant degree, with representational works it is clear when an artist has done well: if an object or person has been accurately portrayed, anyone can see that something skillful has been accomplished.  Moreover, human beings have a natural desire to depict the world around us. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 1, works of art are "representational" when they "portray literal likenesses."  Similarly, Paragraph 2 conveys that the goal of representational art is for "an object or person [to be] accurately portrayed."  Therefore, the author uses the term "representational art" to refer to works that realistically depict how beings or objects appear in the world.
Similarly, a painting of animals as they appear from a ground-level vantage point would illustrate how the animals literally appear from a given perspective.  Consequently, such a work would be an example of "representational art" as the author uses the term.
  By contrast, none of the following works is an example of "representational art" as the author uses the term:
A painting portraying animals as collections of geometric shapes (Choice B).  Portraying animals as collections of geometric shapes would leave out specific details of the animals' physical appearance.  Accordingly, such a depiction would not yield "literal likenesses" of the animals (Paragraph 1).
A painting of animals that represent the artist's hidden fears (Choice C).  In this context, the animals would "represent" the artist's fears in a symbolic way, not a literal one (ie, the animals' physical appearance would not literally resemble the emotion of fear).  By contrast, the author uses the term "representational" to refer to art that depicts the visible appearance of a being or object.
A still life that depicts common objects from multiple perspectives at once (Choice D).  In the natural world, objects are only viewed from a single perspective at a time.  Therefore, depicting objects from multiple perspectives at once would not exemplify "representational art" as the author uses the term.

text: In one episode of a 1981 TV show, an art critic praises a painting of a single circle, stating that it "reduces experience to its most elemental aesthetic" and is "quite profound in its simplicity."  This scenario best supports the assertion that:
explanations:
A typical skepticism toward art analysis stems from the impression that it is characterized by trickery or puffery of some sort.  The average viewer sees little of note in a given work, but is assured of its great significance by a member of the intellectual elite; if only the viewer understood art, he would perceive the work's many virtues….  We must dispel this misconception.  The task is to universalize: to make clear how an artist's vision is more than idiosyncratic, extending to the shared spaces of human experience. (Paragraph 5)
In Paragraph 5, the author discusses a common negative perception of art analysis.  Many people perceive such analysis as making implausible, grandiose claims about art that is actually unimpressive: "The average viewer sees little of note in a given work but is assured of its great significance by a member of the intellectual elite; if only the viewer understood art, he would perceive the work's many virtues."
Similarly, an art critic who praises a painting of a single circle could easily be seen as exemplifying such a tendency toward implausible and grandiose claims.  By describing how supposedly "profound" such a simplistic painting is, the critic contributes to the perception that art analysis is "characterized by trickery or puffery of some sort" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, this scenario best supports the assertion that art analysis is often viewed with skepticism because it can seem pretentious or phony.
  By contrast, this scenario would not best support the assertion that:
an abstract work may seem like "an indistinct hodgepodge" that is difficult to make sense of (Choice B).  Although the painting of the circle is presumably meant to be abstract, it would not constitute "an indistinct hodgepodge (confusing jumble)" (Paragraph 3).  Rather, a single circle would be a distinct, easily identifiable shape.
those in the art world are often frustrated by ordinary people's views of abstract works (Choice C).  Paragraph 1 states that "[f]or those of us whose careers are devoted to art, a common frustration is the low opinion that the public at large has of abstract works and styles."  However, in the given scenario, the art critic does not express any attitudes about ordinary people's opinions; rather, he simply praises the painting.
with representational art it is generally clear when an artist has done well (Choice D).  By claiming that the painting is "quite profound in its simplicity," the art critic highlights the supposedly deep significance of the painting, not the artist's accuracy in depicting a circle.  Hence, the scenario does not exemplify the ease of determining when "an object or person has been accurately portrayed" (Paragraph 2).

text: The poem based on Munch's diary entry is most likely incorporated into the passage (Paragraph 2) to:
explanations:
In a poem based on an 1892 diary entry, Munch relates the genesis of what would become his most celebrated work.  He was walking across a bridge with two friends in the vicinity of Ekeberg Hill, overlooking Oslo, when "…the sun was setting—suddenly the sky turned blood-red—I paused, feeling exhausted, and leaned on the fence—there was blood and tongues of fire above the blue-black fjord and the city––my friends walked on and I stood there trembling with anxiety—and I sensed an infinite Scream passing through nature." (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 quotes Munch's "poem based on an 1892 diary entry" describing "the genesis (origin or beginning) of his most celebrated work," namely, the moment when he "'sensed an infinite Scream passing through nature.'"  Consequently, the author most likely incorporated this poem into the passage in order to depict the circumstances surrounding the artwork's conception (origin).
By contrast, it is unlikely that the author incorporated the poem into the passage in order to:
show that an artist can use a short-lived moment as a stimulus for a permanent work of art (Choice A).  In Paragraph 2, the author explicitly states that Munch's poem "relates the genesis" of The Scream, indicating that this is the purpose of the poem's inclusion in the passage.  Therefore, describing the short-lived moment when the artist "'sensed an infinite Scream'" serves to depict how the painting came into being (ie, its conception or origin) rather than to show how a particular moment might become a stimulus for a permanent work of art.
portray Munch as a writer (Choice B).  Paragraph 2 quotes a poem Munch wrote "based on an 1892 diary entry" about his personal experience when he "'sensed an infinite Scream passing through nature.'"  However, the passage makes no further mention of Munch's poetry or writing, nor does it ever identify Munch as a writer.
show the appeal of Munch's paintings (Choice D).  As Paragraph 2 makes clear, the poem based on the diary entry relates an experience of Munch's that served as "the genesis " of The Scream.  However, although the content of this poem might prove useful for understanding the appeal of this painting, it reveals nothing about Munch's other paintings or their appeal.

text: The passage suggests that a work of art is most relatable if it:
explanations:
Nevertheless, as art curator Martha Tedeschi asserts, The Scream is one of only a handful of paintings in the history of art able to "communicate a specific meaning almost immediately to almost every viewer"; its primitive character transmits a raw emotionality and subjectivity.  Unsurprisingly, then, the painting has over-spilt the bounds of traditional art to become an icon of popular culture. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 quotes Tedeschi's claim that The Scream is "only one of a handful of paintings…able to 'communicate a specific meaning almost immediately to almost every viewer.'"  It can therefore be inferred that the author believes that exuding (radiating) universal appeal is what makes a work of art most relatable—that is, easy for people to relate to or find meaning in.
By contrast, the passage does not suggest that a work of art is most relatable if it:
combines popular styles (Choice A).  Paragraph 4 states that when painting The Scream, Munch was "[i]nfluenced by luminaries (prominent individuals) such as the impressionist painter Monet and the more deeply expressive Van Gogh."  Although this evidence shows that Munch did combine popular artistic styles, the passage does not suggest that combining styles was essential to making this work, or any artwork, easy for people to relate to.
embodies the mood of the times (Choice C).  Paragraph 4 states that "The Scream aptly captured both the self-indulgence (decline and excess) and despair characterizing the turn of the twentieth century at the same time that it heralded the existential angst (deep anxiety or dread) of the mid-century."  However, Paragraph 5 explains that The Scream can "'communicate a specific meaning almost immediately to almost every viewer,'" showing that it also exemplifies an artwork that is easy for viewers from many different time periods to relate to.
portrays its subject realistically (Choice D).  Paragraph 3 describes the main figure in The Scream as being "ill-defined and ghostlike...against the menacing background of a bloodshot sky."  Such a description demonstrates that The Scream portrays its subject unrealistically.

text: Which of the following best represents the author's primary concern in the passage?
explanations:
…Edvard Munch's instantly identifiable painting…The Scream, destabilizes the very concept of a work of art as discrete and unique…[and] constitutes not a single but a multiplicitous work. (Paragraph 1)
…Munch's free-form style, vivid colors, and striking juxtapositions mark this work as avant-garde. (Paragraph 4)
The Scream is one of only a handful of paintings in the history of art able to "communicate a specific meaning almost immediately to almost every viewer"…. [T]he painting has over-spilt the bounds of traditional art to become an icon of popular culture. (Paragraph 5)
Ironically, however, it is the "single" provocative image of The Scream that, as both masterpiece and pop icon, has eclipsed all this artist's other works. (Paragraph 7)
According to Paragraph 1, The Scream is "instantly identifiable" (ie, indicating popularity) but deviates from "the very concept of a work of art as discrete (separate and distinct) and unique" because it boasts multiple versions and was "conceived of…not as a freestanding piece" of art.  Moreover, in Paragraph 4, the painting's "free-form style, vivid colors, and striking juxtapositions" are labeled "avant-garde (unusual or innovative)."
Paragraph 5 discusses how The Scream has "become an icon of popular culture," and Paragraph 6 relates two "unusual thefts" of the painting that have added to its notoriety.  Lastly, Paragraph 7 claims that, due to its popularity, The Scream "has eclipsed all this artist's other works."
Consequently, the main concern of the passage is to consider aspects of a work of art that may have contributed to its unusualness and popularity.
By contrast, the following do not represent the passage's main concern:
To provide evidence that artists with many works are more successful than those with fewer works (Choice B).  Paragraph 7 shows that despite being a "remarkably prolific (productive) painter," Munch is mostly famous for just a single work, The Scream.  Therefore, the passage does not suggest that an artist's success is directly connected to the quantity of his or her work.
To support increased opportunities for artists to express their personal experiences in their work (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 describes The Scream as "the artistic consequence" of Munch's "terrifying epiphany"—that is, his personal experience.  Although the painting therefore constitutes an example of artwork based on personal experience, the passage neither discusses nor supports more opportunities for artists to express their personal experiences in their work.
To show how the existence of multiple versions affects the value of a particular work (Choice D).  Paragraph 1 describes The Scream as "[b]oasting two versions in pastel and two in oil" and as "arguably constitut[ing] not a single but a multiplicitous work."  However, the passage never associates multiple versions of a work with its artistic or material value.

text: The author's probable motive in mentioning the thieves' postcard message is to show that:
explanations:
In an almost comical heist, two men employed a ladder to easily access a second-story window and abscond with the painting, taking the time to leave a postcard that read, "Thanks for the poor security."  Then, in 2004, robbers entered Oslo's Munch Museum in broad daylight, intimidated museum guards with firearms, and used a wire cutter to extract another version of The Scream from the wall along with Munch's Madonna painting. (Paragraph 6)
Paragraph 6 relates that when a version of The Scream was stolen in 1994, the thieves "[took] the time to leave a postcard that read, 'Thanks for the poor security.'"  The inclusion of this detail adds humor to the narrative but, more importantly, also shows how the thieves wished to underscore (emphasize) the ease with which they were able to abscond (escape or flee) with this famous painting.  This inference is further supported by the stark contrast with the second theft, in which thieves "intimidated museum guards with firearms" in order to seize the painting (Paragraph 6).
By contrast, the author's probable motive for mentioning the postcard message was not to show that:
complicated methods were used to steal the painting (Choice B).  Paragraph 6 relays how "two men employed a ladder to easily access a second-story window and abscond with the painting."  This description of the heist (robbery) makes it clear that the methods used to steal The Scream were not complicated but simple and easy, requiring only a ladder.
the thieves' commentary did not hinder accomplishment of the theft (Choice C).  Leaving behind the postcard did not hinder the accomplishment of the theft but did serve to underscore its unusual ease.
the thieves' plan to bypass security was very carefully organized (Choice D).  Paragraph 6 states that the thieves used a ladder "to easily access a second-story window and abscond with the painting."  This information indicates that their theft of The Scream was simple, but not necessarily that they had a carefully organized plan to bypass security.  The thieves left the postcard message behind because there was an obvious lack of security that made the theft unusually easy.

text: In the context of the passage, the word kitsch can most accurately be defined as:
explanations:
Wildly appropriated and often misused, the image—through which Munch purported to be doing nothing less than studying his own soul—has appeared on everything from keychains to dormitory posters and is in danger of becoming kitsch. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 describes how The Scream has turned into "an icon of popular culture": the image has been "mass-produced," "wildly appropriated," and "often misused," appearing on "everything from keychains to dormitory posters," and therefore "in danger of becoming kitsch."
Overall, Paragraph 5 emphasizes that the image of The Scream has been trivialized and its status as art diminished through uses that could be judged as in poor taste.  It even implies that these treatments of the image have degraded Munch's stated artistic intention in creating The Scream of "studying his own soul."  Consequently, in the context of the passage, the word kitsch could most accurately be defined as tasteless art.
By contrast, the following definitions do not accurately define the word kitsch as it is used in the context of the passage:
lofty style (Choice A).  Paragraph 5 refers to the image as being "wildly appropriated," "misused," and "in danger of becoming kitsch."  A lofty style (ie, a positive, elevated, and tasteful presentation) would constitute the opposite of these negative treatments.
cheap workmanship (Choice C).  Paragraph 5 clearly states that it is the "misuse" and wild appropriation of the image itself rather than the workmanship (mechanical skill) invested in its reproduction that puts it "in danger of becoming kitsch."
playful imitation (Choice D).  Paragraph 5 discusses how the "misuse" of the image of The Scream has put it "in danger of becoming kitsch."  However, a playful imitation of an artistic image would not necessarily constitute a misuse of the image; for example, it could represent a meaningful parody of the original work or an homage.

text: Suppose that the majority of artists prefer to create several versions of a work.  How would this correspond to the ideas about art presented in the passage?
explanations:
Norwegian artist Edvard Munch's instantly identifiable painting Der Schrei der Natur or, more simply, The Scream, destabilizes the very concept of a work of art as discrete and unique.  Boasting two versions in pastel and two in oil as well as a lithograph—all generated between 1893 and 1910—Munch's masterpiece arguably constitutes not a single but a multiplicitous work.  Moreover, Munch originally conceived of the painting not as a freestanding piece, but as part of a more ambitious project called the Frieze of Life. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 identifies "the very concept of a work of art" as something "discrete (ie, separate and distinct) and unique," in contrast to The Scream, which boasts "two versions in pastel and two in oil as well as a lithograph (a type of print)."  Consequently, finding out that the majority of artists actually prefer to create several versions rather than just one version of a work would weaken the passage contention that the standard work of art is singular and separate.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 1 states that the typical work of art is "discrete and unique" and then holds up Munch's painting The Scream as unusual because it is "multiplicitous" and does not embody these qualities.  Paragraph 1 also implies that The Scream is unusual because it was not created as a "freestanding piece" of art.  Therefore, if the majority of artists prefer to create several versions of a work, this finding would weaken rather than strengthen the passage contention that The Scream is an unusual work of art.
(Choice C)  Paragraph 5 relates that, according to art curator Martha Tedeschi, "The Scream is one of only a handful of paintings in the history of art able to 'communicate a specific meaning almost immediately to almost every viewer.'"  Although this assertion implies that only a few paintings have universal appeal, it does not draw a connection between an artwork's multiplicity and its appeal.  Therefore, if the majority of artists prefer to create several versions of a work, this finding would be irrelevant to the passage inference that only a few paintings possess such universal appeal.
(Choice D)  Paragraph 1 relates how Munch created a work of art that boasted "two versions in pastel and two in oil as well as a lithograph" and "arguably constitute[d] not a single but a multiplicitous work."  Therefore, the idea that artists prefer to express the same artistic vision in slightly different forms would strengthen rather than weaken the passage inference that there can be more than one version of an artistic vision.

text: Why does the author most likely introduce the topic of the Victorian Internet by discussing the sociological conditions prevalent between 1820 and 1914?
explanations:
Lasting roughly from 1820 to 1914, the Victorian Era is often defined by its many distinctive sociological conditions, including industrialization, urbanization, railroad travel, imperialism, territorial expansionism, and the frictions sparked by Darwinism and democratic reform.  However, descriptors that may not come as readily to mind are "the Information Age" and "the Age of Communication"; nor would we likely associate this era with something called the "highway of thought," which emanated from the electric telegraph—an invention that, in retrospect, could be renamed "the Victorian Internet."  Yet the rise of the electric telegraph in the mid-1800s constituted the greatest revolution in communication since the invention of the printing press in the fifteenth century and until the launch of the World Wide Web at the end of the twentieth century. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 attempts to show the popular view of the Victorian Era.
