The author describes it as "often defined by its many distinctive sociological conditions, including industrialization, urbanization, railroad travel, imperialism, territorial expansionism, and the frictions sparked by Darwinism and democratic reform."  The author then stresses that the Victorian Era is not typically thought of as "'the Information Age' and 'the Age of Communication,'" nor is the telegraph commonly recognized as "an invention that…could be renamed 'the Victorian Internet.'"  He or she also emphasizes that "the rise of the electric telegraph…constituted the greatest revolution in communication" since the printing press and before the World Wide Web.
Accordingly, the author shows that, although the telegraph had a dramatic impact, Victorian society had already experienced a series of cultural upheavals and technological innovations by the time telegraphic communication arose.  As people are more likely to associate the Victorian Era with those other dramatic changes, the impact of the telegraph often goes unacknowledged.  Therefore, the most likely reason the author introduces the topic of the Victorian Internet by discussing the sociological conditions prevalent between 1820 and 1914 is to suggest that the many other dramatic changes of the period cause people to overlook the telegraph's impact.
 (Choices A and B)  To explore the details of an era of change leading to the inevitable development of the telegraph; and To reveal the socioeconomic factors that made improvements in communication possible.  Paragraph 1 lists many of the significant changes that occurred during the Victorian Era, including "industrialization, urbanization, railroad travel, imperialism, [and] territorial expansionism," as well as "the frictions sparked by Darwinism and democratic reform."  The author then describes the development of the telegraph as another dramatic but often unrecognized change during this era.  However, he or she never provides any information to suggest that the telegraph's development was an inevitable result of the other changes that took place.  Furthermore, the author never suggests that the rise of the telegraph, or other improvements in communication, was made possible by the given socioeconomic factors.
(Choice D)  To overcome the notion of the telegraph as a phenomenon that transcended its time.  In referring to telegraphic communication as "the greatest revolution in communication since…the printing press in the fifteenth century and…the World Wide Web at the end of the twentieth century" (Paragraph 1), the author connects the telegraph system with both a past and a future system of dramatically accelerated communication.  Accordingly, the passage does not present the telegraph as a phenomenon entirely embedded in the specific sociological conditions of the Victorian Era; instead, it is revealed to be another transformative and highly influential communication revolution in world history.  Thus, the author likely discusses the sociological conditions prevalent at the time in order to support rather than to overcome the notion of the telegraph as transcending its time.

text: Based on the passage, the comparison between Victorian and modern online subcultures suggests:
explanations:
A new type of skilled worker, the telegrapher, was born.  He or she belonged to a vast, online community, whose semi-anonymous members shared a unique intermediary role as well as a language of dots and dashes—vaguely prefiguring the exchange of bits and bytes along modern computer networks.  Like today's online communities, these telegraphers fostered their own subculture: jokes and anecdotes flew over the wires; some operators invented systems to play games, and occasional romances blossomed.  Regrettably, hackers, scammers, and shady entrepreneurs also frequented the byways of this early internet. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, "the telegrapher…belonged to a vast, online community" of individuals who remained largely unknown but "shared a language of dots and dashes—vaguely prefiguring the exchange of bits and bytes along today's computer networks."  The author further explains how "these telegraphers fostered their own subculture," which was like a modern online community: "[J]okes and anecdotes flew over the wires; some operators invented systems to play games, and occasional romances blossomed."  As with today's internet, there were also "hackers, scammers, and shady entrepreneurs."
Accordingly, despite the vast differences between the culture of the Victorian Era and that of the twenty-first century, the passage suggests that their respective communication systems led to similar shared online experiences and so to the development of comparable subcultures.  Therefore, based on the passage, the comparison between Victorian and modern online subcultures suggests that that even when two cultures are distinct, their online subcultures tend to be similar.
 (Choice B)  that the development of a subculture is the most significant effect of online communication.  Paragraph 3 focuses on the profound socioeconomic consequences of telegraphic communication such as "'an irreversible acceleration in the pace of business life.'"  In Paragraph 4, the author also notes that an online subculture of telegraphers, "whose semi-anonymous members shared a unique intermediary role as well as a language of dots and dashes," developed.  However, in comparison with the socioeconomic effect, the author seems to view the development of such a subculture as an interesting and inevitable (but not particularly significant) effect of telegraphic communication, similar to the development of today's online internet communities.
(Choice C)  that an online subculture is defined solely by a shared language.  In Paragraph 4, the author describes "the vast, online community" of Victorian telegraphers as "semi-anonymous" and sharing "a unique intermediary role as well as a language of dots and dashes."  Thus, while the author implies that a shared language is essential to defining this online subculture, he or she also mentions shared status and a role.  The author then goes on to compare the telegraph subculture to "today's online communities," describing various activities characteristic of both: "[J]okes and anecdotes flew over the wires; some operators invented systems to play games, and occasional romances blossomed."  Accordingly, the passage does not suggest that an online subculture is defined solely by a shared language.
(Choice D)  that the transmission of messages cannot be trusted due to online criminal activity.  According to Paragraph 4, telegraphers formed "a vast, online community" with its own subculture.  The author then points out that "hackers, scammers, and shady entrepreneurs also frequented the byways of this early internet."  Thus, some illicit activity was being conducted on the Victorian Internet, as it is on today's internet.  However, the passage emphasizes that the telegraph sparked dramatic changes in communication and business, suggesting that, despite some criminal activity, online transmission of messages could generally be trusted.

text: Given passage information, which of the following assertions most aptly describes how the economic climate of the Victorian Era was transformed as a result of the telegraph?
explanations:
Following some spectacular failures, a durable cable was stretched across the floor of the Atlantic Ocean, enabling Europe and the U.S. to exchange messages within minutes.  In the 1870s, the British Empire connected London with outposts in India and Australia.  While individual telegram speed remained relatively constant, an endless deluge of information began to pour through the wires.  There was, as Tom Standage observes, "an irreversible acceleration in the pace of business life," reflecting how "telegraphy and commerce thrived in a virtuous circle."  It was as though "rapid long-distance communication had effectively obliterated time and space," begetting the phenomenon known as "globalization." (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 outlines how foreign communications and, thus, commerce increased as telegraphic networks were expanded: "a durable cable was stretched across the floor of the Atlantic Ocean, enabling Europe and the U.S. to exchange messages within minutes.  In the 1870s, the British Empire connected London with outposts in India and Australia."  As a result of this expansion, "an endless deluge of information poured through the wires," triggering "'an irreversible acceleration in the pace of business life.'"  Hence, telegraphy and commerce were mutually reinforced.  Overall, the impact of these changes was so profound it seemed that the telegraph "'had effectively obliterated time and space.'"
Accordingly, as overseas communication irreversibly increased, businesses evolved in response to the new "'rapid long-distance communication'" and its effects.  Therefore, as a result of the transformation wrought by the telegraph, the economic climate during the Victorian Era adapted to an acceleration of foreign communications.
 (Choice A)  It adapted to regulations controlling the pace of business.  Paragraph 3 states that after the expansion of both the domestic and foreign telegraph networks, there was "'an irreversible acceleration in the pace of business life,'" and telegraphy and commerce mutually thrived.  However, the passage never mentions any regulations designed to control the increased pace of business after the telegraph came into wide commercial use.
(Choices C and D)  It adapted to an increase in the localization of markets; and It adapted to a reduction in domestic trade deals.  According to Paragraph 3, when the transatlantic cable was installed, it enabled "Europe and the U.S. to exchange messages within minutes."  In addition, the distant parts of the British Empire were connected with London.  As a result of this telegraph expansion, "an endless deluge of information poured through the wires."  Moreover, "there was…'an irreversible acceleration in the pace of business life,'" as telegraphy and commerce reinforced each other.  According to the passage, "'[R]apid long-distance communication…obliterated time and space,' begetting the modern phenomenon known as 'globalization.'"  Thus, during the Victorian Era, the economic climate had to adapt to an increase in the globalization, not the localization, of markets due to the rise of the telegraph.  However, although the passage indicates an increase in international trade, it never suggests that there was a corresponding reduction in domestic trade deals.

text: In the last paragraph, the author compares telegrams with text messages.  Based on this comparison, the author considers the telegram to be a communication mode that was:
explanations:
Predictably, newer forms of the original telegraphic technology—first the telephone and, much later, the fax machine—eventually encroached.  The last telegram departed from India in 2013, but the twenty-first century has arguably seen a revival of this communication form in the text message.  As Standage claims, texting has not only "reincarnate[d] a defunct nineteenth-century technology" but reinforced "the democratization of telecommunications" inaugurated by the miraculous Victorian Internet. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 5, "[T]he twenty-first century has arguably seen a revival of this communication form in the text message."  The author then cites Tom Standage's claim that texting has not only brought back to life a nineteenth century form of technology but "reinforced 'the democratization of telecommunications'" begun with "the miraculous Victorian Internet."  The term "democratization" strongly implies that the telegram was widely available in its time, offering many members of Victorian society the chance to use this form of fast long-distance communication.
Accordingly, the author indicates that, as with text messaging today, the telegram in the Victorian Era was a mode of communication readily available to most of the general population.  Therefore, based on the comparison between telegrams and text messages in the last paragraph, the author considers the telegram to be a mode of communication that was commonplace.
 By contrast, the author does not consider the telegram to be a mode of communication that was:
elitist (Choice A).  Paragraph 5 cites Standage's claim that "texting…reinforced 'the democratization of telecommunications'" brought about by "the miraculous Victorian Internet."  To the extent that the telegram was democratic or generally available to the masses, it could not be considered elitist—that is, available to only a select few.
overrated (Choice C).  The rapid transmission of long-distance messages or telegrams represented a new technology in the nineteenth century that the author describes as "the greatest revolution in communication since the invention of the printing press" (Paragraph 1).  Likewise, in Paragraph 5, he or she calls the electric telegraph or Victorian Internet "miraculous."  Accordingly, the author stresses that in its time the telegraph was an extraordinary phenomenon rather than something overrated.
unique (Choice D).  Paragraph 5 states that "[p]redictably, newer forms of the original telegraphic technology—first the telephone and, much later, the fax machine—eventually encroached."  Having noted that the last telegram was sent in 2013, the author points out "the revival of this communication form in the text message."  Thus, the similarity between the telegram and the text message suggests that the author does not view the telegram as a unique form of communication, but as one that has been subject to imitation and has generated analogues.

text: Which of the following statements is implied by passage information?
explanations:
Within 20 years, telegraph cables crisscrossed the continental U.S. and much of Europe....  Following some spectacular failures, a durable cable was stretched across the floor of the Atlantic Ocean, enabling Europe and the U.S. to exchange messages within minutes.  In the 1870s, the British Empire connected London with outposts in India and Australia.  While individual telegram speed remained relatively constant, an endless deluge of information began to pour through the wires.  There was, as Tom Standage observes, "an irreversible acceleration in the pace of business life," reflecting how "telegraphy and commerce thrived in a virtuous circle."  It was as though "rapid long-distance communication had effectively obliterated time and space," begetting the phenomenon known as "globalization." (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 tracks the overseas expansion of the telegraph over the three decades that followed its invention: "telegraph cables crisscrossed…much of Europe," and "a durable cable was stretched across the floor of the Atlantic Ocean, enabling Europe and the U.S. to exchange messages within minutes."  Furthermore, "In the 1870s, the British Empire connected London with outposts in India and Australia."  As a result of this expansion, "an endless deluge of information poured through the wires," triggering "'an irreversible acceleration in the pace of business life.'"  Thus, in Europe (and elsewhere) telegraphy and commerce mutually thrived.
Accordingly, passage information implies that the markets in Europe depended on both continental and overseas "'rapid long-distance communication'" (Paragraph 3), enabled by the newly expanded telegraph system.  Therefore, passage information implies that European markets became heavily dominated by telegraphic communication.
 By contrast, passage information does not imply that:
the transatlantic telegraph system provided less reliable service than the domestic system (Choice A).  Paragraph 3 states that "[f]ollowing some spectacular failures, a durable cable was stretched across the floor of the Atlantic Ocean, enabling Europe and the U.S. to exchange messages within minutes."  However, even though the transatlantic telegraph system had proven difficult to install, the passage never suggests that it provided less reliable service than the domestic system.
the telegraph can be considered an essentially American invention (Choice B).  Paragraph 2 outlines the invention of the telegraph: "After countless attempts by scientists to use electricity to transmit messages, innovators in both Britain and America…worked at harnessing electromagnetic forces to send communications via cable."  The passage then conveys the difference that American efforts "culminated in the transmission of a message along a 40-mile telegraphic wire…while in Britain the technology was initially reserved for railway signaling."  Thus, the passage maintains that the British invented the telegraph at the same time as the U.S., even though they initially used it for a different purpose.
the speed of the typical telegram was continually increasing (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 describes how telegraph networks expanded and telegraphic communication accelerated with the installation of overseas cables after 1870.  However, the author distinguishes how, "[w]hile individual telegram speed remained relatively constant, an endless deluge of information began to pour through the wires."  Consequently, although the passage implies a great increase both in the distance that telegrams could travel and in the overall volume of telegraphic transmissions, it does not specify that there was a corresponding increase in the speed of the typical telegram.

text:
Leach's critique of Frazer (Paragraph 4) is based on:
concerns about methodology
the importance of fieldwork
opposition to a comparative approach
explanations:
Leach gazed backward upon The Golden Bough as a target rather than a benchmark.  While acknowledging Frazer's legendary status as "a colossus in the history of English scholarship," Leach nevertheless attacked him as a plagiarist, distortionist, and popularizer.  In a particularly scathing critique entitled "Golden Bough or Gilded Twig?" he condemned his predecessor's "artistic license," alleging that he routinely embellished sources and twisted information to support preformulated theories.  According to Leach, Frazer relied shamelessly on secondhand material culled from missionaries and imperial officials rather than on his own interactions with native peoples.  Moreover, many of his comparisons of myths seemed based solely on superficial resemblances between just a few elements.  Lastly, Leach joined in decrying what critics termed Frazer's "misapplication of Darwin's theory of biological evolution to human history and psychology" that depicted cultures as progressing through predictable stages from belief in magic to belief in religion, and, finally, in science. (Paragraph 4)
The passage presents Edmund Leach's view that the methods Frazer used in his voluminous The Golden Bough were fundamentally flawed.  According to Paragraph 4, Leach attacked Frazer "as a plagiarist, distortionist, and popularizer."  He denounced Frazer's" 'artistic license,' alleging that he routinely embellished sources and twisted information to support preformulated theories."  Leach also claimed that "Frazer relied shamelessly on secondhand material" and that "many of his comparisons of myths were based solely on superficial resemblances between just a few elements."  Furthermore, Paragraph 4 notes that Leach was among those who scorned "Frazer's 'misapplication of Darwin's theory of biological evolution to human history and psychology,'" which maintained that cultures advanced "through predictable stages."  Therefore, according to the passage, Leach's critique of Frazer is based on concerns about methodology (Number I).
The passage indicates that Leach saw fieldwork, which would yield firsthand information, as an essential part of anthropological research.  He emphasized that "Frazer relied shamelessly on secondhand material culled (gathered) from missionaries and imperial officials rather than on his own interactions with native peoples" (Paragraph 4).  Consequently, Leach's critique of Frazer is based in part on the importance of fieldwork to anthropological writings (Number II).
(Number III)  Paragraph 4 cites Leach's criticism that "many of [Frazer's] comparisons of myths were based solely on superficial resemblances between just a few elements."  Accordingly, he believed that Frazer's comparisons were not drawn from sufficient evidence.  Thus, Leach's criticism is directed at Frazer's resistance to gathering firsthand evidence when applying a comparative approach rather than at such an approach itself.  Therefore, the passage does not suggest that Leach's critique of Frazer is based on opposition to a comparative approach.

text: The passage implies that Frazer's work was popular because:
explanations:
An instantaneous bestseller when it appeared in 1890, Sir James Frazer's The Golden Bough: A Study in Magic and Religion was…considered controversial….  While the book's overwhelming popularity assured its place in posterity, the changing face of science and the further emergence of anthropology as a discipline meant it would end up as reviled as it was revered….  [A]t best it was exalted as a dazzling display of erudition packaged in poetic prose.  Moreover, as a rare example of adventure tale, travelogue, and detective story rolled into one, The Golden Bough was enormously entertaining to read. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 describes Frazer's The Golden Bough as divergent in several significant ways.  It was considered "controversial" within the field of anthropology, largely because of its flawed methodologies and lack of fieldwork.  Nevertheless, Frazer's text turned out to be "an instantaneous bestseller."  It is described as "a dazzling display of erudition (learnedness) packaged in poetic prose."  More specifically, the passage author calls it "a rare example of adventure tale, travelogue, and detective story rolled into one" and, as such, "enormously entertaining to read."
These descriptions suggest that Frazer's work featured a unique and interesting combination of diverse qualities one would not expect to find in an anthropological text but that gave it a distinctly literary appeal and accounted for its "overwhelming popularity."  Therefore, the passage implies that Frazer's work was popular because it diverged from the more scientific presentation of some anthropological works.
 By contrast, the passage does not imply that Frazer's work was popular because:
it promoted the notion that wisdom can be conveyed through myth (Choice B).  Paragraph 2 describes The Golden Bough as a "vast compendium of myth and ritual" that "emphasized the striking similarities in myths across cultures and time periods."  Thus, Frazer's work suggests that many societies share conceptions about important aspects of life.  Accordingly, one might suppose the common elements in those myths conveyed wisdom.  However, the passage never indicates that Frazer's work promoted the notion that wisdom can be conveyed through myth.
it enabled the reader to achieve a deep understanding of a particular culture (Choice C).  Frazer's work is described as "a vast compendium of myth and ritual" with an emphasis on "the striking similarities found in myths across cultures and time periods."  As such, The Golden Bough took "a comparativist or universalist view," and Frazer "piled example upon example."  It is then reasonable to assume that the reader of this huge collection of myths from diverse civilizations would gain information about a wide variety of cultures, leading to a broad understanding of many cultures rather than a deep understanding of a particular culture.
it demonstrated that the comparativist method can be used to elucidate myths across cultures (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 2, The Golden Bough "emphasized the striking similarities found in myths across cultures and time periods" in what amounted to "a comparativist or universalist view that Frazer…employed lavishly, piling example upon example."  Thus, Frazer's work seemed to demonstrate that the comparative method could be used to elucidate (shed light on) various myths across cultures.  However, the passage never links such a demonstration to the popularity of his work.

text: Based on the passage, one can most reasonably conclude that Frazerian anthropology seeks to:
explanations:
First published in two volumes, Frazer's vast compendium of myth and ritual had by 1915 filled twelve.  The work emphasized the striking similarities found in myths across cultures and time periods—in other words, a comparativist or universalist view that Frazer did not invent but employed lavishly, piling example upon example.  Frazer's text proved an intellectual and stylistic phenomenon with an ever-expanding influence on the cultural milieu. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, Frazer's work "emphasized the striking similarities found in myths across cultures and time periods."  Frazer's method could thus be called "comparativist or universalist."  Such an approach, which Frazer reportedly "employed lavishly, piling example upon example," would have focused on common elements appearing in myths from different societies.  Therefore, one can most reasonably conclude that Frazer's approach to anthropology seeks to identify the mythic elements that a society shares with others.
 (Choices A and C)  emphasize the connection between a society's myths and language; and organize the basic components of myths into pairs of opposites.  Paragraphs 3 and 4 describe how later anthropologists tended either to diverge from or to build on Frazer's work.  For example, "Claude Lévi-Strauss went on to integrate Frazer's comparative method with the structural linguistics of Ferdinand de Saussure and Roman Jakobson to create structural anthropology, which organized the basic elements of myths into binary oppositions" (Paragraph 3).  Therefore, the passage indicates that structuralist anthropology, not Frazerian anthropology per se, sought to connect a society's myths with the general structure of language.  In addition, the passage conveys that structuralist anthropology "organized the basic elements of myths into binary oppositions," that is, arranged these basic components into pairs of opposites.  However, by contrast, Frazer's comparativist approach "emphasized the striking similarities found in myths across cultures and time periods."
(Choice D)  turn ineffective mythic practices into effective ones.  Paragraph 4 conveys Leach's criticism that "Frazer relied shamelessly on secondhand material culled from missionaries and imperial officials rather than on his own interactions with native peoples" as he had no direct interactions with native peoples nor the opportunity to observe their rituals.  Given that this was the case, it is implausible that Frazerian anthropology would have sought to intervene in or to try to transform mythic practices in any way.  Furthermore, the passage does not indicate that even Frazer's successors—such as Malinowski, "who…began incorporating fieldwork into the discipline, focusing on the ways mythic practices contributed to the overall stability of a society" (Paragraph 3)—were interested in trying to revise the mythic practices of the peoples with whom they interacted to make them more effective.

text: Based on the passage information about Frazer's approach to anthropology, which of the following texts would most reasonably be regarded as Frazerian?
explanations:
The work emphasized the striking similarities found in myths across cultures and time periods—in other words, a comparativist or universalist view that Frazer did not invent but employed lavishly, piling example upon example. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 states that Frazer's work "emphasized the striking similarities found in myths across cultures and time periods—in other words, a comparativist or universalist view that Frazer…employed lavishly, piling example upon example."  Based on this information, Frazer believed that, regardless of historical context or geography, myths (ie, culturally significant stories) were informed by the same basic patterns.  Consequently, an account in which the lives of diverse people all follow common mythic patterns would most reasonably be regarded as Frazerian.
 (Choice A)  A text detailing direct observations of the rituals of people from a specific tribe.  The passage suggests that Frazer's work was criticized because it was not based on firsthand research.  As Paragraph 3 states, Malinowski "departed radically" from Frazer's approach by "incorporating fieldwork" into his anthropological studies.  Similarly, Paragraph 4 conveys that Leach denounced Frazer for having "relied shamelessly on secondhand material…rather than on his own interactions with native peoples."  Thus, Frazer would not have actually observed tribal rituals.  Therefore, a text detailing direct observations of the rituals of people from a specific tribe would not be regarded as Frazerian.
(Choices C and D)  An article stressing the incompatibilities between the myths of Europe and Africa; and A poem that describes someone's personal myth.  Paragraph 2 states that The Golden Bough "emphasized the striking similarities in myths across cultures and time periods," taking "a comparativist or universalist view" in which Frazer cited "example upon example."  Thus, to be identified as Frazerian an article would have to stress the similarities between the myths of Europe and Africa, not the incompatibilities.  Similarly, a poem identified as Frazerian would describe a universal myth based on common or shared experiences, not a personal myth based on unique or individual experiences.

text: What is the central idea of the passage?
explanations:
Ironically, one of the most influential works of anthropology ever written was destined to have its most enduring impact outside that field….  While the book's overwhelming popularity assured its place in posterity, the changing face of science and the further emergence of anthropology as a discipline meant it would end up as reviled as it was revered. (Paragraph 1)
Frazer's text proved an intellectual and stylistic phenomenon with an ever-expanding influence on the cultural milieu.  Those pulled into the Frazerian vortex included pioneering psychologists Freud and Jung as well as many of the most creative writers of the early 20th century, such as James Joyce, Joseph Conrad, and T. S. Eliot. (Paragraph 2)
Leach nevertheless attacked [Frazer] as a plagiarist, distortionist, and popularizer….alleging that he routinely embellished sources and twisted information to support preformulated theories.  According to Leach, Frazer relied shamelessly on secondhand material…rather than on his own interactions with native peoples.  Moreover, many of his comparisons of myths seemed based solely on superficial resemblances between just a few elements.  Lastly, Leach joined in decrying what critics termed Frazer's "misapplication of Darwin's theory of biological evolution to human history and psychology"…. (Paragraph 4)
Such criticism notwithstanding, the popularity of The Golden Bough has remained largely undiminished and its impact on the culture of the early 20th century indisputable. (Paragraph 5)
The passage's opening statement about Frazer's The Golden Bough conveys the central idea: "Ironically, one of the most influential works of anthropology ever written was destined to have its most enduring impact outside that field."  Paragraph 1 also states that the book's "overwhelming popularity assured its place in posterity" even though "the changing face of science and the further emergence of anthropology as a discipline meant it would end up as reviled as it was revered."
Paragraph 2 reinforces that "Frazer's text proved an intellectual and stylistic phenomenon with an ever-expanding influence on the cultural milieu (environment)."  As the author also notes, it influenced "pioneering psychologists Freud and Jung as well as many of the most creative writers of the 20th century."
In Paragraph 4, Leach denounces Frazer as being—in the context of emerging anthropology—"a plagiarist, distortionist, and popularizer" who misapplied methods and theories.  However, as Paragraph 5 reasserts, "[T]he popularity of The Golden Bough has remained largely undiminished and its impact on the culture of the early 20th century indisputable."  Consequently, the central idea of the passage is that The Golden Bough's influence on culture outweighs its influence on anthropology.
 (Choice A)  The Golden Bough was written more as a work of literature than of anthropology.  Paragraph 1 describes Frazer's text as "packaged in poetic prose."  Furthermore, it proved "a rare example of adventure tale, travelogue, and detective story all rolled into one" that was "enormously entertaining to read."  According to Paragraph 2, the work had an "ever-expanding influence on the cultural milieu (environment)" and on "many of the most creative writers of the early 20th century."  Such evidence underscores that The Golden Bough was more appreciated as a work of literature than of anthropology.  However, the passage also focuses on the work's scientific shortcomings and its influence in psychology.
(Choice B)  Progress in anthropology has made Frazer's work less relevant.  The passage stresses how Frazer's work became less relevant in the field of anthropology.  As Paragraph 1 states, "[T]he changing face of science and the further emergence of anthropology as a discipline meant [The Golden Bough] would end up as reviled as it was revered."  According to Paragraph 3, later "groundbreaking anthropological works…departed radically in method and style from Frazer's grand exercise in mythography (collecting and studying myths) and ethnography (describing the customs of particular peoples and cultures)."  Furthermore, as fieldwork became essential, Frazer was criticized for relying on "secondhand material" (Paragraph 4).  However, the passage's central idea also stresses that Frazer's work had more influence outside anthropology.
(Choice C)  Frazer's work influenced the formation of structural anthropology.  Passage information reveals that Frazer's work did influence the formation of structural anthropology.  According to Paragraph 3, "Claude Lévi-Strauss went on to integrate Frazer's comparative method with the structural linguistics of Ferdinand de Saussure and Roman Jakobson to create structural anthropology."  However, as the passage also emphasizes, Frazer's approach had limited direct impact on anthropology, influencing fields such as psychology and literature instead.

text:
Which of the following ravens exhibited the least success at retrieving the suspended food in Heinrich's experiment?
Bird 3
Bird 27
Bird 30
explanations:
One occasion of such behavior was documented by University of Vermont zoologist Bernd Heinrich in an experiment with Common Ravens.  Heinrich's central focus was whether the birds could discern the solution to a newly encountered problem of food acquisition without any training or prior familiarity with the problem's elements.  To address this question, he presented groups of ravens with pieces of meat suspended from a perch by a length of string.  The food was too far from either the perch or the ground to be reached from those vantage points.  Hence, accessing the food efficiently would require using the string itself, a situation not encountered in the wild and to which none of the birds had been previously exposed. (Paragraph 2)
The first two ravens to approach the food found little success in retrieving it.  As Heinrich relates, both Bird 3 and Bird 27 attempted to jump and grab the meat from the air.  Although this process resulted in only tiny scraps of food being obtained, both birds initially "tried no other method after the pattern was established on the first day."  However, another raven fared far better.…  Days later, Bird 5 also discovered how to access the meat in this way, completing "the entire repetitive sequence correctly all at once."  Eventually Bird 3 and Bird 30 learned as well, but only after weeks of further opportunities. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 2 describes "an experiment with Common Ravens" conducted by Bernd Heinrich, based on the presentation of "pieces of meat suspended from a perch by a length of string."  Because the meat could not be reached from either the perch or the ground, "accessing the food efficiently would require using the string itself."
According to Paragraph 3, "The first two ravens to approach the food found little success in retrieving it.  As Heinrich relates, both Bird 3 and Bird 27 attempted to jump and grab the meat from the air."  The author notes that despite the inadequacy of these efforts, at first neither bird modified its behavior: "Although this process resulted in only tiny scraps of food being obtained, both birds initially 'tried no other method after the pattern was established on the first day.'"  Therefore, at the beginning of the experiment both Bird 3 and Bird 27 were very unsuccessful at retrieving the food.
However, the passage goes on to convey that "[e]ventually Bird 3 and Bird 30 learned" how to use the string to pull up the meat, "after weeks of further opportunities."  By contrast, the passage never suggests that Bird 27 likewise learned at any point in the experiment.  Therefore, Bird 27 exhibited the least success at retrieving the suspended food in Heinrich's experiment (Number II).
 (Number I)  Bird 3.  Bird 3 "initially 'tried no other method'" besides ineffectively attempting to grab the meat from the air.  However, unlike Bird 27, the passage indicates that "[e]ventually Bird 3…learned" how to successfully access the suspended food (Paragraph 3).
(Number III)  Bird 30.  Paragraph 3 states that "Bird 5…discovered how to access the meat."  The author then adds that "[e]ventually Bird 3 and Bird 30 learned as well, but only after weeks of further opportunities."  Therefore, the passage includes Bird 30 in the group of ravens that learned to successfully retrieve the meat in Heinrich's experiment.

text: In the context of the passage, what is the primary significance of the claim that the suspended food represents a situation ravens would not encounter in the wild?
explanations:
One occasion of such behavior was documented by University of Vermont zoologist Bernd Heinrich in an experiment with Common Ravens.  Heinrich's central focus was whether the birds could discern the solution to a newly encountered problem of food acquisition without any training or prior familiarity with the problem's elements.  To address this question, he presented groups of ravens with pieces of meat suspended from a perch by a length of string.  The food was too far from either the perch or the ground to be reached from those vantage points.  Hence, accessing the food efficiently would require using the string itself, a situation not encountered in the wild and to which none of the birds had been previously exposed. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, "Heinrich's central focus was whether the birds could discern the solution to a newly encountered problem of food acquisition without any training or prior familiarity with the problem's elements."  In the experiment he designed, groups of ravens encountered "pieces of meat suspended from a perch by a length of string."  In this scenario, "accessing the food efficiently would require using the string itself, a situation not encountered in the wild and to which none of the birds had been previously exposed."
Because Heinrich was testing whether ravens could solve a completely unfamiliar problem, it was essential to ensure that neither instinct nor prior experience could influence their ability to approach it.  In other words, Heinrich wanted to preclude those factors as possible origins of the birds' responses.  Therefore, the primary significance of the claim that the suspended food represents a situation ravens would not encounter in the wild is that it rules out potential sources for the birds' behavior.
 By contrast, none of the following represents the primary significance of the claim that the suspended food represents a situation ravens would not encounter in the wild:
It means that the food retrieval could not be achieved through trial and error (Choice A).  Paragraph 3 describes how Bird 4 "'performed a behavioral sequence of at least six steps…with no apparent trial-and-error learning for most if not all of these steps.'"  However, the passage never indicates that the experiment was designed to prevent a trial-and-error approach.  Moreover, whether such an approach could have been successful is a separate point from whether the scenario would be encountered in the wild.
It highlights that the experiment focused on animals in captivity (Choice C).  It can reasonably be assumed that Heinrich's experiment was performed on animals in captivity, since it took place over several weeks and the birds were identified by numbers.  Thus, working with captive animals was an inherent part of the experiment.  Accordingly, the fact that ravens would not encounter the experimental scenario in the wild is not intended to highlight the ravens' captivity.  Rather, the author highlights "the ravens' apparent ability to solve a problem for which neither instinct nor experience could be expected to have prepared them" (Paragraph 4).
It explains the difficulty of the task presented (Choice D).  Paragraph 2 explains that "Heinrich's central focus was whether the birds could discern the solution to a newly encountered problem."  Accordingly, the fact that the ravens had to approach that problem "without any training or prior familiarity with the problem's elements" is the most significant part of the experiment's design.  Therefore, although the passage does imply that the task of retrieving suspended meat was difficult for the ravens, that difficulty is secondary to the point that experience and instinct would not have prepared the ravens to confront the situation presented.

text: What is the main point of Paragraph 4?
explanations:
The most notable point of these observations is the ravens' apparent ability to solve a problem for which neither instinct nor experience could be expected to have prepared them.  Heinrich casts his experiment in terms of testing for insight, or "the possibility of mental awareness—of seeing into a situation."  Naturally, such awareness can only be inferred rather than observed directly, and researchers should be wary of the tendency to anthropomorphize animals when discussing their mental capabilities.  Nevertheless, such wariness should not prevent us from drawing at least probable or tentative conclusions.  Bird 4 especially seems almost to have mentally worked through the scenario in the intervening time between its originally unsuccessful and subsequent successful attempts to retrieve the food.  In the human world, we might speak of someone thinking about a problem for a while before trying another solution.  Even if we are reluctant to view Bird 4's behavior as a precise analogue, it seems clear that the raven displayed evidence of a noteworthy mental operation.  In further experiments, some other ravens also demonstrated the ability to pull up food on strings.  Although Heinrich notes that the birds exhibiting this behavior are "possibly exceptional," they represent a fascinating example in our understanding of animal intelligence. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, "The most notable point of these observations is the ravens' apparent ability to solve a problem for which neither instinct nor experience could be expected to have prepared them.  Heinrich casts his experiment in terms of testing for insight, or 'the possibility of mental awareness—of seeing into a situation.'"  The author implies that the test was successful, suggesting that some of the ravens did see into the situation in this way.  For instance, "Bird 4 especially seems almost to have mentally worked through the scenario in the intervening time between its originally unsuccessful and subsequent successful attempts to retrieve the food."
The author further compares Bird 4's behavior to "the human world, [where] we might speak of someone thinking about a problem for a while before trying another solution."  In addition, the passage goes on to say that "some other ravens also demonstrated the ability to pull up food on strings," declaring that those ravens "represent a fascinating example in our understanding of animal intelligence."  Therefore, Paragraph 4 focuses on the idea that, based on Heinrich's findings, at least some ravens seem to exhibit insight in solving problems.
 By contrast, none of the following represents the main point of Paragraph 4:
Heinrich conceived his experiment as testing for insight (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 4, "Heinrich casts his experiment in terms of testing for insight."  However, the larger point of the paragraph is that the test seems to have been successful.  For instance, "Bird 4…displayed evidence of a noteworthy mental operation," and the birds exhibiting similar behavior "represent a fascinating example in our understanding of animal intelligence."
Ravens' mental capabilities are exceptional among most animals (Choice B).  Paragraph 4 discusses ravens that "demonstrated the ability to pull up food on strings."  The author notes that although "the birds exhibiting this behavior are 'possibly exceptional,' they represent a fascinating example in our understanding of animal intelligence."  Accordingly, Paragraph 4 suggests that these birds are exceptional among other ravens; it does not compare the mental capabilities of ravens to those of other animals.
Ravens' mental capabilities should not be anthropomorphized (Choice D).  Paragraph 4 states that "researchers should be wary of the tendency to anthropomorphize animals when discussing their mental capabilities."  However, the author then implies that some level of anthropomorphizing may be justified, stating that "such wariness should not prevent us from drawing at least probable or tentative conclusions."  In addition, he or she arguably anthropomorphizes explicitly by comparing one raven's mental capabilities to "the human world, [where] we might speak of someone thinking about a problem for a while before trying another solution."

text: Which of the following pieces of information would most weaken the author's conclusions about the birds in Heinrich's experiment?
explanations:
Heinrich's central focus was whether the birds could discern the solution to a newly encountered problem of food acquisition without any training or prior familiarity with the problem's elements….  Hence, accessing the food efficiently would require using the string itself, a situation not encountered in the wild and to which none of the birds had been previously exposed. (Paragraph 2)
Thus, the raven "performed a behavioral sequence of at least six steps…with no apparent trial-and-error learning for most if not all of these steps, chaining these steps together into a single unbroken sequence."  Days later, Bird 5 also discovered how to access the meat in this way, completing "the entire repetitive sequence correctly all at once."  Eventually Bird 3 and Bird 30 learned as well, but only after weeks of further opportunities. (Paragraph 3)
Heinrich casts his experiment in terms of testing for insight, or "the possibility of mental awareness—of seeing into a situation."  Naturally, such awareness can only be inferred rather than observed directly….  Nevertheless, such wariness should not prevent us from drawing at least probable or tentative conclusions….  Even if we are reluctant to view Bird 4's behavior as a precise analogue, it seems clear that the raven displayed evidence of a noteworthy mental operation.  In further experiments, some other ravens also demonstrated the ability to pull up food on strings.  Although Heinrich notes that the birds exhibiting this behavior are "possibly exceptional," they represent a fascinating example in our understanding of animal intelligence. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 2, "Heinrich's central focus was whether the birds could discern the solution to a newly encountered problem of food acquisition without any training or prior familiarity with the problem's elements."  Thus, his experiment was intended to represent a challenge "to which none of the birds had been previously exposed."  Similarly, Paragraph 3 describes Bird 4 as performing "'a behavioral sequence of at least six steps…with no apparent trial-and-error learning for most if not all of these steps.'"  The author further indicates that Bird 5, Bird 3, and Bird 30 also eventually learned how to successfully access the meat in the experiment.
Paragraph 4 notes that Heinrich was "testing for insight, or 'the possibility of mental awareness—of seeing into a situation.'"  The author implies that he or she sees that test as successful: although "such awareness can only be inferred rather than observed directly," we can draw "at least probable or tentative conclusions" about ravens' capabilities.  For instance, Bird 4 "displayed evidence of a noteworthy mental operation," and the successful ravens "represent a fascinating example in our understanding of animal intelligence."
However, if some ravens had access to the suspended food when not being observed by Heinrich, it is possible that they engaged in a trial-and-error process or otherwise gained experience with the problem without Heinrich's awareness.  If so, this fact would call into question the nature of the birds' success and its implications for their mental capabilities; hence, it would weaken the author's conclusions about the birds in Heinrich's experiment.
 (Choice A)  The Loggerhead Shrike, a non-Corvid species, instinctually suspends its prey by impaling it on thorns.  Paragraph 1 states that "some members of the Corvid family (such as ravens, crows, and jays) display a high capability to successfully confront novel challenges through innovative behavior."  However, information about a non-Corvid species would not affect whether ravens display such capabilities.  Moreover, even if a comparison between Corvids and non-Corvids is implied, the instinct of Shrikes to impale and suspend their prey is not an equivalent situation to a bird encountering food suspended by a string.  Therefore, the Shrike's behavior would not weaken the author's conclusions about the birds in Heinrich's experiment.
(Choices B and C)  Instead of attempting to retrieve the suspended food, some ravens tried to steal food retrieved by others; and Some ravens never successfully retrieved the suspended food.  Paragraph 3 states that Bird 27 "found little success in retrieving" the food and implies that it never learned how to acquire the meat effectively.  Similarly, Paragraph 4 conveys that "some other ravens…demonstrated the ability to pull up food on strings," but it also notes Heinrich's assertion that "the birds exhibiting this behavior are 'possibly exceptional.'"  Accordingly, the passage suggests that only some of the ravens in Heinrich's study demonstrated exceptional abilities.  Therefore, if other ravens were unsuccessful at retrieving the food (or simply tried to steal it from others), that would not weaken the author's conclusions.

text: During another researcher's observation of Corvids, a Steller's Jay deliberately broke a twig off a bush and subsequently thrust it at an American Crow with which it was competing for food.  The researcher interpreted the jay's behavior as a unique instance of a bird using a weapon.  This interpretation would most accord with which of the following ideas in the passage?
explanations:
Research on animal intelligence has proliferated in recent decades, producing additional evidence of complex types of thought in non-human creatures.  Although primates have been the most frequent subjects of such study, observations of avians have at times proved even more striking.  In particular, some members of the Corvid family (such as ravens, crows, and jays) display a high capability to successfully confront novel challenges through innovative behavior. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 states that "[r]esearch on animal intelligence has proliferated in recent decades, producing additional evidence of complex types of thought in non-human creatures."  In the scenario described in the question, the researcher interprets the jay's behavior as constituting the use of a weapon.  In other words, the jay seemed to intentionally make a tool that it then used to threaten another animal, behavior that suggests a purposive mental process involving multiple steps.  Therefore, the researcher's interpretation would most accord with the conclusion that animal behavior research provides evidence of complex types of thought in non-humans.
 (Choice A)  The claim that avians have displayed even more striking behavior than primates.  According to Paragraph 1, "Although primates have been the most frequent subjects of such study, observations of avians (birds) have at times proved even more striking."  However, the passage never discusses any examples of primate behavior, nor specifically whether a primate may have used a weapon.  Without this information, it is unclear whether the jay's behavior should be seen as more striking than the behavior of primates.  Hence, the researcher's interpretation would not necessarily accord with that idea.
(Choices B and C)  The claim that some types of challenges would not be encountered in the wild; and The conclusion that Corvids are highly capable of successfully confronting novel challenges.  According to Paragraph 1, "[S]ome members of the Corvid family (such as ravens, crows, and jays) display a high capability to successfully confront novel challenges through innovative behavior."  The jay's behavior of breaking a twig from a bush to use it as a weapon can indeed be seen as innovative.  However, the challenge it faced involved competing with a rival for food, a common situation that is frequently encountered by wild animals.  Consequently, the researcher's interpretation does not most accord with ideas about confronting novel challenges or challenges that would not be encountered in the wild.

text: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as a consideration that should be made by the doctor prior to deciding what must be done with the antidote?
explanations:
Accordingly, the doctor has only enough of the antidote to save either Citizen A or the five other citizens.  (Paragraph 2)
It may seem clear that a doctor could not justifiably allocate the entirety of an antidote to preserving one citizen's life at the expense of losing five others.  However, suppose that Citizen A is the only patient currently present in the doctor's clinic, as the remaining patients are being transferred to Dr. Jones' facility by their respective physicians.  Citizen A is, in fact, Dr. Jones' longtime patient.  The doctor must therefore decide between two exigencies:  to save his own patient's life or to await the arrival of the five remaining citizens.  (Paragraph 3)
One should consider, for instance, how long each patient can survive without the antidote.  (Paragraph 4)
The passage does not mention that the doctor should consider the possibility that the antidote may not function properly in each citizen.  Rather, the passage assumes that the antidote will function, but that each citizen will require a different amount of it, depending on the amount of poison consumed.
Based on the passage, Dr. Jones should consider the following prior to administering the antidote:
The amount of antidote necessary to cure each patient:  "the doctor has only enough of the antidote to be able to save citizen A or the five other citizens" (Paragraph 2).  Citizen A would require the entire antidote whereas the other citizens would require only a fraction of the antidote to be cured. (Choice A)
His responsibility to the patient in the clinic:  Dr. Jones' decision is complicated by the fact that Citizen A, a "longtime patient," is "the only patient currently present" in the clinic.  Therefore, the doctor must consider if he should "save his own patient's life" (Paragraph 3). (Choice B)
The urgency of time in administering the antidote:  Dr. Jones must consider how long he can wait for the remaining patients to arrive to administer the antidote.  He has to choose between administering the antidote to Citizen A or waiting for the other "five remaining citizens" to arrive. (Choice D)

text: The author probably mentions the crystal ball to:
explanations:
This dilemma asks the judicious individual to take into account additional factors that might encumber his or her ability to save the citizens who have not yet arrived.  One should consider, for instance, how long each patient can survive without the antidote.  Unfortunately, no one has a crystal ball to predict future events.  A decision must be made in conjunction with the information available at the time.  (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 mentions the crystal ball to highlight the doctor's inability to predict the future in conjunction with the severity of the choice he must make:  save citizen A or save the five citizens.  This is important because Dr. Jones must accept whatever decision he makes.  According to the passage, he unfortunately does not have a crystal ball to predict the ending and must struggle with the uncertainty of the outcome of his choice.
(Choice A)  The crystal ball is mentioned after discussing the risk of losing any of the six citizens and considering "how long each patient can survive without the antidote."  The crystal ball indicates that the outcome of the decision cannot be predicted, but is completely unrelated to the definition of good versus evil in this circumstance.
(Choice B)  Although the risk of losing all the citizens is related to the time it will take for them to arrive at the clinic, the crystal ball does not pertain directly to the urgency of time.
(Choice C)  The crystal ball does not serve to (symbolically) undermine the doctor's ability to make an appropriate decision.

text: The author implies that the virtues of compassion, empathy, and loyalty are:
explanations:
With this in mind, one may argue that the determination of good versus evil in making a decision lies in the doctor's motivations as he considers the consequences of his impending actions.  Imagine Dr. Jones' nurse exclaiming, "But the doctor cannot make an objective comparison between the lives of other citizens and his own patient!"  Yet, perhaps the doctor would be selfishly inclined to save Citizen A, as Citizen A is the only one whose death would be considered a grievous personal loss.  (Paragraph 5)
But are such selfish human instincts then to be labeled as evil?  The same propensities labeled as selfish underlie characteristics classified as decent human virtues, such as compassion, empathy, and loyalty.  (Paragraph 6)
As Paragraph 5 explains, there are instincts associated with personal attachment to others (ie, Citizen A's "death would be considered a grievous personal loss").  The author states that the same human instincts that underlie Dr. Jones' personal motives (ie, selfishness) to save Citizen A also underlie "decent human virtues" such as "compassion, empathy, and loyalty."
In other words, Dr. Jones may be considered selfish in his desire to save Citizen A because he is attached to this patient.  Such personal attachments (which can lead to bias) are necessary to cultivate the "decent human virtues" mentioned by the author.
(Choices A and B)  The author does not indicate whether these values are characteristic of all doctor-patient relationships/interactions or whether they are enhanced by the experience of grief and loss.
(Choice C)  There are no passage indications to suggest that compassion, empathy, and loyalty are guided by universal (common to everyone) human instincts.  On the contrary, "the determination of good versus evil…lies in the doctor's motivations."  Therefore, human instincts may be good (ie, compassion, empathy, and loyalty) or evil (ie, selfishness).

text: Suppose that, following ingestion of Poison H by the citizens, Dr. Jones modifies the antidote slightly in an attempt to provide more to all affected patients.  Dr. Jones finds that as a result of the modifications, the efficacy of the antidote diminishes rapidly as time passes.  According to this new information, one can assume that the doctor would:
explanations:
This dilemma asks the judicious individual to take into account additional factors that might encumber his or her ability to save the citizens who have not yet arrived.  One should consider, for instance, how long each patient can survive without the antidote.  (Paragraph 4)
The new information provided states that following ingestion of Poison H, the doctor modified the antidote, but that due to these modifications the efficacy (effectiveness/success) of the antidote diminished (decreased) rapidly with time.  Paragraph 4 suggests that if Dr. Jones did not administer the entire antidote to Citizen A and waited for the remaining citizens to arrive, there would be a chance that the citizens would die from the poison while being transported to his clinic.
In light of the new scenario, the Dr. Jones would have had to quickly choose between giving the antidote to Citizen A and hoping it is still effective or waiting a longer time for the other citizens to arrive and risking the antidote becoming completely ineffective.  In addition, the antidote would be less effective in the remaining five citizens even if they were still alive.  As a result, Dr. Jones would be more likely to administer the antidote to Citizen A, the only patient in the clinic at the time.
(Choice B)  Dr. Jones would be less likely in this circumstance to withhold the antidote from Citizen A, given that, in the time following ingestion of Poison H, the efficacy of the antidote decreases.  The doctor is at greater risk of losing all six citizens, but he could still make a timely decision and hope to save at least Citizen A, who is present.
(Choice C)  The passage does not indicate whether Dr. Jones would defer to his nurse in making the decision.
(Choice D)  It is unlikely that Dr. Jones would fail to consider this new information (ie, the diminishing efficacy of the antidote), as it would affect his ability to save all poisoned citizens.

text: Which of the following conclusions would be most in accordance with the ideas expressed in the passage?
explanations:
Evil can most accurately be defined as the direct antithesis of good.  However, when a human situation does not lend itself to clear designations of ultimate good and ultimate evil, or of right and wrong, then the best that one can hope for is to be able to make an informed decision about which course of action is "more right" and which is "more wrong."  (Paragraph 1)
In such circumstances, the decision between right and wrong, or the moral dilemma, escalates into what is more accurately a personal determination of good and evil.  In this way, the relative construct of right and wrong, as determined by one's best attempts at logic and sense, must be subordinated to a moral imperative that may be said to be absolute:  namely, that one must abide by an internal commitment to what one has reasoned to be the right decision and follow a corresponding course of action in the allotted time.  (Paragraph 7)
Paragraph 1 implies that morality relies on certain, absolute universal laws and, beyond that, an individual's own reasoning in particular scenarios.  The author alludes to universal morality in the first sentence of the passage by stating, "Evil can most accurately be defined as the direct antithesis of good."  This suggests that the author does believe in absolute constructs that define good and evil.
However, the author also claims that certain situations do not lend themselves "to making clear designations of ultimate good and ultimate evil" and that, in these circumstances, individuals must use their own insight or reasoning to decide the best course of action.  In this case, the definitions of good and evil are not fixed (Choice C).
In Paragraph 7, the author reveals "a moral imperative that may be said to be absolute:  namely, that one must abide by an internal commitment to what one has reasoned to be the right decision and follow a corresponding course of action in the allotted time."  The individual remains responsible to determine a "relative construct of right and wrong, or the moral dilemma" according to the individual's "best attempts at logic and sense."
(Choice B)  In Paragraph 6, the author claims that a decision can "be argued as evil" as in cases when an individual "opts to dismiss or distrust his individual conscience."
(Choice D)  When the author defines evil as "the direct antithesis of good," this is proposed as a universally accepted truth.  The author focuses on explaining that individuals must use their own "internal commitment" to judge what is right and what is wrong (Paragraph 7).  Therefore, this internal moral compass is likely guided by the universal truth that both good and evil exist and accordingly provides guidance for decision-making.

text: A study finds that 90% of practicing doctors believe that the most beneficial treatment decisions cannot be determined by computer-generated algorithms but must be determined in light of a doctor's observations of the preference and needs of an individual patient.  How would this finding relate to the information expressed in the passage?
explanations:
Evil can most accurately be defined as the direct antithesis of good.  However, when a human situation does not lend itself to making clear designations of ultimate good and ultimate evil, or of right and wrong, then the best that one can hope for is to be able to make an informed decision about which course of action is "more right" and which is "more wrong."  (Paragraph 1)
If 90% of doctors believe that no set of rules (computer-generated algorithms) exist that can determine the best course of action for each individual patient, this claim would support the author's assertion that humans (not computers) should abide by an internal commitment to what is right and what is wrong.  In these cases, doctors must use their insight and observations of an individual patient to determine for themselves which decisions are "more right" and most beneficial to a patient.
(Choices A and C)  This finding neither directly supports nor challenges the idea that morality, as defined in terms of good and evil, is absolute or clearly designated.
(Choice D)  This statistic suggests that the best a doctor can hope for is, in fact, to determine which actions are "more right" and which are "more wrong" in a given scenario.

text: Physician burnout has been associated with exhaustion and a loss of interest, compassion, and previously acknowledged purpose.  How would these symptoms affect Dr. Jones if he were experiencing physician burnout?
explanations:
There are particular circumstances in which the doctor would indeed be remiss to the point of what could be argued as evil—as in cases where he opts to dismiss or distrust his individual conscience.  Consider the case in which he doubts his ability to arrive at a judicious conclusion and abdicates his responsibility for making this grave decision to the nurse.  Or consider the case in which he concludes that it is indeed more valiant to save the five citizens, yet fails to act on his decision out of personal anguish at losing Citizen A or to put an end to the ordeal.  (Paragraph 6)
Paragraph 6 clearly states that the doctor "doubts his ability to arrive at a judicious (well-judged/sensible) conclusion."  This means that the doctor was consciously weighing the seriousness of his decision.  However, if Dr. Jones were experiencing physician burnout:  defined as exhaustion and a loss of interest, compassion, and previously acknowledged purpose, he would most likely dismiss his own conscience in making a decision.  In the second example in Paragraph 6, the doctor fails to wait for the remaining five citizens "to put an end to the ordeal," which would more likely occur if he were burned out.
(Choice A)  In the passage, Dr. Jones' potential grief over the idea of the losing Citizen A is linked to his feeling of personal attachment, which the author relates to the human virtue of compassion.  A doctor experiencing loss of compassion during burnout would be less likely to harbor feelings of attachment to Citizen A.
(Choice C)  The characteristics of physician burnout do not indicate whether the doctor would require more or less information to complete the decision.  However, if Dr. Jones were tired or otherwise experiencing a loss of interest, he might make decisions more hastily, therefore taking less information into account.
(Choice D)  If Dr. Jones were experiencing physician burnout, he would be experiencing exhaustion and loss of interest, implying that he would be less able to make sound decisions.  Therefore, he would be less likely to arrive at a judicious (sensible) conclusion regarding the antidote.

text: Which of the following distinctions between related concepts is NOT made by the passage author?
explanations:
Of late it has become popular among linguists and literary theorists to assert that a work's meaning depends upon the individual reader.  It is readers, we are told, not authors, who create meaning, by interacting with a text rather than simply receiving it.  Thus, a reader transcends the aims of the author, producing their own reading of the text.  Indeed, on this line of thinking, even to speak of "the" text is to commit a conceptual error; every text is in fact many texts, a plurality of interpretations that resist comparative evaluation.  This view is nonsense.  That many otherwise sensible scholars should be attracted to it can perhaps be readily explained, but we should first delineate why the theory goes so far astray.... (Paragraph 1)
The passage begins by discussing a theory of interpretation which is held by many scholars, but which the passage author opposes.  According to Paragraph 1, "[I]t has become popular among linguists and literary theorists to assert that a work's meaning depends upon the individual reader.  It is readers, we are told, not authors, who create meaning."  Although the passage author asserts that "[t]his view is nonsense," they admit that "many otherwise sensible scholars [are] attracted to it."
By describing them as "otherwise sensible," the passage author implies that such scholars are generally credible (even if they are wrong about this particular idea).  However, the passage never describes any scholars as unsensible or non-credible.  Therefore, the passage author does not make a distinction between credible and non-credible scholars.
 By contrast, the passage author makes distinctions between each of the following:
Greater and lesser types of literature (Choice A).  Paragraph 4 contrasts "the loftiest tomes of Shakespeare or Milton" with "the lowliest of yellowed paperbacks."  Thus, by describing some literature as lofty and other literature as lowly, the passage author conveys that some types of literature are of greater significance than others.
An idea's content and its correctness (Choice B).  In describing a hypothetical conversation, Paragraph 3 states that "Jones might judge Smith's ideas to be wrong, unfounded, etc.  But whether Smith's ideas are right or wrong is a different matter from what those ideas are."  Therefore, the passage author distinguishes between the content of Smith's ideas and whether those ideas are correct.
Accurate and inaccurate interpretations (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 5, literary scholarship "must presume the existence of standards for success: accuracy and inaccuracy, depth or shallowness of analysis, grounds for preferring one interpretation to another."  Therefore, the passage author distinguishes between accurate and inaccurate interpretations of literature.

text: Based on the view of interpretation described by the passage author in Paragraph 1, which of the following areas of study would be most similar to literary scholarship?
explanations:
Of late it has become popular among linguists and literary theorists to assert that a work's meaning depends upon the individual reader.  It is readers, we are told, not authors, who create meaning, by interacting with a text rather than simply receiving it.  Thus, a reader transcends the aims of the author, producing their own reading of the text.  Indeed, on this line of thinking, even to speak of "the" text is to commit a conceptual error; every text is in fact many texts, a plurality of interpretations that resist comparative evaluation.  This view is nonsense. (Paragraph 1)
In Paragraph 1, the passage author describes a view of interpretation in which "[i]t is readers…not authors, who create meaning."  On this line of thinking, "a reader transcends the aims of the author," with the result that multiple scholars of a work generate "a plurality of interpretations that resist comparative evaluation."  Thus, according to this view the meaning of a literary work is determined by those who analyze it, regardless of what the work's creator may have intended.
Like works of literature, works of art are also interpreted.  Similarly, although it is reasonable to think that artists create their works with a certain message in mind, it would be likely for different critics to have different interpretations of what those works mean.  Accordingly, based on the view of interpretation described by the passage author in Paragraph 1, art criticism would be most similar to literary scholarship.
 (Choice A)  Code decryption.  Paragraph 1 discusses the view that "[i]t is readers…not authors, who create meaning" and that "every text is in fact many texts, a plurality of interpretations that resist comparative evaluation."  However, the purpose of code decryption is to expose disguised communication in order to determine an author's specific message.  Consequently, unlike the view of interpretation described in Paragraph 1, code decryption is based on the assumption that the true meaning of a work depends on its author, not its readers.
(Choice B)  Linguistic translation.  Paragraph 1 describes a view of literary scholarship in which "[i]t is readers…not authors, who create meaning….  Thus, a reader transcends the aims of the author."  However, the intention of linguistic translation is to accurately render a speaker's original ideas into another language.  Unlike studies in literature or art, there is no presumption that it could be appropriate for translators to "superimpose their own volitional perspectives (ie, interpret a work in terms of their own subjective views)" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, there is a key difference between linguistic translation and literary scholarship as described in Paragraph 1.
(Choice D)  Forensic accounting.  Forensic accounting is used to uncover hidden evidence of financial crimes.  Accordingly, the only correct "interpretation" of the records involved would be one that accurately describes the financial activities of a person or corporation.  Therefore, unlike the view of literary interpretation described in Paragraph 1, such a process would not involve producing "a plurality of interpretations that resist comparative evaluation."

text: The author's "more complex supposition" in Paragraph 2 implies that speakers:
explanations:
Suppose Smith is conveying his ideas to Jones in conversation (the particular topic is of no consequence).  Afterward, we discover that the men differ in their accounts of what Smith had expressed.  At this point, Jones may decide that he misunderstood Smith, or perhaps that Smith was unclear.  A more complex supposition might be that Smith misused some key term, so his words did not fully match his intentions.  Any of these possibilities would reasonably describe why Jones and Smith possessed different opinions about what Smith had said. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 describes a scenario in which "Smith is conveying his ideas to Jones in conversation….  Afterward, we discover that the men differ in their accounts of what Smith had expressed."  One possible explanation for this difference is the "more complex supposition…that Smith misused some key term, so his words did not fully match his intentions."
If Smith misused a key term with the result that his words did not match his intentions, then he was mistaken about what the term meant.  Accordingly, it would be Smith's fault that Jones did not understand what Smith was saying, because Smith did not accurately communicate his message.  Therefore, the author's "more complex supposition" implies that speakers can fail to accurately convey the meaning of their ideas.
 By contrast, the author's "more complex supposition" does not imply that speakers:
are not responsible for whether listeners correctly interpret the meaning of their ideas (Choice A).  If "Smith misused some key term," that would mean it was his fault that "Jones and Smith possessed different opinions about what Smith had said" (Paragraph 2).  Specifically, Smith's mistake about the term prevented Jones from understanding what Smith had meant.  Accordingly, the passage indicates that speakers can be responsible for whether listeners correctly interpret the meaning of their ideas.
cannot fail to accurately convey the meaning of their ideas (Choice B).  If "Smith misused some key term" (Paragraph 2), he would not have expressed what he meant correctly.  Accordingly, Smith would have failed to accurately convey the meaning of his ideas.
may sometimes be mistaken about the actual meaning of their ideas (Choice C).  The "more complex supposition" described in Paragraph 2 is that "Smith misused some key term, so his words did not fully match his intentions."  In this scenario, although Smith knew what ideas he wanted to convey, he was mistaken about the meaning of a word.  Hence, the passage makes a distinction between ideas and the words used to express them.  Paragraph 3 then states that "in questions about what Smith meant….  Smith must be the authority."  Therefore, the passage indicates that speakers are correct about the meaning of their ideas, even when they are mistaken about the meaning of a term.

text: Which of the following statements, if true, would most support the passage author's argument about interpretation?
explanations:
From the loftiest tomes of Shakespeare or Milton to the lowliest of yellowed paperbacks, authors produce works with a particular message in mind.  It is readers' task to discern that message, not to superimpose their own volitional perspectives. (Paragraph 4)
To think otherwise is to undermine the foundation of literary scholarship.  For what is the purpose of such scholarship, if not to seek understanding of an author's creation?  One examines the text, taking note of style, historical context, allusions to other works, and other factors, in addition, of course, to the surface sense of the words themselves.  If such an enterprise is to be reasonable, it must presume the existence of standards for success: accuracy and inaccuracy, depth or shallowness of analysis, grounds for preferring one interpretation to another.  Different readers may come to different conclusions about a text, it is true.
