explanations:
As time passes, however, the wealth or destitution of one generation is bequeathed to the next, and then inequality becomes ingrained.  What was before an earned difference of outcome is now an unearned difference of potential.  One individual has an advantage that another lacks—not gained through striving and perseverance but inherited through accident of birth. (Paragraph 5)
Such effects only compound over time.  Inevitably, dynasties of wealth accrue by which a few through mere circumstance enjoy economic mastery over the many, who face through the tyranny of chance an undeserved impediment. (Paragraph 6)
In post-industrial America, governmental reforms and regulations on commerce and industry were required to redress the systemic injustices perpetuated by dynastic wealth, as well as to protect the welfare of a multitude bound to wages insufficient to secure life's necessities. (Paragraph 8)
The author argues that wealth redistribution is necessary as a response to economic inequality, especially as it concerns "dynasties of wealth" (Paragraph 6) that arise through inheritance.  According to Paragraph 5, "the wealth or destitution of one generation is bequeathed to the next, and then inequality becomes ingrained."  In the author's view, this ingrained inequality is unjust because the economic advantage that some people possess over others is simply "inherited though accident of birth" rather than "gained through striving and perseverance."  Thus, wealth redistribution is needed in order "to redress (remedy) the systemic injustices perpetuated by dynastic wealth" (Paragraph 8).
Accordingly, the tax system the author would most likely view as beneficial to society would be a progressive tax, where wealthier individuals are taxed at a higher rate than poorer individuals.  By requiring wealthier people to pay a relatively larger proportion of taxes, such a system would help to prevent the creation of dynastic wealth and its associated inequality.
 By contrast, the author would not most likely view the following kinds of taxes as beneficial to society:
a regressive tax, where the tax rate is eventually capped at a maximum level regardless of an individual's wealth (Choice B).  Under such a tax system, the richest individuals would pay proportionally less as their level of wealth rises, and as a result their descendants would inherit an even greater unearned economic advantage.  Accordingly, this kind of tax would contribute to the economic inequality and dynastic wealth that the author views as problematic.
a flat tax, where all individuals are taxed at the same rate regardless of their level of wealth (Choice C).  By taxing the poor at the same rate as the rich, this tax system would preserve the existing levels of economic advantage or disadvantage.
a consumption tax, where individuals' tax rates are based primarily on the value of goods and services that they purchase (Choice D).  Although wealthy individuals can afford to buy more expensive goods and services than poorer individuals, they can also choose whether or not to purchase such luxury items.  Hence, they could potentially reduce or eliminate the power of a consumption tax to affect them at a proportionally higher rate.  Accordingly, such a tax would be less effective at facilitating wealth redistribution than one that directly taxes wealthier individuals at a higher rate.

text: Which of the following scenarios is the best example of a "tyranny of chance" (Paragraph 6), as the passage author uses the term?
explanations:
Nonetheless, this claim of initial social equality is precisely what socialism rejects as illusory.  Let us suppose that everyone in society begins life upon equal footing....  Equality is shattered, but justly, and from an early uniformity of status rise differences in wealth, garnered according to the abilities and enterprise displayed by each person. (Paragraph 4)
As time passes, however, the wealth or destitution of one generation is bequeathed to the next, and then inequality becomes ingrained….  One individual has an advantage that another lacks—not gained through striving and perseverance but inherited through accident of birth. (Paragraph 5)
Such effects only compound over time.  Inevitably, dynasties of wealth accrue by which a few through mere circumstance enjoy economic mastery over the many, who face through the tyranny of chance an undeserved impediment. (Paragraph 6)
In Paragraph 4, the passage author implies that inequality can be just if it arises through fair competition, "according to the abilities and enterprise displayed by each person."  However, he or she stresses that such fair competition would depend on "everyone in society begin[ning] life on equal footing," which is not the case.  Rather, much inequality simply arises by chance.
For example, the author stresses that when existing wealth or poverty is passed to the next generation, there inevitably arises a situation in which "[o]ne individual has an advantage that another lacks—not gained through striving and perseverance but inherited through accident of birth" (Paragraph 5).  Thus, the author states that "through mere circumstance," there are disadvantaged individuals "who face through the tyranny of chance an undeserved impediment" (Paragraph 6).
Therefore, the author uses the term "tyranny of chance" to describe situations in which an individual is unfairly disadvantaged in society due to personal circumstances beyond his or her control (eg, being born into an impoverished family).  Accordingly, a job candidate who receives few employment offers because he is physically unattractive is the best example of a tyranny of chance.  Such a candidate does not deserve the disadvantage he suffers, because it is caused by a factor over which he had no control.
 By contrast, none of the following scenarios is the best example of a tyranny of chance:
A patient cannot have a desired medical procedure performed because her doctor has ethical concerns (Choice A).  A doctor's ethical concerns would most likely be based upon standards of practice that would be applied to any equivalent patient; they would not be a matter of chance or based on the woman's unique characteristics.
A defendant is found guilty at trial because his attorney could not persuade the jury that he is innocent (Choice C).  If the defendant were innocent but found guilty because his attorney could not persuade the jury, then the defendant could be considered as suffering an unfair disadvantage or "tyranny of chance."  However, if the defendant did commit the crime and was found guilty because his attorney could not persuade the jury, then it would be a deserved verdict, not a "tyranny of chance."  No information is given regarding whether the defendant actually committed the crime, so whether he faced a "tyranny of chance" cannot be determined.
A frequent gambler loses more than she wins because the games are engineered to have a higher likelihood of money loss (Choice D).  Although gambling involves games of chance, the likelihood of winning or losing would apply to any person who plays them (ie, the games are designed to make all players more likely to lose money).  Accordingly, while the frequent gambler loses more than she wins, she is not unfairly disadvantaged by her personal characteristics.  Therefore, this situation does not represent a tyranny of chance.

text: The description of socialism as "a pervasive bogeyman" is part of the author's claim that:
explanations:
For decades, socialism has been a pervasive bogeyman laying siege at the periphery of the American psyche.  Policies and candidates alike are dismissed out of hand by pronouncing them "socialist," the term sufficing to preclude further consideration.  However, such reactions to any topic ought to give us pause: have we truly judged an idea as unworthy, impractical, or unjust?  Or do we simply demonstrate an unreflective fear of a label? (Paragraph 1)
In Paragraph 1, the author calls socialism "a pervasive bogeyman laying siege at the periphery of the American psyche," thus portraying people as afraid of ideas thought to be socialist.  Moreover, the author asserts, this fear is so influential that the mere label 'socialist' is enough to make people reject those ideas prejudicially: "Policies and candidates alike are dismissed out of hand by pronouncing them 'socialist,' the term sufficing to preclude (rule out) further consideration."
Accordingly, the author implies that in dismissing socialist candidates and policies due to fear, people do not truly examine socialist ideas to evaluate them.  Therefore, the description of socialism as "a pervasive bogeyman" is part of the author's claim that people seldom genuinely examine socialist ideas.
 By contrast, the description of socialism as "a pervasive bogeyman" is not part of a claim that:
most Americans are unconcerned about socialist ideas (Choice A).  In Paragraph 1, the author describes American attitudes toward socialist ideas: "Policies and candidates alike are dismissed out of hand by pronouncing them 'socialist,' the term sufficing to preclude further consideration."  Accordingly, the author suggests that Americans are so concerned about socialist ideas that anything called 'socialist' is automatically rejected.
concerns about socialism are not reflected by the reality of socialism in practice (Choice C).  The author suggests that policies should not be "dismissed out of hand" due to fears about socialism (Paragraph 1).  However, this contention is part of a claim that socialist ideas should be genuinely evaluated; it is not based on assertions about the reality of socialism in practice.
objections to socialism are baseless (Choice D).  The author claims that "legitimate scrutiny is warranted" regarding socialism (Paragraph 2), implying that it is reasonable to look critically at socialist ideas.  Additionally, the author later suggests that "a 'pure' form of either capitalism or socialism will ultimately prove destructive" (Paragraph 8), implying that objections to socialism should be taken seriously.

text: Based on the passage, a socialist would argue that those who object to wealth redistribution should actually support it because:
explanations:
The objection to redistribution of wealth rests on the idea that it takes from the more deserving and gives to the less—if not to the lazy or the layabout.  Given equality of opportunity, why should he who toils be denied the right of harvest?  Why should he who idles be afforded an equal reward? (Paragraph 3)
As time passes, however, the wealth or destitution of one generation is bequeathed to the next, and then inequality becomes ingrained.  What was before an earned difference of outcome is now an unearned difference of potential…not gained through striving and perseverance but inherited through accident of birth. (Paragraph 5)
Such effects only compound over time.... The socialist's claim, then, is that complaints against redistribution of wealth fail in light of the very concern for fairness upon which they are founded. (Paragraph 6)
Paragraph 3 poses the rhetorical questions: "[W]hy should he who toils be denied the right of harvest?  Why should he who idles be afforded an equal reward?"  These objections to wealth redistribution (ie, transferring wealth from economically advantaged groups to economically disadvantaged groups) are based on a conception of economic fairness.  Specifically, the objectors believe economic inequality is fair as long as wealth goes to the people who have earned it and is not given to those who did not earn it themselves.
However, socialists point out that individuals who inherit wealth also did not earn it themselves.  When wealth is passed down it is "not gained through striving and perseverance but inherited through accident of birth" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, socialists argue that "complaints against redistribution of wealth fail in light of the very concern for fairness upon which they are founded" (Paragraph 6).  In other words, if the inherited wealth is not redistributed, then wealth is given to those who did not earn it, violating the conception of fairness on which objections to wealth redistribution are based.
Accordingly, based on passage information, a socialist would argue that those who object to wealth redistribution should instead support it because the objectors' own commitment to fairness makes wealth redistribution justified.
 (Choice A)  wealth redistribution is consistent with capitalism.  Paragraph 8 describes capitalism as "liable to exploitation," citing the example of "the systemic injustices perpetuated by dynastic wealth."  Hence, the passage indicates that capitalism leads to the kind of economic injustice that wealth redistribution is designed to alleviate.  Accordingly, the passage does not suggest that wealth redistribution is consistent with capitalism, but rather that wealth redistribution would help to correct a drawback of capitalism.
(Choice B)  people should not be denied the rewards of their labor.  According to Paragraph 3, "capitalists and socialists will likely agree" on the sentiments expressed by two rhetorical questions: "[W]hy should he who toils be denied the right of harvest?  Why should he who idles be afforded an equal reward?"  However, the socialist's argument for wealth redistribution is based on the second of these points (ie, that people should not receive unearned rewards) rather than the first (ie, that people should not be denied the rewards of their labor).
(Choice C)  the majority of people have benefited from past socialistic reforms.  Paragraph 8 states that "[i]n post-industrial America, governmental reforms and regulations on commerce and industry were required to redress (remedy) the systemic injustices perpetuated by dynastic wealth."  A socialist would likely agree that people have benefited from such reforms.  However, the argument that those who object to wealth redistribution should instead support it is based not on the effect of past reforms, but instead on the objectors' own values.  Specifically, a socialist would argue that concern for economic fairness justifies wealth redistribution, regardless of whether the objectors agree that past socialistic reforms were beneficial.

text: Which of the following statements regarding the author's argument would represent the most reasonable criticism?
explanations:
In fact, capitalists and socialists will likely agree on the broad outlines of what fairness entails.  The objection to redistribution of wealth rests on the idea that it takes from the more deserving and gives to the less—if not to the lazy or the layabout.  Given equality of opportunity, why should he who toils be denied the right of harvest?  Why should he who idles be afforded an equal reward? (Paragraph 3)
As time passes, however, the wealth or destitution of one generation is bequeathed to the next, and then inequality becomes ingrained.  What was before an earned difference of outcome is now an unearned difference of potential. (Paragraph 5)
Such effects only compound over time...The socialist's claim, then, is that complaints against redistribution of wealth fail in light of the very concern for fairness upon which they are founded. (Paragraph 6)
A key part of the author's argument involves the relationship between wealth redistribution and economic fairness.  Although socialists generally support wealth redistribution while capitalists oppose it, the author asserts that both groups "will likely agree on the broad outlines of what fairness entails."  Specifically, capitalists and socialists both believe economic fairness means that wealth should go to those who earn it.  Thus, "he who toils" has a right to economic reward, but "he who idles" does not (Paragraph 3).
Nevertheless, the author argues that this connection between toil and reward inevitably breaks down.  When wealth or poverty is passed to the next generation, "[w]hat was before an earned difference of outcome is now an unearned difference of potential" (Paragraph 5).  In other words, although the person who works has originally earned wealth, someone who only inherits that same wealth has not earned it.  Therefore, the author argues that "complaints against redistribution of wealth fail" (Paragraph 6).  Rather, wealth redistribution is justified to help restore the "equality of opportunity" (Paragraph 3) needed to connect economic rewards with a person's own efforts in acquiring them.
However, the author never provides any details about the way this redistribution should function.  Accordingly, even if one accepts the author's conclusion that wealth redistribution is necessary for economic fairness, it may be unclear what form that redistribution could take, whether certain proposals would be effective, and so on.  Hence, lacking these details could call into question whether the proposed wealth redistribution is actually feasible.  Therefore, the most reasonable criticism of the author's argument would be that the passage does not discuss how wealth redistribution should be achieved.
 (Choice A)  Some Americans are already receptive to socialist ideas.  Paragraph 1 states that in America, "[p]olicies and candidates alike are dismissed out of hand by pronouncing them 'socialist.'"  However, this attitude could be typical or widespread without applying to every American.  Accordingly, even if some Americans are already receptive to socialist ideas, that fact would not challenge the author's argument that Americans in general should be more willing to consider such ideas.
(Choice B)  Historically, proposals to redistribute wealth have always faced resistance.  Part of the passage argument concerns addressing "[t]he objection to redistribution of wealth" (Paragraph 3) and explaining why, in the author's view, that objection fails.  Therefore, the idea that wealth redistribution faces resistance would not be a criticism of the author's argument, but one of its motivations.
(Choice C)  Every economic system has some benefits and some flaws.  In Paragraph 8, the author suggests that "a 'pure' form of either capitalism or socialism will ultimately prove destructive."  Thus, he or she argues that instead of following any one economic system exclusively, we should "instead inquire which ideas, and in what combination, best promote the justice whose value we profess."  Therefore, the idea that every economic system has benefits and flaws is something the author seems to acknowledge; hence, that idea would not serve as a criticism of the author's argument.

text: The author suggests that the majority of people in America are opposed to socialism mainly due to:
explanations:
Policies and candidates alike are dismissed out of hand by pronouncing them "socialist," the term sufficing to preclude further consideration.  However, such reactions to any topic ought to give us pause: have we truly judged an idea as unworthy, impractical, or unjust?  Or do we simply demonstrate an unreflective fear of a label? (Paragraph 1)
Are the dismissive reactions towards socialism then justified?  Not as such…. Rather than embrace or reject one system from the outset, we must avoid a focus on labels and instead inquire which ideas, and in what combination, best promote the justice whose value we profess. (Paragraph 8)
According to Paragraph 1, people in America tend to just assume socialism is detrimental and therefore reject it unthinkingly: "[p]olicies and candidates alike are dismissed out of hand by pronouncing them 'socialist,' the term sufficing to preclude further consideration."  Thus, in the author's view, most Americans do not truly examine the ideas behind socialism, but instead "simply demonstrate an unreflective fear of a label" (Paragraph 1).
Likewise, the author further alludes to this idea in Paragraph 8, asserting that "we must avoid a focus on labels and instead inquire which ideas, and in what combination, best promote the justice whose value we profess."  In this way, the author again implies that Americans reject ideas called 'socialist' without considering those ideas for themselves.  Therefore, the author suggests that the majority of people in America are opposed to socialism mainly due to a pre-existing bias against it.
 (Choice A)  uneasiness over government influence.  Paragraph 7 mentions a historical case in which socialism was implemented, when "eleventh-century Chinese statesman Wang An-shih instituted state control of the economy."  However, although this information connects socialism to government influence, the author never suggests that uneasiness over such influence is the main reason many Americans oppose socialism.
(Choice B)  confusion about what policies it entails.  Paragraph 2 states that "[p]erhaps the gravest threat of socialist programmes to capitalist America is their perceived unfairness" in transferring wealth from certain groups to others.  Thus, the passage conveys that people have some awareness of socialist ideas and the "threat" they represent.  Therefore, the author does not suggest that many Americans reject socialism due to confusion over what policies it entails, but rather that they reject it because they have a negative view of those policies.
(Choice D)  a scrutiny of its ideas.  In Paragraph 1, the author states that "[p]olicies and candidates alike are dismissed out of hand by pronouncing them 'socialist,' the term sufficing to preclude further consideration."  He or she then goes on to say: "Initial prejudice notwithstanding, legitimate scrutiny is warranted" (Paragraph 2).  Therefore, the author indicates that there are reasons to scrutinize socialism, but suggests that most people do not actually engage in such scrutiny; rather, they reject socialism due to their prejudice against it.

text: The passage author's attitude toward the bewildered concert-goer is:
explanations:
To the untutored layman, an orchestra's or choir's conductor may seem a superfluous appendage (although the view is unlikely to be expressed in such lofty terms).  Indeed, this sentiment is aptly conveyed by one bewildered concert-goer, who asked his companion: "They know the song, and the music's right there in front of them.  So what do they need the guy with the wand for?"  This flagrant ignorance aside, it is true that the purpose of a conductor (and his baton) is but little understood by those who only listen to music rather than produce it.  Yet conductors play a pivotal role in these productions, elevating a performance beyond what it would be as merely a group of musicians engaged in a common cause. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 describes a "bewildered concert-goer" who did not understand why the musicians had a conductor: "'They know the song, and the music's right there in front of them.  So what do they need the guy with the wand for?'"  The passage author calls this question an example of "flagrant ignorance" (ie, ignorance that is especially extreme and blameworthy), suggesting that he or she looks down upon the concert-goer for asking it.
The author further displays this disdainful attitude through remarks about language use, which imply that the concert-goer lacks intelligence and sophistication.  For instance, the author asserts that confusion about conductors "is unlikely to be expressed in such lofty terms" as "superfluous appendage" (ie, an unnecessary or pointless addition) and emphasizes that conductors use a "baton" rather than a "'wand.'"
Consequently, the passage author belittles and ridicules the bewildered concert-goer, exhibiting an attitude of open condescension.
 (Choices A and B)  thorough puzzlement; and shocked incredulity.  Paragraph 1 describes the concert-goer as displaying "flagrant ignorance" about the purpose of conductors.  However, the author then suggests that similar types of ignorance are relatively common, stating: "it is true that the purpose of a conductor (and his baton) is but little understood by those who only listen to music rather than produce it."  Accordingly, the author does not express confusion or disbelief about the concert-goer.  Rather, he or she treats the concert-goer's reaction as an especially pronounced example of how "[t]o the untutored layman, an orchestra's or choir's conductor may seem a superfluous appendage."
(Choice D)  delighted amusement.  Paragraph 1 describes the concert-goer's question about conductors as a case of "flagrant ignorance."  This highly negative portrayal would suggest that the author views the concert-goer as obnoxious and dull; he or she never suggests that the concert-goer's ignorance is delightful or amusing.

text: Based on information in the passage, a crucial difference between the role of a sports coach in a game and the role of a conductor in a concert is that:
explanations:
Such factors explain why the comparison of a conductor to a sports coach would represent an inadequate understanding.  For while a coach instructs the players, determining their course and addressing their deficiencies, he does not take the field or court along with them.  However much he guides them, when the whistle blows, it is they who partake in the actual striving. (Paragraph 4)
A more apt analogy is provided by Paul Engelstad: "At the conclusion of a fine concert, the conductor shares the applause and is quick to give credit to his choir.  But when the ship flounders and is lost, the responsible captain accepts all blame and absolves his crew from any fault."  The conductor is as much a performer as the singer or instrumentalist under his command; together they voyage successfully or sink. (Paragraph 5)
According to the passage, conductors and sports coaches differ in terms of how they influence a concert or game.  Although a coach gives instructions to the athletes, "he does not take the field or court along with them.  However much he guides them, when the whistle blows, it is they who partake in the actual striving" (Paragraph 4).  Thus, although coaches affect the outcome of a game by training and instructing the players, they do not play in the game themselves.
By contrast, the act of conducting is itself a part of the concert.  By directing the musicians, a conductor "is as much a performer as the singer or instrumentalist under his command; together they voyage successfully or sink" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, the passage implies that a crucial difference between the role of a sports coach in a game and the role of a conductor in a concert is that conductors perform alongside the musicians.
 (Choices A and B)  conductors give the credit for successes to the performers; and conductors shoulder the blame for every failure.  In Paragraph 5, the author cites Paul Engelstad's position that conductors should attribute successes to their performers, but take the blame for any failures themselves: "'At the conclusion of a fine concert, the conductor shares the applause and is quick to give credit to his choir.  But when the ship flounders and is lost, the responsible captain accepts all blame and absolves his crew from any fault.'"
However, although the author draws a contrast between conductors and sports coaches, this distinction is not based on how they assign credit or blame, but rather on whether they "partake in the actual striving" alongside their players (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, it would be consistent with passage information if both conductors and coaches take the blame for any failures but give their players credit for successes.
(Choice D)  conductors communicate instructions non-verbally.  According to Paragraph 4, conductors use physical cues to influence performers.  For instance, "[t]iming, volume, and emotional expressiveness can all be communicated non-verbally."  However, the passage never discusses whether coaches might similarly communicate with players non-verbally.  Therefore, the passage does not distinguish between conductors and sports coaches in terms of giving non-verbal instructions.

text: Which of the following statements about conductors and singers is most strongly suggested by Paragraph 3?
explanations:
Nor is it purely a figure of speech that one can see a musical piece's character in the conductor.  Timing, volume, and emotional expressiveness can all be communicated non-verbally; not only through overt gestures but kinesthetically, via the operation of mirror neurons.  As Riikka Pietiläinen-Caffrey notes, "Studies of the mirror neuron system are helpful for explaining scientifically what conductors already know by experience."  Singers subconsciously mimic physical cues from a conductor, affecting their "tone of voice, pronunciation, gesture, body posture, and breathing rates."  Through even small adjustments to his or her own body, a conductor may therefore correct—or exacerbate—issues with singers' vocal quality, stance, proper inhalation, and so on, both during rehearsals and, more crucially, in concerts. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, singers "can see a musical piece's character in the conductor.  Timing, volume, and emotional expressiveness can all be communicated non-verbally."  The author then describes the effects of this non-verbal communication, asserting that "[s]ingers subconsciously mimic physical cues from a conductor, affecting their 'tone of voice, pronunciation, gesture, body posture, and breathing rates.'"
Thus, Paragraph 3 indicates that conductors influence many aspects of singers' performance, and that some parts of this process may occur subconsciously.  Therefore, conductors may influence the performance of singers in ways that the singers are not directly aware of.
 (Choice B)  Conductors typically do not provide verbal instructions to singers during rehearsals.  Paragraph 3 states that "[t]iming, volume, and emotional expressiveness can all be communicated nonverbally," and that "[s]ingers subconsciously mimic physical cues from a conductor."  However, although conductors can communicate using non-verbal cues, this does not exclude the possibility that they also provide verbal instructions to singers during rehearsals.  For instance, a conductor might verbally instruct singers before they begin singing, but use non-verbal cues while the singing is taking place.
(Choice C)  Difficulties experienced by singers are caused by conductors giving inaccurate physical cues.  According to Paragraph 3, "Through even small adjustments to his or her own body, a conductor may therefore correct—or exacerbate (make worse)—issues with singers' vocal quality, stance, proper inhalation, and so on."  However, although the conductor may correct or exacerbate singers' issues, the passage never suggests that he or she was the cause of those issues.  Rather, it simply states that the influence of a conductor can affect whether singers improve or grow worse in those areas.
(Choice D)  Conductors who possess an understanding of mirror neurons influence singers more effectively.  Paragraph 3 cites Riikka Pietiläinen-Caffrey's assertion that "'[s]tudies of the mirror neuron system are helpful for explaining scientifically what conductors already know by experience.'"  Accordingly, this statement does not suggest that conductors influence singers more effectively when they understand mirror neurons.  Rather, it suggests that conductors "already know by experience" how to influence singers, and the mirror neuron system helps to explain why their techniques are effective.

text: Which of the following discoveries would most undermine the author's claims about the role of conductors?
explanations:
To the untutored layman, an orchestra's or choir's conductor may seem a superfluous appendage….  This flagrant ignorance aside, it is true that the purpose of a conductor (and his baton) is but little understood by those who only listen to music rather than produce it.  Yet conductors play a pivotal role in these productions, elevating a performance beyond what it would be as merely a group of musicians engaged in a common cause. (Paragraph 1)
In essence, the conductor is a unifying force, effecting a full transformation of complementary musical parts into a singular yet multifaceted whole. (Paragraph 2)
The conductor as captain thus gives the music its ultimate sense and expression.  The musical score has its instructions, but it is the conductor's interpretive vision that determines how the notes should be played or sung.  In short, the conductor infuses a work with passion, that element which, in the words of Terry York, "modulates the performance to something greater than the sum of its parts." (Paragraph 6)
Throughout the passage, the author stresses the importance of conductors in raising musical performances to greater heights.  For instance, Paragraph 1 states that "conductors play a pivotal role…elevating a performance beyond what it would be as merely a group of musicians engaged in a common cause."  Similarly, Paragraph 2 asserts that "the conductor is a unifying force, effecting a full transformation of complementary musical parts into a singular yet multifaceted whole."  Finally, the author concludes by stating that "the conductor infuses a work with passion, that element which…'modulates the performance to something greater than the sum of its parts'" (Paragraph 6).
Thus, the author asserts that conductors improve musical performances, enabling them to reach a level of excellence beyond what the musicians would achieve on their own.  However, if there were little difference in quality between performances that included conductors and those that did not, this would suggest that a conductor's efforts actually do not have much impact.  In that case, conductors would indeed be "a superfluous appendage" (Paragraph 1) rather than a transformative and elevating force.  Consequently, the author's claims about the role of conductors would be most undermined if symphonies receive similar acclaim from professional music critics whether or not the orchestras were led by a conductor.
 (Choice A)  When a conductor is not present, professional musicians still play their instruments with a high level of proficiency.  According to Paragraph 1, conductors "elevat[e] a performance beyond what it would be as merely a group of musicians engaged in a common cause."  However, this claim does not mean that musicians lack proficiency at playing their instruments when a conductor is not present.  Rather, the musicians may be highly skilled in either case, yet they could still have their performance as a group made "'greater than the sum of its parts'" by a conductor (Paragraph 6).
(Choice C)  Research studies suggest that the effects of conducting have little to do with the mirror neuron system.  According to Paragraph 3, "Timing, volume, and emotional expressiveness can all be communicated non-verbally; not only through overt gestures but kinesthetically, via the operation of mirror neurons."  However, if it were discovered that the effects of conducting have little to do with the mirror neuron system, that would challenge only the explanation of why conductors' techniques are effective.  It would not challenge the effectiveness of the techniques themselves.
(Choice D)  A survey of non-musicians finds that a majority of people believe conductors are important to the coherence and overall quality of a concert.  In this scenario, the author would be wrong that "the purpose of a conductor…is but little understood by those who only listen to music rather than produce it" (Paragraph 1).  Instead, most non-musicians would understand the purpose of conductors.  However, this discovery would undermine only the author's claims about how non-musicians conceive of conductors; it would not undermine his or her claims about the role of conductors.

text: Which of the following ideas is the author inconsistent about in the passage?
explanations:
In essence, the conductor is a unifying force, effecting a full transformation of complementary musical parts into a singular yet multifaceted whole.  A composer's vision is thereby transmitted through the musicians to be delivered to the audience—by the hand of the conductor, the truth of the music is made manifest. (Paragraph 2)
The conductor as captain thus gives the music its ultimate sense and expression.  The musical score has its instructions, but it is the conductor's interpretive vision that determines how the notes should be played or sung.  In short, the conductor infuses a work with passion, that element which, in the words of Terry York, "modulates the performance to something greater than the sum of its parts." (Paragraph 6)
When describing conducting in Paragraph 2, the author states: "A composer's vision is thereby transmitted through the musicians to be delivered to the audience—by the hand of the conductor, the truth of the music is made manifest."  Accordingly, in this part of the passage, the author implies that conductors transmit a composer's vision, which is identified as "the truth of the music."
However, Paragraph 6 asserts that "[t]he conductor as captain thus gives the music its ultimate sense and expression.  The musical score has its instructions, but it is the conductor's interpretive vision that determines how the notes should be played or sung."  Thus, in this later part of the passage, the author implies that a conductor may use his or her own "interpretive vision" for the music despite the composer's instructions in the musical score.
Consequently, the author is inconsistent about whether conductors convey their own vision for a piece of music or the vision of the composer.
 By contrast, the author is not inconsistent about any of the following ideas in the passage:
Whether the role of conductors is generally understood or misunderstood (Choice B).  In Paragraph 1, the author asserts that "the purpose of a conductor…is but little understood by those who only listen to music rather than produce it."  Hence, the author suggests that the role of conductors is generally misunderstood; he or she never contradicts this claim elsewhere in the passage.
Whether conductors and coaches are entirely dissimilar or only somewhat different (Choice C).  The author conveys that conductors and coaches are similar in that both help to improve the performance of those they lead.  For example, conductors "correct…issues with singers' vocal quality, stance, proper inhalation, and so on" (Paragraph 3), and "a coach instructs the players…addressing their deficiencies" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, although the author asserts that "the comparison of a conductor to a sports coach would represent an inadequate understanding" (Paragraph 4), he or she never suggests that the two roles are entirely dissimilar.
Whether the information about conductors applies more to conducting orchestras or choirs (Choice D).  The author refers to conducting both choirs and orchestras, but never draws a distinction between the two types of conducting.  For example, Paragraph 5 states that "[t]he conductor is as much a performer as the singer or instrumentalist under his command," and Paragraph 6 refers to determining "how the notes should be played or sung."  Thus, the author implies that his or her remarks apply to both choirs and orchestras; he or she never suggests otherwise in the passage.

text: Passage information suggests that Beethoven's symphony and Klimt's frieze were notable in part because they:
explanations:
In Swafford's astute estimation, the Ninth embodies Beethoven's own quest for the perfect melody; it is about "the composer composing." (Paragraph 2)
Klimt further immortalized the tune with his monumental frieze spanning three sides of the room it occupies.  This "Ode to Joy" mural depicts humanity's desperate struggle to achieve happiness through the power of art.  In the process, the painter reveals his own tortured search for the perfect style.  As a result, the finished frieze reflects a syncretism of ancient Greek, Byzantine, early medieval, Japanese, and contemporary Viennese art, yet also gleams with the unique gold inlay that would characterize Klimt's work. (Paragraph 3)
The passage stresses that both Beethoven and Klimt allowed the evidence of their own artistic struggles to show through their finished works.  For instance, Paragraph 2 presents Jan Swafford's view that "the Ninth embodies Beethoven's own quest for the perfect melody; it is about 'the composer composing.'"  In other words, the Ninth presents the composer's artistic process and efforts.  Similarly, Paragraph 3 conveys that Klimt revealed "his own tortured search for the perfect style" through his painting.  As a result of this search, "the finished frieze reflects a syncretism (mixture) of ancient Greek, Byzantine, early medieval, Japanese, and contemporary Viennese art, yet also gleams with the unique gold inlay that came to characterize Klimt's work."
Consequently, passage information suggests that Beethoven's symphony and Klimt's frieze were notable in part because they revealed the process and great effort entailed in art.
 (Choice A)  stressed the frailties over the triumph of the human spirit.  Both Beethoven's symphony and Klimt's frieze emphasized the resiliency of the human spirit.  As the author points out, Beethoven's Ninth has "served as protest song, hymn to freedom, and unifying chant" and has been "regularly hailed as 'a universal human anthem' and 'the battle cry of humanity'" (Paragraph 2).  Likewise, Klimt's frieze describes how, with the help of the arts, the human spirit is strong enough to overcome the trials of existence: "the magnificent image of a solitary muse…attests that the human quest for happiness will find its ultimate fulfillment in art" (Paragraph 6).  Therefore, rather than merely stressing the frailties of the human spirit, both Beethoven's symphony and Klimt's frieze emphasized that the human spirit is ultimately triumphant.
(Choice B)  incorporated instructive messages to other artists.  The passage conveys that both Beethoven's Ninth and Klimt's frieze illustrate the struggles of artistic creation.  Paragraph 2 cites Jan Swafford's view that the Ninth "embodies Beethoven's own quest for the perfect melody" and reflects "'the composer composing.'"  Paragraph 3 then conveys that the frieze reveals Klimt's "own tortured search for the perfect style."  Although other artists could likely relate to these struggles, the passage never indicates that either work contained instructive messages directed toward other artists.
(Choice D)  portrayed each person's journey toward happiness as unique.  As Paragraph 2 notes, the finale to Beethoven's Ninth is "regularly hailed as 'a universal human anthem' and 'the battle cry of humanity.'"  Thus, the symphony represents humanity as striving toward a shared freedom and happiness.  Likewise, in Klimt's frieze, humanity is engaged in a struggle to overcome "the hostile forces…that obstruct human happiness" (Paragraph 5).  In the final panel, "the magnificent image of a solitary muse…attests that the human quest for happiness will find its ultimate fulfillment in art" (Paragraph 6).  Accordingly, the passage suggests that both Beethoven's symphony and Klimt's frieze presented a collective journey toward happiness—one that belongs to all humanity rather than one that was uniquely personal.

text: Which of the following claims is strongly supported by passage evidence?
explanations:
This "Ode to Joy" mural depicts humanity's desperate struggle to achieve happiness through the power of art.  In the process, the painter reveals his own tortured search for the perfect style.  As a result, the finished frieze reflects a syncretism of ancient Greek, Byzantine, early medieval, Japanese, and contemporary Viennese art, yet also gleams with the unique gold inlay that would characterize Klimt's work. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, Klimt's Beethoven Frieze "reveals his own tortured search for the perfect style."  The author then describes how "the finished frieze reflects a syncretism (mixture) of ancient Greek, Byzantine, early medieval, Japanese, and contemporary Viennese art, yet also gleams with the unique gold inlay that came to characterize Klimt's work."  Hence, the passage describes how when painting the frieze, Klimt integrated artistic styles from various sources, which he then overlayed with an innovation of his own.  Accordingly, the claim that Klimt's artistic technique reflected multiple sources is strongly supported by passage evidence.
 By contrast, passage evidence does not support the following claims:
Klimt was conscious of the prestige involved in creating the frieze (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 1, Klimt's "spectacular wall painting was commissioned as a part of the fourteenth exhibition of the Viennese Secession" and was "[u]nveiled as an homage (public honoring) to the great composer."  The author further conveys that "the exhibit was meant to be temporary" but Klimt's frieze "was restored and became an enduring masterpiece."  Although this information suggests that Klimt's frieze was considered important to the exhibit and was later held in high regard, the passage never reveals how Klimt felt about painting the frieze or whether he was aware of any prestige being involved.
Klimt's work was influential while that of his contemporaries was not (Choice C).  Paragraph 1 stresses that "in the case of Klimt's frieze, what began as an ad hoc (ie, set up for a particular purpose) display, painted directly on brittle plaster, was restored and became an enduring masterpiece."  The fact that the mural was deliberately restored and has since been proclaimed a masterpiece demonstrates that the frieze was influential.  However, the passage never discusses the other Secessionist painters' work and whether it was influential.
Many Secessionists were much more conventional than Klimt (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 1, the Viennese Secession was "an association of radically nontraditional artists founded in 1897 and headed by Klimt."  Hence, these artists could be characterized as highly unconventional.  However, the passage never discusses whether other Secessionist artists were any more or less conventional than Klimt.

text: The passage most strongly suggests which of the following about choral pieces?
explanations:
With his Ninth Symphony, first performed in 1824, Beethoven revolutionized the symphonic genre; in particular, the final movement was the first such work to feature a chorus. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, "With his Ninth Symphony, first performed in 1824, Beethoven revolutionized the symphonic genre."  Likely his most radical innovation was the symphony's final movement, which became "the first such work to feature a chorus."  This fact implies that in succeeding years other composers would also feature choruses in their symphonies.  Consequently, the passage most strongly suggests that choral pieces are more prevalent in symphonies after Beethoven's time.
 By contrast, although the following statements may describe Beethoven's "Ode to Joy," the passage never suggests that they are characteristic of choral pieces:
Choral pieces are composed by musicians rebelling against convention (Choice A).  Paragraph 2 states that "Beethoven revolutionized the symphonic genre" with the choral movement of his Ninth Symphony.  However, the passage never generalizes from Beethoven's "Ode to Joy" to convey the idea that choral pieces are more likely to be composed by musicians who rebel against convention.
Choral pieces are derived from common tunes that anyone could sing (Choice C).  Paragraph 2 conveys Jan Swafford's words about the Ninth Symphony's choral piece: "[Beethoven] 'erected a movement of epic scope on a humble little tune that anyone can sing.'"  However, the humble origin of the "Ode to Joy" is presented as ironic or surprising rather than as something typical of choral pieces.
Choral pieces readily lend themselves to visual representation (Choice D).  Although the painter Klimt chose to depict the choral piece or "Ode to Joy" of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony on his frieze, the passage never connects this fact to the idea that choral pieces readily lend themselves to visual representation.

text: Based on the passage, many of the figures in Klimt's frieze are meant to be interpreted as:
explanations:
First, sylph-like female figures—genii signifying the human yearning for happiness—float past.  Next, naked, pitiable figures, including the emaciated form of a girl and a kneeling couple, epitomize humanity's suffering.  They implore a knight in shining golden armor, behind whom looms the feminine dyad of Compassion and Ambition, to protect humankind. (Paragraph 4)
The middle wall portrays the hostile forces—external as well as internal—that obstruct human happiness.  The giant gorilla-like monster Typhoeus, whose lower body morphs into that of a winding serpent, symbolizes not only the typhoid disease that ravaged Europe but also the destructive winds of war.  To the left stand his three, snake-haired, Gorgon-like daughters, above whom peer the grimacing faces of Sickness, Madness, and Death—scourges prevalent in the Viennese society of Klimt's day.  To the monster's right, the threefold evils of Lasciviousness, Wantonness, and Intemperance lurk, while dwarfed before his serpentine coil appears the horrifying hag of Gnawing Grief. (Paragraph 5)
On the far wall, the ephemeral feminine genii of human desires once again float past.  In the following panel, a vertical arrangement of five females appearing to awaken represents the different art forms.  Farther to the right, the magnificent image of a solitary muse holding a golden lyre attests that the human quest for happiness will find its ultimate fulfillment in art. (Paragraph 6)
The passage presents many of the figures in Klimt's frieze as symbolic.  For example, Paragraph 4 describes the "sylph-like (slender and graceful) female figures—genii signifying the human yearning for happiness" and the "naked, pitiable figures, including the emaciated form of a girl and a kneeling couple [who] epitomize (represent) humanity's suffering."  In addition, the "feminine dyad (pair) of Compassion and Ambition" is mentioned.  While these figures have human form, they represent concepts or abstract ideas such as happiness and suffering.
Likewise, Paragraph 5 showcases "hostile forces" that, though abstract, have living forms such as the "giant gorilla-like monster Typhoeus," who "symbolizes…the destructive winds of war," as well as "Sickness, Madness, and Death," which are portrayed as "grimacing faces."  Others, including "the threefold evils of Lasciviousness, Wantonness, and Intemperance" and "the horrifying hag of Gnawing Grief," are also mentioned.
Paragraph 6 presents more symbolic figures: "[A] vertical arrangement of five females…represents the different art forms."  Farther on, "a solitary muse holding a golden lyre attests that the human quest for happiness will find its ultimate fulfillment in art."
Although the figures mentioned above have the forms of humans or other living beings, they stand for abstract concepts, such as compassion, war, and grief.  Therefore, based on the passage, many of the figures in Klimt's frieze are meant to be interpreted as personified concepts.
 (Choice B)  muses.  According to Paragraph 6, "[T]he magnificent image of a solitary muse…attests that the human quest for happiness will find its ultimate fulfillment in art."  However, this muse is only one of the figures in the frieze; the passage never indicates that any of the other figures are meant to be muses.
(Choice C)  dream images.  In describing the frieze, Paragraph 4 mentions "sylph-like female figures—genii signifying the human yearning for happiness," while Paragraph 6 conveys that "the ephemeral (transient) feminine genii of human desires once again float past."  Even though these figures might appear dream-like, the passage never suggests that they are meant to represent images from a dream.
(Choice D)  lovers.  In Paragraph 4, the author mentions "a kneeling couple" who are supposed to "epitomize humanity's suffering" but are not depicted as lovers.  By contrast, Paragraph 6 describes the final panel of the frieze, where "locked in an embrace, a man and woman kiss."  While the kissing couple represent lovers, most of the images on the frieze are solitary figures—for example Typhoid, the Horrifying Hag, and the muse—or feminine groups of two, three, or five.  Accordingly, while some of the figures on the frieze may be lovers, many are not.

text: Of the following assertions about painters, which is most strongly suggested by information in Paragraph 3?
explanations:
Klimt further immortalized the tune with his monumental frieze spanning three sides of the room it occupies.  This "Ode to Joy" mural depicts humanity's desperate struggle to achieve happiness through the power of art.  In the process, the painter reveals his own tortured search for the perfect style.  As a result, the finished frieze reflects a syncretism of ancient Greek, Byzantine, early medieval, Japanese, and contemporary Viennese art, yet also gleams with the unique gold inlay that would characterize Klimt's work. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, in painting his "Ode to Joy" mural, Klimt "reveals his own tortured search for the perfect style."  Hence, his "finished frieze reflects a syncretism (mixture) of ancient Greek, Byzantine, early medieval, Japanese, and contemporary Viennese art, yet also gleams with the unique gold inlay that came to characterize Klimt's work."  Accordingly, the passage implies that Klimt's desire to find the perfect style prompted him to borrow from multiple artistic influences while incorporating his own unique stylistic flourish.  Therefore, the information in Paragraph 3 suggests that painters who are in search of a new style are more likely to be eclectic.
 By contrast, none of the following assertions is strongly suggested by the information in Paragraph 3:
Painters prior to Klimt rarely revealed the struggles required to produce their artistic works (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 3, in the process of painting his "Ode to Joy" mural, Klimt "reveals his own tortured search for the perfect style."  However, the passage never indicates whether any of the artists who preceded Klimt ever revealed the struggles of their artistic process in their works.
The works of successful painters include a distinctive identifying feature (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 points out that the Beethoven Frieze "gleams with the unique gold inlay that came to characterize Klimt's work."  However, although the passage mentions this unique feature of the work of Klimt, who was an innovative and successful painter of the Viennese Secession, it never comments on whether the works of other successful painters include a similarly distinctive identifying feature.
The most impressive paintings are those in which the painters borrow from other art forms (Choice D).  Paragraph 1 describes Klimt's frieze as "offer[ing] a visual representation of the finale to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony."  Accordingly, Klimt borrowed from another art form, namely music.  However, despite Klimt's example, the passage never generalizes to suggest that the most impressive paintings are those in which the painters borrow from other art forms.  Moreover, Paragraph 3 does not discuss painters borrowing from other art forms but focuses on the eclectic nature of Klimt's work.

text: The passage indicates that the lyrics to "Ode to Joy" derived from:
explanations:
With his Ninth Symphony, first performed in 1824, Beethoven revolutionized the symphonic genre; in particular, the final movement was the first such work to feature a chorus.  Ironically, the prima materia of that sublime finale was a drinking song, called "Ode to Joy," written by the German Romantic poet Friedrich Schiller.  As biographer Jan Swafford sums up, Beethoven "erected a movement of epic scope on a humble little tune that anyone can sing." (Paragraph 2)
In describing Beethoven's Ninth, the author notes that "the prima materia (base substance) of that sublime finale was a drinking song, called 'Ode to Joy'" (Paragraph 2).  This song was written by Friedrich Schiller, who was a German Romantic poet.  Accordingly, the passage indicates that the lyrics to "Ode to Joy" derived from a poet's work.
 (Choice A)  Beethoven's vision of the fitting words for the perfect melody.  Paragraph 2 presents Jan Swafford's view that "the Ninth embodies Beethoven's own quest for the perfect melody; it is about 'the composer composing.'"  However, although Beethoven was searching for the perfect melody, the passage never indicates that he was searching for the perfect words or lyrics to accompany that melody.  In fact, Paragraph 2 reveals that what became the finale to the Ninth "was a drinking song, called 'Ode to Joy,'" the lyrics to which were "written by the German Romantic poet Friedrich Schiller."
(Choices B and C)  folk tunes created and sung in German taverns; and an anonymous drinking song.  As Paragraph 2 points out, "[T]he prima materia of that sublime finale" that ended Beethoven's Ninth "was a drinking song, called 'Ode to Joy,' written by the German Romantic poet Friedrich Schiller."  As such, "Ode to Joy" might possibly have been sung in German taverns; however, the passage never suggests that it derived from folk tunes created in such taverns but instead stresses that it was written by Schiller.  Likewise, it was not an anonymous drinking song but one with a known author.

text: The description of Putnam's thought experiments would suggest which of the following about Twin Earth?
explanations:
In the experiment's original formulation, Putnam asks the reader to imagine Earth centuries in the past, along with a nearly identical Twin Earth. (Paragraph 1)
In this version of Twin Earth, the metal molybdenum is used instead of aluminum for pots and pans, and ordinary people cannot tell the difference between them. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 1, the Twin Earth thought experiment "asks the reader to imagine Earth…along with a nearly identical Twin Earth."  In one version of that thought experiment, Twin Earth differs from Earth because "the metal molybdenum is used instead of aluminum for pots and pans, and ordinary people cannot tell the difference between them" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, all the pots and pans that would be made of aluminum on Earth are made of molybdenum on Twin Earth.  Consequently, the description of Putnam's thought experiments would suggest that on Twin Earth, molybdenum would be as common as aluminum is on Earth.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 2 states that "the intension of the term 'water' would be the same on Earth and Twin Earth.  People on both worlds would possess the same concept of that term and embody the same mental states while using it."  Therefore, lakes and oceans would be conceived of in the same way on both Earth and Twin Earth, even though 'water' would refer to H2O in one case and XYZ in the other.
(Choice C)  According to Paragraph 4, Putnam specifies that "'the words 'aluminum' and 'molybdenum' are switched on Twin Earth: 'aluminum' is the name of molybdenum, and 'molybdenum' is the name of aluminum.'"  However, the fact that the names are "switched" in relation to Earth does not mean that people on Twin Earth would be mistaken about the names that they use.  Rather, on Twin Earth, a speaker would correctly use the name 'aluminum' to refer to the metal that on Earth would be known as 'molybdenum.'
(Choice D)  According to Paragraph 2, "the extension of 'water' on each world would actually be different, because it would apply to H2O on Earth but to XYZ on Twin Earth.  Therefore, Putnam argues that a term's meaning is constituted partially by the features of a speaker's world."  Consequently, the Twin Earth thought experiments compare speakers on Earth with those on Twin Earth, such as "an Earthling Oscar1 and his Twin Earth counterpart Oscar2" (Paragraph 5).  However, such counterparts are not like biological twins, who typically share one and the same world.  Therefore, the passage gives no reason to think that biological twins would complicate the thought experiment.

text: The passage author implies that the second version of the Twin Earth thought experiment:
explanations:
This formulation avoids the problems inherent to "twin water," as switching molybdenum and aluminum would not entail an essential physical difference between people on Earth and those on Twin Earth.  Thus this example might seem to justify Putnam's position on linguistic reference. (Paragraph 5)
However, some linguists, such as Crane, have posed an intriguing question in response to this claim.  Why not suppose that for Oscar1 and Oscar2, the extension of the word 'aluminum' is both aluminum and molybdenum?...  In that case, while 'aluminum' would indeed have the same intension on Earth and Twin-Earth, it would have the same extension as well, dissolving Putnam's argument. (Paragraph 6)
Putnam might object that only features of each man's actual world fixes the extension of 'aluminum.'  On that view, the term's meaning is not affected by the hypothetical question of how, for instance, Oscar1 would mentally classify a pan from Twin Earth.  But…  Crane's response to the Twin Earth scenario cannot be dismissed so easily. (Paragraph 7)
The second version of the thought experiment "avoids the problems inherent to" the original formulation; thus the author states that "this example might seem to justify Putnam's position on linguistic reference" (Paragraph 5).  However, the author also notes that "some linguists, such as Crane, have posed an intriguing question in response to this claim."  If that response is plausible, it would result in "dissolving Putnam's argument" (Paragraph 6).
Paragraph 7 suggests one way in which "Putnam might object" to Crane's response.  However, the author asserts that "Crane's response to the Twin Earth scenario cannot be dismissed so easily."  Accordingly, the author indicates that this response still needs to be addressed, implying that the second version of the Twin Earth thought experiment would require further argument to successfully justify Putnam's position.
By contrast, the author does not imply that the second version of the Twin Earth thought experiment:
suffers from the same problems as the original formulation of the scenario (Choice A).  In Paragraph 5, the author writes: "This [second] formulation avoids the problems inherent to 'twin water'" (ie, the first formulation of the scenario).
is decisively refuted by the response of Crane and other linguists (Choice B).  The author argues that "Crane's response to the Twin Earth scenario cannot be dismissed so easily" (Paragraph 7).  However, that assertion does not in itself mean that there is no other way to potentially defend Putnam's position.  Hence, to say that the Twin Earth thought experiment "is decisively refuted" by Crane's response would overstate the author's claim in the passage.
fails because people on Earth and Twin Earth would be psychologically dissimilar (Choice D).  Putnam argues that a man on Earth and a man on Twin Earth may have "no difference at all in their psychological states when they use the word 'aluminum'" (Paragraph 5).  However, the passage suggests that other linguists agree with this claim.  For instance, Crane accepts the idea that "[i]f either man somehow encountered a pan from the other Earth, he would call its metal 'aluminum'" (Paragraph 6), indicating that the two men's mental states would be similar in this regard.

text:
The author describes Putnam's original formulation of the Twin Earth scenario as "incoherent" because:
fictional scenarios do not tell us anything about the actual world.
people on Earth could not be physically identical to those on Twin Earth.
Putnam underestimates the role of internal mental states in linguistic reference.
explanations:
In the experiment's original formulation, Putnam asks the reader to imagine Earth centuries in the past, along with a nearly identical Twin Earth.  However, while the substance called 'water' on Twin Earth is indistinguishable from Earth water in terms of appearance, taste, boiling point, etc., it is not H2O but a different chemical compound that Putnam calls 'XYZ.' (Paragraph 1)
The most immediate objection to Putnam's argument is that the situation described is incoherent, as the human body is largely composed of water.  Although this fact means that Putnam's description of Twin Earth is literally impossible, most scholars have been oddly willing to overlook this deficiency. (Paragraph 3)
This formulation avoids the problems inherent to "twin water," as switching molybdenum and aluminum would not entail an essential physical difference between people on Earth and those on Twin Earth.  Thus this example might seem to justify Putnam's position on linguistic reference. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 1 conveys that in the original Twin Earth scenario "Putnam asks the reader to imagine Earth…along with a nearly identical Twin Earth.  However, while the substance called 'water' on Twin Earth is indistinguishable from Earth water…it is not H2O but a different chemical compound that Putnam calls 'XYZ.'"  According to Paragraph 3, "The most immediate objection to Putnam's argument is that the situation described is incoherent, as the human body is largely composed of water."  The author notes that "this fact means that Putnam's description of Twin Earth is literally impossible."
Paragraph 5 specifies that the thought experiment's second formulation "avoids the problems inherent to 'twin water,' as switching molybdenum and aluminum would not entail an essential physical difference between people on Earth and Twin Earth."  In other words, people on Earth and Twin Earth could not really be identical in the first formulation, because the bodies of the former would be composed of H2O, while the bodies of the latter would be composed of XYZ.
Consequently, the author describes Putnam's original formulation of the Twin Earth scenario as incoherent because it entails that people on Earth could not be physically identical to those on Twin Earth. (Number II)
(Number I)  The author argues that in Putnam's first formulation "the situation described is incoherent," viewing that fact as problematic even though "most scholars have been oddly willing to overlook this deficiency" (Paragraph 3).  Accordingly, the author believes there are flaws in Putnam's thought experiment.  However, he or she never objects to the fact that it involves fictional scenarios, nor argues that fictional scenarios cannot tell us about the actual world.
(Number III)  The thought experiment includes the idea that "[p]eople on both worlds would possess the same concept of that term [water] and embody the same mental states while using it (Paragraph 2).  Hence, the passage conveys that Putnam takes account of the role of internal mental states in linguistic reference; the author never suggests that Putnam has underestimated that role.  Moreover, the author argues that "the situation described is incoherent, as the human body is largely composed of water" (Paragraph 3).  Therefore, the author's objection concerns facts about the physical composition of the human body, not about internal mental states.

text: The author views the willingness of scholars to overlook the "deficiency" in Putnam's argument as:
explanations:
The most immediate objection to Putnam's argument is that the situation described is incoherent, as the human body is largely composed of water.  Although this fact means that Putnam's description of Twin Earth is literally impossible, most scholars have been oddly willing to overlook this deficiency.  For instance, Dennett deems it irrelevant, while Ebbs opines that "the difficulties it raises need not affect the point of the thought experiment." (Paragraph 3)
If for whatever reason we ignore that objection, we may at least attend to a different example, set in contemporary times. (Paragraph 4)
The author emphasizes that "Putnam's description of Twin Earth is literally impossible," but states that despite this fact "most scholars have been oddly willing to overlook this deficiency" (Paragraph 3).  Accordingly, the author suggests that the scholars' position is unexpected.  The author later continues: "If for whatever reason we ignore that objection…" suggesting puzzlement over the position taken by those scholars.  Therefore, the author views the willingness of scholars to overlook the "deficiency" in Putnam's argument as a surprising state of affairs.
(Choices A and D)  The author states that "most scholars have been oddly willing to overlook this deficiency" (Paragraph 3), implicitly questioning those scholars' position.  The author also remarks: "If for whatever reason we ignore that objection, we may at least attend to a different example" (Paragraph 4), further implying that he or she may disagree with the scholars' reasoning.  Consequently, the author is not convinced that overlooking the deficiency in Putnam's argument is a justified decision or a matter of practicality.
(Choice C)  The author objects to the fact that "most scholars have been oddly willing to overlook this deficiency."  However, he or she never suggests that those scholars have failed to comprehend the deficiency.  Rather, they are presented as simply viewing it as unimportant: "For instance, Dennett deems it irrelevant, while Ebbs opines that 'the difficulties it raises need not affect the point of the thought experiment'" (Paragraph 3).

text: Given the information in the passage, Putnam most likely set the first formulation of the Twin Earth thought experiment "centuries in the past" in order to:
explanations:
A long-standing position in linguistics is that terms with the same intensional meaning must refer to the same objects in the world.  Hilary Putnam's "Twin Earth" thought experiment challenges this view by arguing that two speakers could use a term in the same way yet refer to different entities.  In the experiment's original formulation, Putnam asks the reader to imagine Earth centuries in the past, along with a nearly identical Twin Earth.  However, while the substance called 'water' on Twin Earth is indistinguishable from Earth water in terms of appearance, taste, boiling point, etc., it is not H2O but a different chemical compound that Putnam calls 'XYZ.' (Paragraph 1)
Given this scenario, the intension of the term 'water' would be the same on Earth and Twin Earth.  People on both worlds would possess the same concept of that term and embody the same mental states while using it.  However, the extension of 'water' on each world would actually be different, because it would apply to H2O on Earth but XYZ on Twin Earth. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 1, "Hilary Putnam's 'Twin Earth' thought experiment…[argues] that two speakers could use a term in the same way yet refer to different entities."  Putnam describes a scenario in which "'water' on Twin Earth is indistinguishable from Earth water" but is nevertheless "a different chemical compound that Putnam calls 'XYZ.'"
Paragraph 2 conveys that "[p]eople on both worlds would possess the same concept of that term [water] and embody the same mental states while using it."  Nevertheless, the term 'water' would actually refer to different substances on each world, "because it would apply to H2O on Earth but XYZ on Twin Earth."  Therefore, the point of the scenario is to describe a situation in which two people had identical concepts of what a word means, yet the word did not refer to the same entity in both cases.
However, if people in the scenario knew the chemical composition of water or twin water, respectively, then they would have different conceptions of what the term 'water' means, undermining the point of the thought experiment.  Consequently, the thought experiment was most likely set centuries in the past to situate it prior to knowledge of chemistry, removing that complication.
By contrast, Putnam did not most likely set the first formulation of the Twin Earth thought experiment "centuries in the past" in order to:
reflect the longevity of the standard linguistic position (Choice B).  Paragraph 1 states that Putnam's thought experiment challenges "[a] long-standing position in linguistics."  However, the passage never suggests that Putnam's thought experiment needed to reflect the longevity of that position.
make it easier for deficiencies in his argument to be overlooked (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 describes a flaw in Putnam's original thought experiment, but notes that "most scholars have been oddly willing to overlook this deficiency."  However, the passage never suggests that Putnam was aware of the deficiency in advance yet simply hoped for it to be overlooked instead of correcting it.
allow the second version to be comparatively stronger (Choice D).  Paragraph 5 states that the second version of the thought experiment "avoids the problems inherent to 'twin water,'" implying that the second formulation is stronger than the first in this respect.  However, the author never suggests that Putnam intentionally chose the setting of the first formulation to make the second version stronger by comparison.

text: Based on Gorgias' arguments in the passage, the claim that Helen is to blame for the Trojan War:
explanations:
It instead defends the woman who, by abandoning her husband, King Menelaus of Sparta, and eloping with the Trojan prince Paris, has perennially borne the blame for instigating the Trojan War.  Thus, in advocating for her innocence, Gorgias' efforts must aim not just at absolving a wayward wife of wrongdoing, but at toppling the long-held tradition that turned a Greek matriarch into a traitor of country and consort. (Paragraph 1)
Firstly, Gorgias submits, Helen is not guilty since her departure to Troy was likely the will of the gods or the result of fate or chance—forces against which she was powerless.  Alternatively, she may have been physically coerced, in which case she stood helpless against her abductor.  It is also conceivable that the Spartan queen, enamored at the sight of the Trojan prince, was the victim of Love, a powerful deity against which she could hardly have been expected to prevail. (Paragraph 2)
A further possibility—one that Gorgias entertains at length—cites the efficacy of speech, for despite the "subtlety" of its material substance, speech is a "mighty despot."  Certainly, as Gorgias proposes, when persuasion is added to speech, it "molds the mind in the way it wishes."  Furthermore, he posits, its effect on the mind is "as irresistible as that of drugs on the body."  Therefore, the blame for Helen's seduction and consequent defection belongs not to the one persuaded, but to the persuader. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 1 conveys the traditional view of Helen as "the woman who, by abandoning her husband…and eloping with the Trojan prince Paris, has perennially borne the blame for instigating the Trojan War."  By contrast, in Paragraph 2, Gorgias claims that "Helen is not guilty since her departure to Troy was likely the will of the gods or the result of fate or chance"—or, alternatively, of physical coercion or victimization by Love—all "forces against which she was powerless."
In Paragraph 3, Gorgias "cites the efficacy (power) of speech," stating that "when persuasion is added to speech, it 'molds the mind in the way it wishes,'" producing an effect "'as irresistible as that of drugs on the body.'"  Gorgias thus concludes that "the blame for Helen's seduction and consequent defection belongs not to the one persuaded, but to the persuader."
Accordingly, in each of Gorgias' arguments, forces beyond Helen's control precipitated her departure from Greece.  However, the traditional view, namely, that Helen is to blame for the Trojan War, attaches too much importance to human agency, ignoring the role of these nonhuman forces.
 By contrast, each of the following reflects an aspect of Gorgias' defense of Helen rather than the view that she is to blame for the war:
exaggerates the power of persuasion (Choice A).  In Paragraph 3, Gorgias "cites the efficacy of speech," comparing it to a "'mighty despot.'"  He claims that "when persuasion is added to speech, it 'molds the mind in the way it wishes,'" producing an effect "'as irresistible as that of drugs on the body.'"  Consequently, Gorgias concludes, "the blame for Helen's seduction and consequent defection belongs not to the one persuaded, but to the persuader."  Therefore, blaming Helen rather than Paris actually underestimates the power of persuasion in her decision to depart.
exaggerates the role of Trojan aggression (Choice B).  According to Gorgias' argument in Paragraph 2, Helen "may have been physically coerced, in which case she stood helpless against her abductor."  This reference to the possibly coercive behavior of the Trojan prince Paris emphasizes that Trojan aggression may have factored into Helen's departure from Greece.  However, the traditional view of Helen as "abandoning her husband…and eloping with…Paris" (Paragraph 1), and thus as responsible for the war, denies the role of Trojan aggression in the incident.
attaches too much importance to divine agency (Choice C).  Gorgias claims that "Helen is not guilty since her departure to Troy was likely the will of the gods or a result of fate or chance—forces against which she was powerless."  He also proposes that "enamored" by Paris, she became "the victim of Love, a powerful deity against which she could hardly have been expected to prevail" (Paragraph 2).  Consequently, Gorgias attaches great importance to the role of divine agency in Helen's desertion, whereas the traditional view, by blaming her, attaches more importance to human agency.

text: Many other Greek writers have offered their own narratives about Helen of Troy.  Which of the following accounts is most in accord with Gorgias' arguments in Paragraph 2?
explanations:
In support of the much-maligned matron, the ancient rhetorician marshals a series of arguments that while following the laws of logic, seem more fanciful than probable.  Firstly, Gorgias submits, Helen is not guilty since her departure to Troy was likely the will of the gods or the result of fate or chance—forces against which she was powerless.  Alternatively, she may have been physically coerced, in which case she stood helpless against her abductor.  It is also conceivable that the Spartan queen, enamored at the sight of the Trojan prince, was the victim of Love, a powerful deity against which she could hardly have been expected to prevail. (Paragraph 2)
In Paragraph 2, Gorgias argues that "Helen is not guilty since her departure to Troy was likely the will of the gods or the result of fate or chance—forces against which she was powerless."  He then goes on to propose that she "may have been physically coerced," before relating that "[i]t is also conceivable that the Spartan queen, enamored at the sight of the Trojan prince, was the victim of Love, a powerful deity against which she could hardly have been expected to prevail."  This argument would most closely correspond with the account from Euripides' Trojan Women that Paris and Helen's love affair represented the fulfillment of a curse by Aphrodite.  Accordingly, Helen's elopement with Paris would not have been her fault, but the fault of the goddess who is often represented as the deity of love.
 By contrast, the following accounts, because they attribute more agency to Helen, are less in accord with Gorgias' arguments:
