Homer's Odyssey:  Helen claimed that although she was a Trojan captive, she bravely risked helping the Greeks during the war (Choice A). In Paragraph 2, Gorgias argues that Helen is innocent because the gods, fate, chance, physical force, love, or language—"forces against which she was powerless"—compelled her departure to Troy.  Accordingly, Gorgias portrays Helen as a mere victim of external forces without suggesting that she deserves credit for trying to help the Greeks during the war.
Isocrates' Speech in Praise of Helen:  Helen heroically embraced her designated fate as the daughter of the god Zeus (Choice C). In Paragraph 2, Gorgias claims that "Helen is not guilty since her departure to Troy was likely the will of the gods or the result of fate or chance—forces against which she was powerless."  Accordingly, Gorgias portrays Helen as a helpless victim of her fate rather than as a semi-divine martyr accepting of her fate.
Stesichorus' Palinode:  Helen was escorted to Egypt to avoid abduction but was still blamed for the war because a look-alike was sent to Troy in her place (Choice D).  In Paragraph 2, Gorgias argues that Helen "may have been physically coerced, in which case she stood helpless against her abductor."  Accordingly, Gorgias portrays Helen as the victim of her abductor and so not to blame for starting the war.  He does not offer an alibi to the effect that she was never abducted or never went to Troy.

text: Gorgias seems to undermine his own purpose in the Encomium by doing which of the following?
explanations:
Thus, in advocating for her innocence, Gorgias' efforts must aim not just at absolving a wayward wife of wrongdoing, but at toppling the long-held tradition that turned a Greek matriarch into a traitor of country and consort. (Paragraph 1)
Gorgias' systematic defense culminates in a complicated quod erat demonstrandum.  The orator proclaims that by revealing the truth he has not only countered ignorance but exonerated Helen from blame, thus freeing her from ignominy.  However, the Encomium now threatens to tarnish its own reputation.  In a final self-referential and self-contradictory twist, perhaps designed to cast doubt on authorial intent, the sophist discloses: "I have composed this speech to praise Helen—and as an amusement for myself." (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 1 states that "in advocating for her innocence, Gorgias' efforts…aim…at absolving a wayward wife of wrongdoing…[and] toppling the long-held tradition."  In Paragraph 5, Gorgias "proclaims that by revealing the truth he has not only countered ignorance but exonerated (unburdened) Helen from blame, thus freeing her from ignominy (public disgrace)."  However, Paragraph 5 also conveys that "[i]n a final self-referential and self-contradictory twist, perhaps designed to cast doubt on authorial intent, the sophist discloses: 'I have composed this speech to praise Helen—and as an amusement for myself.'"
Accordingly, Gorgias claims that he has achieved his aim of absolving Helen; he also suggests that he may have composed this speech to amuse himself, thus seeming to trivialize it.  Therefore, by teasing his audience that he might not be serious, after claiming to have spoken the truth, Gorgias could be seen to undermine his own purpose in the Encomium.
 By contrast, Gorgias does not seem to undermine his own purpose in the Encomium by:
maintaining faith in language's power, after revealing its seemingly deceptive nature (Choice A).  Gorgias compares speech to a "'mighty despot'" and says that "when persuasion is added to speech, it 'molds the mind in the way it wishes,'" producing an effect "'as irresistible as that of drugs on the body'" (Paragraph 3).  Gorgias thus "transfers the culpability (blame) for Helen's desertion…onto [Paris'] words and onto the whole of language as an overpowering and potentially deceptive force."  Accordingly, speech's potentially deceptive effect on the listener is a form of persuasion and illustrates language's power.  Hence, language's claim to power is not incompatible with a potentially deceptive nature.
deliberately employing a sophistic strategy, after acknowledging its questionable reputation (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 1, "defending the infamous Helen amounts to defending the indefensible."  Furthermore, "[b]y undertaking this task, Gorgias risks incurring the accusation frequently hurled by conservative thinkers at the…sophists…of contriving (engineering) to make the weaker argument the stronger."  However, regardless of whether Gorgias was consciously employing this sophistic strategy, the passage never suggests that he acknowledged its questionable reputation.
composing a complicated defense of his subject, after suggesting he would praise her (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 1, "[d]espite advertising itself as an 'encomium,' or speech in praise of an individual, the text does not proceed to laud its subject…Helen of Troy.  It instead defends the woman who…has perennially borne the blame for instigating the Trojan War."  This information suggests that, although titled an "encomium," as if meant to praise Helen, the speech functions more properly as a defense.  However, in Paragraph 5, Gorgias concludes that he composed the speech (in part) "to praise Helen."  Gorgias further observes that he has accomplished his purpose, namely to "exonerate…Helen from blame [and] free…her from ignominy" by telling the truth.  Accordingly, the passage shows that composing a speech in Helen's defense is complicated because in order to defend her, Gorgias must redeem her reputation or, in effect, praise her.

text: What does the discussion of Gorgias' style in Paragraph 4 suggest about the way his rhetoric functions?
explanations:
It is noteworthy, though typical of Gorgias, that he uses his innovative and elaborate style to reflect the substance of the Encomium with all its paradoxes.  His distinctively paradoxical style mixes poetry with prose, overflows with rhetorical figures, and juxtaposes contrasting terms.  The results are often spellbinding—indeed, the most ornate examples of Gorgianic oratory have been likened to magical incantations but also subject to unfair attacks from imperceptive critics denouncing them as "a plethora of words and a paucity of ideas." (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, "It is noteworthy, though typical of Gorgias, that he uses his innovative and elaborate style to reflect the substance of the Encomium with all its paradoxes."  As Paragraph 4 describes, "[h]is distinctively paradoxical style mixes poetry with prose, overflows with rhetorical figures, and juxtaposes contrasting terms."
This information indicates that Gorgias' "distinctively paradoxical style" mirrors the substance or content of his works, such as the Encomium, which are likewise typically paradoxical or ironic in character.  Therefore, the discussion of Gorgias' style in Paragraph 4 suggests that his rhetoric functions so that Gorgianic style and content often reinforce one another.
 (Choice A)  Gorgianic style is excessive verbiage without substance.  According to Paragraph 4, Gorgias' style is "often spellbinding" and some of his more elaborate speeches have been "likened to magical incantations."  As a result, his works have been "subject to unfair attacks from imperceptive critics denouncing them as 'a plethora (overabundance) of words and a paucity (scarcity) of ideas.'"  Accordingly, this information implies that such types of criticisms can be dismissed as largely illegitimate.  Therefore, the discussion of Gorgias' style in Paragraph 4 suggests that his rhetoric has actual substance and is not just a lot of empty words.
(Choice B)  Gorgianic style was developed specifically to defend the indefensible.  According to Paragraph 1, "defending the infamous Helen amounts to defending the indefensible."  Paragraph 4 then states, "It is…typical of Gorgias, that he uses his innovative and elaborate style to reflect the substance of the Encomium with all its paradoxes.  That distinctively paradoxical style mixes poetry with prose, overflows with rhetorical figures, and juxtaposes contrasting terms."  Consequently, Gorgias' paradoxical style tends to mirror the likewise ironic or paradoxical content of his speeches.  However, the passage never suggests that Gorgianic style was developed specifically to accomplish the essentially paradoxical rhetorical task of defending the indefensible.
(Choice D)  Gorgianic style frequently sabotages the ideas in a speech.  Paragraph 4 describes Gorgias' style as "innovative and elaborate" as well as "distinctively paradoxical," mixing "poetry with prose" and featuring "rhetorical figures" and "contrasting terms."  Furthermore, Paragraph 4 then conveys that the style is "spellbinding" and "the most ornate examples…have been likened to magical incantations but also subject to unfair attacks from imperceptive critics denouncing them as 'a plethora of words and a paucity of ideas.'"  This evidence suggests that Gorgias' unique style can produce texts with a disproportionately greater quantity of words compared to the quantity of ideas.  However, such a scenario indicates only that the words might overwhelm or somehow distract from the ideas in a speech, not that Gorgianic style would actually sabotage (deliberately destroy) these ideas.

text: Which of the following assertions best exemplifies Gorgias' conception of language as it is presented in Paragraph 3?
explanations:
A further possibility—one that Gorgias entertains at length—cites the efficacy of speech, for despite the "subtlety" of its material substance, speech is a "mighty despot."  Certainly, as Gorgias proposes, when persuasion is added to speech, it "molds the mind in the way it wishes."  Furthermore, he posits, its effect on the mind is "as irresistible as that of drugs on the body."  Therefore, the blame for Helen's seduction and consequent defection belongs not to the one persuaded, but to the persuader.  With this startling refutation, the sophist transfers the culpability for Helen's desertion not just onto the Trojan Paris as her seducer, but onto his words and onto the whole of language as an overpowering and potentially deceptive force. (Paragraph 3)
In Paragraph 3, Gorgias "cites the efficacy (power) of speech," comparing it to a "'mighty despot.'"  He states that "when persuasion is added to speech, it 'molds the mind in the way it wishes,'" producing an effect "'as irresistible as that of drugs on the body.'"  Gorgias then concludes that "the blame for Helen's seduction…belongs not to the one persuaded, but to the persuader," and quite possibly belongs even to "the whole of language as an overpowering and potentially deceptive force."
Accordingly, language, as irresistibly persuasive and potentially deceptive, has the power to affect the listener's mind.  It follows that a speaker can use language to persuade the listener to let go of one point of view and adopt another.  Consequently, Gorgias' conception of language as presented in Paragraph 3 is best exemplified by the assertion that speech is a means of realigning the listener's perspective.
 (Choice A)  Speech is a means of conveying the speaker's thoughts objectively.  In Paragraph 3, Gorgias claims that "when persuasion is added to speech, it 'molds the mind in the way it wishes,'" producing an effect "'as irresistible as that of drugs on the body.'"  Gorgias also states that language can be "an overpowering and potentially deceptive force."  Given these qualities, speech as portrayed by Gorgias is not exclusively or primarily a means of communicating thoughts in an unbiased or objective manner.
(Choices C and D)  Speech is a means of guiding the listener down a wrong path; and Speech is a means of convincing the listener of the truth.  In Paragraph 3, Gorgias claims that "when persuasion is added to speech, it 'molds the mind in the way it wishes,'" producing an effect "'as irresistible as that of drugs on the body.'"  Furthermore, Gorgias describes "the whole of language as an overpowering and potentially deceptive force."  Accordingly, Gorgias' conception of language emphasizes speech's overwhelming power to persuade and potentially deceive.  However, this conception does not imply that speech's persuasive power is solely or primarily used either to mislead the listener or to compel the listener to believe the truth.

text: Suppose an art student plans to analyze a painting classified as part of the Impressionist movement.  The passage author would most likely recommend that:
explanations:
The danger of this state of affairs is the prospect that works of art will be fitted to theories instead of theories being fitted to works of art.  While theory cannot be abandoned, it must follow criticism rather than lead it.  Otherwise, both beginning students and established art historians may find their analyses guided toward conclusions that are more or less pre-ordained, like detectives who begin an investigation with a suspect already in mind.  An artwork's style and features must be discovered from the bottom up, letting the work speak to us on its own terms and reducing the chance that important evidence is misconstrued or overlooked. (Paragraph 3)
Even apart from such concerns, it is beneficial overall for works to be studied free of theoretical constraints.  This is not because established theory is necessarily wrong, but because doing so allows critical insights to develop organically. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 3 discusses the "danger…that works of art will be fitted to theories instead of theories being fitted to works of art."  The author warns that if theory is too influential when studying an artwork, scholars "may find their analyses guided toward conclusions that are more or less pre-ordained (determined in advance), like detectives who begin an investigation with a suspect already in mind."  Accordingly, the author asserts that "[a]n artwork's style and features must be discovered from the bottom up, letting the work speak to us on its own terms."
The author further emphasizes this point in Paragraph 5, stating that "it is beneficial overall for works to be studied free of theoretical constraints…because doing so allows critical insights to develop organically."  Thus he or she argues that art must be studied in itself, without letting existing theory about a work influence its analysis.
Consequently, if an art student plans to analyze a painting classified as part of the Impressionist movement, the passage author would most likely recommend that the analysis should proceed without considering the typical features of Impressionism.
 (Choice A)  the analysis should employ methodology similar to that of a detective investigating a case.  The author argues that "theory…must follow criticism rather than lead it," because otherwise analyses of art may be "guided toward conclusions that are more or less pre-ordained, like detectives who begin an investigation with a suspect already in mind."  Therefore, a comparison to detectives is made to illustrate one of the author's points.  However, the author does not suggest that art analysis should employ methodology similar to that of a detective investigating a case.
(Choices B and D)  the analysis should incorporate information about the most characteristic features of Impressionist paintings; and the analysis should take into account facts about the particular Impressionist who created the painting.  The author warns about "the prospect that works of art will be fitted to theories instead of theories being fitted to works of art," asserting that "theory…must follow criticism rather than lead it" (Paragraph 3).  By contrast, allowing an analysis to incorporate information about the most characteristic features of Impressionist paintings or facts about a particular Impressionist painter would constitute the opposite practice, with theory leading criticism.  Consequently, the passage author would not recommend either of these approaches.

text:
The problems in art scholarship addressed by Youngna Kim relate to which of the following issues?
I.  Non-academic agendas
II.  Inadequate funding for research
III.  Inequities between fields of study
explanations:
For instance, a regrettably long-standing assumption in Asian art studies was that Korean artworks were dependent upon outside cultural influences from China or Japan.  In some cases, this belief was the result of honest mistakes, albeit ones that more attentive research might have avoided.  As Youngna Kim stresses, however, we must not ignore the perceived value of that assumption to those wishing to justify Korea's former status as an occupied nation.  In the years since Korea gained independence in 1945, the original, non-derivative insights of Korean art have begun to be recognized.  Still, Kim points out that as recently as 1994, the fifth edition of A History of Far Eastern Art included "only 17 Korean artworks, compared with about 240 from Japan."  Although progress continues to be made, challenges to establishing Korean art as a more comparably sized discipline remain. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, "a regrettably long-standing assumption in Asian art studies was that Korean artworks were dependent upon outside cultural influences from China or Japan."  Although the author states that "[i]n some cases, this belief was the result of honest mistakes," he or she also cites Youngna Kim's point about "the perceived value of that assumption to those wishing to justify Korea's former status as an occupied nation."  Therefore, the passage indicates that this problematic assumption resulted partially from a non-academic agenda (ie, a political one) (Number I).
Paragraph 4 states that "[i]n the years since Korea gained independence in 1945, the original, non-derivative insights of Korean art have begun to be recognized."  However, this recognition has proceeded slowly, as "Kim points out that as recently as 1994, the fifth edition of A History of Far Eastern Art included 'only 17 Korean artworks, compared with about 240 from Japan.'"  Accordingly, the passage states that "challenges to establishing Korean art as a more comparably sized discipline remain."  Therefore, the problems addressed by Youngna Kim relate in part to inequities between fields of study, specifically inequities between Korean art and art originating in other parts of Asia (Number III).
  (Number II)  Inadequate funding for research.  Paragraph 4 discusses the "regrettably long-standing assumption…that Korean artworks were dependent upon outside cultural influences from China or Japan."  According to the author, "[i]n some cases, this belief was the result of honest mistakes, albeit ones that more attentive research might have avoided."  Therefore, the author criticizes the quality of research performed in relation to this assumption.  However, he or she never connects this criticism to lack of funding, nor discusses the funding provided for art history research in Korea.  Consequently, the passage does not suggest that the problems in art scholarship addressed by Youngna Kim relate to inadequate funding for research.

text: Given the information in the passage, the author's intended audience is most likely:
explanations:
The overemphasis on theory in art scholarship is lampooned in the 1997 film Bean.  In an early exchange between its principal characters… (Paragraph 1)
Although the purpose of the movie scene is simply comedic effect, Joan Holladay has made a similar point quite seriously about her work collaborating on Gothic Sculpture in America.  Reflecting on this experience, she writes: "One of the more sobering lessons was that we may not be training our students very well at old-fashioned looking.  With the increasing interest in theory, connoisseurship has fallen by the wayside; one younger colleague had considerable trouble finding appropriate stylistic comparisons, while another noted, 'I think I'm not very good at this.'" (Paragraph 2)
While theory cannot be abandoned, it must follow criticism rather than lead it.  Otherwise, both beginning students and established art historians may find their analyses guided toward conclusions that are more or less pre-ordained, like detectives who begin an investigation with a suspect already in mind.  An artwork's style and features must be discovered from the bottom up, letting the work speak to us on its own terms and reducing the chance that important evidence is misconstrued or overlooked. (Paragraph 3)
The author is concerned about "[t]he overemphasis on theory in art scholarship" (Paragraph 1), citing Joan Holladay's observation that "'we may not be training our students very well at old-fashioned looking.  With the increasing interest in theory, connoisseurship (critical familiarity or expertise) has fallen by the wayside'" (Paragraph 2).  Thus, the passage alludes to the way students are trained in art history.
Similarly, Paragraph 3 states that "theory…must follow criticism rather than lead it.  Otherwise, both beginning students and established art historians may find their analyses guided toward conclusions that are more or less pre-ordained (determined in advance)."  The author then recommends that "[a]n artwork's style and features must be discovered from the bottom up, letting the work speak to us on its own terms."  As such, the passage also refers to the way works of art are analyzed.
Therefore, as the passage seems directed toward readers involved with both analyzing art and training students, the author's intended audience is most likely professors of art history at universities.
  (Choice B)  administrators of art museums.  The passage discusses issues related to "[t]he overemphasis on theory in art scholarship" (Paragraph 1), such as how "analyses [are] guided toward conclusions" (Paragraph 3) and allowing works of art "to be studied free of theoretical constraints" (Paragraph 5).  However, although works of art are often displayed in museums, the passage never discusses issues related to how those museums are administrated.
(Choice C)  students taking classes in art history.  Paragraph 2 cites Joan Holladay's observation that "we may not be training our students very well at old-fashioned looking.  With the increasing interest in theory, connoisseurship has fallen by the wayside.'"  This statement suggests that the way art history students are trained might need to be adjusted in order to provide them with greater skills.  Accordingly, the author's intended audience is more likely to be those who teach classes in art history, rather than the students taking those classes.
(Choice D)  researchers working in the field of Korean art.  In Paragraph 4, the author discusses the "regrettably long-standing assumption in Asian art studies…that Korean artworks were dependent upon outside cultural influences from China or Japan."  However, the passage also refers to "Joan Holladay['s]…work collaborating on Gothic Sculpture in America" (Paragraph 2) and "James McNeill Whistler's Portrait of the Artist's Mother" (Paragraph 5), suggesting that Korean art is one example in support of a larger theme.  Therefore, the author's intended audience is most likely broader than just researchers working in the field of Korean art.

text: Based on the discussion of Korean art in Paragraph 4, with which of the following assertions would Youngna Kim most likely agree?
explanations:
As Youngna Kim stresses, however, we must not ignore the perceived value of that assumption to those wishing to justify Korea's former status as an occupied nation.  In the years since Korea gained independence in 1945, the original, non-derivative insights of Korean art have begun to be recognized.  Still, Kim points out that as recently as 1994, the fifth edition of A History of Far Eastern Art included "only 17 Korean artworks, compared with about 240 from Japan."  Although progress continues to be made, challenges to establishing Korean art as a more comparably sized discipline remain. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 states that "[i]n the years since Korea gained independence in 1945, the original, non-derivative insights of Korean art have begun to be recognized."  However, Youngna Kim indicates that this recognition has come slowly, noting that "as recently as 1994, the fifth edition of A History of Far Eastern Art included 'only 17 Korean artworks, compared with about 240 from Japan.'"  Accordingly, the passage relates that "although progress continues to be made, challenges to establishing Korean art as a more comparably sized discipline remain."
Therefore, although scholarship in Korean art has evolved since 1945, Youngna Kim would most likely agree that Korean art faces significant obstacles despite the country having gained independence in 1945.
  By contrast, Youngna Kim would not most likely agree that:
Most Korean artworks have been accidentally misattributed to outside cultural influences (Choice A).  Paragraph 4 discusses the "regrettably long-standing assumption…that Korean artworks were dependent upon outside cultural influences from China or Japan."  In response to this claim, "Youngna Kim stresses [that] we must not ignore the perceived value of that assumption to those wishing to justify Korea's former status as an occupied nation."  Therefore, Kim does not suggest that most Korean artworks have been accidentally misattributed to outside cultural influences.  Rather, she implies that such misattributions were made intentionally due to political motives.
A History of Far Eastern Art included fewer Korean examples in 1994 than in previous years (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 4, "[i]n the years since Korea gained independence in 1945, the original, non-derivative insights of Korean art have begun to be recognized.  Still, Kim points out that as recently as 1994, the fifth edition of A History of Far Eastern Art included 'only 17 Korean artworks, compared with about 240 from Japan.'"  Therefore, passage information suggests that representation of Korean art has gradually increased since 1945, although this increase has come at a slow pace.
The original insights of Korean art have increased in number since 1945 (Choice C).  Paragraph 4 states that "[i]n the years since Korea gained independence in 1945, the original, non-derivative insights of Korean art have begun to be recognized."  Therefore, the passage does not suggest that Korean art itself changed after 1945; rather, it suggests that art scholarship has changed in more frequently recognizing the original insights of Korean art.

text: Based on the passage, the "bottom up" approach to analyzing artwork described in Paragraph 3 would primarily involve which of the following?
explanations:
The danger of this state of affairs is the prospect that works of art will be fitted to theories instead of theories being fitted to works of art.  While theory cannot be abandoned, it must follow criticism rather than lead it.  Otherwise, both beginning students and established art historians may find their analyses guided toward conclusions that are more or less pre-ordained, like detectives who begin an investigation with a suspect already in mind.  An artwork's style and features must be discovered from the bottom up, letting the work speak to us on its own terms and reducing the chance that important evidence is misconstrued or overlooked. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 discusses the danger "that works of art will be fitted to theories instead of theories being fitted to works of art."  The author warns that in such cases, "both beginning students and established art historians may find their analyses guided toward conclusions that are more or less pre-ordained (determined in advance)."  In other words, the author argues that if art theory guides the study of a particular work of art, then conclusions about that artwork may be biased by pre-existing ideas and not accurately reflect the features of the artwork itself.
Consequently, the author's assertion in Paragraph 3 that "[a]n artwork's style and features must be discovered from the bottom up, letting the work speak to us on its own terms" would most likely involve ignoring prior research in the artwork's genre as initially irrelevant.
  By contrast, that "bottom up" approach to analyzing artwork would not primarily involve:
Accepting the insights only of scholars proven to be credible (Choice A).  The author warns about the possibility that "both beginning students and established art historians may find their analyses guided toward conclusions that are more or less pre-ordained" (Paragraph 3).  Accepting the insights of other scholars could guide analysis in the way the author argues against, and the author never makes a distinction regarding whether a scholar is credible.  Consequently, this approach would not be part of the author's "bottom up" analysis.
Undermining existing theory about the work in question (Choice B).  Paragraph 5 states that artworks should be "studied free of theoretical constraints…not because established theory is necessarily wrong, but because doing so allows critical insights to develop organically."  Therefore, the author's goal is not to undermine existing theory, but to prevent it from unduly influencing art scholarship.
Exposing the political agenda motivating previous analyses (Choice C).  Paragraph 4 states that the author's approach to art analysis "helps to mitigate (lessen) the risks of misclassification or critical complacency (unreflective acceptance), as well as the related issue of scholarship's contamination by political interests."  Paragraph 5 then states: "Even apart from such concerns, it is beneficial overall for works to be studied free of theoretical constraints."  Accordingly, although the author's approach might expose political agendas in some cases, that is just one aspect of its general purpose of preventing theory from overly influencing analysis.

text: Which of the following most aptly describes Robinson's perspective on the use of semicolons (Paragraph 1)?
explanations:
Although the semicolon frequently substitutes for a conjoining word—for example, "and" or "but"—unlike those terms, it fails to elucidate the nature of the relationship between the information conveyed on either side of it.  Thus, as writer Paul Robinson points out, the semicolon creates a dubious linkage he suspects may "gloss over imprecise thought."  Robinson also impugns the hybridized mark as likely superfluous, implying that nearly half of all semicolons might be replaced with periods while for more than a quarter, the comma would suffice. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 leads into writer Paul Robinson's view on the semicolon with a general description of how the mark functions, noting that "[a]lthough the semicolon frequently substitutes for a conjoining word—for example, 'and' or 'but'—unlike such terms, it fails to elucidate (make clear) the nature of the relationship between the information conveyed on either side of it."  This description is similar to Robinson's perspective that a semicolon "creates a dubious linkage he suspects may 'gloss over (conceal or disguise) imprecise thought.'"  Thus, Robinson views semicolons as connecting ideas in a sentence in ways that tend to be uncertain or vague.  Therefore, the statement that semicolons promote the loose correlation of ideas most aptly describes Robinson's perspective on the use of semicolons.
 (Choice A)  Semicolons merely separate independent clauses.  According to Paragraph 1, "Although the semicolon frequently substitutes for a conjoining word—for example, 'and' or 'but'—unlike such terms, it fails to elucidate the nature of the relationship between the information conveyed on either side of it."  In a similar vein, Paragraph 1 presents Robinson's view of semicolons as creating "dubious linkage[s]" between clauses that he suspects may "gloss over imprecise thought."  This view emphasizes the possibility that semicolons can be used as much to link as to separate.  Furthermore, such a perspective communicates the suspicion that semicolons conceal a lack of clarity or specificity.  Consequently, Robinson's perspective is more nuanced than the idea that semicolons merely separate independent clauses.
(Choice C)  Semicolons help convey the author's specific meaning.  Paragraph 1 reveals how, in Robinson's view, "the semicolon creates a dubious linkage he suspects may 'gloss over imprecise thought.'"  Accordingly, Robinson believes semicolons tend to disguise a lack of precision in thought that leaves the author's meaning vague or general.  In Robinson's perspective, then, semicolons do not help convey the author's specific meaning.
(Choice D)  Semicolons serve a function distinct from that of other marks.  As Paragraph 1 claims, Robinson has attacked the semicolon "as likely superfluous," suggesting that "nearly half of all semicolons might be replaced with periods," and that for many of the rest, "the comma would suffice."  Therefore, Robinson's perspective is that semicolons frequently do not serve a function distinct from that of other marks of punctuation.

text: The main point of Paragraph 3 is best described by which of the following?
explanations:
For all its purported deficiencies and disadvantages, the semicolon came to boast sundry useful functions.  Perhaps the most indisputable is the ability to effectively organize items in a sentence otherwise cluttered with too many commas.  As a versatile mark of myriad possibilities, the semicolon was enthusiastically embraced by the likes of George Bernard Shaw and Virginia Woolf; the latter used them idiosyncratically to stitch disparate grammatical structures into paragraph-long sentences.  In Truss' opinion, employing a semicolon represents one of the highest compliments a writer can pay her readership, as if to say that the perspicacious reader is eminently capable of deciphering authorial innuendo.  More subtle than a period, more substantive than a comma, the semicolon breeds nuance, hinting at hermeneutical depths. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 discusses some different possible uses for the semicolon, emphasizing how "[f]or all its purported (supposed) deficiencies and disadvantages, the semicolon came to boast sundry (several or various) useful functions"; one of these is "to effectively organize items in a sentence otherwise cluttered with too many commas."
In addition, the semicolon is described as "versatile" and said to offer "myriad (countless) possibilities" that "were enthusiastically embraced" by some well-known writers.  For example, Virginia Woolf "used them idiosyncratically to stitch disparate (different) grammatical structures into paragraph-long sentences."  Finally, the author relays Lynne Truss' opinion that "employing a semicolon represents one of the highest compliments a writer can pay her readership."
Accordingly, Paragraph 3 suggests that the semicolon has many functions and describes three distinct purposes for which authors might use it.  Therefore, the statement that authors have adapted the use of semicolons for a variety of purposes best describes the main point of Paragraph 3.
 By contrast, each of the following statements describes just one facet of Paragraph 3's main point:
An author might use a semicolon as a way to pay the reader a compliment (Choice A).  Paragraph 3 presents Truss' view that "employing a semicolon represents one of the highest compliments a writer can pay her readership, as if to say that the perspicacious (astute) reader is eminently capable of deciphering authorial innuendo (ie, suggestion or hint from the author)."  However, Paragraph 3 does highlight other uses for semicolons, such as organizing long sentences or serving an author's idiosyncratic writing style.
Semicolons may be problematic, but they can regulate other punctuation marks (Choice B).  Paragraph 3 emphasizes that while the semicolon has "purported deficiencies and disadvantages," it eventually "came to boast sundry useful functions," the most indisputable being its "ability to effectively organize items in a sentence otherwise cluttered with too many commas."  However, as the passage indicates, authors can also use semicolons idiosyncratically or even, according to Truss, to pay the reader a compliment.
Some authors are notable for their idiosyncratic use of semicolons (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 3, "the likes of George Bernard Shaw and Virginia Woolf" were eager to make use of the seemingly versatile new semicolon.  Woolf in particular "used [semicolons] idiosyncratically to stitch disparate grammatical structures into paragraph-long sentences."  However, Paragraph 3 also stresses that semicolons have an "indisputable" function, namely, "to effectively organize items in a sentence otherwise cluttered with too many commas."  In addition, the author conveys Truss' view that "employing a semicolon represents one of the highest compliments a writer can pay her readership."

text: What does the passage author imply in the last paragraph about Italian printer Aldus Manutius?
explanations:
With Manutius—who also introduced the italic font and gave the comma its distinctive contours—punctuation came of age, moving from a matter of the author's discretion to a matter of rules as society progressed from oral recitation to silent reading.  Thus, rather than a servant of prosody, merely marking pauses like musical notation, punctuation became the handmaid of syntax, purveying sense along with style. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 details how Manutius not only invented the semicolon but made other contributions to punctuation—for example, he "introduced the italic font and gave the comma its distinctive contours."  By referring to the contours of the comma which give the mark its shape as "distinctive," the author indicates that those contours are still recognizable and characteristic of the comma's form today, more than five hundred years later.  Consequently, in the last paragraph, the passage author implies that Aldus Manutius transformed the shape of the comma into a version that proved enduring.
 (Choice A)  He suggested typographical innovations that others found hard to embrace.  Paragraph 4 relays Cecilia Watson's account of the reception of Manutius' newly invented semicolon: "[N]o sooner had the ink dried on its premier instantiation (representation) than the mark began to proliferate (multiply rapidly)."  Accordingly, the passage indicates that once Manutius introduced it, the typographical innovation of the semicolon was quickly embraced by others.
(Choices B and D)  He undervalued traditional punctuation marks like the colon; and He invented a new punctuation mark, rendering older marks obsolete.  As Paragraph 4 relays, "Aldus Manutius…first contrived (engineered) to wed the comma with the colon to invent the semicolon in 1494."  However, while Manutius did invent a new punctuation mark, the semicolon, the passage never indicates that he was motivated to do so because he placed less value on traditional punctuation marks, such as the colon, than other printers did, or even that he favored this new mark over the older ones.  The passage also never suggests that by introducing the semicolon, Manutius caused any existing punctuation marks, such as colons and commas, to become obsolete.

text: Cecelia Watson describes the fifteenth-century literati as "testing-out and tinkering-with" punctuation (Paragraph 4).  Based on this information, it can most reasonably be assumed that Manutius' predecessors:
explanations:
It was Italian humanist and printer extraordinaire Aldus Manutius who first contrived to wed the comma with the colon to invent the semicolon in 1494.  This feat capped what Cecelia Watson has characterized as a time "of writerly experimentation and invention"—a time "when there were no punctuation rules," only a protracted "testing-out and tinkering-with of punctuation by the fifteenth-century literati" as they struggled to communicate the subtleties of their ideas and express their voices in print….  With Manutius—who also introduced the italic font and gave the comma its distinctive contours—punctuation came of age, moving from a matter of the author's discretion to a matter of rules as society progressed from oral recitation to silent reading. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, punctuation took a long time to evolve and become standardized.  In particular, Cecelia Watson represents the period before Aldus Manutius invented the semicolon as a "time 'of writerly experimentation and invention…when there were no punctuation rules.'"  Instead, there was what Watson calls "a protracted 'testing-out and tinkering-with of punctuation by the fifteenth-century literati (ie, educated people interested in art and literature)' as they struggled to communicate the subtleties of their ideas and express their voices in print."  However, after Manutius—who also introduced italics and shaped the comma—"punctuation came of age, moving from a matter of the author's discretion to a matter of rules."
In relaying Watson's claim that Manutius' predecessors had been "testing-out and tinkering-with" punctuation, the passage indicates that these individuals had been experimenting with different ways to use punctuation more effectively.  As Paragraph 4 also notes, rather than establishing rules for usage, these predecessors would often leave punctuation decisions up to individual writers who were trying out different uses.  Therefore, Watson's claim that the fifteenth-century literati were "'testing-out and tinkering-with'" (Paragraph 4) punctuation most likely means that Manutius' predecessors had not fully determined some of the functions of punctuation.
 By contrast, based on Watson's description of the fifteenth-century literati as "'testing-out and tinkering-with'" punctuation (Paragraph 4), it would not be most reasonable to assume that Manutius' predecessors:
had not desired to convey the nuances of sense and style (Choice A).  In her description, Watson specifies how these literati "struggled to communicate the subtleties of their ideas and express their voices in print."  Consequently, it is likely that the predecessors of Manutius did desire to convey the nuances of sense and style.  Furthermore, the fact that these struggles came to an end when Manutius' standardized punctuation—which allowed it to become "the handmaid of syntax, purveying (providing) sense along with style"—would reinforce such a conclusion.
had not considered punctuation to be an important matter (Choice B).  Watson's description of a "protracted" period of "testing-out and tinkering-with" reveals that Manutius' predecessors expended considerable effort in experimenting with punctuation.  Such effort would indicate that these predecessors most likely considered punctuation an important matter.
had not been concerned with innovation in punctuation (Choice D).   Before noting the "protracted" struggle with punctuation carried out by the "literati" of the fifteenth century, Watson characterizes the time period as one "of writerly experimentation and invention."  This characterization stresses that at least some of Manutius' predecessors were trying out different ways to use punctuation and possibly inventing new marks, thereby revealing a concern with innovation.

text: What function is performed in the passage by Truss' claim that employing a semicolon can represent a compliment from the author to the reader (Paragraph 3)?
explanations:
For all its purported deficiencies and disadvantages, the semicolon came to boast sundry useful functions.  Perhaps the most indisputable of these is the ability to effectively organize items in a sentence otherwise cluttered with too many commas.  As a versatile mark of myriad possibilities, the semicolon was enthusiastically embraced by the likes of George Bernard Shaw and Virginia Woolf; the latter used them idiosyncratically to stitch disparate grammatical structures into paragraph-long sentences.  In Truss' opinion, employing a semicolon represents one of the highest compliments a writer can pay her readership, as if to say that the perspicacious reader is eminently capable of deciphering authorial innuendo.  More subtle than a period, more substantive than a comma, the semicolon breeds nuance, hinting at hermeneutical depths. (Paragraph 3)
After referencing the "purported (supposed) deficiencies and disadvantages" of semicolon use, Paragraph 3 introduces some of the mark's potential advantages, or "sundry (various) useful functions."  These functions notably include "the ability to effectively organize items in a sentence otherwise cluttered with too many commas" and the ability "to stitch disparate grammatical structures into paragraph-long sentences."  The author then presents Truss' claim that "employing a semicolon represents one of the highest compliments a writer can pay her readership" because it seems to say that an astute reader is "eminently capable of deciphering authorial innuendo (ie, suggestion or hint from the author)."
Consequently, use of the semicolon requires the reader to think about the author's meaning in nuanced ways.  This use creates a complex effect on the reader, and the writer, in turn, honors the reader's intelligence by creating this effect through semicolon usage.  Therefore, Truss' claim functions in the passage to reveal a potentially complex effect of semicolon use on the reader.
 By contrast, none of the following represents the function of Truss' claim in the passage:
It discredits the notion that semicolons are a cause of confusion (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 1, the use of the semicolon can "[sow] the seeds of semantic confusion (ie, confusion about the meaning of words)."  Later, Paragraph 3 conveys Truss' opinion that a semicolon represents a compliment by the writer to the reader who "is eminently capable of deciphering authorial innuendo."  That the reader needs to decipher what the author has written and punctuated with semicolons reinforces the notion that the punctuation mark is often associated with some confusion or ambiguity about meaning.  Consequently, Truss' claim does not deny that semicolons can be a cause of confusion.
It highlights a widely acknowledged justification for extensive semicolon use (Choice B).  Paragraph 3 presents Truss' view that "employing a semicolon represents one of the highest compliments a writer can pay her readership."  However, the passage never suggests that this sentiment about semicolon usage is shared by others, nor does it indicate what the popularly accepted opinion about, let alone justification, for extensive semicolon use might be.
It establishes that semicolons can help writers to attract readers (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 3, "In Truss' opinion, employing a semicolon represents one of the highest compliments a writer can pay her readership" because it seems to say that "the perspicacious reader is eminently capable of deciphering authorial innuendo."  However, whether or not authors are actually flattering readers through semicolon use, Truss' claim does not imply that authors try to attract readers by using semicolons, nor that readers are attracted to texts that feature an abundance of semicolons.

text: Suppose it were discovered that starvation during the final months of pregnancy resulted in children who were smaller than average even as adults.  How would this new information affect the passage claim about intrauterine deprivation and adult obesity?
explanations:
The initial results, published in 1976, revealed that, among other health consequences, individuals exposed to deprivation during early gestation had much higher than normal rates of obesity as adults.  Research by scientists from both the Netherlands and the US, together with new information from the field of epigenetics…, now suggests that nutritional restriction during early gestation effectively inactivates specific genes. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, the initial results of the Dutch Hunger Winter Study, which compared the Hunger Winter babies with their unaffected siblings, "revealed that…individuals exposed to deprivation during early gestation had much higher than normal rates of obesity as adults."  However, the new information that starvation during the last months of pregnancy (ie, late gestation) resulted in children who were smaller than average even as adults has no bearing on what occurs earlier in gestation.  Therefore, this new information would not affect the passage claim about early intrauterine deprivation and adult obesity.
(Choices A, C, and D)  The new information that starvation during the last months of pregnancy resulted in children who were smaller than average even as adults is irrelevant to the passage claim about early intrauterine deprivation leading to adult obesity.  Therefore, this new information would neither strengthen (support) nor falsify (refute) that claim.  In addition, because it is irrelevant, this information would not demonstrate that the passage claim needs to be reexamined.

text: The Hunger Winter babies and their siblings had offspring who are now well into adulthood.  Based on the passage, being able to also study these offspring long-term was most useful to the epidemiologists because it allowed them to:
explanations:
…[I]n individuals whose mothers suffered near-starvation during the early stages of pregnancy, DNA methylation silenced specific genes that normally help boost the rate at which the body consumes cellular energy.  The inactivation of these genes lowers metabolism, causing an increased tendency toward adult obesity. (Paragraph 4)
Furthermore, it has now been documented that the offspring of the Hunger Winter babies frequently exhibit the same health problems as their parents, including not only obesity, but also diabetes and cardiovascular disease.  Thus, with the advancement of genomics, this unfortunate period of starvation in the Netherlands offers strong evidence that DNA methylation is heritable…. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 4 explains that "in individuals whose mothers suffered near-starvation during the early stages of pregnancy, DNA methylation silenced specific genes that normally help boost the rate at which the body consumes cellular energy," leading to "an increased tendency toward adult obesity."  Paragraph 5 then states that "the offspring of the Hunger Winter babies frequently exhibit the same health problems as their parents," offering "strong evidence that DNA methylation is heritable."
These statements suggest that differences in methylation patterns are inherited and correlate with adult disease.  Consequently, the fact that the Hunger Winter babies and their siblings had offspring who are now well into adulthood was most useful to researchers because it enabled them to hypothesize that different health outcomes in the adult offspring correlate to the differences in their methylation patterns.
By contrast, none of the following statements represent the reason why being able to study the offspring long-term was most useful to epidemiologists:
estimate the offspring's likelihood of obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease in adulthood (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 5, "it has now been documented that the offspring of the Hunger Winter babies frequently exhibit the same health problems as their parents, including not only obesity, but also diabetes and cardiovascular disease."  However, this fact was established long after the Dutch Hunger Winter Study began, which means that the likelihood of adult disease was confirmed, not estimated or predicted.
determine the current methylation patterns of the offspring (Choice B).  If epidemiologists were to determine the current methylation patterns of the adult offspring, it would provide them with data.  However, such information about methylation patterns, which are believed to be heritable, is not useful in itself; rather, it becomes useful when researchers can correlate it with adult disease.
ascertain at which stages of the offspring's lives the effects of the methylation were most pronounced (Choice D).  The passage discusses the effects of methylation in the adult offspring of the Hunger Winter babies.  It also proposes that methylation patterns are heritable but does not discuss methylation's effects at different stages of the offspring's lives, nor suggest that at some stages they are more pronounced.

text: From the discussion in Paragraph 3, one can reasonably conclude that prior to World War II, there were NO studies that:
explanations:
The famine was among the best documented in modern history, and the Dutch Hunger Winter Study has been the first study to examine the long-term consequences of intrauterine starvation.  The study compared 422 individuals exposed to adverse intrauterine conditions with 463 siblings who were the products of pregnancies that either came to term before the famine began or occurred afterward. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 states that "[t]he famine was among the best documented in modern history, and the Dutch Hunger Winter Study has been the first study to examine the long-term consequences of intrauterine starvation."  One can therefore reasonably conclude that prior to this famine, or prior to World War II, there were no studies that examined the long-term (as opposed to the short-term) effects of nutritional deficiency before birth.
(Choices A and C)  Paragraph 3 states that "[t]he famine was among the best documented in modern history."  This implies that earlier famines had also been well documented or studied.  Such documentation would have provided information about the effects of starvation on particular population groups.
(Choice B)  Paragraph 3 says that the Dutch Hunger Winter Study "compared 422 individuals exposed to adverse intrauterine conditions with 463 siblings who were the products of pregnancies that either came to term before the famine began or occurred afterward."  However, the passage does not state whether there had been prior studies that compared children born during famine with those born before or after.

text: The response to which of the following queries would be most relevant for assessing whether the Dutch Hunger Winter Study accurately measured the long-term health effects of intrauterine starvation?
explanations:
However, the horror of the Dutch famine that occurred toward the end of the war, what in the Netherlands is commonly called the Hongerwinter, has provided epidemiologists a unique opportunity to research the long-term health effects of nutritional deficiency in utero on a specific cohort of individuals. (Paragraph 1)
The famine was among the best documented in modern history, and the Dutch Hunger Winter Study has been the first to examine the long-term consequences of intrauterine starvation.  The study compared 422 individuals exposed to adverse intrauterine conditions with 463 siblings who were the products of pregnancies that either came to term before the famine began or occurred afterward. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 1 says "the Dutch famine…provided epidemiologists a unique opportunity to research long-term health effects of nutritional deficiency in utero on a specific cohort of individuals."  Paragraph 3 also mentions that "the Dutch Hunger Winter Study has been the first study to examine the long-term consequences of intrauterine starvation" and "compared 422 individuals exposed to adverse intrauterine conditions with 463 siblings who were the products of pregnancies" that did not occur during the famine.  The study was therefore intended to measure the long-term health effects of intrauterine starvation, making this the research objective.
The answer to how much or to what degree the mothers were exposed to the famine is important (and the most relevant option) because it allows for assessment of whether the research objective of the study was measured accurately.  For example, if some mothers were exposed to the famine more than others, the mothers with more exposure would be presumed to have had babies with more severe long-term health effects.  Researchers would have to ask this question and get a satisfactory answer (ie, all mothers were exposed to similar degrees of starvation/famine) to ensure that the study was valid.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 3 says "the study compared 422 individuals exposed to adverse intrauterine conditions with 463 siblings who were the products of pregnancies that either came to term before the famine began or occurred afterward."  Whether other potential participants died prior to the study would not affect the study's research objective as it pertains to the already reported number of actual participants.
(Choice B)  According to Paragraph 1, the Dutch famine "has provided epidemiologists a unique opportunity to study the long-term health effects of nutritional deficiency in utero on a specific cohort of individuals."  Because the focus of the study is intrauterine starvation, information about whether the mothers of these individuals had starved at some time prior to the famine is not directly relevant to the study's research objective.
(Choice C)  Paragraph 3 states that the study participants were "422 individuals exposed to adverse intrauterine conditions" because of the famine, along with "463 siblings" who were not exposed.  As the country of origin of the participants would have had no bearing on this exposure, knowing what percentage of them were not native to the Netherlands is irrelevant to the study's research objective.

text: Given the information in the passage, how might the Netherlands have escaped the German retribution?  The Dutch government could have:
explanations:
The devastation began in September 1944 when Allied Airborne Forces failed to seize control of the bridge that crosses the Rhine at Arnhem.  To impede German ground troops and assist the Allies, the Dutch government then ordered a railway strike, prompting the Germans to retaliate with an embargo that cut off food and fuel supplies to the central and western provinces of the Netherlands, including the country's largest urban centers. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 explains how after the Allies' attempt to seize control of the bridge at Arnhem failed, "the Dutch government ordered a railway strike, prompting the Germans to retaliate with an embargo that cut off food and fuel supplies to the central and western provinces of the Netherlands."  Therefore, it was the railway strike that caused the Germans to retaliate.  Consequently, the Dutch could have escaped this retribution (retaliation or punishment) by the Germans if they had refrained from shutting down the railroad.
(Choice B)  Paragraph 2 refers to "the German-occupied Netherlands" and relates how a railway strike was ordered "to impede German ground troops and assist the Allies" after the Allies' attempt to take the bridge at Arnhem failed.  However, this is the sole example of Dutch resistance to the German forces mentioned in the passage.  Furthermore, the passage never suggests that resisting German occupation more fiercely would have enabled the Dutch to escape German retribution.  Moreover, the passage does not describe what fiercer resistance would have entailed.
(Choice C)  Paragraph 2 indicates that by imposing the railway strike, the Dutch were attempting to "assist the Allies" and "impede German ground troops…, prompting the Germans to retaliate with an embargo."  Consequently, for the Dutch, joining forces with the Allies actually prompted rather than prevented German retribution.
(Choice D)  The passage reports only that "Allied Airborne Forces failed to seize control of the bridge that crosses the Rhine River at Arnhem" (Paragraph 2).  There is no indication that the Dutch fought alongside the Allies for control of the bridge, or that had they done so, the results would have been different.  Rather, the passage describes only the Dutch government's decision to launch a railway strike and the German retribution for this act.

text: Which of the following passage assertions is the most essential for readers to accept in order for them to find the author's argument reasonable?
explanations:
Although airplanes and automobiles have now assumed greater prominence, the time has arrived for the resurgence of railroads.  A revitalized and advanced railway system would confer numerous essential benefits on both the United States and the globe. (Paragraph 2)
In a sense these two obstacles are one, as American dependence on personal automobiles is partially due to the paucity of rapid public transportation. (Paragraph 3)
A high-speed passenger rail system would dramatically transform American life as travel between cities and states became quicker and more convenient, encouraging commerce, business, and tourism.  Such a system would also make important strides in environmental preservation.  According to a 2007 British study, "CO2 emissions from aircraft operations are...at least five times greater" than those from high-speed trains. (Paragraph 4)
We should thus move ahead with confidence that the rewards will outweigh the expenditure as citizens increasingly choose to travel by train.  Both for society's gain and the crucial well-being of the planet, our path forward should proceed upon rails. (Paragraph 5)
The author's argument is that America should build a high-speed rail system because doing so would grant "numerous essential benefits on both the United States and the globe" (Paragraph 2).  These benefits include "encouraging commerce, business, and tourism" as well as making "important strides in environmental preservation" (Paragraph 4).  However, those benefits would occur only if the public is willing to use high-speed rail as a frequent mode of transportation.
The author suggests that this willingness exists.  For instance, Paragraph 3 states that "American dependence on personal automobiles is partially due to the paucity (lack) of rapid public transportation," implying that Americans would use such transportation if they had access to it.  Likewise, Paragraph 5 makes this point more explicitly by asserting that "the rewards [of high-speed rail] will outweigh the expenditure as citizens increasingly choose to travel by train."
Nevertheless, if American citizens continued to depend mostly on airplanes and cars even with high-speed trains available, then such trains would not actually provide the benefits that the author envisions.  Consequently, for readers to find the author's argument reasonable, it is most essential for them to accept the assertion that the public would readily adopt high-speed rail travel if it were available.
 (Choice A)  The airline and car industries have undue influence over American travel.  Paragraph 2 states that "airplanes and automobiles have now assumed greater prominence" compared to trains in America, and Paragraph 3 cites "the current dominance of the automobile" as an obstacle to support for high-speed trains.  Accordingly, the author would likely agree that the airline and car industries have undue influence over American travel.  However, his or her argument depends more crucially on the idea that those industries' influence is caused by "the paucity of rapid public transportation" (Paragraph 3), and thus that the public would readily adopt high-speed rail travel if it were available.
(Choice B)  A high-speed railroad network would encourage economic activity.  According to Paragraph 4, "A high-speed passenger rail system would dramatically transform American life…encouraging commerce, business, and tourism."  However, these economic benefits (as well as any environmental ones) could only be realized if citizens choose to embrace this mode of transportation.  Therefore, the assertion that a high-speed railroad network would encourage economic activity is less essential to the author's argument than the idea that the public would adopt high-speed rail travel once it is available.
(Choice C)  The superiority of foreign railroads disadvantages America in international trade.  Paragraph 3 states that "[t]he railroads of Europe and Japan…have vastly outpaced their American counterparts."  Although this statement indicates that foreign railroads are superior to those in America, the author's argument is not based on the idea that building high-speed railroads would improve America's international trade.  Rather, the author claims that "travel between [American] cities and states would become quicker and more convenient" and that such railroads would "make important strides in environmental preservation" (Paragraph 4).

text: Which of the following is most like the relationship between American railroads and British railroads as they are described in the passage?
explanations:
Locomotives were invented in England, with the first major railroad connecting Liverpool and Manchester in 1830.  However, it was in America that railroads would be put to the greatest use in the nineteenth century. (Paragraph 1)
While that speed was achieved under tightly controlled conditions, it still speaks to the great disparity in railroad development between the United States and other countries since the mid-twentieth century.  British trains travel at speeds much higher than those in America, where both the trains themselves and the infrastructure to support them have simply been allowed to fall behind. (Paragraph 3)
According to the passage, the first American trains overshadowed their British counterparts, but in modern times British trains are superior.  For instance, Paragraph 1 conveys that although "[l]ocomotives were invented in England…it was in America that railroads would be put to the greatest use in the nineteenth century."  Paragraph 3 then explains that there has been a "great disparity in railroad development between the United States and other countries since the mid-twentieth century."  In particular, "British trains travel at speeds much higher than those in America, where both the trains themselves and the infrastructure to support them have simply been allowed to fall behind."
Therefore, this relationship is most analogous to a situation in which an apprentice artist surpasses a master's early works but does not live up to the master's later works.  Like the British railroads, the original artist (the master) was first surpassed, but his later works re-established his superior position.
 By contrast, none of the following situations is most analogous to the relationship between American railroads and British railroads, because they do not include a re-established superiority:
A financial investor earns large sums of money in the short term but loses a larger amount over time (Choice B).  There is no suggestion in this analogy that such an investor later recoups her losses.  Moreover, her situation is not described in relation to another entity that surpasses her.
A rookie athlete sets a team record but in later seasons his record is broken by a newer player (Choice C).  In the scenario described, the rookie's record is later broken by a newer player, not by the previous record holder.  Accordingly, while the newer player sets a superior record, he does not re-establish his superiority.
An investigative journalist races to break a story but is beaten to the punch by a rival network (Choice D).  There is no suggestion in this analogy that the journalist later beats the rival network to the punch on other stories.

text: For which of the following passage claims does the author provide supporting evidence?
explanations:
A high-speed passenger rail system would dramatically transform American life as travel between cities and states became quicker and more convenient, encouraging commerce, business, and tourism.  Such a system would also make important strides in environmental preservation.  According to a 2007 British study, "CO2 emissions from aircraft operations are...at least five times greater" than those from high-speed trains.  For similar reasons, Osaka, Japan, was ranked as "the best…green transportation city in Asia" by the 2011 Green City Index.  As Lee-in Chen Chiu notes in The Kyoto Economic Review, Osakans travel by railway more than twice as much as they travel by car. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 states that a high-speed rail system would "make important strides in environmental preservation."  The author then supports this claim with data comparing the environmental effects of rail travel to those of travel by airplane or automobile: "According to a 2007 British study, 'CO2 emissions from aircraft operations are...at least five times greater' than those from high-speed trains."  Similarly, "Osaka, Japan, was ranked as 'the best…green transportation city in Asia' by the 2011 Green City Index," and "Osakans travel by railway more than twice as much as they travel by car."
Therefore, the author provides supporting evidence for the claim that increasing the use of high-speed railroads would be beneficial for the environment.
 By contrast, the author provides no supporting evidence for the following claims:
Developing a countrywide high-speed rail system would come with significant costs (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 5, "developing a countrywide high-speed rail system would come with significant costs."  However, the author makes this assertion without providing any specific information regarding such costs.
A high-speed passenger rail system would dramatically transform American life (Choice B).  Paragraph 4 states that "[a] high-speed passenger rail system would dramatically transform American life as travel between cities and states became quicker and more convenient, encouraging commerce, business, and tourism."  However, the author provides no data to support the idea that such a transformation would occur.
The United States still has the largest railroad network in the world (Choice C).  Paragraph 1 states that "[b]y 1887 there were nearly 164,000 miles of railroad tracks in America, and by 1916 that number had swelled to over 254,000."  Paragraph 2 then asserts that "the United States still has the largest railroad network in the world."  However, this assertion is not supported by evidence because the author does not provide the current total mileage of railroad tracks in America nor compare that number to the mileage of other countries' railroad networks.

text: How would the author's argument be impacted if studies suggest there is an increasing trend of people using ride-sharing services for transportation?
explanations:
The chief obstacles to garnering support for such a project are the current dominance of the automobile and the languishing technology of existing railroads.  In a sense these two obstacles are one, as American dependence on personal automobiles is partially due to the paucity of rapid public transportation.  The railroads of Europe and Japan, by comparison, have vastly outpaced their American counterparts. (Paragraph 3)
We should thus move ahead with confidence that the rewards will outweigh the expenditure as citizens increasingly choose to travel by train. (Paragraph 5)
Part of the author's argument is that Americans would use more public transportation if it were feasible, but they are often forced to depend on vehicle ownership out of necessity.  For example, Paragraph 3 connects the "current dominance of the automobile" in American life to the "languishing (neglected or weakened) technology of existing railroads," and asserts that "American dependence on personal automobiles is partially due to the paucity (lack) of rapid public transportation."  Similarly, in Paragraph 5 the author asserts that if a high-speed rail network were built, "citizens [would] increasingly choose to travel by train," which would reduce the need for them to own cars.
Thus, if there is an increasing trend of people using ride-sharing services for transportation, this trend would indicate that people are moving away from depending on their own vehicles for travel.  Accordingly, such a trend would support the author's assumption that the public could be willing to depend less on vehicle ownership.
 (Choice A)  It would refute the author's suggestion that trains would help fill a transportational need.  The author advocates high-speed rail as a way to address "the paucity of rapid public transportation" (Paragraph 3) in America.  In addition, he or she implies that such a rail system would help take the place of air travel, noting that "'CO2 emissions from aircraft operations are…at least five times greater' than those from high-speed trains" (Paragraph 4).  Thus, a trend toward increased use of ride-sharing services suggests a need for additional transportation options which trains might also help to fill.  Moreover, ride-sharing is unlikely to replace air travel as the author suggests high-speed rail might do.  Therefore, an increasing trend of people using ride-sharing services for transportation would not refute the idea that trains would help fill a transportational need.
(Choice B)  It would weaken the author's comparison between the Transcontinental Railroad and high-speed rail.  According to Paragraph 5, "developing a countrywide high-speed rail system would come with significant costs.  However, that was also true of the original Transcontinental Railroad, as indeed it is with virtually any great project undertaken for the public good."  Therefore, the author compares the Transcontinental Railroad and modern high-speed rail as ambitious but costly projects designed for society's benefit.  The basis for this comparison is not affected by an increase in the number of people using ride-sharing services.
(Choice D)  It would reinforce the author's claim that automobiles have made public transportation less important.  Paragraph 3 states that "American dependence on personal automobiles is partially due to the paucity of rapid public transportation."  Accordingly, the author argues that there is a lack of effective public transportation in America, to which the predominance of automobiles is a response.  However, he or she does not claim that automobiles have made public transportation less important.

text: In the context of the passage, which of the following best explains Zoellner's claim that "[u]nder the skin of modernity lies a skeleton of railroad tracks"?
explanations:
While the United States still has the largest railroad network in the world, it operates largely in the background of American life, and citizens no longer view trains with the sense of importance those machines once commanded.  Nevertheless, the economic and industrial advantages those citizens enjoy today would not have been possible without America's history of trains; as Tom Zoellner reminds us, "Under the skin of modernity lies a skeleton of railroad tracks." (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, American citizens "no longer view trains with the sense of importance those machines once commanded."  However, the author points out that "the economic and industrial advantages those citizens enjoy today would not have been possible without America's history of trains; as Tom Zoellner reminds us, 'Under the skin of modernity lies a skeleton of railroad tracks.'"  Therefore, the passage presents Zoellner's quote as an elaboration of the idea that America's past use of railroads was essential to producing the country's modern way of life.
Consequently, in the context of the passage, Zoellner's claim indicates that American trains have been crucial in producing the country as we know it.
 By contrast, in the context of the passage, Zoellner's claim does not indicate that:
American trains now represent an obsolete technology (Choice A).  Paragraph 3 states that "in America…both the trains themselves and the infrastructure to support them have simply been allowed to fall behind," which suggests that to some extent American trains represent an obsolete technology.  However, the passage does not connect Zoellner's quote to that idea, but instead to the claim that the advantages of modern society "would not have been possible without America's history of trains" (Paragraph 2).
American trains have been overshadowed by other forms of transportation (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 2, "airplanes and automobiles have now assumed greater prominence" in America.  However, Zoellner's quote is used to indicate the past role of railroads in producing "the economic and industrial advantages [American] citizens enjoy today."  The passage does not connect Zoellner's quote to the idea that trains have been overshadowed.
American trains have been largely retired from use in current society (Choice C).  According to the passage, "the United States still has the largest railroad network in the world," even though "it operates largely in the background of American life" (Paragraph 2).

text: Of the following passage claims, which could most easily be confirmed or refuted?
explanations:
The railroads of Europe and Japan, by comparison, have vastly outpaced their American counterparts.  Japan has operated high-speed rail lines continuously since 1964, and in 2007, a French train set a record of 357 miles per hour….  British trains travel at speeds much higher than those in America, where both the trains themselves and the infrastructure to support them have simply been allowed to fall behind.  In much of Europe it is common for trains to travel at close to 200 miles per hour. (Paragraph 3)
One of the author's points in arguing for a high-speed rail system in America is that trains in other countries are now much more advanced.  According to Paragraph 3, "[t]he railroads of Europe and Japan…have vastly outpaced their American counterparts."  For example, "Japan has operated high-speed rail lines continuously since 1964, and in 2007, a French train set a record of 357 miles per hour."  Meanwhile, in America, "both the trains themselves and the infrastructure to support them have simply been allowed to fall behind.  In much of Europe it is common for trains to travel at close to 200 miles per hour."
These comparisons between the trains of America and those of Europe and Japan are based on currently existing, measurable data points concerning factors such as speed and years of operation.  Accordingly, the claim that the railroads of Europe and Japan have vastly outpaced their American counterparts could most easily be confirmed or refuted.
 (Choice A)  Americans no longer view trains with the sense of importance they once commanded.  Although it could be true that American citizens "no longer view trains with the sense of importance those machines once commanded" (Paragraph 2), it is difficult to directly confirm or refute such a general claim about people's views and opinions.
(Choice C)  An advanced railway system would benefit America economically.  The author asserts that an advanced railway system would promote "commerce, business, and tourism" (Paragraph 4).  However, that claim is a projection rather than something which can be measured at present.  Accordingly, it is difficult to confirm or refute whether an advanced railway system would in fact benefit America economically as the author claims.
(Choice D)  A high-speed passenger rail system would dramatically transform American life.  The author claims that "[a] high-speed passenger rail system would dramatically transform American life as travel between cities and states became quicker and more convenient, encouraging commerce, business, and tourism" (Paragraph 4).
