Hofmannsthal's poignant epistle portended a crisis of language so common among writers in the first half of the twentieth century it led Austrian psychoanalyst Edmund Bergler to coin the term "writer's block" in 1947.  Ein Brief also epitomized Hofmannsthal's own estrangement from his craft as three years earlier the muse had forsaken this poetic prodigy.  However, for Hofmannsthal, unlike the fictional Chandos or the real-life Rimbaud, rehabilitation followed inhibition: he would eventually win renown as the chief librettist of opera composer Richard Strauss. (Paragraph 5)
Each passage section explores some aspect(s) of the phenomenon now known as writer's block.  Calling the condition "an occupational hazard" that suggests a deeper disorder, the author examines its possible origins in Paragraph 1.  For example, Romantic poets "equated creativity with an unseen and uncontrollable force that…either infused the writer or passed him by."  By contrast, the Symbolist poets were said "to blame their silence on the inadequacies of language itself."  The author also stresses that a block's outcome is ultimately "unpredictable," as evidenced by the respective experiences of Rimbaud and Valéry.
According to Paragraph 2, "perhaps no one has delineated the ubiquitous (present everywhere) writer's malady with more pathos (intensity of feeling) than Viennese poet and dramatist Hugo von Hofmannsthal in his 1902 Ein Brief (A Letter)."  The personal linguistic crisis suffered by his fictional Lord Chandos is then detailed.
Paragraph 5 concludes that the Chandos letter "portended (foretold) a crisis of language so common among writers in the first half of the twentieth century it led Austrian psychoanalyst Edmund Bergler to coin the term 'writer's block' in 1947."  Lastly, the passage reports Hofmannsthal's own experience with a blockage from which he seemed to fully recover.  Hence, the main purpose of the passage is to investigate facets of the phenomenon of writer's block.
 (Choice A) analyze the wavering productivity experienced by many writers.  In exploring writer's block, the passage touches on the issue of productivity.  For example, Rimbaud "ceased versifying altogether" at 20 years old, "while fellow Symbolist poet Paul Valéry deserted the métier (vocation) for two decades" (Paragraph 1).  Likewise, the fictional Chandos is portrayed as a "previously prolific (productive) writer" (Paragraph 3) who became blocked.  Furthermore, according to Paragraph 5, Hofmannsthal himself experienced a blockage, eventually recovering to become a successful librettist (writer of opera texts).  Thus, in examining writer's block, the passage reports on the fluctuating productivity of a few writers rather than analyzing changes in the productivity of many writers.
(Choice C) recreate a seventeenth-century experience of writer's block.  Paragraph 2 describes Hofmannsthal's Chandos letter as a "short but dense fictional work [that] takes the form of an early seventeenth-century missive (letter) addressed to the English philosopher and scientist Sir Francis Bacon."  However, while the letter's fictional author, Lord Chandos, is imagined as Bacon's contemporary, his experience with writer's block is not presented from a seventeenth-century perspective.  Moreover, Hofmannsthal composed this text at the very beginning of the twentieth century after being blocked himself.
(Choice D) offer hope to creative writers who strive to be more productive.  Paragraph 5 reports that Hofmannsthal had suffered "estrangement from his craft," but "would eventually win renown as the chief librettist of opera composer Richard Strauss."  Such an example might seem to offer blocked writers hope for their own rehabilitation.  However, the passage also discusses cases with less favorable outcomes, such as those of Rimbaud and the fictional Chandos, and explores the condition's origins and effects.

text: The "economic marginality" and "occupational plurality" the author describes in Paragraph 4 constitute:
explanations:
This is not…to say that life on the Aran isles was ever easy; in fact…[it] demanded a delicate equilibrium, and in the face of economic marginality most households resorted to occupational plurality—to include any combination of fishing, agriculture, kelp-making, boat-making, fowling, textiles, and manual labor. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 indicates that life on the Aran Islands "demanded a delicate equilibrium (balance)" and was characterized by "economic marginality" (ie, the economy was unstable and limited).  Consequently, "most households resorted to occupational plurality," meaning that most people sought to diversify, or increase the number and type of jobs that they did in order to increase their income.  Therefore, the "economic marginality" and "occupational plurality" the author describes in Paragraph 4 constitute a model of how job diversification can bolster (strengthen) economic stability.
(Choice B)  Paragraph 4 discusses different possible types of occupations available to the "denizens (inhabitants) of Inishmore," such as "kelp-making, boat-making, fowling, textiles, and manual labor."  However, the passage never indicates that there was job growth, meaning an increase in either the number or types of jobs available on the island.  Therefore, "economic marginality" and "occupational plurality" do not constitute an example of how job growth can improve dire financial circumstances.
(Choice C)  Paragraph 4 presents "occupational plurality" as part of an "ever-shifting quest for resources" and as one possible way for the inhabitants of Inishmore to maintain the "delicate balance" of their "lifestyle" during the 19th century.  However, the passage never suggests that "economic marginality" and "occupational plurality" constitute an inevitable (unavoidable) condition of island life.
(Choice D)  Paragraph 4 presents "occupational plurality" (having multiple jobs or sources of income) as a strategy for balancing "economic marginality" (an unstable and limited economic base) on Inishmore.  This economic situation represented "a delicate balance" and "an ever-shifting quest for resources" that allowed the inhabitants to achieve a basic or modest level of prosperity before tourism took hold.  Paragraph 5 then indicates that, at some point, these islanders became "heavily reliant on the outside—particularly on a tourist industry"—for their economic survival "rather than [being] self-sufficient."  Therefore, the passage does not suggest that "economic marginality" and "occupational plurality" constitute an optimum (best possible) situation for economic self-sufficiency.

text: Based on the passage, the marketing of the Man of Aran sweater indicates that inhabitants of Inishmore are:
explanations:
Eighty years later, this image of Aran life endures, perpetuating a myth that has arguably become a commodity as real as the Man of Aran sweater sold on Inishmore but typically knit elsewhere in Ireland—a symbol of the island's dual character, of its commercial nature that so patently contradicts its celebrated identity as isolated and self-sufficient.  Still, the persistence of this image of remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship, however fabricated or embellished, has helped the island reinvent its economy as one heavily reliant on the outside—particularly on a tourist industry that brings in as many as 2,000 visitors a day by ferry—rather than self-sufficient. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 describes the Man of Aran sweater as "sold on Inishmore but typically knit elsewhere in Ireland."  Paragraph 5 also states that the sweater is "a symbol of the island's dual character, of its commercial nature that so patently (openly) contradicts its celebrated identity as isolated and self-sufficient."  Moreover, "the persistence of this image of remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship…has helped the island reinvent its economy as one heavily reliant…on a tourist industry…rather than self-sufficient."
This evidence shows that islanders are deliberately trying to sell the "myth" or "image" of the Aran Islands along with the sweaters to make a profit.  Therefore, the marketing of the Man of Aran sweater indicates that inhabitants of Inishmore are essentially commercial.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 5 states that the Man of Aran sweater was "sold on Inishmore but typically knit elsewhere in Ireland" and that it was "a symbol of the island's dual character, of its commercial nature that so patently contradicts its celebrated identity as isolated and self-sufficient."  Although this evidence may indicate that inhabitants are using the island's "image of remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship" to sell more sweaters, the passage does not support the idea that inhabitants of Inishmore are corrupt business people (ie, engaged in illegal or unjust practices to make money).
(Choice C)  Paragraph 5 describes the image of the Aran Islands marketed through the Man of Aran sweater as one of "remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship…[that] has helped the island reinvent its economy as one heavily reliant on the outside—particularly on a tourist industry…rather than self-sufficient."  Although the sweater is marketed through the outdated but persistent image of the Aran Islands as self-sufficient, this marketing does not indicate that inhabitants of Inishmore are fiercely independent.
(Choice D)  Paragraph 5 states that the Man of Aran sweater was "sold on Inishmore but typically knit elsewhere in Ireland."  The passage also reveals that marketing the Aran image of "remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship" through the sweater "has helped the island reinvent its economy as one heavily reliant…on a tourist industry…rather than self-sufficient."  Accordingly, the marketing of the Man of Aran sweater does not indicate that inhabitants of Inishmore are passive or inefficient but, rather, shows them to be active and efficient in reinventing their economy.

text: Based on the passage, which of the following BEST characterizes the most recent economy of Inishmore?
explanations:
Eighty years later, this image of Aran life endures, perpetuating a myth that has arguably become a commodity as real as the Man of Aran sweater sold on Inishmore but typically knit elsewhere in Ireland—a symbol of the island's dual character, of its commercial nature that so patently contradicts its celebrated identity as isolated and self-sufficient.  Still, the persistence of this image of remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship, however fabricated or embellished, has helped the island reinvent its economy as one heavily reliant on the outside—particularly on a tourist industry that brings in as many as 2,000 visitors a day by ferry—rather than self-sufficient. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 describes the island's "celebrated identity" as "isolated and self-sufficient" and states that "the persistence of this image of remoteness, exposure and inexorable hardship…has helped the island reinvent its economy as…reliant on the outside, particularly on a [flourishing] tourist industry."  Therefore, the most recent economy of Inishmore would be best characterized as largely focused on adapting to the demands of the tourist industry.
By contrast, the most recent Inishmore economy would not be best characterized as:
Solely dependent on foreign perceptions for its prosperity (Choice B).  Paragraph 5 describes tourists as drawn largely to Inishmore by an external image or foreign perception of "remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship."  Moreover, "the persistence of this image…however, fabricated or embellished…has helped the island to reinvent its economy as one heavily reliant on the outside," particularly on tourism.  However, tourism is not the island's only source of prosperity: Paragraph 3 discusses the inhabitants' resourcefulness in having developed other profitable industries such as fishing and kelp-making.
Consistently substandard but entirely autonomous (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 indicates that Inishmore's economy used to be more self-sufficient (ie, autonomous) and subsistent (at maintenance level or substandard), but "by the early 19th century," the island had established several industries that depended on trade with the mainland and boosted the economy, in particular, the "thriving, if seasonal" kelp industry.  More importantly, Paragraph 5 reveals that the economy is now "heavily reliant on the outside—particularly on a tourist industry" and that this industry is flourishing.
Mainly dependent on the resourcefulness of its citizens (Choice D).  Paragraph 3 depicts 19th-century Inishmore citizens as able to "effectively counterbalance the meagerness of their island's natural resources by swiftly focusing on new and evermore efficient ways to exploit them."  Moreover, Paragraph 4 depicts the citizens as later resourceful in multiplying their occupations when faced with "economic marginality."  Paragraph 5, however, makes it clear that Inishmore's economy is now "heavily reliant on the outside—particularly on a [flourishing] tourist industry."

text: Suppose that the tourist industry on Inishmore were to decline sharply, resulting in a substantial economic loss.  Based on the information in the passage, the author would be most likely to advise the inhabitants to:
explanations:
Seaweed could also be harvested by the ton and burnt in kilns to produce kelp, the sale of which on the mainland continues to be a thriving, if seasonal, industry, often more reliable than fishing. (Paragraph 3)
In describing the development of profitable industries on Inishmore, Paragraph 3 cites "the abundance of seaweed off its shores" and explains that "seaweed could…be harvested by the ton and burnt in kilns to produce kelp, the sale of which on the mainland continues to be a thriving, if seasonal, industry, often more reliable than fishing."  These facts suggest the author would be most likely to advise the inhabitants to increase the production and export of the abundant kelp as a way to help compensate for the economic loss caused by a sharp decline in the tourism industry.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 2 describes Inishmore as "a landscape whose barrenness offered an almost equal shortage of arable (suitable for growing crops and raising livestock) land and surface water."  Moreover, as Paragraph 3 indicates that "most of the boulders" had already been "cleared away" to create more land on Inishmore, further expansion would be quite limited.  Accordingly, the author would be unlikely to advise the inhabitants to create more arable land to compensate for the substantial economic loss caused by a decline in tourism.
(Choice B)  Paragraph 5 describes the Man of Aran sweater as "sold on Inishmore but typically knit elsewhere in Ireland."  The passage also refers to the sweater as a "commodity" that sells the "image" or "myth" of life on the Aran islands.  This description indicates that the sweater is primarily marketed and sold to tourists, and so a sharp decrease in tourism would cause a sharp decrease in sweater sales.  Consequently, the author would be unlikely to advise Inishmore inhabitants to manufacture such a tourist-dependent product to help compensate for the economic loss from a sharp decline in tourism.
(Choice C)  Paragraph 3 states that the fishing industry on Inishmore was often less "reliable" than the kelp industry.  Therefore, the author would be unlikely to advise the inhabitants to expand the sale of seafood to the mainland to make up for a sharply declining tourist industry.

text: The information that Inishmore is now particularly favored as a place of tourism is NOT plausibly connected to which of the following assertions?  Inishmore:
explanations:
Eighty years later, this image of Aran life endures, perpetuating a myth that has arguably become a commodity as real as the Man of Aran sweater sold on Inishmore but typically knit elsewhere in Ireland—a symbol of the island's dual character, of its commercial nature that so patently contradicts its celebrated identity as isolated and self-sufficient.  Still, the persistence of this image of remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship, however fabricated or embellished, has helped the island reinvent its economy as one heavily reliant on the outside—particularly on a tourist industry that brings in as many as 2,000 visitors a day by ferry—rather than self-sufficient. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 shows that the perpetuation of the "myth" of the Aran Islands as "isolated and self-sufficient" and a place of "remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship" fuels the tourist industry there.  Consequently, if Inishmore were to overcome this image, such a change would not be plausibly connected to Inishmore's prosperous tourist industry.  If the idea of the island as a barren place of hardship disappears, tourists would be less likely to visit the island.
By contrast, the following can be plausibly connected to Inishmore being favored as a place of tourism:
Inishmore has been the most historically intriguing of the islands (Choice A).  Paragraph 2 states that Inishmore was "certainly the most historically colorful" of the islands, having survived "Viking raiders" and "Cromwellian soldiers."  In addition, it "hosted the first monastic communities of Ireland."  This historical background would likely attract tourists to the island.
Inishmore has long been considered to be on the edge of civilization (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 1, the island was situated "on what…must have seemed the very periphery of the civilized world."  Moreover, its remote and wild nature has constituted "a myth that has arguably become a commodity (something bought and sold)" (Paragraph 5), thus attracting tourists.
Inishmore has long been engaged in a dramatic struggle against nature (Choice C).  Paragraph 4 discusses the documentary film Man of Aran as dramatizing (ie, representing for an audience and in a way that likely exaggerates or distorts) "the islanders' daily existence as a never-ending and desperate struggle against the elements, particularly the constant apocalyptic (catastrophic) threat of the sea."  This supposed long-standing and dramatic struggle with the sea is part of the "image" or "myth" (Paragraph 5) of the Aran Islands that attracts tourists.

text: Based on the passage, the author implies that the inhabitants of Inishmore believed that the sea:
explanations:
For example, the abundance of seaweed off its shores supplied a remedy for the scarcity of soil.  Once most of the boulders were cleared away, the sand could be layered with the seaweed, which, as it rotted, transformed the granular matter into fertile earth in which common crops such as barley, rye, oats, and potatoes have since been cultivated.  More land also meant more livestock could be raised, and the grass-fed calves of the island are still prized by mainlanders.  Seaweed could also be harvested by the ton and burnt in kilns to produce kelp, the sale of which on the mainland continues to be a thriving, if seasonal, industry, often more reliable than fishing. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 states that "the abundance of seaweed off [Inishmore's] shores supplied a remedy for the scarcity of soil": it "could be layered" into the sand so that when "it rotted, [it] transformed the granular matter into fertile earth."  On this newly created land, "common crops…have since been cultivated…[and] livestock could be raised."  Moreover, the sea supported kelp-making, "a thriving, if seasonal, industry, often more reliable than fishing."  Furthermore, the island's commerce or trade with the mainland must have depended on sea travel.  Therefore, based on the passage, the author implies that the inhabitants of Inishmore believed the sea was essential for their economic stability.
(Choice A)  As Paragraph 3 shows, although the rocky, barren island naturally lacked "arable (suitable for growing crops) land," more land could be created by layering sand "with seaweed."  The crops and livestock on land were therefore ultimately dependent on the sea.  According to the passage, then, the author does not imply that the inhabitants of Inishmore believed that the sea was as important as their land, but rather that it was more important.
(Choice B)  Although Paragraph 3 suggests that fishing was not the most reliable industry, the sea offered other industries, such as the production of kelp, "the sale of which on the mainland continues to be a thriving, if seasonal, industry, often more reliable than fishing."  Therefore, based on the passage, the author does not imply that the inhabitants of Inishmore believed that the sea was too unpredictable to be their chief financial resource.
(Choice D)  The Man of Aran documentary, mentioned in Paragraph 4, depicted the sea as a "constant apocalyptic (catastrophic) threat" to the inhabitants of Inishmore, implying that any labor carried out on the water or the shore, such as fishing, could have been perilous (dangerous) or, at least, risky.  However, Paragraph 4 stresses that the film had "dramatized (ie, represented for an audience and in a way that likely exaggerated or distorted) the islanders' daily existence as a never-ending and desperate struggle against the elements," especially the sea, and that "life on Inishmore even in the 1800s was a far cry from that depicted in...Flaherty's self-styled documentary…of 1934."  Therefore, the author does not imply that the inhabitants of Inishmore believed that the sea was generally correlated with peril.

text: Which of the following situations in the tourist business is most analogous to the one described in Paragraph 5 regarding the Man of Aran sweater?
explanations:
Eighty years later, this image of Aran life endures, perpetuating a myth that has arguably become a commodity as real as the Man of Aran sweater sold on Inishmore but typically knit elsewhere in Ireland—a symbol of the island's dual character, of its commercial nature that so patently contradicts its celebrated identity as isolated and self-sufficient.  Still, the persistence of this image of remoteness, exposure, and inexorable hardship, however fabricated or embellished, has helped the island reinvent its economy as one heavily reliant on the outside—particularly on a tourist industry that brings in as many as 2,000 visitors a day by ferry—rather than self-sufficient. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 explains that the Man of Aran sweater, "sold on Inishmore but typically knit elsewhere in Ireland," is marketed to tourists as an authentic product of the island.  Similarly, the box of chocolates the Canadian tourist buys in France, although being marketed as Swiss chocolate, was actually made in Belgium and, so, is not authentically Swiss.  Even though the chocolates are being purchased in a third country (France), this situation in the tourist business is the most analogous (equivalent) to the situation of the Man of Aran sweater described in the passage.
By contrast, the following situations are not analogous to the situation of the Man of Aran sweater:
An Italian tourist orders pizza while visiting a historic village in Japan (Choice A).  The Man of Aran sweater sold on Inishmore is a traditional item that is not made locally.  By contrast, the pizza served in Japan is a nontraditional food made locally.  Furthermore, unlike the sweater, the pizza is not being marketed as authentic to the Japanese village (or even to Italy).
A Brazilian tourist buys a business suit that was made in China during a trip to London (Choice B).  Although the suit was made in a different country (China), it is not being marketed as authentic to London (England) or elsewhere.
An American tourist buys a turkey in Mexico to celebrate Thanksgiving dinner (Choice C).  The tourist who buys a turkey in Mexico to celebrate Thanksgiving (an American holiday) is not buying something strongly or uniquely associated with a foreign country.  Although the turkey may have been raised locally, it is a traditional food associated with the purchaser's home country.

text: Based on the passage, it can most reasonably be inferred that Wagner's greatest impact as a composer was due to his:
explanations:
However, the most influential Wagnerian innovation was the evolution and systematic application of what would later be known as the leitmotif, a recurring musical phrase or melody closely associated with a particular character, place, or object in the drama….  [Leitmotifs] could, as Hans von Wolzogen explains, be "developed, interwoven, assimilated with each other, and multifariously transformed."  Wagner also strategically employed them as "motifs of memory" that reminded the audience of previous scenes in the drama.  Thus, leitmotifs not only served as dramatic devices to signal the appearance of different characters but provided the internal musical logic and unifying mechanism for the entire operatic cycle.  Through liberal use of leitmotifs, Wagner was able to generate something Michael Halliwell describes as "a dense, constantly evolving, and fully enclosed dramatic world" whose musical complexity was staggering. (Paragraph 3)
Yet his accomplishments in opera surpassed that of any other composer, including his Italian counterpart Giuseppe Verdi.  In fact, few areas of European and world culture have escaped Wagner's influence….  Nevertheless, moviegoers today would struggle to identify Wagner's innovative use of the leitmotif as the progenitor of musical film scores and, particularly, of the popular phenomenon of the "theme song." (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 3, "the most influential Wagnerian innovation was the evolution and systematic application of…the leitmotif, a recurring musical phrase or melody closely associated with a particular character, place, or object in the drama."  For the innovative composer, leitmotifs provided creative possibilities for shaping the operatic score because, as Von Wolzogen states, "they could…be 'developed, interwoven, assimilated with each other, and multifariously (variously) transformed.'"  Wagner used leitmotifs as a musical mechanism and "dramatic device" that, by reminding the audience of earlier scenes and signaling the appearance of various characters, served to unify the operatic work.  Furthermore, by using leitmotifs strategically, Wagner could develop an opera into what Halliwell called "'a dense, constantly evolving, and fully enclosed dramatic world,'" the musical complexity of which was astonishing.
Wagner's complex use of leitmotifs was greatly influential; in fact, "his accomplishments in opera surpassed that of any other composer."  Furthermore, in cinema, as Paragraph 5 explains, Wagner's "innovative use of the leitmotif" was "the progenitor (parent) of musical film scores and, particularly, of the popular phenomenon of the 'theme song.'"  Therefore, based on the passage, it can most reasonably be inferred that Wagner's greatest impact as a composer was due to his use of leitmotifs as a complex musical device.
 (Choice A)  elevation of opera by inventing the phenomenon of Gesamtkunstwerk.  According to Paragraph 1, Wagner "set out to revitalize and revolutionize" opera by "adopt[ing] the concept of Gesamtkunstwerk, or 'total work of art.'"  He now viewed "the ideal form of opera as a synthesis (mixture) of the poetic, visual, musical, and dramatic arts."  Thus, the composer made sure that "rather than the opera's drama being subordinate (secondary) to the music, as was typical in [his] time, the music would now be integrated with the drama."  However, while it is plausible that Wagner's application of the theory of Gesamtkunstwerk served to elevate opera, the passage indicates that composer did not invent the phenomenon but merely "adopted" it.
(Choice B)  shaping the musical scores to suit the libretti.  According to Paragraph 1, Wagner diverged from most composers of his day in ensuring that "rather than the opera's drama being subordinate to the music, as was typical in [his] time, the music would now be integrated with the drama."  Thus, Wagner's practice of shaping his music to fit the dramas or libretti (lyrics and narratives) influenced opera.  However, as Paragraph 3 emphasizes, "the most influential Wagnerian innovation was the evolution and systematic application of…the leitmotif"; this innovation influenced not only opera, but also "the not-yet-invented art of cinema" (Paragraph 5).
(Choice C)  efforts to preserve opera's distinction from other genres.  Having adopted "the concept of Gesamtkunstwerk, or 'total work of art,'" Wagner came to view "the ideal form of opera as a synthesis of the poetic, visual, musical, and dramatic arts."  Accordingly, "the music would now be integrated with the drama" (Paragraph 1).  Therefore, the passage indicates that Wagner sought to combine traditional opera music with other art forms (such as poetry and drama); he did not try to maintain opera as a separate artistic endeavor, nor did he make efforts to preserve opera's distinction from these other genres.

text: Based on the information in Paragraph 3, which of the following conclusions could most reasonably be drawn?
explanations:
However, the most influential Wagnerian innovation was the evolution and systematic application of what would later be known as the leitmotif, a recurring musical phrase or melody closely associated with a particular character, place, or object in the drama.…  They could, as Hans von Wolzogen explains, be "developed, interwoven, assimilated with each other, and multifariously transformed."  Wagner also strategically employed them as "motifs of memory" that reminded the audience of previous scenes in the drama.  Thus, leitmotifs not only served as dramatic devices to signal the appearance of different characters but provided the internal musical logic and unifying mechanism for the entire operatic cycle.  Through liberal use of leitmotifs, Wagner was able to generate something Michael Halliwell describes as "a dense, constantly evolving, and fully enclosed dramatic world" whose musical complexity was staggering. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, Wagner was innovative in using the leitmotif, or "recurring musical phrase or melody closely associated with a particular character, place, or object."  Leitmotifs had creative potential because they were versatile; they could, as Von Wolzogen describes, "'be developed, interwoven, assimilated with each other, and multifariously (variously) transformed.'"  In other words, they could be overlapped.  In Wagnerian opera, leitmotifs constituted not only a "dramatic device" but supplied "the internal musical logic and unifying mechanism" for the whole, suggesting the composer overlapped them.
Furthermore, according to Halliwell, Wagner was able to use leitmotifs to produce "'a dense, constantly evolving, and fully enclosed dramatic world,'" which implies a complex network of overlapping leitmotifs.  Consequently, based on the information in Paragraph 3, it can most reasonably be concluded that various leitmotifs overlapped with each other in Wagnerian opera.
 (Choices B and C)  A single leitmotif represented different entities; and Some leitmotifs were played only once.  Paragraph 3 defines the concept of the leitmotif as "a recurring musical phrase or melody closely associated with a particular character, place, or object in the drama."  Accordingly, to qualify as a leitmotif, a musical phrase must be played more than once and can represent only one entity.
(Choice D)  Only a few leitmotifs occurred frequently in a single work.  As a "musical phrase or melody closely associated with a particular character, place, or object in the drama" (Paragraph 3), a leitmotif would be repeated throughout a musical score.  However, although Wagner was known for his liberal and systematic use of leitmotifs, Paragraph 2 never discusses the number of leitmotifs that appear or their frequency.

text: Which of the following is an assumption made by the author in Paragraph 1?
explanations:
Judging the opera of his day to be in a desperate state of decline, the 19th-century German composer Wilhelm Richard Wagner—arguably the most controversial, if not the most titanic, figure in the history of classical music—set out to revitalize and revolutionize the genre.  In his 1851 book-length essay, Opera and Drama, Wagner adopted the concept of Gesamtkunstwerk, or "total work of art," leading him to envision the ideal form of opera as a synthesis of the poetic, visual, musical, and dramatic arts.  Thus, rather than the opera's drama being subordinate to the music, as was typical in Wagner's time, the music would now be integrated with the drama. (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 describes how "the 19th-century German composer Wilhelm Richard Wagner…set out to revitalize and revolutionize" the musical genre of opera.  Having adopted the notion of Gesamtkunstwerk, or "total work of art," he came to view the "ideal form of opera as a synthesis of the poetic, visual, musical, and dramatic arts."  His application of the principles of Gesamtkunstwerk to opera meant that "rather than the opera's drama being subordinate (secondary) to the music, as was typical in Wagner's time, the music would now be integrated with the drama."
Therefore, before Wagner's innovations in the 19th century, the dramatic aspects of opera would have been subordinate to the music.  Accordingly, the author makes the assumption that prior to the 19th century, opera composers emphasized the musical score over the drama in their works.
 (Choice A)  The most innovative composers in the history of music tended to be controversial.  Paragraph 1 describes Wagner as "arguably the most controversial, if not the most titanic (larger than life), figure in the history of classical music" whose goal was "to revitalize and revolutionize" opera.  Thus, Wagner was not only innovative as a composer but tended to attract attention to himself.  However, Paragraph 1 never indicates whether in the history of music other composers had not been both innovative and controversial.
(Choice C)  Wagner was the most esteemed composer of the 19th century.  The passage portrays Wagner as being an innovative opera composer and refers to his Ring cycle as a "masterpiece" (Paragraph 4).  Paragraph 5 states that "[Wagner's] accomplishments in opera surpassed that of any other composer, including his Italian counterpart Giuseppe Verdi."  However, while the author retrospectively describes Wagner as surpassing other composers' accomplishments, he or she never claims that Wagner was the most esteemed composer during the 19th century.
(Choice D)  Few European operas produced in the 19th century were popular.  According to Paragraph 1, Wagner saw "the opera of his day" as being "in a desperate state of decline" and, accordingly, "set out to revitalize and revolutionize the genre."  However, Paragraph 1 never indicates whether the public shared Wagner's negative view of the opera of his day, nor discusses the popularity of 19th-century European operas.

text: Which of the following claims about 19th-century composers is implied by passage information?
explanations:
In contrast to the practices of his predecessors and contemporaries, like Carl Maria von Weber and Giacomo Meyerbeer, Wagner blurred the lines between the traditional operatic components of recitative (musical dialogue) and aria (solo) and virtually eliminated large choral segments. (Paragraph 2)
In Paragraph 2, the author compares Wagner's methods of composition to those of his peers: "In contrast to the practices of his predecessors and contemporaries…Wagner blurred the lines between the traditional operatic components of recitative (musical dialogue) and aria (solo) and virtually eliminated large choral segments."  Thus, the passage suggests that Wagner was an innovator who dared to overturn traditional practices, unlike most 19th-century opera composers who followed long-standing operatic conventions.  Accordingly, passage information implies that most 19th-century opera composers were more concerned with convention than risk-taking.
 (Choice A)  Most made an impact beyond the European world of opera.  According to Paragraph 5, "[F]ew areas of European and world culture have escaped Wagner's influence."  For example, the composer had a lasting impact on the art of film: "[H]is Ring cycle combined story with visual elements and dramatic music to anticipate the not-yet-invented art of cinema."  However, the passage never indicates whether there were other 19th-century composers whose impact had extended beyond the European world of opera.
(Choice B)  Most chose to write the lyrics to their own operas.  Paragraph 4 conveys that "[u]nlike most opera composers, Wagner wrote not only the musical scores to his works, but also the libretti (the lyrics and narrative)."  Hence, the passage indicates that Wagner diverged from the practices of his musical predecessors and contemporaries in choosing to write his own lyrics or libretti.  Therefore, the passage does not imply that most 19th-century opera composers chose to write the lyrics to their own operas.
(Choice D)  Most created operas based on stories from mythology.  According to Paragraph 4, Wagner's Ring cycle libretti "were based on the medieval epics of Norse and Germanic mythology."  However, the passage never mentions whether other 19th-century opera composers produced operas based on stories from mythology.

text: According to the passage, people who hear leitmotifs in movies would be likely to experience:
explanations:
[Leitmotifs] could, as Hans von Wolzogen explains, be "developed, interwoven, assimilated with each other, and multifariously transformed."  Wagner also strategically employed them as "motifs of memory" that reminded the audience of previous scenes in the drama.  Thus, leitmotifs not only served as dramatic devices to signal the appearance of different characters but provided the internal musical logic and unifying mechanism for the entire operatic cycle.  Through liberal use of leitmotifs, Wagner was able to generate something Michael Halliwell describes as "a dense, constantly evolving, and fully enclosed dramatic world" whose musical complexity was staggering. (Paragraph 3)
Most notably, his Ring cycle combined story with visual elements and dramatic music to anticipate the not-yet-invented art of cinema.  Indeed, early film score composers were schooled in Wagnerian techniques; they understood the versatile and subtle power of the leitmotif to unify all aspects of the drama and influence the audience emotionally. (Paragraph 5)
In Paragraph 3, the author discusses Wagner's use of the leitmotifs (repeating musical phrases linked to individual elements or characters of the drama) as a crucial means of unifying or interconnecting the different elements of a dramatic work.  For example, Wagner would employ them as "'motifs of memory,'" which "reminded the audience of previous scenes in the drama."  In this way, leitmotifs "provided the internal musical logic and unifying mechanism" for Wagner's operatic works.  Furthermore, according to Halliwell, the unifying power of the leitmotif enabled the composer to create "'a dense…and fully enclosed dramatic world.'"
The interconnecting potential of the leitmotif as developed by Wagner was later applied to the art of filmmaking.  As Paragraph 5 conveys, "early film score composers…understood the versatile and subtle power of the leitmotif to unify all aspects of the drama and influence the audience emotionally."  Therefore, based on the passage, people who hear leitmotifs in movies would be likely to experience an emotional response to interconnected dramatic elements.
 (Choice A)  feelings of satisfaction at being able to identify characters.  Paragraph 3 describes leitmotifs as "closely associated with a particular character"; this association allows them to serve "as dramatic devices" that signal the appearance of different characters.  Paragraph 5 later indicates that the use of leitmotifs in film has the power to "influence the audience emotionally."  However, the passage never claims that this emotional influence on the audience engenders feelings of satisfaction from the ability to identify characters.
(Choice C)  a bias against musical scores that feature theme songs.  According to Paragraph 5, a prominent aspect of Wagner's influence on musical film scores was the transformation of the leitmotif into "the popular phenomenon of the 'theme song.'"  By referring to the movie theme song as "the popular phenomenon," the passage implies that cinematic audiences would be familiar with theme songs and would likely react favorably to such songs rather than being biased against them.
(Choice D)  an appreciation of Wagner's influence on film music.  In Paragraph 5, the author states that "moviegoers today would struggle to identify Wagner's innovative use of the leitmotif as the progenitor of musical film scores and, particularly, of the popular phenomenon of the 'theme song.'"  Accordingly, the passage assumes that most filmgoers would be unaware of any Wagnerian influence on cinematic scores.  Therefore, the passage does not suggest that a common audience reaction to hearing leitmotifs in movies would include an appreciation for Wagner's influence on film.

text: If the passage description of the Panamanian revolution against Colombia (Paragraph 5) is accurate, which of the following would NOT be a reasonable assumption?
explanations:
The first to attempt such a feat were the French, under the leadership of Ferdinand de Lesseps.  Having formerly engineered the Suez Canal connecting the Mediterranean and Red Seas, Lesseps was a natural choice to head what was presumed to be a similar endeavor.  With the enthusiastic support of his country and the permission of the Colombian government (which controlled Panama at that time), Lesseps and his team began work in 1880, 11 years after the Suez Canal had been completed. (Paragraph 3)
With the failure of the French, the stage was set for the United States to try its hand….  Shortly thereafter, Panamanian dissident Manuel Amador led a rebellion against the Colombian government, while a U.S. warship happened to be sailing off the coast.  Victory was swift; as writer Janet Pascal notes: "The entire revolution lasted only a few hours.  Only one shopkeeper and a donkey were killed."  Afterward, newly independent Panama granted construction rights and control of the future canal to the United States. (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 3, the first country that attempted to build a canal in Panama was France, which had "the permission of the Colombian government (which controlled Panama at that time)."  However, Paragraph 5 relates that the French failed in this endeavor, and that "[s]hortly thereafter, Panamanian dissident Manuel Amador led a rebellion against the Colombian government."  This revolution was successful, and afterward "newly independent Panama granted construction rights and control of the future canal to the United States."
Since the Panamanians allowed the United States to come into their country to build a canal, they must not have objected to a foreign nation building in Panama.  Therefore, if the passage description of the Panamanian revolution against Colombia is accurate, it would not be reasonable to assume that the Panamanians resented Colombia for allowing a foreign nation to build in their country.
 By contrast, all of the following would be reasonable assumptions:
Colombian forces posed little resistance to Amador's revolution (Choice B).  In describing Panama's rebellion against Colombia, Paragraph 5 relates that "[v]ictory was swift….  'The entire revolution lasted only a few hours.  Only one shopkeeper and a donkey were killed.'"  Accordingly, based on the quickness and ease with which the revolution was carried out, it clearly did not face much resistance from Colombian forces.
The Colombian government recognized the potential for United States military intervention (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 5, "Manuel Amador led a rebellion against the Colombian government, while a U.S. warship happened to be sailing off the coast."  The presence of a U.S. warship at the exact time the rebellion was taking place could easily have been interpreted as a sign of American support for the rebellion.  Thus, especially given the ease of victory for the revolutionaries, the Colombian government seems to have recognized the potential for United States military intervention.
The United States favored Panamanian independence from Colombia (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 5, the United States benefited from the Panamanian revolution.  When considering a site for the canal, a "drawback to choosing Panama was that the Colombian government would not agree to let the U.S. control the canal once it was built."  However, after the revolution, "newly independent Panama granted construction rights and control of the future canal to the United States."  Since the United States obtained exactly what it wanted from Panama's new government, it can reasonably be assumed that the U.S. favored Panamanian independence from Colombia.

text: Passage information suggests that France's attempt to build the canal might have succeeded if:
explanations:
The first to attempt such a feat were the French, under the leadership of Ferdinand de Lesseps.  Having formerly engineered the Suez Canal connecting the Mediterranean and Red Seas, Lesseps was a natural choice to head what was presumed to be a similar endeavor.  With the enthusiastic support of his country and the permission of the Colombian government (which controlled Panama at that time), Lesseps and his team began work in 1880, 11 years after the Suez Canal had been completed. (Paragraph 3)
However, the mountainous jungles and swamps of Panama proved a pernicious contrast to the flat sands of Egypt.  Equipment toppled down hillsides or was swallowed into the mud, while frequent rains washed excavated dirt mounds back into the pits from which they had been extracted.  More devastating was the human toll.  Living conditions were squalid and miserable, as workers were ravaged by rampant yellow fever and malaria.  Over twenty thousand lives were lost, with no end in sight to the scourge of disease or to the faltering project.  Ultimately, the construction company went bankrupt, some of its members were imprisoned, and the elderly Lesseps died. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 3, the French sought to build a canal in Panama "under the leadership of Ferdinand de Lesseps.  Having formerly engineered the Suez Canal connecting the Mediterranean and Red Seas, Lesseps was a natural choice to head what was presumed to be a similar endeavor."  Thus, the French believed they would succeed at building a canal in Panama because of their previous success at building one in another part of the world.
Unfortunately, the situation in Panama was quite different from that of the previous project.  As Paragraph 4 relates: "the mountainous jungles and swamps of Panama proved a pernicious contrast to the flat sands of Egypt.  Equipment toppled down hillsides or was swallowed into the mud, while frequent rains washed excavated dirt mounds back into the pits from which they had been extracted."  Furthermore, the French suffered devastating human casualties as "workers were ravaged by rampant yellow fever and malaria.  Over twenty thousand lives were lost, with no end in sight to the scourge of disease or to the faltering project."
Therefore, because the French did not account for differences between the environments of Egypt and Panama, they experienced catastrophic losses to both their equipment and their workforce, dooming their attempt to build the canal.  Hence, that disastrous outcome might have been avoided if the French had taken account of those differences.  In other words, their attempt to build the canal might have succeeded if they had more thoroughly studied Panama's environment.
 By contrast, passage information does not suggest that France might have succeeded if:
They had provided their workers with better equipment (Choice B).  One of the many problems that the French faced while building in Panama was that "[e]quipment toppled down hillsides or was swallowed into the mud" (Paragraph 4).  However, the passage attributes this misfortune to the difficulty of building in "the mountainous jungles and swamps of Panama," not to any defect in the equipment itself.
Ferdinand de Lesseps had been less elderly (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 4, after the French failed to build the canal in Panama, "the construction company went bankrupt, some of its members were imprisoned, and the elderly Lesseps died."  However, although the passage mentions that Lesseps was elderly, it never associates the failure of the project with his age.
Ferdinand de Lesseps had been more experienced in canal building (Choice D).  The passage states that Lesseps was "a natural choice" to lead the Panama Canal project because he had "formerly engineered the Suez Canal connecting the Mediterranean and Red Seas" (Paragraph 3).  Therefore, the problem was not that Lesseps lacked experience in canal building.  Rather, he had not accounted for the differences between the environments of Egypt and Panama, which "proved a pernicious contrast" (Paragraph 4).

text: Which of the following claims, if true, would most challenge the passage idea that after taking account of its greater width but more hospitable terrain, Nicaragua was a better site for a canal than Panama (Paragraph 5)?
explanations:
With the failure of the French, the stage was set for the United States to try its hand.  Some American engineers recommended that the canal should be built through Nicaragua instead of Panama; although the former country was much wider, its terrain was significantly more hospitable. (Paragraph 5)
Traversing the breadth of Panama and incorporating a series of locks to raise and lower ships to different elevations, the Panama Canal finally made it possible to sail from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific without circumnavigating South America. (Paragraph 7)
According to Paragraph 5, some American engineers argued that the canal should be built in Nicaragua because "although the former country was much wider [than Panama], its terrain was significantly more hospitable."  Thus, these engineers believed that it would be worth having to build a longer canal because of how much easier the building process would be.
Later, Paragraph 7 describes the Panama Canal as "incorporating a series of locks to raise and lower ships to different elevations."  Hence, the canal could not be built as a simple channel across the country; its construction was complicated by the need to include locks to allow elevation changes.
Therefore, if in most regions, land elevation above sea level is higher in Nicaragua than in Panama, there would be added difficulty when building in Nicaragua; construction workers would either have to make more extensive use of such locks, or excavate through mountains.  Accordingly, this added difficulty would challenge the engineers' idea that Nicaragua's terrain was more hospitable than Panama's, and thus that it was a better site for a canal despite its greater width.
 (Choice A)  The Panamanian landscape contains greater natural variation than that of Nicaragua.  Paragraph 4 notes that "the mountainous jungles and swamps of Panama proved a pernicious contrast to the flat sands of Egypt," making the Panama Canal much more difficult to build than the Suez Canal had been.  Therefore, the passage indicates that the varied landscape encountered in Panama was a hindrance to building a canal, unlike the type and consistency of terrain in Egypt.  Accordingly, if the Panamanian landscape contained greater natural variation than that of Nicaragua, this fact would not challenge the idea that Nicaragua was a better site for a canal than Panama.
(Choice C)  A sizeable lake occupies a critical portion of Nicaragua's land mass.  Paragraph 2 indicates that the canal project was meant to create a "waterway through Central America."  If a sizeable lake occupied a critical portion of Nicaragua's land mass, then there would already be a waterway through part of that land, which could be incorporated into the man-made sections of the canal.  Therefore, the presence of such a lake would support (not challenge) the idea that Nicaragua was a better site for a canal than Panama.
(Choice D)  The government of Nicaragua insisted on controlling the canal once it was built.  Paragraph 5 conveys that when the United States was considering where to build the canal, a "drawback to choosing Panama was that the Colombian government would not agree to let the U.S. control the canal once it was built."  Therefore, if the Nicaraguan government also would not have let the U.S. control the canal, the same drawback would exist whichever of the two countries the canal was built in.  Accordingly, this claim would not challenge the idea that Nicaragua was a better site for a canal than Panama.

text: The author does NOT provide information about Panama's:
explanations:
With the enthusiastic support of his country and the permission of the Colombian government (which controlled Panama at that time), Lesseps and his team began work in 1880, 11 years after the Suez Canal had been completed. (Paragraph 3)
Shortly thereafter, Panamanian dissident Manuel Amador led a rebellion against the Colombian government….  Victory was swift; as writer Janet Pascal notes: "The entire revolution lasted only a few hours.  Only one shopkeeper and a donkey were killed."  Afterward, newly independent Panama granted construction rights and control of the future canal to the United States. (Paragraph 5)
The author states that "the Colombian government…controlled Panama" in the nineteenth century (Paragraph 3), until "Panamanian dissident Manuel Amador led a rebellion" that brought about a "newly independent Panama" (Paragraph 5).  However, although such a revolution would have involved violence against the ruling Colombian government, the author provides no information about any Panamanian military, either before or after the revolution occurred.
 By contrast, the author does provide information about Panama's:
size (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 5, "[s]ome American engineers recommended that the canal should be built through Nicaragua instead of Panama; although the former country was much wider."  Therefore, the author conveys that Panama is much narrower in size than Nicaragua.
location (Choice B).  Panama is identified as belonging to "Central America" (Paragraph 2), with its canal "finally [making] it possible to sail from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific without circumnavigating South America" (Paragraph 7).
climate (Choice C).  Paragraph 4 indicates that Panama was subject to "frequent rains."

text: Which of the following recommendations for a student's English project is most similar to what "[s]ome American engineers recommended," based on the description in Paragraph 5?
explanations:
With the failure of the French, the stage was set for the United States to try its hand.  Some American engineers recommended that the canal should be built through Nicaragua instead of Panama; although the former country was much wider, its terrain was significantly more hospitable. (Paragraph 5)
According to the passage, Panama was not the only country considered as a possible site for the canal.  As Paragraph 5 states, "[s]ome American engineers recommended that the canal should be built through Nicaragua instead of Panama; although the former country was much wider, its terrain was significantly more hospitable."  Thus, these engineers believed that building in Nicaragua would be worth the tradeoff: even though the canal would have to be longer, the construction itself would be easier.
Therefore, this recommendation is most similar to suggesting that the student should choose the option that allows them to write a longer paper about the less complicated topic.  Like the proposed Nicaraguan canal, the paper would have to be longer, but the writing process would be easier.
 By contrast, none of the following suggestions is like what "[s]ome American engineers recommended":
The student should choose the option that allows them to write a shorter paper about the more complicated topic (Choice A).  This suggestion would be similar to building in Panama instead of Nicaragua; the paper would not need to be as long, but the writing itself would be more difficult.
Before choosing a topic, the student should first engage in a background research phase to properly assess both topics (Choice C).  The passage does not describe the engineers as having recommended a research phase before choosing a canal site.  Rather, their assessment that Nicaragua was a better canal site than Panama was the result of research they had already done.
The student should discuss the project with the course professor and get advice on which topic to choose (Choice D).  The passage does not describe the engineers as recommending consultation with another party before deciding on a canal site.  Rather, the engineers themselves were the ones consulted about where and how to build the canal.

text: Which of the following claims about ethical behavior is assumed in the author's argument?
explanations:
In another sense, however, Sarah's actions were not fraudulent at all, because she herself believed in the power of tarot; one can be factually wrong without being morally wrong.  To the extent that Sarah sincerely tried to give her callers what she thought were legitimate psychic readings, she displayed honesty and integrity. (Paragraph 4)
Obviously, there is no such thing as a real psychic, and the predictions are nothing but superstition.  But even a disclaimer like "for entertainment purposes only" does not justify a business model that takes advantage of a customer's false belief or misrepresents what it supposedly offers.  Because Sarah honestly tried to give genuine psychic readings, her actions were ethical whereas her employer's actions were unethical. (Paragraph 5)
While discussing the ethics of Sarah's work at the psychic hotline, the author asserts in Paragraph 4 that "one can be factually wrong without being morally wrong."  Thus, he or she argues that whether people are ethical depends on their motives rather than their level of knowledge.  For instance, the author points out that even though "[f]ortune-telling does not work," Sarah believed that it did.  Therefore, she "displayed honesty and integrity" by trying to give customers what she thought were the real psychic readings they were paying for.
On the other hand, Sarah's employer acted unethically by addressing customers using "scripts based on corporate assumptions of what callers wanted to hear" instead of providing "'genuine' psychic readings" (Paragraph 3).  According to the author, it does not matter ethically that "the predictions are nothing but superstition," because the hotline still acted dishonestly by "claim[ing] to sell accurate predictions from 'real psychics' while knowingly providing nothing of the sort" (Paragraph 5).
Therefore, in contrasting Sarah and her employer, the author treats the intention behind each party's behavior as more ethically relevant than the facts about "psychic readings."  Consequently, the author's argument includes the assumption that ethical behavior depends more on a person's intentions than on actual circumstances.
 (Choice A)  It is a matter of being true to oneself instead of following others.  Although Sarah followed her own ideas instead of conforming to those of her company, the author asserts that she behaved ethically because she "displayed honesty and integrity" (Paragraph 4) and "acted in good faith" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, the author's argument does not necessarily assume that ethical behavior is a matter of being true to oneself rather than following others.  Rather, the author argues that the nature of Sarah's behavior is what made her more ethical than her employer.
(Choice C)  It requires a certain amount of intellectual understanding.  The author argues that Sarah acted ethically even though she lacked the understanding that her belief in tarot was "factually wrong" (Paragraph 4) and "nothing but superstition" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, the author does not assume that ethical behavior requires a certain amount of intellectual understanding.
(Choice D)  It varies according to each individual's personal values.  The author states that the "employer's actions were unethical" because the business "takes advantage of a customer's false belief [and] misrepresents what it supposedly offers" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, the author does not assume that ethical behavior varies according to each individual's values; rather, he or she takes the position that the employer acted from unethical values.

text: The author's assertion that "in some cases a lie is true" most likely means that:
explanations:
What is a lie?  Most would say that a lie is simply a statement that is false, or that the act of lying is to tell someone something false.  Despite the popularity of that definition, it is not really accurate, as telling someone a falsehood is not in fact the same thing as lying.  Even more strangely, in some cases a lie is true—not in a metaphorical sense, but literally. (Paragraph 1)
Essentially, if someone tries to convince you of something he thinks is false, then he is lying—regardless of whether his statement really is false or, unbeknownst to him, happens to be true.  But if he says something he believes is true but is actually false, then he is not lying.  Thus, what makes a statement a lie is not whether it is false, but whether it is meant to deceive. (Paragraph 2)
One of the author's points in the passage is that a common definition of lying is flawed.  According to Paragraph 1, although most people would say "the act of lying is to tell someone something false," that definition "is not really accurate."  The author then makes the further claim that "in some cases a lie is true—not in a metaphorical sense, but literally."
Paragraph 2 helps to explain this assertion by distinguishing what a speaker believes from the truth or falsity of his or her claim.  According to the author, "[I]f someone tries to convince you of something he thinks is false, then he is lying—regardless of whether his statement really is false or, unbeknownst to him, happens to be true."  In other words, a speaker might incorrectly believe that a statement is false, and try to trick someone else into believing it.  In that case, the speaker is telling a lie, despite the fact that the statement in question is true.  Hence, "what makes a statement a lie is not whether it is false, but whether it is meant to deceive."
Therefore, the author defines telling a lie as trying to convince someone of a statement that the speaker believes to be false.  However, he or she points out that such a statement might in fact be true.  Consequently, the phrase "in some cases a lie is true" means that a statement may be true even though the speaker believes it to be false.
 (Choice B)  what seems true to one person may seem false to another person.  In Paragraph 2, the author argues that a speaker could believe his statement is false while "unbeknownst to him, [it] happens to be true."  Accordingly, the assertion that "in some cases a lie is true" refers to a statement that is "literally" true (Paragraph 1) as opposed to "factually wrong" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, although in general it is likely that some statements seem true to one person but false to another, this is not what is meant by the author's assertion.
(Choice C)  a false statement may be compelling enough to fool people.  Although the passage describes scenarios in which people believe statements that are "actually false" (Paragraph 2) or "factually wrong" (Paragraph 4), it does not discuss how compelling a statement may be or its ability to fool people.
(Choice D)  in some cases a statement is both true and false simultaneously.  The passage describes situations in which people incorrectly believe false statements are true.  For instance, in the author's thought experiment, Mark "says something he believes is true but is actually false" (Paragraph 2).  Similarly, Sarah is described as "saying something that is manifestly untrue" about tarot readings, even though "she herself believed in the power of tarot" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, the author conveys that a statement may be false even though someone believes it to be true; he or she never suggests that a statement may be both true and false simultaneously.

text: Why does the author discuss the thought experiment where a co-worker claims there is a meeting (Paragraph 2)?
explanations:
To determine whether Mark was lying, what you need to know is whether he believed there was going to be a meeting.  If he did, then he didn't lie to you; he was just mistaken.  Essentially, if someone tries to convince you of something he thinks is false, then he is lying—regardless of whether his statement really is false or, unbeknownst to him, happens to be true.  But if he says something he believes is true but is actually false, then he is not lying. (Paragraph 2)
A related and unusual example comes from real life.  Sarah was hired by a psychic hotline to tell the fortunes of those who called in. (Paragraph 3)
Fortune-telling does not work….  In another sense, however, Sarah's actions were not fraudulent at all, because she herself believed in the power of tarot; one can be factually wrong without being morally wrong. (Paragraph 4)
Sarah honestly tried to give genuine psychic readings….  Her product may have been fake, but her honesty was real. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 2 describes a thought experiment in which Mark says there is a meeting scheduled.  Although that statement is false, the author notes that Mark was not necessarily lying: "[W]hat you need to know is whether he believed there was going to be a meeting.  If he did, then he didn't lie to you; he was just mistaken."  Accordingly, the thought experiment illustrates that just because Mark said something false does not mean that he was dishonest (ie, that he was intentionally trying to deceive someone).
The remainder of the passage applies this distinction to the "related and unusual example" (Paragraph 3) of Sarah's psychic predictions.  The author notes that although "[f]ortune-telling does not work," Sarah "herself believed in the power of tarot" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, even though her claims about predicting the future were false, they were not intended to deceive anyone.  Thus, "[h]er product may have been fake, but her honesty was real" (Paragraph 5).
Therefore, the author argues that Sarah's real-life situation is like the scenario in the thought experiment: although she made statements that were false, that does not mean that she was dishonest.  Consequently, the author discusses the thought experiment in Paragraph 2 to provide evidence supporting a distinction between being dishonest and making a false statement.
 (Choice A)  To exemplify the risk that one may place trust in a statement that is later revealed to be false.  The thought experiment describes believing Mark only to later discover that "his statement was false" (Paragraph 2).  However, the author never discusses the risk of placing trust in such a statement.
(Choice B)  To illustrate that issues of ethical concern commonly arise even in familiar everyday contexts.  Paragraph 2 describes a scenario in which a co-worker "tells you that there is a meeting."  However, although this could be considered a familiar, everyday setting, the author never highlights this feature of the scenario's context.  Rather, he or she simply uses it to introduce a point about truth-telling and honesty.
(Choice C)  To describe the contrast between a lie itself and the act of telling a lie.  In Paragraph 1, the author describes a common view about the definition of a lie: "Most would say that a lie is simply a statement that is false, or that the act of lying is to tell someone something false."  Thus, the author presents these claims as two ways of expressing the same idea about lying.  Accordingly, he or she does not describe a contrast between a lie itself and the act of telling a lie.

text: Suppose that Sarah's employer offered not to fire her if she would agree to use the company's approved scripts.  What would the passage author most likely recommend that Sarah should do?
explanations:
Obviously, there is no such thing as a real psychic, and the predictions are nothing but superstition.  But even a disclaimer like "for entertainment purposes only" does not justify a business model that takes advantage of a customer's false belief or misrepresents what it supposedly offers.  Because Sarah honestly tried to give genuine psychic readings, her actions were ethical, whereas her employer's actions were unethical. (Paragraph 5)
The passage author criticizes the psychic hotline's business model because it "takes advantage of a customer's false belief [and] misrepresents what it supposedly offers" (Paragraph 5).  In addition, he or she asserts that "[b]ecause Sarah honestly tried to give genuine psychic readings, her actions were ethical whereas her employer's actions were unethical."  Accordingly, if Sarah accepted the employer's offer to use the company's scripts, the author would view this decision as agreeing to be dishonest and unethical.
Therefore, if Sarah's employer offered not to fire her if she agreed to use the company's scripts, the passage author would most likely recommend that Sarah should refuse the offer and leave the company anyway.
 (Choice A)  Accept the offer for now but start searching for different employment.  Paragraph 5 states that "[Sarah's] actions were ethical, whereas her employer's actions were unethical."  Therefore, the author would probably not suggest that Sarah accept the employer's offer for now (even while searching for different employment) because she would then be participating in the company's unethical behavior.
(Choice C)  Agree to the offer but still continue giving traditional tarot readings.  According to the author, Sarah behaved ethically because she "displayed honesty and integrity" (Paragraph 4) and "acted in good faith" (Paragraph 5).  If Sarah agreed to the company's offer but continued giving traditional tarot readings anyway, this would represent dishonesty and acting in bad faith toward her employer.  Therefore, the author would probably not recommend this course of action.
(Choice D)  Counter-offer to teach the other employees traditional tarot instead.  Although the author states that Sarah's use of tarot exhibited "honesty and integrity," he or she nevertheless views tarot itself as "inherently fraudulent" and based on ideas that are "manifestly untrue" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, even if the other employees were to give traditional tarot readings, the author would still view those employees as participating in a business that "takes advantage of a customer's false belief" (Paragraph 5).  Therefore, the passage author would most likely not recommend that Sarah counter-offer to teach the other employees traditional tarot instead.

text: Based on the passage, a comparison between Sarah's psychic readings and the hotline's psychic readings is most like a comparison between:
explanations:
In another sense, however, Sarah's actions were not fraudulent at all, because she herself believed in the power of tarot; one can be factually wrong without being morally wrong.  To the extent that Sarah sincerely tried to give her callers what she thought were legitimate psychic readings, she displayed honesty and integrity. (Paragraph 4)
Certainly, she acted in good faith while her employer clearly did not.  The hotline claimed to sell accurate predictions from "real psychics" while knowingly providing nothing of the sort. (Paragraph 5)
The passage states that Sarah was "factually wrong without being morally wrong," because she "sincerely tried to give callers what she thought were legitimate psychic readings" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, Sarah made an honest mistake about what she was giving the customers.  By contrast, the company "claimed to sell accurate predictions from 'real psychics' while knowingly providing nothing of the sort" (Paragraph 5).  Thus, the company was intentionally offering the customers something that it knew was not genuine.
Similarly, someone who confuses a rock for gold is making an honest mistake, whereas someone who paints rocks to pass them off as gold intentionally offers something that is not genuine.  Therefore, a comparison between Sarah's psychic readings and the company's psychic readings is most like a comparison between confusing a rock for gold and painting rocks to pass them off as gold.
 By contrast, none of the following resembles a comparison between Sarah's psychic readings and the hotline's psychic readings:
wondering whether a rumor is true and spreading a rumor regardless of whether it is true (Choice A).  Sarah did not wonder whether her psychic readings were true, but sincerely "thought [they] were legitimate" predictions about the future (Paragraph 4).
suspecting a signature is a forgery and forging a signature on a contract (Choice B).  Suspecting that a signature is a forgery means thinking that the signature could be forged, but being unsure.  This is unlike Sarah's view of her psychic readings, which "she thought were legitimate" (Paragraph 4).
guessing that a company's value will fall and slandering a company to hurt its value (Choice D).  A guess is a supposition that one is not necessarily sure about.  This is unlike Sarah's view toward her psychic readings, which "she herself believed in" (Paragraph 4).

text: Suppose that Sarah performed her own tarot reading which predicted she would eventually be fired for not using company scripts.  If Sarah kept giving customers traditional readings anyway, the passage author would probably NOT draw which of the following conclusions?
explanations:
Sarah was hired by a psychic hotline to tell the fortunes of those who called in.  When speaking to a customer she would use a tarot deck in the traditional way, then describe the cards' perceived implications for the person's future.  However, her employer did not want the psychics to provide "genuine" psychic readings, but instead to address customers using approved scripts based on corporate assumptions of what callers wanted to hear.  Because Sarah was giving the customers "real" psychic readings instead of the company's pre-fabricated ones, her employment was terminated. (Paragraph 3)
In another sense, however, Sarah's actions were not fraudulent at all, because she herself believed in the power of tarot; one can be factually wrong without being morally wrong.  To the extent that Sarah sincerely tried to give her callers what she thought were legitimate psychic readings, she displayed honesty and integrity. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 3, when Sarah worked at the psychic hotline, "her employer did not want the psychics to provide 'genuine' psychic readings, but instead to address customers using approved scripts based on corporate assumptions of what callers wanted to hear."  Nevertheless, Sarah refused to follow the company scripts and insisted on "us[ing] a tarot deck in the traditional way" for her customers.  Because of this behavior, she was ultimately fired.
In the scenario described in the question, Sarah's own tarot reading predicts this firing in advance.  In that case, if Sarah believed in the power of tarot, she would have reason to change her behavior at work in order to avoid being fired.  Accordingly, if she did not change her behavior, one might conclude that she did not really believe in the power of tarot after all.
However, that conclusion would not make sense in light of passage information.  If Sarah did not really believe in the power of traditional tarot readings, then she would have had no reason to perform them against her employer's wishes.  Rather, she could have simply followed the employer's instructions in the first place.  Therefore, the fact that she insisted on giving customers traditional tarot readings suggests that she did believe tarot was real and that she wanted "to give her callers what she thought were legitimate psychic readings" (Paragraph 4).
Consequently, in the scenario described, the passage author would probably not conclude that Sarah's actions suggest she did not really believe in the power of traditional tarot readings.
 (Choices A and C)  Sarah's prediction based on her tarot reading only happened to be correct by coincidence; and Sarah could have guessed she would be fired for giving traditional tarot readings anyway.  The author calls fortune telling "inherently fraudulent," and adds that "[t]hose seeking to purchase knowledge about their future could not—except perhaps by lucky coincidence—receive what they hoped to buy" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, the author would argue that Sarah's successful prediction had nothing to do with the supposed power of tarot, but could easily be based on ordinary reasoning.  For instance, it is highly plausible to suppose an employer might fire an employee who, like Sarah, refused to follow company procedures.  Thus, Sarah could reasonably have guessed she would be fired anyway, regardless of whether her tarot reading coincidentally predicted that this would occur.
(Choice D)  Sarah demonstrated integrity by continuing to give traditional tarot readings.  In Paragraph 4, the author asserts that Sarah acted ethically by continuing to give traditional tarot readings: "To the extent that Sarah sincerely tried to give her callers what she thought were legitimate psychic readings, she displayed honesty and integrity."  Accordingly, if Sarah stuck to that decision despite also believing that it would require a personal sacrifice (ie, the loss of her job), this would likely reinforce the author's view that she demonstrated integrity.

text: In the author's thought experiment, which of the following questions would be most relevant to determining whether Mark lied about the meeting?
explanations:
To see why, consider a thought experiment.  Let's say that your co-worker, Mark, tells you that there is a meeting in the conference room at 11:00 AM….  Did your co-worker lie to you?  You already know his statement was false (because there was no meeting), but that knowledge is insufficient.  To determine whether Mark was lying, what you need to know is whether he believed there was going to be a meeting.  If he did, then he didn't lie to you; he was just mistaken.  Essentially, if someone tries to convince you of something he thinks is false, then he is lying—regardless of whether his statement really is false or, unbeknownst to him, happens to be true.  But if he says something he believes is true but is actually false, then he is not lying.  Thus, what makes a statement a lie is not whether it is false, but whether it is meant to deceive. (Paragraph 2)
One of the author's key points is that just because someone says something false does not necessarily mean that the person is lying.  To support this assertion, Paragraph 2 provides a thought experiment in which "your co-worker, Mark, tells you that there is a meeting in the conference room at 11:00 AM."  There isn't really a meeting, so Mark's statement was false.  Thus, the question arises: "Did your co-worker lie to you?"
