According to the author, whether Mark lied depends on "whether he believed there was going to be a meeting.  If he did, then he didn't lie to you; he was just mistaken."  In other words, there is a crucial difference between making a false statement intentionally and doing so accidentally.  While the former case constitutes lying, the latter case is not a lie but an honest mistake.  Thus, the author asserts that "what makes a statement a lie is not whether it is false, but whether it is meant to deceive."  Therefore, knowing whether Mark lied depends on knowing whether his claim about the meeting was meant to deceive you.
In the thought experiment, no one shows up for the meeting besides yourself, which means that Mark was not present either.  If he wasn't in the conference room because he knew all along that there wasn't a meeting, then he intentionally deceived you.  On the other hand, if he wasn't in the conference room because he was running late or was called away, then he only told you something false by mistake.  Consequently, the most relevant question to determining whether Mark lied about the meeting is: Why wasn't Mark in the conference room at 11:00?
 (Choices B and D)  Was there ever really a meeting scheduled for that day and time?; and Why did no other co-workers show up to the meeting?  Although the answers to these questions might reveal whether Mark's statement was false, the passage asserts that "what makes a statement a lie is not whether it is false, but whether it is meant to deceive" (Paragraph 2).  However, whether Mark's statement was meant to deceive cannot be determined from these questions.  For instance, suppose that no other co-workers showed up to the meeting because they knew that no meeting had been scheduled for that day and time.  That information would not show whether Mark mistakenly believed that there would be a meeting.  Accordingly, these questions are not the most relevant to determining whether Mark lied.
(Choice C)  What did Mark claim the purpose of the meeting was?  Knowing what Mark claimed the purpose of the meeting was would not indicate whether his statement was "meant to deceive" (Paragraph 2).  For example, if Mark honestly believed there was a meeting scheduled, then the meeting's supposed purpose would be part of his mistaken belief.  Similarly, if he knew there was no meeting scheduled, then the meeting's supposed purpose would be part of his deception.  Therefore, answering this question would not help determine whether Mark was lying.

text: Which of the following best describes Johnston's claim that the Lacanian ego is "a coagulation of inter- and trans-subjective alien influences," based on information in the passage?
explanations:
Alienation, lack, absence, and conflict are thus constitutive of the Lacanian ego.  The child's image—and, hence, the emerging ego—marks an ontological gap that turns into a repository for the projections and desires, whether conscious or unconscious, of parents and others.  Consequently, this image, as Adrian Johnston notes, is "always already overwritten" with words that are not the child's own.  In Johnston's view, the ego could be more properly described as "a coagulation of inter- and trans-subjective alien influences."  Rather than a "fluid and autonomous subject," it becomes a rigid and "heteronomous" entity.  Derived from the desires of others, the ego is, in Lacanian terms, "extimate," or internally exterior.  Both alien and alienating, it is an irreducible contradiction. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 details Lacan's theory of how the ego forms during the Mirror Stage: "The child's image—and, hence, the emerging ego—marks an ontological (pertaining to existence) gap that turns into a repository for the projections and desires, whether conscious or unconscious, of parents and others."  The author then presents Adrian Johnston's description of the Lacanian ego as "'always already overwritten' with words that are not the child's own."  Hence, the Lacanian ego can be understood as "[d]erived from the desires of others."  As Johnston goes on to point out, one might even call this ego "'a coagulation of inter- and trans-subjective alien influences.'"
Thus, in Johnston's interpretation, the ego develops by attracting and retaining not only the conscious—but the unconscious—desires of others.  Accordingly, Johnston's claim that the Lacanian ego is "a coagulation of inter- and trans-subjective alien influences" is best described by the statement that the Lacanian ego absorbs the unconscious wishes of others.
 (Choice A)  The Lacanian ego neutralizes conflicting emotional states.  Paragraph 3 explains how during the Mirror Stage the child has conflicting emotions toward his image, which he perceives as more perfect than himself: "[T]he infant's reaction to the image or Ideal-I is narcissistic; he is attracted to it as a model but feels aggression toward it as a rival."  Paragraph 4 then asserts that "[a]lienation, lack, absence, and conflict are…constitutive of the Lacanian ego."  Johnston's description of the ego as made up of "'inter- and trans-subjective alien influences'" and as "'heteronomous'" (governed by others) supports this assertion.  Hence, rather than neutralizing conflicting emotional states, the Lacanian ego derives from and maintains such states.
(Choices B and C)  The Lacanian ego is purposely constructed by the adults tending the infant; and The Lacanian ego attempts to defend itself from the desires of others.  According to Paragraph 4, the Lacanian ego forms as a reaction when the child along with tending adults sees his image for the first time.  The image, and consequently, the emerging ego, constitutes a kind of empty space that becomes "a repository for the projections and desires…of parents and others."  As Johnston's interpretation of Lacan stresses, due to its receptivity, the emerging ego "is 'always already overwritten' with words that are not the child's own."  Since such desires and projections are often unconscious, Johnston's interpretation suggests that the adults tending the infant are not completely aware of their role in constructing the child's ego.  Furthermore, the passage suggests that far from attempting to defend itself from the desires of others, the emerging ego is inherently receptive to such desires.

text: What does the Lacanian notion of misrecognition suggest about the ego?
explanations:
Lacan variously describes the formation and consequent function of the ego as a schismatic event of misrecognition…and a process of dialectical tension.  That process sets up an interchange between identification and alienation, generating confusion between being a subject as opposed to an object, between self and other, between what is "me" and "not me." (Paragraph 1)
At this phase of development, the child lacks any sense of a unified self.  However, when encouraged by an adult, he is able to recognize his reflection in the glass and, at the same time, comes to understand that the specular image looking back at him is, in fact, not himself.  In other words, the image provides the infant with the first glimpse of himself as an object, as "other."  According to Lacan…the child experiences…confusion at being unable to distinguish between what is and what is not himself.  Therefore, such recognition amounts to a form of misrecognition, the French term for which, méconnaissance, implies an essential misunderstanding or lack of knowledge. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 1 discusses Lacan's notion of misrecognition in the context of the Mirror Stage and ego formation: the Lacanian ego emerges from "a schismatic (fracturing) event of misrecognition…and a process of dialectical (based on opposites) tension."  Such a process establishes "an interchange between identification and alienation" that results in "confusion…between self and other.'"  Paragraph 2 goes on to emphasize how at this stage "the child lacks any sense of a unified self."  In recognizing his own reflection, the infant realizes, paradoxically, that the image "is, in fact, not himself"; thus, for the first time, he sees himself as "an object, as 'other.'"
Accordingly, during the Mirror Stage, the child becomes confused, "unable to distinguish between what is and what is not himself."  As the passage indicates, in Lacan's framework, "such recognition amounts to…misrecognition" or, more precisely, a "misunderstanding or lack of knowledge" of the self as other (Paragraph 2).  Therefore, the Lacanian notion of misrecognition suggests that the ego cannot be distinguished from the other.
 (Choice B)  The ego's formation is based on self-knowledge.  The Mirror Stage reveals self-knowledge to be problematic.  According to Paragraph 2, "[T]he initial fascination and pleasure the child experiences upon self-recognition dissolves into confusion at being unable to distinguish between what is and what is not himself."  Due to this confusion, Lacan believed "such recognition amounts to…misrecognition," the word for which in French connotes "an essential misunderstanding or lack of knowledge."  Accordingly, from a Lacanian perspective, ego formation is based not on self-knowledge but on a lack of self-knowledge.
(Choice C)  The ego can overcome its incoherence.  During the Mirror Stage, the child's sense of self wavers between coherence and incoherence.  Even though "the child in the mirror appears coherent, coordinated, and whole, the child himself continues to perceive his body as uncoordinated and fragmentary, resulting in a profound sense of incongruity and disharmony."  Thus, the image in the mirror "holds up an 'Ideal-I,'" one that "is ultimately unattainable, though we will likely spend the rest of our lives in pursuit of it."  As Paragraph 5 summarizes, "the ego is intrinsically and irreparably divided."  Consequently, the Lacanian notion of misrecognition suggests that the ego never becomes whole but instead retains its incoherence.
(Choice D)  The ego's nature is unknowable.  Paragraph 2 describes the child's identity confusion during the Mirror Stage and the consequent effect on the formation of his ego.  According to Lacan, "[T]he child experiences…confusion at being unable to distinguish between what is and what is not himself."  Thus, recognition is actually a kind of misrecognition—an experience Lacan designates by the French term méconnaissance, connoting a "misunderstanding or lack of knowledge."  The ego's nature is then described in Paragraph 4 as constituted by "[a]lienation, lack, absence, and conflict" and as "a repository for the projections and desires…of…others."  Accordingly, since the ego's nature can be described in specific—albeit seemingly negative—terms, the Lacanian notion of misrecognition suggests that the ego's nature is, in fact, knowable.

text: Based on the passage, which of the following experiences during the Mirror Stage would be most likely to facilitate the development of a child's ego?
explanations:
At this phase of development, the child lacks any sense of a unified self.  However, when encouraged by an adult, he is able to recognize his reflection in the glass and, at the same time, comes to understand that the specular image looking back at him is, in fact, not himself.  In other words, the image provides the infant with the first glimpse of himself as an object, as "other." (Paragraph 2)
The passage outlines Lacan's Mirror Stage in which the infant first encounters his reflection in a mirror in the presence of caregivers, facilitating ego development.  At this stage, "the child lacks any sense of a unified self.  However, when encouraged by an adult, he is able to recognize his reflection in the glass and, at the same time, comes to understand that the specular (mirror) image looking back at him is, in fact, not himself."  Accordingly, in Lacan's view, the image "provides the infant with the first glimpse of himself as an object, as 'other'" (Paragraph 2).
As in the Mirror Stage where the infant recognizes the mirror reflection of himself in the presence of his caregivers, a child, by watching himself in family videos, would be able to identify images of himself along with family members. In both scenarios, the child is now able to see the image as separate from himself, "as object, as other."  Therefore, based on the passage, the experience of watching himself in family videos would most likely facilitate the development of a child's ego during what would be the Mirror Stage.
 (Choice A)  Seeing a portrait of himself.  The Mirror Stage and its effects on the child's ego formation depend on the visual stimulus provided by the child's own image and on the presence of a caregiver.  According to Paragraph 2, during this phase, "the child lacks any sense of a unified self.  However, when encouraged by an adult, he is able to recognize his reflection in the glass and, at the same time, comes to understand that the specular (mirror) image…is, in fact, not himself."  By contrast, a portrait, which is static, would not provide the child with the same stimuli and dynamic visual feedback as a mirror in which he could see his own and his caregivers' movements reflected back.  Therefore, the experience of seeing a portrait of himself would be unlikely to facilitate the development of the child's ego.
(Choices B and D)  Encountering new sensory stimuli; and Practicing his motor skills. It is plausible that both new stimuli for the senses and practicing motor skills would have positive effects on a child's ego.  However, the phenomenon of the Mirror Stage centers on the visual stimulus of the mirror image of the child in the presence of caregivers as facilitating ego formation.  Given that scenario as the model, the experience of encountering new sensory stimuli and practicing his motor skills would be unlikely to facilitate the development of the child's ego.

text: Which of the following inferences about the Mirror Stage can most reasonably be drawn from the information in the passage?
explanations:
At this phase of development, the child lacks any sense of a unified self.  However, when encouraged by an adult, he is able to recognize his reflection in the glass and, at the same time, comes to understand that the specular image looking back at him is, in fact, not himself.  In other words, the image provides the infant with the first glimpse of himself as an object, as "other." (Paragraph 2)
The child's image—and, hence, the emerging ego—marks an ontological gap that turns into a repository for the projections and desires, whether conscious or unconscious, of parents and others.  Consequently, this image…is "always already overwritten" with words that are not the child's own. (Paragraph 4)
Lacan's Mirror Stage describes the child's first encounter with his image in a mirror as an event closely involving caregiver(s).  Since at this stage "the child lacks any sense of a unified self" (Paragraph 2), it is only with the encouragement of a caregiver that he "is able to recognize his reflection in the glass."  Nevertheless, at the same time, the child realizes that the image he sees is not himself.  As Paragraph 4 explains, this means that "[t]he child's image—and, hence, the emerging ego—marks an ontological (pertaining to existence) gap."  Furthermore, this gap becomes "a repository for the projections and desires, whether conscious or unconscious, of parents and others."
Thus, the passage shows that the Mirror Stage is mediated by the adults who interact with the infant.  Therefore, one can most reasonably draw the inference that the Mirror Stage is generally facilitated through social interactions rather than unfolding in a purely spontaneous manner.
 By contrast, none of the following inferences regarding the Mirror Stage can reasonably be drawn:
It is likely to cause harm as infants are extremely sensitive to the reactions of others (Choice A).  The passage describes the child's developing ego as extremely sensitive to the reactions of others.  According to Paragraph 4, "The child's image—and, hence, the emerging ego…turns into a repository for the projections and desires, whether conscious or unconscious, of parents and others."  Furthermore, as expressed by Adrian Johnston, "[T]his image…is 'always already overwritten' with words that are not the child's own."  Therefore, the passage presents the reactions of the child's caregivers as facilitating ego formation at this stage and so unlikely to cause harm.
It is a phase of childhood development that loses impact in adulthood (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 explains the possible long-term consequences of the Mirror Stage: "[T]he mirror image…holds up an 'Ideal-I' or future self that promises completeness and perfection."  However, this Ideal-I "is ultimately unattainable, though we will likely spend the rest of our lives in pursuit of it."  Therefore, the passage indicates that the Mirror Stage actually continues to affect a person throughout his or her life.
It is limited by the infant's helplessness, particularly his inability to speak (Choice D).  The passage describes the infant as largely helpless and unable to speak during the Mirror Stage.  Moreover, according to Paragraph 2, at this stage, "the child lacks any sense of a unified self."  Hence, it is only with the encouragement of an attending adult that the child "is able to recognize his reflection," while realizing that this image is not himself.  Paragraph 4 describes the ego emerging from the Mirror Stage as an empty space for "the projections and desires…of…others."  Hence, as Adrian Johnston notes, the ego that emerges "is 'always already overwritten' with words that are not the child's own."  Accordingly, this information suggests that the infant's helplessness and inability to speak are essential to the unfolding of the Mirror Stage and its effects.

text: The passage description of the effects of the Ideal-I on the ego would suggest that:
explanations:
Furthermore, while the reflection in the mirror appears coherent, coordinated, and whole, the child himself continues to perceive his body as uncoordinated and fragmentary, resulting in a profound sense of incongruity and disharmony.  By exuding mastery and harmony, the mirror image functions as a gestalt: it holds up an "Ideal-I" or future self that promises completeness and perfection—a condition, Lacan believes, that is ultimately unattainable, though we will likely spend the rest of our lives in pursuit of it.  Overall, the infant's reaction to the image or Ideal-I is narcissistic; he is attracted to it as a model but feels aggression toward it as a rival. (Paragraph 3)
The Mirror Stage is presented as a normal phase of psychological development in which the child's ego emerges through the tension that arises between the mirror image and his sense of self.  As Paragraph 3 notes, "[T]he child himself continues to perceive his body as uncoordinated and fragmentary, resulting in a profound sense of incongruity and disharmony."  This self-perception is at odds with the image in the mirror, which "[b]y exuding mastery and harmony…holds up an 'Ideal-I' or future self that promises completeness and perfection."  As Lacan posits, "the infant's reaction to the image or Ideal-I is narcissistic; he is attracted to it as a model but feels aggression toward it as a rival."
Thus, according to Lacan's theory of how the ego develops during the Mirror Stage, it is natural for a child to react narcissistically upon seeing his image or Ideal-I for the first time.  Therefore, the passage description of the effects of the Ideal-I on the child's emerging ego suggests that narcissism is a normal part of the ego's development.
 (Choice A)  The personality is a function of the ego but is unaffected by the Ideal-I.  According to Paragraph 3, the mirror image offers the child a kind of model: "[I]t holds up an 'Ideal-I' or future self that promises completeness and perfection."  This Ideal-I "is ultimately unattainable, though we will likely spend the rest of our lives in pursuit of it."  Consequently, since people continue to strive for this perfection and feeling of completeness their whole lives, passage information suggests that the Ideal-I affects the personality.
(Choice B)  Without the ego's aggression, the Ideal-I could not exist.  Paragraph 3 indicates that the infant's reaction to the Ideal-I is narcissistic, and, as a result, "he is attracted to it as a model but feels aggression toward it as a rival."  Accordingly, the passage indicates that the Ideal-I precedes and, in fact, is responsible for provoking the ego's aggression.  Hence, the Ideal-I does not depend on the ego's aggression for its existence.
(Choice D)  The child's previous sense of self-perfection is disrupted by the Mirror Stage.  Paragraph 3 discusses the paradoxical effect of the Mirror Stage: even as "the reflection in the mirror appears coherent, coordinated, and whole, the child himself continues to perceive his body as uncoordinated and fragmentary, resulting in a profound sense of incongruity and disharmony."  Thus, while the child perceives himself as imperfect, the mirror image "holds up an 'Ideal-I' or future self that promises completeness and perfection."  Accordingly, the passage never indicates that the child has a previous sense of self-perfection that is disrupted by the Mirror Stage; instead, during the Mirror Stage the child perceives himself as imperfect in comparison to his reflected image.

text: Based on the passage, James believed his psychological study of religion was worthwhile primarily because it:
explanations:
From the start, James conceived of his study as a psychological inquiry, declaring that "religious feelings and religious impulses must be its subject."  Consequently, he "propose[d] to ignore the institutional branch" of religion, confining himself as far as possible to "personal religion pure and simple."  Furthermore, in this unique exploration, James primarily endeavored to prove that personal experience—that is, the inner religious life of the individual—was the scaffolding upon which the outer religious life of the world was built.  In other words, the power of organized religion was derived from direct, personal communications from the divine.  Therefore, rather than analyze the fixed patterns found in theologies or doctrines, James decided to examine the personal experiences from which such patterns had originally been instituted. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 describes James' approach to the study of religion: he envisioned "a psychological inquiry," adding that "religious feelings and religious impulses" rather than "'the institutional branch'" of religion would be his subject.  As the author indicates, James aimed to show that personal experience was the basis of established religion, describing it as "the scaffolding upon which the outer religious life of the world was built."  Accordingly, James chose to examine the personal experiences that inspired religious practices rather than "the fixed patterns" found in theologies or doctrines.
Hence, James was determined to complete a study of religion that was psychological in nature and so focused on the original, firsthand (ie, more essential) experiences upon which the official patterns of external religious life were built.  Therefore, James believed his purely psychological study of religious experience was worthwhile primarily because it treated religious feelings as more essential than institutionalized religious sentiments.
 (Choice A)  recognized that the study of religion could be hindered by philosophical theorizing.  Paragraph 1 describes James as a radical empiricist who recognized the limitations of reductive thinking and philosophical theorizing.  Thus, James decided to conduct a "psychological inquiry" that used a radically empirical approach to examine "religious feelings and religious impulses" in accounts of personal religious experience.  This empirical approach helped him defend "religious experience against philosophical theorizing."  However, the recognition that philosophical theorizing could be a hindrance was the motivation for James' psychological study of religion rather than the primary reason his study was worthwhile.
(Choice C)  demonstrated the effectiveness of radical empiricism in analyzing any kind of personal religious experience.  According to Paragraph 2, "James primarily endeavored to prove that personal experience" or "the inner religious life of the individual" constituted "the scaffolding upon which the outer religious life of the world was built."  Thus, "James decided to examine the personal experiences from which such patterns had originally been instituted."  As Paragraph 5 indicates, by applying a method emphasizing radical empiricism, James succeeded at rescuing "religious feelings and impulses from reductive thinking and so defended religious experience against philosophical theorizing."  Accordingly, the passage suggests that through his study, James demonstrated the effectiveness of radical empiricism in analyzing any kind of personal religious experience.  However, such a demonstration was a consequence of James' study rather than the purpose that made it worthwhile.
(Choice D)  helped distinguish transformative religious institutions from nontransformative ones.  Paragraph 4 indicates that James felt personal religious experiences and direct encounters with the divine, such as mystical states, should be evaluated "according to their consequences."  In his view, the most important aspect of these experiences was their ability to be transformative for the individual through "the beliefs they engendered and how these were manifested in the life of the belief-holder."  However, the passage never indicates that James thought religious institutions were necessarily transformative for individuals.  In fact, Paragraph 2 underscores that in his study, James "propose[d] to ignore the institutional branch" of religion, confining himself…to 'personal religion pure and simple.'"

text: The central idea of the passage is that:
explanations:
Well known for his radical empiricism, pluralism, and pragmatism, William James fervently defended the primacy of raw experience against the reductive theorizing of philosophy. (Paragraph 1)
…James conceived of his study as a psychological inquiry, declaring that "religious feelings and religious impulses must be its subject."  …James primarily endeavored to prove that personal experience—that is, the inner religious life of the individual—was the scaffolding upon which the outer religious life of the world was built….  Therefore, rather than analyze the fixed patterns found in theologies or doctrines, James decided to examine the personal experiences from which such patterns had been originally instituted. (Paragraph 2)
Nevertheless, James…denied there was any such thing as "the religious sentiment," elementary religious emotion, formula, or essence.  Such oversimplifications and summations were to him suspect, if not dangerous.  As historian Jacques Barzun observes, "this Jamesian resistance to reduction" caused the radical empiricist to champion personal religious experience. (Paragraph 3)
…James took a pragmatic approach that evaluated such encounters according to their consequences.  …[H]e looked at the beliefs they engendered and how these were manifested in the life of the belief-holder. (Paragraph 4)
The passage examines James' commitment to an empirical as well as pragmatic (practical) approach to religion.  Accordingly, Paragraph 1 portrays James as a radical empiricist defending "the primacy of raw experience against the reductive theorizing of philosophy."
Another aspect of James' empirical approach was his related conviction that a study of religion should be psychological in nature, its subject "religious feelings and religious impulses."  Thus, rather than analyze established religious patterns, James studied "the personal experiences from which such patterns had originally been instituted" (Paragraph 2).  Similarly, in emphasizing individual religious experience, James denied the existence of a single "'religious sentiment'" or "essence" (Paragraph 3).
The passage also describes James' approach to religion as pragmatic or based on practical outcomes.  He evaluated personal encounters with the divine "according to their consequences," that is, "the beliefs they engendered and how these were manifested in the life of the belief-holder" (Paragraph 4).
Thus, the passage stresses James' commitment to an empirical and pragmatic approach to studying religion.  Therefore, the central idea is that James believed there are empirical and pragmatic ways of analyzing experience that should be used to study the religious feelings and beliefs of the individual.
 By contrast, although each of the following represents a related Jamesian belief that is discussed in the passage, none constitutes the central idea:
James believed that the theorizing associated with philosophy can be problematic for a study of religion (Choice A).  In James' view, philosophical theories about religion were problematic because they tended to reduce religious experiences to generalities.  Thus, he rejected the possibility of a specific "'religious sentiment'" or "essence" as an example of "oversimplifications" that were "suspect, if not dangerous" (Paragraph 3).  Overall, James' belief that such theorizing was problematic prompted him to decide that empirical and pragmatic ways should be used to study religious feelings and beliefs.
James believed that those who have a direct encounter with the divine have more intense religious lives than those who do not have firsthand experiences (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 2, "James primarily endeavored to prove that personal experience…was the scaffolding upon which the outer religious life of the world was built" and that "the power of organized religion was derived from direct, personal communications from the divine."  Thus, James plausibly believed that those who experience a direct encounter with the divine have more intense religious lives.  However, the passage never provides James' view on the intensity of such lives or compares them.
James believed that the importance of mystical experiences has been largely overlooked by reductionistic thinkers (Choice C).  Although James viewed mystical experiences as "the most profoundly transformative of religious experiences," he encountered "detractors, doubters, and reductionists" who wished to dismiss them (Paragraph 4).  Thus, the passage implies that James believed the importance of mystical experiences has been largely overlooked by reductionists.  Being resistant to reduction, however, James took an empirical and pragmatic approach to analyze mystical and other personal religious experiences.

text: The passage author most likely mentions that James "had himself delved into spiritualism" (Paragraph 3) in order to:
explanations:
Nevertheless, James—whose ancestors had been strict Calvinists, whose father had been an eccentric and erratic follower of obscure, utopian sects, and who had himself delved into spiritualism—denied that there was any such thing as "the religious sentiment," no elementary religious emotion, formula, or essence.  Such oversimplifications and summations were to him suspect, if not dangerous. (Paragraph 3)
Paragraph 3 suggests James' religious background influenced his later thinking on religion.  Notably, his ancestors were "strict Calvinists," his "eccentric" father had followed "obscure, utopian (excessively idealistic) sects," and James himself is described as having been involved in spiritualism (ie, a system of belief involving attempts to communicate with the dead).  The passage suggests that as a result of this exposure, James denied "any such thing as 'the religious sentiment,' elementary religious emotion, formula, or essence."  He dismissed such ideas as "oversimplifications and summations" that could be "dangerous."
Accordingly, the passage reveals James as having been exposed to a range of religious beliefs, suggesting that such exposure might account for his openness to the variety of religious experiences.  Therefore, the passage author most likely mentions that James "had himself delved into spiritualism" in Paragraph 3 in order to help shed light on James' receptivity to diverse religious perspectives.
 (Choices B and C)  provide an example of an unconventional religious movement; and exemplify the wide array of different religious beliefs available at the time.  Paragraph 3 details James' varied religious background: his ancestors are described as "strict Calvinists" and his father a "follower of obscure, utopian sects"; notably, James himself "delved into spiritualism."  Hence, the author's mention of spiritualism—a somewhat radical religious trend—provides an example of an unconventional religious movement and helps show the range of religious beliefs available at the time.  However, in the context of James' study of religion, especially his denial of "the religious sentiment," the mention of his experience with spiritualism more likely functions to suggest a basis for his receptivity to a wide variety of religious experiences.
(Choice D)  illustrate James' belief in the importance of trying different types of religions for oneself.  Paragraph 3 details James' religious background, including exposure to Calvinism and "obscure, utopian sects" as well as his own exploration into spiritualism.  While the mention of such details might suggest James believed in trying various forms of religions, the passage never provides his views on sampling different religions nor suggests he recommended this to other people.

text: Suppose a philosopher wanted to analyze an individual's account of his or her religious conversion.  James would likely argue that the most valuable information for this analysis would come from:
explanations:
In addition to emphasizing the empirical and pluralistic aspects of religious experience, James took a pragmatic approach that evaluated these encounters according to their consequences.  In particular, he looked at the beliefs they engendered and how these were manifested in the life of the belief-holder.  He determined that the mystical state was the most profoundly transformative of religious experiences.  To the myriad detractors, doubters, and reductionists who would dismiss such states as forms of hysteria or side effects of superstition, he responded that "the most important way to discern the real from the unreal" and "to distinguish pathology from truly divine states" was not to expose their "root causes" but to assess the "fruits" they yielded. (Paragraph 4)
In conducting his study of religion, James adopted a pragmatic (practical) as well as an empirical approach.  Accordingly, as Paragraph 4 conveys, he believed that personal religious experiences should be evaluated based on their practical outcomes, that is, "according to their consequences."  Thus, James "looked at the beliefs [such experiences] engendered and how these were manifested in the life of the belief-holder."  The author further stresses that James was interested in how religious experiences (particularly mystical states) proved "transformative" for an individual.  In his view, both the authenticity and the transformative power of such experiences should be judged by "the 'fruits' they yielded."
Therefore, if a philosopher wanted to analyze a particular person's account of his or her religious conversion, James would likely argue that the most valuable information for this analysis would come from observing whether the individual's actions reveal a lasting personal transformation.
 By contrast, if a philosopher wanted to analyze a particular person's account of religious conversion, James would be unlikely to argue that the most valuable information for that analysis would come from any of the following:
discerning within the person's experience specific repeatable steps leading to conversion (Choice A).  According to Paragraph 2, "James primarily endeavored to prove that personal experience…was the scaffolding upon which the outer religious life of the world was built."  As Paragraph 3 explains, James rejected the notion of any single "'religious sentiment'" or "essence," seeing such "oversimplifications" as "suspect" and even "dangerous."  Thus, James' resistance to reductive thinking led him to "champion personal religious experience" in its own right, not as a source offering specific steps to conversion that others can repeat.
examining the established religious patterns that such experiences influence (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 2, "James primarily endeavored to prove that personal experience…was the scaffolding upon which the outer religious life of the world was built."  Therefore, as the author stresses, "rather than analyze the fixed patterns found in theologies or doctrines," James decided to examine the individual experiences from which these established patterns had been instituted.
identifying within that account apparent universal principles such as kindness, mercy, and love (Choice D).  According to Paragraph 2, James made "'religious feelings and religious impulses'" the focus of his study, which he confined to "'personal religion, pure and simple.'"  As Paragraph 3 reports, he also believed there was no such thing as "'the religious sentiment.'"  Furthermore, although James experienced how easy it was at times to be "seduced by the commonalities in the narratives" he had collected, he nevertheless "insisted on a plurality of individual realities."  Hence, James would be more interested in focusing on individual, particular aspects within religious accounts than in identifying any apparent common or universal principles.

text: In Paragraph 3, the passage author indicates that William James:
explanations:
Nevertheless, James…denied that there was any such thing as "the religious sentiment," elementary religious emotion, formula, or essence.  Such oversimplifications and summations were to him suspect, if not dangerous.  As historian Jacques Barzun observes, "this Jamesian resistance to reduction" caused the radical empiricist to champion personal religious experience.  However, James did admit that, seduced by the commonalities in the narratives, he was at times tempted to develop a science of religion. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, James "denied there was any such thing as 'the religious sentiment,' elementary religious emotion, formula, or essence."  In fact, James was suspicious of "oversimplifications and summations."  Due to this "'resistance to reduction'" or opposition to theoretical abstraction, he focused on personal religious experience.  However, as the author points out, "James did admit that, seduced by the commonalities in the narratives, he was at times tempted to develop a science of religion."  Thus, despite James' commitment to rejecting universal principles in favor of individual experiences, he admitted to sometimes wavering from that stated focus.
Consequently, in Paragraph 3, the passage author indicates that William James could struggle to remain consistent in emphasizing individual religious experiences over broader commonalities.
 (Choice A)  established a scientific framework based on shared characteristics of religious experiences.  According to Paragraph 3, "James did admit that, seduced by the commonalities in the narratives, he was at times tempted to develop a science of religion."  However, the passage author indicates that James resisted this temptation toward reductive thinking.  He instead continued to "champion personal religious experience," and he "insisted on a plurality of individual realities."  Furthermore, when compiling "personal testimonies of divine encounters," James was intent on "allowing a plethora (overabundance) of different voices to speak."  Thus, the passage author indicates that James emphasized the individual nature of religious experiences rather than trying to establish a scientific framework based on shared characteristics among them.
(Choice B)  underestimated the role of rational argument in religious studies.  As Paragraph 3 conveys, "[I]n The Varieties, [James] carefully compiled personal testimonies of divine encounters, allowing a plethora of different voices to speak on the nature of such experience, rather than marshal (assemble) a sustained argument."  Accordingly, James relied on people's reported experience rather than rational argument as the basis for his study.  However, the author never evaluates James' position: there is no suggestion in the passage that James underestimated or was mistaken about the role rational arguments could play in religious studies.
(Choice D)  endorsed some of the religious and intellectual movements of his day in The Varieties.  According to Paragraph 3, James' "ancestors had been strict Calvinists" and his father a "follower of obscure, utopian (excessively idealist) sects," while James "had himself delved into spiritualism."  However, the author never suggests that James endorsed any ideas from these religious movements in his volume on religion.  Furthermore, by conveying that, while "other thinkers equated the ultimate nature of reality with monism (oneness)," James himself believed in "a plurality of individual realities," the author reveals James as being open to different views rather than as endorsing any particular movements of his day.

text: Why does the author most likely begin the passage discussion about the nature of blackmail by first describing the crime of extortion?
explanations:
Both blackmail and extortion are crimes of coercion: one party attempts to gain by threatening action that would be injurious to another, unless a specified demand is met (usually for financial payment).  However, with extortion the threatened action itself is also illegal.  For example, suggesting that one will vandalize property unless the owner pays a fee would be extortion, because it is unlawful to damage what belongs to another.  On the other hand, promising to expose a secret unless the subject pays would generally be blackmail, because in most cases there is nothing criminal about sharing factual information.  But in light of this distinction, an interesting question arises: Why is blackmail a crime? (Paragraph 1)
This question is more difficult than it may appear, and legal theorists, philosophers, and even economists have attempted to provide answers.  The "puzzle" or "paradox" of blackmail is to explain the following: How does offering to choose an otherwise legal option (eg, keeping silent), in exchange for compensation, make that choice a criminal act? (Paragraph 2)
The passage begins by distinguishing blackmail from extortion.  According to Paragraph 1, both "are crimes of coercion: one party attempts to gain by threatening action that would be injurious to another, unless a specified demand is met."  However, the two practices differ because with extortion, "the threatened action itself is also illegal," whereas with blackmail this is not the case.  For instance, revealing a secret is generally a legal act, so threatening to do so unless payment is made would be blackmail rather than extortion.
However, the author then notes that this distinction between extortion and blackmail raises a question: "Why is blackmail a crime?" (Paragraph 1).  Paragraph 2 goes into more detail, asking: "How does offering to choose an otherwise legal option (eg, keeping silent), in exchange for compensation, make that choice a criminal act?"  In other words, it is easy to see why extortion is illegal, because the threatened action is illegal.  But it is harder to see why blackmail is illegal, because the threatened action would be legal on its own.  Thus, most of the passage is devoted to addressing this puzzle about blackmail.
Accordingly, the description of extortion is used to introduce the question of why blackmail is illegal, which "is more difficult than it may appear" (Paragraph 2).  Therefore, the author most likely begins the passage discussion about the nature of blackmail by first describing the crime of extortion in order to anticipate the suggestion that it may be unclear why blackmail is illegal.
  (Choice A)  To justify the common tendency to use the terms 'blackmail' and 'extortion' interchangeably.  According to Paragraph 1, there is a significant difference between blackmail and extortion.  While both practices involve coercive threats, "with extortion the threatened action itself is also illegal," which is not the case with blackmail.  The passage then conveys that because of this distinction, it may even be unclear why blackmail is considered a crime.  Therefore, the passage implies that the terms 'blackmail' and 'extortion' should not be used interchangeably.
(Choice C)  To demonstrate how one legal definition eventually led to the specification of another distinct crime.  In Paragraph 1, the author provides general definitions for the crimes of extortion and blackmail.  However, he or she never discusses the history of these legal definitions, nor suggests that one definition eventually led to the specification of another distinct crime.
(Choice D)  To suggest that the definition of blackmail illustrates problems with illegality as a concept.  According to the passage, the distinction between blackmail and extortion makes it difficult to answer the question: "Why is blackmail a crime?" (Paragraph 1).  Thus, the author portrays this specific question about the illegality of blackmail as puzzling.  However, he or she never suggests that the definition of blackmail illustrates problems with the concept of illegality in general.

text: What is the author's attitude toward the position "a few scholars" hold regarding blackmail's legal status?
explanations:
Similarly, a few scholars have argued that blackmail should be legal because it actually benefits its target.  Rather than having a secret revealed against his wishes, the target is afforded the opportunity to choose what to him is a more favorable outcome—merely paying a fee.  Thus, like the retailer above, the blackmailer has increased the options available to the "victim," placing him in a better situation than he would have been otherwise. (Paragraph 4)
However, the most compelling argument relates to the ongoing effects of blackmail.  Law professor Richard Epstein stresses that the "business model" of successful blackmail is essentially participation in a kind of fraud—not against the blackmailed party, but against the party from whom information is concealed….  Moreover, the presence or potential of blackmail often incentivizes additional harmful or criminal activity by the perpetrator, the target, or both.  Thus, blackmail's effects are not only acute but systemic and pervasive.  As Epstein remarks, "Blackmail is made a crime not only because of what it is, but because of what it necessarily leads to." (Paragraph 6)
Paragraph 4 describes the view of "a few scholars" who argue that "blackmail should be legal because it actually benefits its target."  According to these scholars, blackmail offers the chance to avoid an undesirable outcome by "merely paying a fee."  Hence, in these scholars' view, "the blackmailer has increased the options available to the 'victim,' placing him in a better situation than he would have been otherwise."
However, Paragraph 6 describes an argument by Richard Epstein that the passage author calls "the most compelling."  According to Epstein, successful blackmail "is essentially participation in a kind of fraud—not against the blackmailed party, but against the party from whom information is concealed."  Furthermore, blackmail "often incentivizes additional harmful or criminal activity."  As such, Epstein states that "'[b]lackmail is made a crime not only because of what it is, but because of what it necessarily leads to.'"
Therefore, the author believes that "the most compelling argument" about blackmail comes from Epstein, who claims blackmail is wrong for reasons that go beyond the effects on its immediate target.  Consequently, the author's attitude toward the position of "a few scholars" is opposed, because there are additional grounds upon which blackmail is presented as harmful.
  (Choice A)  Favorable, because blackmail is depicted as no more harmful than normal business negotiations.  According to Paragraph 3, "[c]ertain types of financial coercion are a normal, expected part of business transactions."  Paragraph 4 then describes "a few scholars" as drawing an analogy between such legitimate threats in business and the kinds of threats made by a blackmailer.  However, the author never endorses this comparison; instead, he or she expresses support for Epstein's view that "'successful blackmail is essentially participation in a kind of fraud'" (Paragraph 6).
(Choices C and D)  Undecided, as the author describes both harmful and beneficial aspects to blackmail; and Indifferent, as the author never addresses the claim that victims of blackmail are actually better off.  Although the author does not directly address the claim that blackmail "actually benefits its target" (Paragraph 4), he or she does take a position about blackmail's effects and legal status.  In Paragraph 6, the author praises Epstein's view that "blackmail is essentially participation in a kind of fraud" and that it "often incentivizes additional harmful or criminal activity" (Paragraph 6).  Thus, the author supports Epstein's characterization of blackmail as a harmful activity that should be considered a crime.  Therefore, the author is neither undecided nor indifferent about the view that blackmail should be legal.

text: Suppose that a politician is vulnerable to being the target of blackmail as it is described in Paragraph 1.  Which of the following cases would most clearly constitute an example of blackmail, based on the author's description?
explanations:
Both blackmail and extortion are crimes of coercion: one party attempts to gain by threatening action that would be injurious to another, unless a specified demand is met (usually for financial payment).  However, with extortion the threatened action itself is also illegal.  For example, suggesting that one will vandalize property unless the owner pays a fee would be extortion, because it is unlawful to damage what belongs to another.  On the other hand, promising to expose a secret unless the subject pays would generally be blackmail, because in most cases there is nothing criminal about sharing factual information.  But in light of this distinction, an interesting question arises: Why is blackmail a crime? (Paragraph 1)
Paragraph 1 describes the characteristics of blackmail and distinguishes it from extortion.  Both practices "are crimes of coercion: one party attempts to gain by threatening action that would be injurious to another, unless a specified demand is met (usually for financial payment)."  In addition, with blackmail (unlike extortion), the threatened action would be legal under normal circumstances.  Accordingly, a typical instance of blackmail would be threatening to reveal sensitive information about a person unless he or she pays money to avoid that outcome.
Therefore, the clearest example of blackmail would be a case where the politician lies about accepting money from lobbyists, and his assistant threatens to go to the press unless the politician gives him a raise.  This scenario meets all the criteria for blackmail described by the author: the assistant attempts to gain financially through coercion, by threatening to reveal information (an otherwise legal act) unless he is given a raise.
 By contrast, none of the following cases meet all the criteria described by the author:
The politician misappropriates funding, and his assistant threatens to file an ethics complaint unless the politician returns the money (Choice A).  In this case, there is no attempt to gain on the part of the person making the threat.  Rather, the assistant's demand is for the rightful ownership of the funds to be restored.
The politician plans to vote against financial help for a community, and a citizen from that community threatens to harass the politician's family unless the politician approves the money instead (Choice B).  Paragraph 1 distinguishes between blackmail and extortion by noting that "with extortion the threatened action itself is also illegal," whereas in cases of blackmail the threatened action would be legal under other circumstances.  Because harassment is itself a crime, this scenario represents a case of extortion rather than blackmail.
The politician amasses large gambling debts, and a relative threatens to tell the politician's wife unless the politician tells her himself (Choice C).  The relative in this case is not seeking to gain personally, but rather to maintain the well-being of the politician's wife.  In addition, unlike a case of blackmail, the relative's threat does not include the possibility of keeping the politician's secret.  Rather, the demand is for the information to be revealed either way.

text: Which of the following claims about blackmail is most strongly suggested by the information in Paragraph 6?
explanations:
However, the most compelling argument relates to the ongoing effects of blackmail.  Law professor Richard Epstein stresses that the "business model" of successful blackmail is essentially participation in a kind of fraud—not against the blackmailed party, but against the party from whom information is concealed.  If Charlie's well-being depends on whether he knows particular facts about Bob, then Bob's attempt to conceal that information is injurious to Charlie.  As such, Adam can only blackmail Bob by perpetuating Bob's deceit.  Moreover, the presence or potential of blackmail often incentivizes additional harmful or criminal activity by the perpetrator, the target, or both.  Thus, blackmail's effects are not only acute but systemic and pervasive.  As Epstein remarks, "Blackmail is made a crime not only because of what it is, but because of what it necessarily leads to." (Paragraph 6)
In Paragraph 6, the author stresses Richard Epstein's view that cases of blackmail involve "ongoing effects" that "are not only acute but systemic and pervasive (ie, intrinsic and continual)."  For example, in addition to coercing the original target, blackmail functions as "essentially participation in a kind of fraud…against the party from whom information is concealed."  Thus, if Adam is blackmailing Bob over information that is hidden from Charlie, then "Adam can only blackmail Bob by perpetuating Bob's deceit."
Similarly, the author asserts that acts of blackmail do not exist in a vacuum but frequently lead to further wrongdoing: "[T]he presence or potential of blackmail often incentivizes additional harmful or criminal activity by the perpetrator, the target, or both."  Hence, the passage conveys that blackmail is not merely a discrete case of causing harm but part of a larger series of harmful acts.
Therefore, the information in Paragraph 6 strongly suggests that cases of blackmail often involve multiple instances of wrongdoing rather than just one.
  (Choice A)  Most attempts to explain blackmail's illegality are based on considerations of fraud.  Paragraph 6 highlights Richard Epstein's view that "successful blackmail is essentially participation in a kind of fraud."  However, the passage does not suggest that this perspective is typical of most attempts to explain blackmail's illegality.  Rather, by stating that Epstein gives "the most compelling argument," the author implies that there are other such attempts which are based on different considerations.  Moreover, Paragraph 5 describes arguments about blackmail's legal status that do not mention fraud.
(Choice B)  The illegality of blackmail has nothing to do with the effects on its actual targets.  According to Paragraph 6, part of the justification for blackmail's illegality is that "the presence or potential of blackmail often incentivizes additional harmful or criminal activity by the perpetrator, the target, or both."  Therefore, the passage includes blackmail's effects on its targets in the reasons why "'[b]lackmail is made a crime.'"
(Choice C)  The wrongness of blackmail cannot be understood in terms of rights.  In Paragraph 6, the author states that Epstein's discussion of fraud represents "the most compelling argument" about blackmail.  However, although Epstein's argument does not specifically refer to rights, his position could still be understood in terms of that concept.  For instance, the reason it is wrong to engage in "fraud…against the party from whom information is concealed" could be that such fraud violates the rights of that party.

text: Which of the following assertions is NOT suggested by passage information?
explanations:
Both blackmail and extortion are crimes of coercion: one party attempts to gain by threatening action that would be injurious to another, unless a specified demand is met (usually for financial payment).  However, with extortion the threatened action itself is also illegal.  For example, suggesting that one will vandalize property unless the owner pays a fee would be extortion, because it is unlawful to damage what belongs to another.  On the other hand, promising to expose a secret unless the subject pays would generally be blackmail, because in most cases there is nothing criminal about sharing factual information.  But in light of this distinction, an interesting question arises: Why is blackmail a crime? (Paragraph 1)
To this end, a comparison to the corporate world is helpful.  Certain types of financial coercion are a normal, expected part of business transactions; for instance, a retailer might threaten to purchase goods from a different wholesaler unless the current one lowers the price per unit.  This sort of tactic is not only legitimate but, in an overall sense, good for all parties. (Paragraph 3)
The passage describes different types of coercion, beginning with two that are criminal.  According to Paragraph 1, "[b]oth blackmail and extortion are crimes of coercion: one party attempts to gain by threatening action that would be injurious to another, unless a specified demand is met (usually for financial payment)."  Hence, although there is a difference between blackmail and extortion, the passage states that each of those crimes involves illegal coercion.
In addition to those cases, Paragraph 3 notes that there are legal kinds of coercion as well, such as ones which occur as "a normal, expected part of business transactions."  For instance, threatening to buy from a different company unless the price is reduced is "not only legitimate but, in an overall sense, good for all parties."
Thus, the passage describes cases of criminal coercion, such as "promising to expose a secret unless the subject pays" (Paragraph 1), as well cases of legal coercion, such as "threaten[ing] to purchase goods from a different wholesaler unless the current one lowers the price per unit" (Paragraph 3).  Hence, the passage implies that it is known in each case whether the type of coercion involved is legal or criminal.  Accordingly, the passage never suggests that coercion's legal status is unclear.
  By contrast, all of the following assertions are suggested by passage information:
Blackmail is a complex issue (Choice B).  Paragraph 1 raises the question "Why is blackmail a crime?"  Paragraph 2 adds that this question "is more difficult than it may appear, and legal theorists, philosophers, and even economists have attempted to provide answers."  The rest of the passage is then devoted to exploring such potential answers, such as the idea that blackmail "involves appropriating what belongs to other people" (Paragraph 5).  Hence, the idea that blackmail is a complex issue is an underlying theme of the passage.
Threats can have positive effects (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 3, some types of threats are a "normal, expected part of business transactions" that have generally positive effects.  For example, "a retailer might threaten to purchase goods from a different wholesaler unless the current one lowers the price per unit."  The author states that "[t]his sort of tactic is…good for all parties," indicating that the effects of such threats can be beneficial.
Blackmail is like a kind of theft (Choice D).  Paragraph 5 describes the view that "coercing someone through blackmail is illegitimate because it involves appropriating (taking for oneself) what belongs to other people."  Likewise, the author conveys that "[a] variation of this view uses more rights-based language" regarding whether or not a person "may reasonably have certain 'claims' to information."  Accordingly, the passage suggests that blackmail can be equated to illegitimately taking what rightfully belongs to someone else.  In other words, it amounts to engaging in a kind of theft.

text: Based on the passage, the need to tear down and rebuild the White House in the mid-twentieth century might have been prevented if:
explanations:
Robert Klara recounts a history of changes to the White House that gradually compromised its structural integrity….  [T]hey had the dual effect of increasing the load borne by the house while decreasing its ability to bear that burden.  The builders responsible for the many additions performed "careless and foolish maneuvers that a first-year architecture student would never have made," such as installing doorways in load-bearing walls or destroying the keystones of a brick arch. (Paragraph 2)
By the turn of the twentieth century, the structural failings of the White House had become difficult to ignore.  The building was likely beyond saving at that point…. (Paragraph 3)
Ultimately, there was little choice but to tear down and rebuild the White House. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 2 discusses "a history of changes to the White House that gradually compromised its structural integrity" and "had the dual effect of increasing the load borne by the house while decreasing its ability to bear that burden."  Moreover, the builders responsible for those changes "performed 'careless and foolish maneuvers that a first-year architecture student would never have made.'"  The passage goes on to state that "[b]y the turn of the twentieth century…[t]he building was likely beyond saving" (Paragraph 3).  In the end, "there was little choice but to tear down and rebuild the White House" (Paragraph 5).
Accordingly, the passage indicates that the need to tear down and rebuild the White House in the mid-twentieth century resulted from past architectural changes that had been poorly planned and executed.  Therefore, that outcome might have been prevented if those past architectural changes had not been so haphazard.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 3 conveys that "[b]y the turn of the twentieth century, the structural failings of the White House had become difficult to ignore.  The building was likely beyond saving at that point."  Paragraph 3 further describes one repair project that "only delayed the inevitable," and another that "had a disastrous side effect…causing enormous structural strain."  Consequently, the passage indicates both that repair projects had been initiated earlier in the century, and that such projects likely would not have prevented the need to tear down and rebuild the White House.
(Choice C)  After Margaret Truman left her piano on a weak floor, "one of the piano's legs crashed through, puncturing the overtaxed wood and sending debris cascading into the room below" (Paragraph 4).  However, the author describes this incident as part of "a long string of architectural warnings" (Paragraph 5), indicating that many other factors contributed to the need to tear down and rebuild the White House.  Consequently, this need would have remained even if Margaret Truman had not left her piano on the weak floor.
(Choice D)  Paragraph 3 states that "[t]he building was likely beyond saving at that point, and President Roosevelt didn't help matters by allowing architect Charles McKim only four months to make repairs."  Therefore, although the passage implies that McKim should have been granted more time to make repairs, it also indicates that the White House likely would have needed to be rebuilt regardless.

text: As the author uses the word, a "crescendo" is best described as:
explanations:
More dramatic incidents involved daughter Margaret Truman's piano.  Not only did the floor of her sitting room begin to sway up and down while she was playing a duet with a friend, but no steps were taken to move the piano away from the weak floor afterward.  Predictably, White House residents and staff were later horrified when one of the piano's legs crashed through, puncturing the overtaxed wood and sending debris cascading into the room below.  As for Margaret, Klara relates how she called the Steinway company to ask for "a man who could come over to rescue a piano." (Paragraph 4)
That event was the crescendo in a long string of architectural warnings.  Ultimately, there was little choice but to tear down and rebuild the White House. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 4 states that the "need to reconstruct the mansion reached a breaking point during the Harry Truman administration."  For example, "[w]alls continued to sink and pull away from ceilings" and chandeliers "swung dangerously from movement on the floor above them."  In addition, "[m]ore dramatic incidents involved daughter Margaret Truman's piano.  Not only did the floor of her sitting room begin to sway up and down while she was playing a duet with a friend," but later "one of the piano's legs crashed through, puncturing the overtaxed wood and sending debris cascading into the room below."
The passage describes this crash as "the crescendo in a long string of architectural warnings" which evidenced the need "to tear down and rebuild the White House" (Paragraph 5).  In other words, the "crescendo" was the striking culmination of a series of events leading to a particular outcome.  Therefore, as the author uses the word, a crescendo is best described as a culminating event.
(Choice A)  In describing the events involving Margaret Truman's piano, Paragraph 4 states: "Predictably, White House residents and staff were later horrified when one of the piano's legs crashed through, puncturing the overtaxed wood and sending debris cascading into the room below."  Accordingly, the author portrays the "crescendo" (Paragraph 5) as a calamity that could have been foreseen.
(Choice B)  Although "crescendo" is a musical term, the author uses it to describe an event when "one of the piano's legs crashed through [the floor]" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, the "crescendo in a long string of architectural warnings" (Paragraph 5) does not refer literally to a musical climax; rather, the author is making a play on words.
(Choice D)  According to Paragraph 4, "[t]he need to reconstruct the mansion reached a breaking point during the Harry Truman administration," implying that the architectural incidents of that time were the final steps that led to tearing down and rebuilding the White House.  Consequently, Margaret Truman's piano "puncturing the overtaxed wood and sending debris cascading into the room below" (Paragraph 4) occurred at the end of a "long string of architectural warnings" (Paragraph 5), rather than at a midpoint.

text: The author most likely mentions the story about Calvin Coolidge (Paragraph 3) in order to:
explanations:
By the time of the 1948–1952 renovation, however, there were plenty of people to blame for the White House's condition.  A combination of poor planning, carelessness, and neglect throughout the intervening years caused a catastrophic deterioration. (Paragraph 1)
In 1925, Calvin Coolidge scoffed at reports that the White House roof was unsafe until "[a] chunk of it broke off and bonked President Coolidge in the head."  Poetic justice notwithstanding, the repairs to which he only then begrudgingly agreed had a disastrous side effect: the weight of the roof was shifted away from the stronger outer walls to the weaker inner ones, causing enormous structural strain. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 1, "there were plenty of people to blame" for the deterioration of the White House, which occurred over time due to "poor planning, carelessness, and neglect."  Paragraph 3 suggests that one such blameworthy person was Calvin Coolidge, who "scoffed at reports that the White House roof was unsafe until '[a] chunk of it broke off and bonked President Coolidge in the head.'"  Even then, Coolidge only "begrudgingly agreed" to proposed repairs, illustrating his reluctance to take the issue seriously.  Therefore, the author most likely mentions the story about Calvin Coolidge to exemplify the neglect shown toward the White House by its occupants.
By contrast, the author does not mention the story about Calvin Coolidge in order to:
reveal the full extent of the White House's structural damage (Choice A).  Although the story reveals part of the structural damage to the White House (ie, damage to the roof), further damage is described more extensively elsewhere.  For instance, "[w]alls continued to sink and pull away from ceilings" and "the entire East Room required scaffolding to prevent the collapse of its ceiling" (Paragraph 4).
illustrate the inadequacy of Charles McKim's past repairs to the White House (Choice B).  Paragraph 3 states that "President Roosevelt didn't help matters by allowing architect Charles McKim only four months to make repairs.  McKim reinforced the second floor as well as he could within the time allotted, but his efforts only delayed the inevitable."  Therefore, the author is not highlighting the inadequacy of McKim's past repairs, but rather the neglect shown by White House occupants like Roosevelt and Coolidge.
illustrate the work required to repair the White House roof (Choice C).  Paragraph 3 states that "Calvin Coolidge scoffed at reports that the White House roof was unsafe until '[a] chunk of it broke off and bonked President Coolidge in the head.'"  However, the passage merely mentions "the repairs to which he only then begrudgingly agreed" without illustrating the work involved.

text: Which of the following is an implicit assumption that the author makes in describing the reasons for the "catastrophic deterioration" of the White House?
explanations:
The destruction of the White House was not the fault of its original builders.  When James Hoban designed a presidential palace to reflect George Washington's vision for a residence in 1792, he upheld the best architectural standards of his day.  By the time of the 1948–1952 renovation, however, there were plenty of people to blame for the White House's condition.  A combination of poor planning, carelessness, and neglect throughout the intervening years caused a catastrophic deterioration. (Paragraph 1)
Robert Klara recounts a history of changes to the White House that gradually compromised its structural integrity, beginning as far back as 1833 when Andrew Jackson had pipes installed for running water. (Paragraph 2)
In Paragraph 1 the author asserts that "[t]he destruction of the White House was not the fault of its original builders.  When James Hoban designed a presidential palace…in 1792, he upheld the best architectural standards of his day."  Instead, the author believes that later people's "poor planning, carelessness, and neglect throughout the intervening years caused a catastrophic deterioration."
Accordingly, the author assumes that upholding the best architectural standards of 1792 was sufficient to make the White House structurally sound.  Otherwise, the building's deterioration might have resulted from flaws in its original construction, rather than from "a history of changes to the White House that gradually compromised its structural integrity" (Paragraph 2).  Therefore, in describing the reasons for the "catastrophic deterioration" of the White House, the author makes the implicit assumption that the standards of sound architecture were well understood in 1792.
By contrast, the author does not assume that:
George Washington possessed some experience in designing buildings (Choice B).  Although the passage states that "James Hoban designed a presidential palace to reflect George Washington's vision for a residence in 1792" (Paragraph 1), it does not indicate that Washington himself designed the White House or had experience in designing buildings.
It would have been impossible for builders to more safely make changes to the White House (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 2, "[t]he builders responsible for the many additions performed 'careless and foolish maneuvers that a first-year architecture student would never have made,' such as installing doorways in load-bearing walls or destroying the keystones of a brick arch."  This description suggests the author believes that changes to the White House could have been made in a safer and more sensible way.
Presidents before Andrew Jackson made cosmetic changes to the White House (Choice D).  The author asserts that there was "a history of changes to the White House that gradually compromised its structural integrity, beginning as far back as 1833 when Andrew Jackson had pipes installed for running water" (Paragraph 2).  However, this claim does not necessarily indicate whether any other changes were made prior to 1833.  For example, there may have been no changes made at all, cosmetic changes, or structural changes that did not reduce the integrity of the building.

text: Which of the following historical facts would be most unexpected, based on passage information about events from the time of the White House's construction to its eventual renovation?
explanations:
The destruction of the White House was not the fault of its original builders.  When James Hoban designed a presidential palace to reflect George Washington's vision for a residence in 1792, he upheld the best architectural standards of his day. (Paragraph 1)
According to Paragraph 1, "James Hoban designed a presidential palace to reflect George Washington's vision for a residence."  Because the White House was originally built to reflect Washington's vision, it would be natural to expect that Washington himself would live in that residence once it was constructed.  Hence, it would be unexpected to learn that, in fact, George Washington never lived in the presidential mansion whose construction he initiated.
By contrast, based on information in the passage, none of the following historical facts run counter to expectations:
Calvin Coolidge outfitted the White House with secondhand pipes taken from Fort Meade army base (Choice A).  Paragraph 1 describes a "combination of poor planning, carelessness, and neglect" that contributed to the White House's "catastrophic deterioration."  Paragraph 3 provides examples of such neglect, stating that "Calvin Coolidge scoffed at reports that the White House roof was unsafe until '[a] chunk of it broke off and bonked President Coolidge in the head,'" and that Coolidge still "only then begrudgingly agreed" to repairs.  Given the passage's portrayal of Coolidge as unwilling to properly maintain the White House, the fact that he outfitted it with secondhand pipes taken from Fort Meade army base is unsurprising.
Andrew Johnson required the White House to be equipped with a telegraph (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 2, "presidents added modern conveniences in pace with technological developments: gas lighting for James Polk, a telephone system for Rutherford Hayes, and air conditioning for Chester Arthur, among others."  Therefore, although Andrew Johnson is not specifically mentioned in the passage, the idea that he required the White House to be equipped with a telegraph is unsurprising based on passage information.
Harry Truman won re-election in 1948 but had to vacate the White House anyway (Choice C).  The passage describes the "1948–1952 renovation" of the White House (Paragraph 1), noting that "[t]he need to reconstruct the mansion reached a breaking point during the Harry Truman administration" (Paragraph 4) and that "there was little choice but to tear down and rebuild the White House" (Paragraph 5).  Given the years-long destruction and rebuilding project, one could reasonably expect that Truman could not live in the White House at that time and had to vacate the premises despite winning re-election.

text: For which of the following statements does the author provide the LEAST evidence in the passage?
explanations:
Ultimately, there was little choice but to tear down and rebuild the White House.  The exterior façade was preserved, as were a few of the interior's furnishings and decorations.  Still, the extensive transformation left many feeling that the White House was no longer the same. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 5 states that "the extensive transformation left many feeling that the White House was no longer the same" after it had been torn down and rebuilt.  However, the author does not provide any further evidence to support this claim.
By contrast, the author provides more evidence for each of the following statements:
Those responsible for the White House were often neglectful or foolish (Choice A).  Paragraph 2 states that "[t]he builders responsible for the many additions performed 'careless and foolish maneuvers that a first-year architecture student would never have made,' such as installing doorways in load-bearing walls or destroying the keystones of a brick arch."  Similarly, Paragraph 3 describes "President Roosevelt…allowing architect Charles McKim only four months to make repairs," while Calvin Coolidge "scoffed at reports that the White House roof was unsafe" and then agreed to repairs only "begrudgingly."
Some repairs to the White House caused as many problems as they solved (Choice B).  According to Paragraph 3, "the repairs to which [Coolidge] only then begrudgingly agreed had a disastrous side effect: the weight of the roof was shifted away from the stronger outer walls to the weaker inner ones, causing enormous structural strain."  Therefore, the passage indicates that some repairs to the White House solved one set of problems (i.e., the crumbling roof) while simultaneously causing others (i.e., enormous structural strain). 
Hoban did not anticipate the kinds of changes that would later be made to the White House (Choice C).  Paragraph 1 conveys that "[w]hen James Hoban designed a presidential palace…in 1792, he upheld the best architectural standards of his day."  Paragraph 2 then describes "a history of changes to the White House…beginning as far back as 1833" in which "presidents added modern conveniences in pace with technological developments."  Accordingly, the author depicts Hoban as producing a well-made building according to the standards of 1792, supporting the idea that "[n]one of these advancements could have been anticipated by Hoban" more than 40 years before they occurred.

text: Given the information in the passage, the suggestion that Boethius may have "found consolation in the thought that his fate had not been his fate" (Paragraph 6) probably means that:
explanations:
The philosophical Dilemma of Freedom and Foreknowledge concerns the apparent incompatibility between human free will and God's knowledge of the future.  The dilemma proceeds as follows: Free will requires the ability to choose from among alternative possible actions.
