But if God knows in advance what a person will do, then there are no possible alternatives, only a single guaranteed outcome conforming to God's prior knowledge.  Consequently, no act is performed freely but instead occurs of necessity. (Paragraph 1)
Various attempts have been made to resolve this dilemma, the most famous being the solution offered by the Roman consul Boethius….  Boethius fell under suspicion of sympathy to the Eastern empire and disloyalty to Theodoric, leading ultimately to his execution in 524 or 525.  It was during the imprisonment preceding this fate that he wrote The Consolation of Philosophy.… (Paragraph 2)
This conception of God's eternality…would seem to eliminate the grounds for thinking that God's knowledge of future actions precludes their being freely chosen. (Paragraph 4)
Boethius' death was brutal and, from our perspective, probably undeserved.  But perhaps in his final moments he found consolation in the thought that his fate had not been his fate. (Paragraph 6)
Paragraph 1 describes "[t]he philosophical Dilemma of Freedom and Foreknowledge," an argument that if God possesses knowledge of the future, then humans do not possess free will.  According to this argument, acting freely requires the power "to choose from among alternative possible actions."  But if God knows what a person will do in the future, then "there are no possible alternatives, only a single guaranteed outcome conforming to God's prior knowledge."  Therefore, if God knows the future, then free will is impossible because all events are a matter of fate, or what is destined to occur.
A potential solution to this dilemma was proposed by Boethius, who was scheduled to be executed and wrote about philosophy "during the imprisonment preceding this fate" (Paragraph 2).  Boethius believed that a correct understanding of God's eternality (existence outside of time) serves to "eliminate the grounds for thinking that God's knowledge of future actions precludes their being freely chosen" (Paragraph 4).  Thus, Boethius argued that God's foreknowledge does not actually mean that all events are fated in advance.
Accordingly, the author uses the term "fate" to refer to two different ideas: "fate" in the sense of an unavoidable destiny, and "fate" in the sense of what was done to Boethius (ie, the order to execute him).  However, Boethius believed he had proven that human events are not a matter of unavoidable destiny, even if God does know the future.  Therefore, the suggestion that Boethius may have "found consolation in the thought that his fate had not been his fate" (Paragraph 6) probably means that although he did not escape execution, Boethius knew that things could have turned out differently.
 (Choice A)  Boethius could find peace through accepting what happened to him.  Boethius was concerned with proving that there are "possible alternatives" to events in human lives, rather than "only a single guaranteed outcome" that "occurs of necessity" (Paragraph 1).  Therefore, the "peace amidst his suffering" (Paragraph 2) that Boethius attains is based in part on the idea that events like his punishment might not have occurred.  Accordingly, passage information does not suggest that Boethius would find peace through accepting what happened to him.
(Choice B)  despite facing execution, Boethius knew that his punishment was undeserved.  Paragraph 6 states that "Boethius' death was brutal and, from our perspective, probably undeserved."  However, the passage never discusses whether Boethius himself believed his punishment was deserved.  Moreover, the idea that Boethius' "fate had not been his fate" alludes to the question of whether fate governs human existence; it does not make reference to whether a person's experiences are deserved.
(Choice D)  Boethius believed that being executed would mean joining God in eternity.  Boethius believed in "God's eternality" (Paragraph 4), and it is possible that he also believed he would join God in the afterlife.  However, the passage never actually discusses Boethius' beliefs about life after death, nor suggests that such beliefs brought him comfort.

text: According to the passage, Boethius' solution to the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma depends on the idea that:
explanations:
The spirit's solution to the dilemma rests partially on rejecting the notion that God truly has foreknowledge as humans understand it.  As described in Book V of Boethius' work, human existence "still lacks the future, while already having lost the past."  Hence, the concept of foreknowledge arises from humanity's experience of events as a temporal succession.  But for God, who exists eternally, events are not temporal.  Past, present, and future are to God's mind what the impressions of a single moment are to human senses. (Paragraph 3)
It is only our experience of time which gives rise to the illusion that such knowledge interferes with free will.  Purportedly, then, God's timelessness resolves the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 3, Boethius' solution to the Dilemma of Freedom and Foreknowledge involves "rejecting the notion that God truly has foreknowledge as humans understand it."  Boethius argues that it is misleading to say God has foreknowledge, because that concept "arises from humanity's experience of events as a temporal succession.  But for God, who exists eternally, events are not temporal."  In other words, God's knowledge of what humans call "the future" is not really foreknowledge, because unlike humans, God is wholly outside of time: "Past, present, and future are to God's mind what the impressions of a single moment are to human senses."
Consequently, Boethius claimed it is incorrect to think that God's awareness of future events constitutes knowing those events in advance.  This claim then serves as a key point in his argument that "God's timelessness resolves the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, Boethius' solution to the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma depends on the idea that it is not really accurate to say that God possesses foreknowledge.
 (Choice A)  foreknowledge as a concept is based on the mistaken belief that humans experience time.  Paragraph 4 describes the idea that "[i]t is only our experience of time which gives rise to the illusion that such knowledge interferes with free will."  Therefore, Boethius did believe that humans experience time.  However, he contrasts this experience with that of God, who instead "grasps the entirety of time as an immediate perception" (Paragraph 3).  Thus, according to Boethius, the mistaken belief is not that humans experience time, but rather that God's knowledge of the future interferes with free will.
(Choice C)  foreknowledge relates to only one part of a broader philosophical issue.  Paragraph 5 states that "[a]lthough there is much to admire in Boethius' reasoning, some philosophers note that a similar dilemma can be generated without referring to God."  These philosophers believe that "[t]he Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma would be subsumed under (ie, subordinate to) a broader Dilemma of Freedom and Future Truths."  Accordingly, the idea that foreknowledge relates to only one part of a broader philosophical issue is ascribed to these other philosophers; it is not part of Boethius' argument.
(Choice D)  human understanding is insufficient to make conclusions about divine foreknowledge.  According to Paragraph 3, Boethius argues that "when considering God's understanding of what we would call future events, 'it will be more correct to think of it not as a kind of foreknowledge of the future, but as the knowledge of a never ending presence.'"  Therefore, Boethius explicitly makes a conclusion about how divine foreknowledge should be understood.  Consequently, he does not suggest that human understanding is insufficient to make such conclusions.

text: Which of the following inferences about Boethius' solution could be drawn from the passage?
explanations:
However, Boethius fell under suspicion of sympathy to the Eastern empire and disloyalty to Theodoric, leading ultimately to his execution in 524 or 525.  It was during the imprisonment preceding this fate that he wrote The Consolation of Philosophy, so named because it personifies Philosophy as a comforting spirit who engages the reader in conversation.  Boethius receives her instruction, attaining peace amidst his suffering through the wisdom she imparts. (Paragraph 2)
According to Paragraph 2, during his imprisonment Boethius "wrote The Consolation of Philosophy, so named because it personifies Philosophy as a comforting spirit who engages the reader in conversation.  Boethius receives her instruction, attaining peace amidst his suffering through the wisdom she imparts."  Therefore, Boethius viewed the philosophical conclusions he described, such as his solution to the Dilemma of Freedom and Foreknowledge, as being a source of consolation and comfort for those who would read his work.  Consequently, it can be inferred that Boethius' solution is intended to ease the minds of those who consider it.
 (Choice A)  It is primarily a language-based argument about proper terminology.  Boethius' solution depends on "rejecting the notion that God truly has foreknowledge as humans understand it" (Paragraph 3).  However, his point is that it is a conceptual error, not just an issue of word choice, to think of God as having foreknowledge.  Boethius argues that one must differentiate between "humanity's experience of events as a temporal succession" and God's experience of "grasp[ing] the entirety of time as an immediate perception" (Paragraph 3).  Accordingly, the passage does not suggest that Boethius' solution to the dilemma is primarily a language-based argument about proper terminology.
(Choices C and D)  It is the most widely accepted solution to the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma; and It is considered the standard position by most philosophers, though not all.  Paragraph 2 states that "[v]arious attempts have been made to resolve this dilemma, the most famous being the solution offered by the Roman consul Boethius."  Paragraph 5 adds that "there is much to admire in Boethius' reasoning."  However, these claims do not necessarily imply that most philosophers accept Boethius' solution.  For instance, the fact that this solution is "the most famous" does not mean that it is viewed as successful.  Similarly, Boethius' argument could be considered a clever or worthy effort to resolve the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma, even if many philosophers believed it was ultimately inadequate.  Therefore, it cannot be inferred from the passage that Boethius' solution is considered the standard or most widely accepted position.

text: Based on Paragraph 5, which of the following criticisms best describes how some philosophers view Boethius' solution?
explanations:
Although there is much to admire in Boethius' reasoning, some philosophers note that a similar dilemma can be generated without referring to God.  On their view of the problem, God is essentially irrelevant because the threat to free will does not come from foreknowledge itself; it comes from the possibility that statements about future actions are true even before those actions occur.  Thus, the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma would be subsumed under a broader Dilemma of Freedom and Future Truths. (Paragraph 5)
According to the passage, some philosophers argue that the dilemma Boethius confronts is just one part of a larger issue.  Boethius is concerned with explaining how free will is compatible with God's knowledge of the future.  However, the philosophers mentioned in Paragraph 5 contend that "a similar dilemma can be generated without referring to God."  In their view, "the threat to free will does not come from foreknowledge itself; it comes from the possibility that statements about future actions are true even before those actions occur."  In other words, the problem is not that God (or anyone) knows the future; the problem is that it is already true what the future will be.
Therefore, these philosophers believe that "the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma would be subsumed under (ie, subordinate to) a broader Dilemma of Freedom and Future Truths."  In that case, the dilemma Boethius confronts would be a narrower version of a more general philosophical problem.  Consequently, the criticism that best describes how some philosophers view Boethius' solution is that it is too limited in scope.
 By contrast, these philosophers would not most likely make any of the following criticisms of Boethius' solution:
It depends on a rationalization (Choice B).  Paragraph 5 states that "some philosophers note that a similar dilemma can be generated without referring to God."  However, the passage never suggests that these philosophers are critical of Boethius' motivations, or that they view Boethius as failing to express legitimate reasons for his positions.
It cannot be supported empirically (Choice C).  According to Paragraph 5, some philosophers argue that "the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma would be subsumed under a broader Dilemma of Freedom and Future Truths."  However, this argument is based on the logical relationship between those two dilemmas, not on examining empirical evidence.  Specifically, while Boethius is concerned that God's foreknowledge seems to threaten free will, the philosophers mentioned argue that "a similar dilemma can be generated without referring to God."  Therefore, these philosophers are making a conceptual argument, not one that refers to empirical support.
It is based on poor reasoning (Choice D).  Paragraph 5 relates that "[a]lthough there is much to admire in Boethius' reasoning, some philosophers note that a similar dilemma can be generated without referring to God.…  Thus, the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma would be subsumed under a broader Dilemma of Freedom and Future Truths."  Accordingly, the passage suggests that these philosophers believe Boethius' solution addresses only one version of a larger philosophical issue, not that his solution was poorly reasoned.

text: What is the purpose of the author's reference to humans being "bounded in time as we are" (Paragraph 5)?
explanations:
Hence, the concept of foreknowledge arises from humanity's experience of events as a temporal succession.  But for God, who exists eternally, events are not temporal.  Past, present, and future are to God's mind what the impressions of a single moment are to human senses; God grasps the entirety of time as an immediate perception. (Paragraph 3)
It is only our experience of time which gives rise to the illusion that such knowledge interferes with free will.  Purportedly, then, God's timelessness resolves the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma. (Paragraph 4)
Thus, the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma would be subsumed under a broader Dilemma of Freedom and Future Truths.  Unfortunately, bounded in time as we are, that issue must remain beyond our present discussion…. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 3 discusses an important distinction that Boethius makes between humans and God with respect to time.  According to Boethius, the idea that God possesses foreknowledge "arises from humanity's experience of events as a temporal succession.  But for God, who exists eternally, events are not temporal."  Thus, Boethius asserts that humans exist in time while God exists outside of time, a point that is essential to his argument that "God's timelessness resolves the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma" (Paragraph 4).
Paragraph 5 then mentions the further problem that "the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma would be subsumed under (ie, subordinate to) a broader Dilemma of Freedom and Future Truths."  However, the author laments: "Unfortunately, bounded in time as we are, that issue must remain beyond our present discussion," indicating that there is insufficient time to discuss this new subject.  Hence, by referring to humans as "bounded in time," the author describes his or her time constraints by again alluding to Boethius' distinction between the human experience of time and God's timelessness.
Therefore, the purpose of the author's reference to humans being "bounded in time as we are" is that it alludes to a crucial distinction made previously in the passage.
 (Choice A)  It reinforces the idea that foreknowledge and free will are incompatible.  Paragraph 1 discusses "the apparent incompatibility between human free will and God's knowledge of the future," or the argument that free will is impossible if God knows the future.  However, Boethius offers a solution to this problem, based on the idea that humans exist in time while God does not.  According to Boethius, this distinction between "our experience of time" and "God's timelessness" (Paragraph 4) shows that foreknowledge and free will are compatible after all.  Therefore, the author's reference to humans as "bounded in time" would not reinforce the idea that foreknowledge and free will are incompatible; rather, it alludes to Boethius' proposed solution to this "apparent incompatibility" (Paragraph 1).
(Choice B)  It implies that future truths cause more serious problems for free will than foreknowledge does.  Paragraph 5 mentions the view of some philosophers that "the Freedom and Foreknowledge Dilemma would be subsumed under a broader Dilemma of Freedom and Future Truths."  In these philosophers' view, this broader version of the problem is not addressed by Boethius' argument.  However, the reference to humans as "bounded in time as we are" is simply used to convey that there is insufficient time to discuss the "broader Dilemma"; it does not itself imply that this dilemma causes more serious problems for free will.
(Choice D)  It helps clarify the rest of the information contained in that paragraph.  By remarking that the new issue "must remain beyond our present discussion" given that humans are "bounded in time as we are" (Paragraph 5), the author indicates that there is insufficient time to discuss the subject that has just been raised.  Accordingly, he or she implies that the information given in that paragraph will not be further clarified.

text:
Based on passage information, why did the legislation proposed by George Mason fail to pass?
The aristocracy believed noblesse oblige made legislation unnecessary.
Immoderation was too ingrained for prohibition to gain support.
Affluent members of society would be affected.
explanations:
For the American "nobility," the immoderation that had marked public life since before the Revolution assumed epic proportions in the later decades of the century.…  Indeed, libertine attitudes so dominated the population that George Mason IV, a congressional representative from the Commonwealth of Virginia, proposed that the federal government impose sumptuary legislation on all strata of society, including the affluent who would have traditionally been excluded from such laws.  However, the motion did not pass, with such social trends proving too deeply rooted.  Nevertheless, Mason was hardly alone in his alarm at the specter of mounting excess. (Paragraph 2)
Paragraph 2 states that "the immoderation that had marked public life since before the Revolution assumed epic proportions" and that "the motion (ie, the proposed sumptuary legislation) did not pass, with such trends proving too deeply rooted."  This evidence suggests that immoderation was not only widespread but had become so deeply ingrained in the society of the early American democratic republic that people resisted measures to prohibit it.  Accordingly, this circumstance would help to explain the legislation's failure to pass. (Number II)
According to Paragraph 2, "the immoderation assumed epic proportions in the later decades of the century."  Paragraph 3 then makes it clear that "[t]he more established members of the republican gentility had long freely indulged in decadent consumption without attracting much attention."  Regarding the legislation, Paragraph 2 states that the proposed sumptuary legislation would be imposed "on all strata (ranks) of society, including the affluent who would have traditionally been excluded from such laws."  Therefore, it can reasonably be inferred that the majority of the affluent would likely have opposed laws restricting their behavior. (Number III)
(Number I)  According to Paragraph 5, "a movement materialized…mandat[ing] that eighteenth-century gentlemen as well as ladies project positive, even edifying, public images as their privileged position behooved (required of them)."  The result of the movement was "a distinctly American variety of noblesse oblige (the duty of the privileged class to behave nobly and responsibly toward the less privileged) throughout the new democratic republic."  This "new paradigm (model)" meant that "keeping up appearances…became paramount (of greatest importance) in order to set examples of permissible public behavior…for the less affluent."  However, the passage never directly connects this movement of noblesse oblige to the legislation being proposed by George Mason and its failing to pass.

text: Based on the passage, what would be the best description of a "rightful exterior signifier"?
explanations:
In America's early democratic republic, the superficial signifiers of social status that had long distinguished the aristocracy in Europe were no longer supposed to apply. (Paragraph 1)
The presumptuous behavior mimicked by the lower classes led to an uproar by those in positions of power, who swiftly moved to modify societal conduct.  In particular, dissonance swelled in Massachusetts, where, within Boston's most select circles, a palpable anxiety over the maintenance of social hierarchies and their rightful exterior signifiers arose. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 1, "the superficial signifiers of social status that had long distinguished the aristocracy in Europe were no longer supposed to apply."  Paragraph 4 mentions that in Boston's "most select circles," the elite experienced a "palpable anxiety over the maintenance of social hierarchies and their rightful exterior signifiers."  This information indicates that there was concern over the possible loss of the very signifiers or visible markers (ie, detectable status symbols) that had served to distinguish the upper class from the lower classes.  Therefore, based on the passage, a detectable status symbol would be the best description of a "rightful exterior signifier."
By contrast, none of the following would constitute a good description of a "rightful exterior signifier":
A legal entitlement (Choice A) would give an individual the right to obtain a particular benefit from the government, but it would not be outwardly visible.
A dress code (Choice C), even one that was mandatory (required), could lead to outward differences in appearance, but it would not necessarily be indicative of class or social status.
An inherited title (Choice D) could indicate social status but would not be visible.

text: Based on the passage, which of the following would be the best example of the "artful impostor"?
explanations:
The presumptuous behavior mimicked by the lower classes led to an uproar by those in positions of power…For the elite few who made up America's haute monde, any posturing of manner or appropriation of dress disrupted the customary rigidity of the social hierarchy, which, to their dismay, had now become increasingly fluid.  There was a communal uneasiness, which grew into national dread, that artful impostors might slip through the boundaries of the social strata undetected.  Yet, vexingly, counterfeits were becoming more difficult to recognize.  Consequently, in order to restrict impersonation, those of questionable lineage faced the threat of ostracization for an act as simple as sitting for a portrait. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, "[t]here was a communal uneasiness, which grew into national dread, that artful impostors might slip through the boundaries of the social strata (ranks) undetected."  Paragraph 4 also conveys that "vexingly, counterfeits were becoming more difficult to recognize."  Indeed, through their dress and generally "presumptuous behavior" (arrogance), some individuals might succeed at maneuvering out of a lower social position and into a higher one, thereby disrupting "the customary rigidity of the social hierarchy."
For instance, a masquerade ball would normally be an event attended by the upper class where a servant would be present only in his/her capacity as a worker.  However, disguised in a costume appropriate for this kind of festivity, a servant might be able to slip through unnoticed, attend the ball, and mingle with the social elite.  Consequently, a servant wearing a costume to attend a masquerade ball would be a good example of an artful impostor who has the potential to disrupt the social hierarchy.
By contrast, none of the following would constitute as good an example of an artful impostor:
A criminal assuming the identity of a wealthy business owner (Choice A) is a kind of impostor trying to disguise his/her own identity.  However, the criminal is not necessarily trying to mask his/her social position.  Moreover, the original social status of the criminal is not indicated, so he/she might even be a wealthy individual.
A merchant seaman marrying a land-owning aristocrat (Choice B) may be trying to elevate his/her social position but would seem to be doing so openly rather than attempting to slip through unnoticed and disrupt the social order.
A rural farmer planning to conduct business in the city (Choice C) may be hoping to interact with members of the upper classes and perhaps to infiltrate their ranks, but there is no indication that he is disguising his identity.  Moreover, there is no way to know the nature of his business, with whom he will conduct it, or its potential for success.

text: Based on information contained in the passage, which of the following would most likely be the greatest deterrent to a fluid social hierarchy?
explanations:
For the elite few who made up America's haute monde, any posturing of manner or appropriation of dress disrupted the customary rigidity of the social hierarchy, which, to their dismay, had now become increasingly fluid.  There was a communal uneasiness, which grew into national dread, that artful impostors might slip through the boundaries of the social strata undetected.  Yet, vexingly, counterfeits were becoming more difficult to recognize.  Consequently, in order to restrict impersonation, those of questionable lineage faced the threat of ostracization for an act as simple as sitting for a portrait. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 4 cites "the customary rigidity of the social hierarchy," whereby individuals generally remained in the social class or position into which they were born.  However, "to their dismay," the upper class sensed that the social hierarchy was losing this rigidity and "had now become increasingly fluid," partly because "counterfeits were becoming more difficult to recognize."
Paragraph 4 also states that "in order to restrict impersonation, those of questionable lineage faced the threat of ostracization (banishment) for an act as simple as sitting for a portrait" (something reserved at the time for the social elite).  Accordingly, banishment from society for engaging in activities above one's designated social position would most likely be a deterrent to a fluid social hierarchy.
(Choice B)  Paragraph 5 mentions that the elite classes were supposed to set "examples of permissible public behavior for the…less affluent."  However, this practice was largely ineffective, as Paragraph 5 later states that most Americans actually "did their best not to emulate their 'role models.'"
(Choice C)  Paragraph 2 states that immoderation (excess) had "marked public life since before the Revolution."  This immoderation led to sumptuary laws being "reinstituted in some states" in the hopes of regulating behavior.  However, the passage provides no information about the laws or their effectiveness.  Consequently, reinstatement of such laws would not necessarily have been a deterrent to social fluidity.
(Choice D)  According to Paragraph 1, "In America's early democratic republic, the superficial signifiers of social status that had long distinguished the aristocracy in Europe were no longer supposed to apply."  However, Paragraph 1 also claims that the social elite "flaunted their status" while condemning "any pretense by the lower classes to a higher social position."  Therefore, it is likely that democratic values were not truly or widely accepted (or applied) and so would not have deterred the increasing social fluidity.

text: With which of the following statements about noblesse oblige would the passage author most likely agree?
explanations:
The new paradigm mandated that eighteenth-century gentlemen as well as ladies project positive, even edifying, public images, as their privileged position behooved.  Therefore, a distinctly American variety of noblesse oblige, though not without its detractors, spread throughout the new democratic republic.  In metropolitan centers across the new nation, the attributes of honor, modesty, and public virtue assumed increasing importance among the "aristocracy."  Keeping up appearances—that were oftentimes not all they seemed—became paramount in order to set examples of permissible public behavior for the benefit of those of humble birth or who were less affluent.  Meanwhile, the bulk of the American population, consisting of those with little wealth or status, did their best not to emulate their "role models." (Paragraph 5)
According to Paragraph 5, "the attributes of honor, modesty, and public virtue assumed increasing importance among the 'aristocracy.'"  However, although "keeping up appearances…became paramount" in order to set an example for the lower strata of society, such appearances "were oftentimes not all they seemed."  This evidence indicates that the elite were just putting on a show to control the masses and had no true desire to change their own self-indulgent behavior.  Consequently, the noblesse oblige (the duty of the privileged class to behave nobly and responsibly toward the less privileged) movement involved hypocrisy (ie, claiming but not practicing moral standards).
(Choice A)  Paragraph 1 indicates that the elite "flaunted their status at the same time that they condemned any pretense by the lower classes to a higher social position," despite the theory that America was a "democratic republic."  Moreover, Paragraph 5 claims that although elite republicans took it upon themselves to serve as "role models" by practicing noblesse oblige, such behavior drew attention to the demarcations (boundaries) between themselves and the lower classes.  In this way their privilege remained intact.  Therefore, passage evidence shows that the noblesse oblige movement was meant to benefit the wealthy, not the lower classes.
(Choice B)  Like the sumptuary laws, the noblesse oblige movement was meant to lead to certain constraints (limits) on the social behavior of the elite.  Consequently, these moderating laws would not need to be counterbalanced (corrected) by further societal restrictions.
(Choice D)  Paragraph 5 suggests that the practice of noblesse oblige did not truly deter social climbers who "did their best not to emulate their 'role models'" (ie, indicating they tried not to follow the new examples of modest conduct).

text: Based on the passage, the elders within elite society most likely:
explanations:
The more established members of the republican gentility had long freely indulged in decadent consumption without attracting much attention.  Nevertheless, most of these older elites criticized their own younger generation, whose coming-of-age was characterized by more overt disregard for the Puritan austerity advocated by their forebears.  The self-gratifying taste for grande cuisine and propensities for haute couture of the upper-class youth were perceived as decidedly improper conduct by their elders. (Paragraph 3)
According to Paragraph 3, "[t]he more established members (ie, older generation) of the republican gentility (the socially superior class) had long freely indulged in decadent (unrestrained) consumption without attracting much attention."  Paragraph 3 also claims that in comparison, the younger generation had a "more overt (open) disregard for the Puritan austerity (severe modesty) advocated by their forebears (ancestors)."  Therefore, the elders within elite society most likely engaged in decadent behavior discreetly (inconspicuously).
(Choice A)  Paragraph 3 states that the "ostentatious comportment" (behavior involving extravagant displays of wealth) of the upper-class youth "influenced those from the inferior echelons (ranks) of society to adopt similar displays."  Furthermore, Paragraph 4 notes that "the presumptuous behavior mimicked by the lower classes led to an uproar by those in positions of power, who swiftly moved to modify societal conduct."  This evidence indicates that the elite felt threatened by the indulgent behavior of the lower echelons (ranks) of society and so may have tried to control them, but they did not succeed very well.
(Choice B)  According to Paragraph 3, "older elites criticized their own younger generation, whose coming-of-age was characterized by more overt disregard for the Puritan austerity advocated by their forebears.  The self-gratifying taste for grande cuisine and propensities for haute couture of the upper-class youth were perceived as decidedly improper conduct by their elders."  This behavior "worsened" and "influenced those from the inferior echelons of society to adopt similar displays," and, finally, according to Paragraph 4, "led to an uproar by those in positions of power."  This passage information indicates that the elders within elite society would not likely have supported reducing adherence to Puritan values, such as "austerity," even though this might have allowed them to indulge themselves more freely.
(Choice D)  According to Paragraph 3, the younger generation's "coming-of-age was characterized by more overt disregard for the Puritan austerity advocated by their forebears" while, in contrast, the elders among elite society preferred to carry on their decadent behavior "without attracting much attention" (ie, more discreetly).

text: What is the primary purpose of the passage?
explanations:
Although the primary canon in the history of political thought largely ignores the views of Immanuel Kant, he nevertheless was as important a political thinker as Rousseau, Locke, or even Aristotle. (Paragraph 1)
There are still other issues surrounding a Kantian theory of the state.  These will need to be dealt with separately, but they should not go overlooked.  Breaking down the barriers that leave Kant outside the primary canon of political theory is a laudable task, which will take much effort to accomplish. (Paragraph 5)
Paragraph 1 states that "the history of political thought largely ignores the views of Immanuel Kant," but asserts that Kant ought to be included in "the primary canon (ie, commonly studied figures or texts)" of political thinkers because he "was as important a political thinker as Rousseau, Locke, or even Aristotle."  The passage goes on to discuss certain issues surrounding Kant's political theory, after which Paragraph 5 claims that "issues surrounding a Kantian theory of the state…should not go overlooked" because "[b]reaking down the barriers that leave Kant outside the primary canon of political theory is a laudable (ie, praiseworthy) task."
These points illustrate that "[b]reaking down the barriers (ie, the issues facing Kant's view of the state) that leave Kant outside the primary canon of political theory" is the author's intent in writing the passage.  The reason for "[b]reaking down [these] barriers" is to encourage political scholars to pay more attention to Kant's political theory; hence, this is the primary purpose of the passage.
(Choice A)  Although Paragraph 1 asserts that "the primary canon in the history of political thought largely ignores the views of Immanuel Kant," this claim serves to introduce the author's larger point that Kant "nevertheless was as important a political thinker as Rousseau, Locke, or even Aristotle," and thus that his political theory deserves more attention.
(Choice B)  Paragraph 5 advocates "[b]reaking down the barriers" that prevent Kant's views from being more widely studied.  However, the author does not argue that a Kantian view of the state should necessarily be adopted or endorsed.
(Choice C)  The passage discusses some resolutions to perceived shortcomings of Kantianism, such as the idea that "Kantians may justify [welfare] legislation on the grounds that it serves an instrumentally necessary role" despite seeming to contradict Kant's notion of political freedom (Paragraph 4).  However, Paragraph 5 suggests that this discussion is part of the author's method of "[b]reaking down the barriers that place Kant outside the primary canon of political theory."  This implies that the passage's main purpose is not to defend a Kantian conception of the state but rather to encourage broader study of Kant's political ideas.

text: Which of the following is most illustrative of Kant's understanding of "rational entities" (Paragraph 4), as described in the passage?
explanations:
Kant himself held that rational entities—such as persons, corporations, and states—have a duty of self-preservation, and thus are obligated to take measures to ensure their continued existence, security, and stability. (Paragraph 4)
According to Paragraph 4, Kant believed that "rational entities—such as persons, corporations, and states—have a duty of self-preservation" and, as such, must act in ways that "ensure their continued existence, security, and stability."  A city manager who provides funding to hire additional police officers because local crime rates are on the rise intends to decrease the city's crime rate and thereby "ensure [the city's] continued existence, security, and stability" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, this manager is most illustrative of Kant's understanding of "rational entities."
By contrast, none of the following is most illustrative of Kant's understanding of "rational entities":
A successful retail chain raises its prices to increase profits, because it faces no real competition from other businesses (Choice A).  Successful retail chains with no real competition are not facing threats to "their continued existence, security, and stability" (Paragraph 4).  Accordingly, raising prices to increase profits would not constitute acting out of a "duty for self-preservation" (Paragraph 4).
A wealthy citizen provides substantial donations to local charities, in order to receive news coverage  (Choice B).  A wealthy citizen who donates to charity in order to receive news coverage would be trying to gain fame or recognition, not acting to ensure his or her "continued existence, security, and stability" (Paragraph 4).
A town council ignores reports of dangerous chemicals in the water supply, since public knowledge of this matter could hurt the local economy (Choice D).  A town council that ignores reports of dangerous chemicals in the water supply is failing to ensure the town's "continued existence, security, and stability" (Paragraph 4), even if doing so prevents the local economy from suffering.

text: Suppose a study was conducted over several democratic societies with large populations.  In each society, the vast majority of citizens voted in favor of paying for assisted living services for the elderly.  This information would most strongly challenge which of the following assumptions made in the passage?
explanations:
The Kantian notion of political freedom…refers to the innate right of every person to independence from being constrained by another's choice….  Laws that do not allow for political freedom are forbidden in Kant's view because within a just civil condition, the promulgation of a law requires that an entire people agree to be subjected to it. (Paragraph 2)
Given Kant's notion of political freedom, to enact [welfare] legislation would be catastrophic.  Welfare legislation violates Kant's own criterion regarding laws promulgated within a just civil condition: Governmental interference of this kind is a prime example of legislation on which an entire people will be divided. (Paragraph 3)
According to the author, the "Kantian notion of political freedom…. requires that an entire people agree to be subjected to" the laws of the state (Paragraph 2).  By contrast, welfare legislation is described as "a prime example of legislation on which an entire people will be divided" (Paragraph 3).  Therefore, the author assumes that political freedom conflicts with welfare legislation.
However, if the vast majority of a state's citizens vote in favor of paying for assisted living services for the elderly (ie, a form of welfare legislation), this would be an example of widespread agreement, rather than an "example of legislation on which an entire people will be divided" (Paragraph 3).  Accordingly, the author's assumption that political freedom conflicts with welfare legislation would be directly called into question.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 4 indicates that "Kantians may justify [welfare] legislation on the grounds that it serves an instrumentally necessary role in upholding the fundamental aims and principles of Kantianism," and identifies political states as "rational entities."  However, the passage does not assume that a political state must support welfare legislation in order to be rational.
(Choice C)  In Paragraph 4, the author claims that Kant made "an egregious (very bad) error" in promoting welfare legislation.  However, the author goes on to say that Kantians (ie, advocates of a view similar to Kant's) "may justify such legislation on the grounds that it serves an instrumentally necessary role in upholding the fundamental aims and principles of Kantianism itself" (Paragraph 4).  Therefore, the author does not assume that Kantians who promote welfare legislation make an egregious error.
(Choice D)  According to the author, the "Kantian notion of political freedom…refers to the innate (present from birth) right of every person to independence from being constrained by another's choice" (Paragraph 2).  However, the author also states that "[w]elfare legislation violates Kant's own criterion" regarding this freedom (Paragraph 3).  Therefore, the author assumes that welfare legislation does not respect every person's innate right to free choice.

text: To decide if welfare legislation is justified, proponents of a Kantian conception of the state would need to determine:
explanations:
The Kantian notion of political freedom—which stands in stark contrast to the notion of transcendental freedom widely associated with Kant's nonpolitical writings—is restricted to the external relations between human persons.  In its political sense, freedom refers to the innate right of every person to independence from being constrained by another's choice.  In other words, every person has the innate right to make choices freely but only so long as these choices do not interfere with those of others. (Paragraph 2)
…[A] Kantian may hold that public provision of welfare is necessary for the state to fulfill its primary function—namely, protecting the liberties of its citizens.  For instance, if failing to adopt welfare legislation would threaten the continued existence, security, or stability of the state, then Kantians may justify such legislation on the grounds that it serves an instrumentally necessary role in upholding the fundamental aims and principles of Kantianism itself. (Paragraph 4)
Paragraph 2 describes the "Kantian notion of political freedom," which "refers to the innate (present from birth) right of every person to independence from being constrained by another's choice."  Based on this understanding of Kantian political freedom, the passage conveys that "proponents of a Kantian conception of the state…may hold that public provision of welfare is necessary for the state to fulfill its primary function—namely, protecting the liberties of its citizens" (Paragraph 4).
Accordingly, in order to decide if welfare legislation is justified, proponents of a Kantian conception of the state would need to determine whether welfare legislation provides citizens with independence from being constrained by others.
(Choice A)  Paragraph 4 states: "Although Kant did not explicitly advocate it himself, a Kantian may hold that public provision of welfare is necessary for the state…on the grounds that it serves an instrumentally necessary role in upholding the fundamental aims and principles of Kantianism itself."  Therefore, proponents of a Kantian conception of the state would evaluate welfare legislation based on Kantian principles, but not necessarily on whether Kant himself advocated such legislation.
(Choice B)  Paragraph 4 states that "a Kantian may hold that public provision of welfare is necessary for the state to fulfill its primary function—namely, protecting the liberties of its citizens."  However, the passage never discusses political or social unrest, nor the influence of these on the state.
(Choice D)  Paragraph 4 states that Kantians may endorse enacting welfare legislation if it is "instrumentally necessary" in order for the state to protect "the liberties of its citizens" (ie, political freedom).  In that case, Kantians must determine whether welfare legislation is instrumentally necessary for political freedom, not the other way around.

text: Which of the following assertions is supported by strong evidence in the passage?
explanations:
This was an egregious error on Kant's part….  Although Kant did not explicitly advocate it himself, a Kantian may hold that public provision of welfare is necessary for…the continued existence, security, or stability of the state….  It is interesting to note that followers of Kant will likely have independent reasons to accept something along these lines.  Kant himself held that rational entities—such as persons, corporations, and states—have a duty for self-preservation, and thus are obligated to take measures to ensure their continued existence, security, and stability. (Paragraph 4)
The passage states that "[w]elfare legislation violates Kant's own criterion" of what makes laws just (Paragraph 3) and, accordingly, describes Kant's promotion of welfare legislation as "an egregious error" (Paragraph 4).  However, the passage goes on to state that "[a]lthough Kant did not explicitly advocate it himself, a Kantian may hold that public provision of welfare is necessary for the state to fulfill its primary function—namely, protecting the liberties of its citizens" (Paragraph 4).
The passage similarly argues that "Kantians may justify such legislation on the grounds that it serves an instrumentally necessary role in upholding the fundamental aims and principles of Kantianism itself."  For instance, welfare legislation may be justified according to the Kantian principle that "states…are obligated to take measures to ensure their continued existence, security, and stability" (Paragraph 4).
Therefore, the passage provides strong evidence that Kantian political theory justifies welfare legislation (even though Kant himself failed to justify it).
(Choice B)  The author states that of the "substantive problems facing Kant's political theory….Most notable among these concerns is Kant's promotion of welfare legislation" (Paragraph 3).  Even though the author asserts that "[t]here are still other issues surrounding a Kantian view of the state" (Paragraph 5), those issues are not portrayed as more notable than those discussed in the passage.
(Choice C)  Although the author claims that "the primary canon in the history of political thought largely ignores the views of Immanuel Kant" (Paragraph 1), the passage does not include any evidence to support this claim.
(Choice D)  The author states that the "notion of transcendental freedom [is] widely associated with Kant's nonpolitical writings" (Paragraph 2).  However, the passage does not discuss any examples of those writings, nor otherwise provide evidence in support of that claim.

text: When first memorizing neuroanatomical structures and their functions, a student associates the amygdala, which starts with the letters A-M-Y and is involved in processing emotions, with her "emotional" friend named Amy.  This scenario illustrates:
explanations:
Memory involves encoding, the transfer of information into long-term memory; storage (retaining the information); and retrieval (accessing the information).  Some information is processed automatically with little effort (eg, registering the characters on a license plate as letters or numbers), but to encode information, attention and effortful processing are often required (eg, encoding a specific license plate takes effort).
Elaboration is an example of an encoding strategy that can enhance memory.  With elaboration, new information is meaningfully associated with previously known information.  This effortful, deep processing tends to result in more connections to the new material, improving learning.
A scenario in which a student meaningfully associates the name and function of the amygdala (ie, new information) to her "emotional" friend named Amy (ie, previously known information) illustrates elaboration, an encoding strategy.
(Choice A)  The elaboration likelihood model (ELM) describes a message's persuasiveness based on how deeply or superficially it is processed and the characteristics of the audience (eg, motivation).  A scenario in which a student links new information to old information does not illustrate the ELM.
(Choice B)  The availability heuristic is the tendency to judge how common or likely something is based on how easily it is recalled (eg, assuming that shark attacks are common because one was recently reported on the news).  A scenario in which a student links new information to old information does not illustrate the availability heuristic.
(Choice D)  Associative learning is the linking of two events or stimuli.  For example, in operant conditioning, a behavior is associated with a consequence (ie, reinforcement or punishment).  A scenario in which a student links new information to old information does not illustrate associative learning.
Educational objective:
Encoding involves the transfer of information into long-term memory.  Information that is attended to and processed more deeply tends to be remembered better.

text: Which statement is NOT accurate regarding human social behavior?
explanations:
Attachment styles
Secure
Insecure
Develops from sensitive, responsive caregivers
Infants readily explore a new environment when caregiver is near
Infants are distressed by a caregiver leaving & comforted on return
Associated with better long-term effects (eg, more satisfaction in adult relationships, greater health outcomes)
Develops from insensitive, unresponsive caregivers
In a new environment, infants are apathetic or overly clingy toward caregiver
Infants are indifferent to, or not comforted by, a caregiver's return
Associated with worse long-term effects (eg, less satisfaction in adult relationships, poorer health outcomes)
Attachment styles, which reflect the emotional bond between child and caregiver, are not formed during the first few hours after birth but rather form during the first few years of life as a result of repeated interactions.  The nature of this ongoing contact between child and caregiver can produce a secure or insecure attachment style.
Secure attachment typically results when caregivers are sensitive and responsive to a child's emotional needs (eg, readily soothing an upset infant).  Securely attached children develop confidence in their ability to explore the world around them and return to their caregivers as a consistent and nurturing base.
Insecure attachment can develop when caregivers do not consistently respond to a child's emotional needs (eg, often ignoring the infant).  Insecurely attached children do not develop confidence in their caregivers' ability to meet their needs, may act indifferent or clingy towards them, and may show little exploration overall.
(Choice A)  Early attachment styles impact an individual's relationships and well-being throughout their lifetime.  For example, individuals with a secure attachment style show less depression and drug abuse as adolescents and tend to be more satisfied with their romantic relationships as adults.
(Choice C)  Sensitive and responsive caregiving does tend to result in more secure attachments.
(Choice D)  Stranger anxiety, psychological distress caused by contact with unfamiliar individuals, peaks around age 1 year and declines as a child matures.  Stranger anxiety is a normal developmental milestone for infants.
Educational objective:
Attachment is the emotional bond between a child and caregiver.  Securely attached children typically have sensitive, responsive caregivers and are more confident in their ability to explore their environment.  Insecurely attached children typically have insensitive, inconsistent caregivers to which they act indifferent or clingy and are less likely to freely explore their environment.

text: In a two-part procedure for teaching children with diabetes to self-inject insulin, a child is first shown a video of same-aged peers self-injecting insulin and is then given a sticker for each attempt to self-inject.  This procedure utilizes:
explanations:
Types of learning
Operant conditioning
Occurs when the likelihood of repeating a behavior is influenced by the outcome of that behavior
Classical conditioning
Occurs when a stimulus that did not previously elicit a meaningful response takes on the properties of a biologically arousing stimulus after being paired
Observational learning
Occurs as the result of watching others engage in a behavior
Observational learning occurs as the result of watching others engage in a behavior.  For example, a child learns how to self-inject insulin by watching peers self-inject in a video.  There are four processes critical to observational learning: attention (focusing on others' behavior), retention (storing observations in memory), reproduction (imitating others' behavior), and motivation (incentive to imitate behavior).
Operant conditioning occurs when the likelihood of repeating a behavior is influenced by a consequence (ie, reinforcement or punishment).  Positive reinforcement increases/maintains behavior through the application of a desirable stimulus (ie, reinforcer).  Primary reinforcers are naturally rewarding (eg, candy), whereas secondary reinforcers are conditioned to be desirable (eg, stickers).
Therefore, a child learning to self-inject insulin by watching peers utilizes observational learning and rewarding the child with a sticker for attempting to self-inject utilizes secondary reinforcement.
(Choices A and B)  Classical conditioning occurs when a neutral stimulus that did not previously elicit a response takes on the properties of a biologically arousing (ie, unconditioned) stimulus after being paired (eg, infant fears a white toy rat after it is paired with a loud noise).  The procedure does not utilize classical conditioning.
(Choices B and C)  In a token economy, certain behaviors (eg, completing homework) are positively reinforced through the use of tokens (eg, gold stars), which are secondary reinforcers that can be exchanged for a desirable reward (eg, 5 gold stars can be exchanged for candy).  The procedure does not involve trading in secondary reinforcers for a desirable reward, so it is not utilizing a token economy.
Educational objective:
Observational learning occurs as the result of watching others.  Primary reinforcers are naturally rewarding (eg, food), whereas secondary reinforcers are conditioned to be desirable (eg, money).

text: A 34-year-old patient describes a history of conflict-ridden interpersonal relationships.  This pattern has been present since late adolescence, occurs across all settings, and has resulted in a history of sporadic employment and tumultuous romantic relationships.  The symptoms are not due to a medical condition or the use of a substance.  Which psychological diagnosis is most likely in this patient?
explanations:
Personality disorders are characterized by inflexible and enduring patterns of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that differ markedly from social norms and cause functional impairment.  Individuals with personality disorders have pathological personal traits (eg, rigidity, greediness) and maladaptive patterns of relating to others (eg, hostility, superficiality) that are stable over time and across situations.
For someone with a pattern of conflict-ridden interpersonal relationships in all settings since late adolescence (ie, stable over time), resulting in a history of sporadic employment and tumultuous romantic relationships (ie, significant impairment), the most likely diagnosis is a personality disorder.
(Choice A)  Mood disorders (eg, depression) are characterized by persistent disruptions in emotional state.  Although individuals with mood disorders may experience social dysfunction (eg, lack of interest in socializing), this is a result of their mood symptomology, not an inflexible and enduring pattern of relating to others (ie, personality disorder).
(Choice B)  Anxiety disorders (eg, generalized anxiety disorder) are characterized by excessive worry.  Although individuals with anxiety disorders may experience social dysfunction (eg, declining social invitations due to anxiety), this is a result of their excessive worry, not an inflexible and enduring pattern of relating to others (ie, personality disorder).
(Choice C)  Dissociative disorders (eg, dissociative identity disorder) are characterized by disruptions in memory and identity.  Although individuals with dissociative disorders may experience social dysfunction (eg, through inconsistent interactions with loved ones), this is a result of their disruptions in memory and identity, not an inflexible and enduring pattern of relating to others (ie, personality disorder).
Educational objective:
Personality disorders are characterized by inflexible and enduring patterns of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors differing markedly from social norms.  Personality disorders are stable over time and across environments and cause significant distress or impairment of functioning.

text: Which of the following best illustrates a normative organization?
explanations:
In sociology, organizations are social structures composed of individuals linked by specific purposes, tasks, and/or common goals.  The three main types of organizations are normative, utilitarian, and coercive.
In normative organizations, people voluntarily unite based on shared values and/or goals (eg, church congregations, sororities).
In utilitarian organizations, members are compensated for their involvement, typically through money (eg, paid employment) or certification/diploma (eg, university students).
In coercive organizations, membership is not freely chosen (eg, prisoners) and/or maintained (eg, military service members must be discharged).
A humanitarian group composed of physician volunteers illustrates an organization in which members are united by shared values and/or goals (ie, a normative organization).
(Choices A and C)  Medical residents and business consultants are compensated for their efforts in a residency program and the workforce, respectively (ie, through certification, pay).  Therefore, both a medical residency program and an insurance company that employs physicians as consultants illustrate utilitarian, not normative, organizations.
(Choice B)  An inpatient psychiatric ward in which involuntarily committed patients are unable to leave as they choose (ie, they must be evaluated and cleared by staff) illustrates a coercive, not a normative, organization.
Educational objective:
Organizations are social structures composed of individuals linked by specific purposes, tasks, and/or common goals.  In normative organizations, people come together based on shared values/goals, whereas utilitarian organizations compensate members for their involvement.  In coercive organizations, membership is not freely chosen and/or maintained.

text: A pharmaceutical company is testing how much sugar should be added to a pediatric oral liquid suspension to make the medication more palatable.  Researchers determine that adding 0.2 g of sugar to 20 mL of oral suspension Z results in children detecting a just noticeable difference in taste.  Based on Weber's law, should the addition of 0.2 g of sugar to 50 mL of oral suspension Z be detectable 50% of the time?
explanations:
The smallest difference between two stimuli a person can detect 50% of the time is called the just noticeable difference (JND), or difference threshold.  As the intensity of the original stimulus increases, the difference threshold also increases.  For example, although the difference between weights of 100 and 102 g may be detectable, the difference between weights of 500 and 502 g is not, even though the difference is also 2 g.
This relationship is quantified by Weber's law, which states that the ratio of the size of the JND to the original stimulus intensity remains constant.  In other words, the change in a stimulus needed to detect a difference is a constant proportion (ie, if one can just detect a difference between weights of 100 and 102 g, the difference between weights of 500 and 510 g would also be just detectable).
If the addition of 0.2 g of sugar to 20 mL of suspension Z is just noticeable 50% of the time, then for a volume that is 2.5 times bigger (20 mL × 2.5 = 50 mL), 0.5 g of sugar (0.2 g × 2.5 = 0.5 g) would be the JND.  Therefore, the addition of 0.2 g of sugar to 50 mL of oral suspension Z would not be detectable because Weber's law is based on a ratio.
(Choice A)  The addition of 0.2 g of sugar is the JND for 20 mL of suspension; for 50 mL of suspension the JND is 2.5 times greater, or 0.5 g.  Therefore, anything less than 0.5 g should not be detectable 50% of the time.
(Choice B)  Weber's law is based on a constant proportion, not a constant value, so the addition of 0.2 g of sugar to 50 mL of oral suspension Z should not be detectable 50% of the time.
(Choice C)  The absolute threshold is the intensity value at which an individual can detect a stimulus 50% of the time; 0.2 g represents the difference threshold, or the smallest difference between two stimuli that can be detected 50% of the time, not the absolute threshold.
Educational objective:
Weber's law states that the proportion of the just noticeable difference (the smallest difference between two stimuli a person can detect 50% of the time) to the original stimulus intensity is a constant.
